headline: REAGAN NAMES AIDE TO FIGHT A-ARMS SPREAD
abstract: The White House announced today that President Reagan would nominate Richard T. Kennedy as Ambassador at Large and special adviser on nuclear energy affairs and on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.   The appointment was also announced at the State Department by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said the move reflected the priority he and President Reagan give to curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.   ''This subject is of such immense importance that we have to have somebody paying attention to it full time,'' Mr. Shultz said of the decision to fill the post, which has been vacant since Gerard C.  Smith resigned after President Carter was defeated.

headline: NEW TIME, NEW TASK FOR HEAD OF PACIFIC ISLE
abstract: Michael Somare, who led Papua New Guinea to independence from Australia in 1975 and who was named Prime Minister on Monday, has returned to power at a time of serious economic and political difficulties.   The country's commodity-based economy is faltering, Australia is anxious to reduce aid to the former colony and relations are tense with Indonesia, which shares the border that divides the island of New Guinea.   The Parliament that returned Mr. Somare to office was elected after a particularly arduous process. Voters, most of whom are illiterate, took three weeks to cast ballots, many traveling to the polls on foot, through some of the world's most inhospitable jungles. When their candidates failed to win, there were several reports of selfmutilation, the traditional reaction to shame. At least six battles were reported fought with spears, axes and bows and arrows in the highlands.

headline: PHONE INDUSTRY BILL FACES UPHILL FIGHT
abstract: A House bill that would reorganize the telephone and data communications industries, placing new restrictions on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, comes up Tuesday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The bill's chances of passage appear to be fading.   Nevertheless, the bill's principal author - Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado - and his staff say they can probably get the bill through the committee in a week and onto the House floor before the end of August, despite the delaying tactics of the bill's opponents.   But there are several reasons why that may not happen and why Congress, after five years of trying, may again fail to adopt the first comprehensive rewriting of telephone legislation since 1934.  The reasons include these:   - The Reagan Administration (with William F. Baxter, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, as its principal spokesman) has come out strongly against the bill in the last month. The Administration contends that the bill is, at best, unnecessary and that it may make harmful changes in the antitrust settlement that Mr. Baxter negotiated with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last January. Under the settlement, A.T.& T. agreed to get rid of its 22 regional telephone companies.

headline: Big Japan Bankruptcy
abstract: The Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today that the filing for protection from creditors by a construction machinery trader, Nakamichi Inc., with total estimated debts of over $100 million, was the largest Japanese corporate failure this year. Figures compiled by the research company are used by the Bank of Japan in its official bankruptcy statistics. Nakamichi is based in Tokyo and has capital of about $1.3 million.

headline: Around the World; Transit Workers Begin Strike in Montreal
abstract: Bus and subway operators began a strike today, leaving 600,000 commuters without public transportation.

headline: R.J. REYNOLDS IN BIG JUMP
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the world's largest cigarette producer, yesterday reported second-quarter profits of $295 million, or $2.74 a share, the highest in its history and a 48.2 percent increase over the $199 million, or $1.82 a share, reported in the 1981 period.  Sales in the quarter were $3.12 billion, 5.1 percent higher than the $2.97 billion reported a year earlier.   Reynolds noted that current earnings were swollen by a $172.7 million cash award - 87 cents a share - received for oilfield properties originally owned by its Aminoil USA unit, after they were nationalized by Kuwait in 1978.   Operating profits excluding the award were $405 million, up a more modest 7.4 percent from $377 million in the 1981 quarter.  ''Reynolds escalated ad spending on tobacco and Del Monte, which penalized earnings by $17 million, or 8 cents a share after taxes,'' said Diana K. Temple, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''If you added the 8 cents to operating earnings'' of $1.87 a share, she continued, operating income would be $1.95 a share, ''or about what I expected.''

headline: Vion to Sue F.B.I.  On Computer Ban
abstract: A Washington-based company that wanted to supply computers made by Hitachi Ltd. to the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it was planning to sue the bureau for illegally denying it a contract.   In a case that has raised eyebrows in the computer industry, the F.B.I. last month announced that it would not award a contract to the Vion Corporation, the lowest bidder, because the Hitachi computers included in the bid contained technology stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation.   The F.B.I. contract went instead to I.B.M., which had bid $17.1 million, about $1 million more than Vion's price. Reasons Called Political   Vion asserts that the contract was for equipment already on the market and therefore did not contain technology that Hitachi has recently been accused of stealing. The company charges that the F.B.I. denied it the contract for political reasons and to avoid embarrassment.

headline: Personal Finance; HOW SAFE IS YOUR MONEY?
abstract: WITH the collapse of the Penn Square Bank, many bank depositors are w ondering just how safe their money is and how Federal deposit i nsurance works. The question is particularly important for the c ustomers of credit unions and savings and loan associations, some ofw hich have millions of dollars of uninsured deposits in the n owdefunct Oklahoma City bank.   Credit union involvement has been particularly widespread. A total of 132 federally insured credit unions have $104 million of uninsured deposits in Penn Square. (Uninsured deposits are balances in excess of $100,000.) There are eight credit unions in New York State alone that have almost $10 million of such deposits. Based on the current assessment of the Penn Square situation by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, each depositor, including the big institutions, should get 80 cents on each dollar, but it may take several years. Meanwhile, the deposits are earning no interest.   As far as Federal regulators know, none of the institutions with uninsured deposits in the bank have formally notified their depositors of the loss. Commercial banks and savings and loan associations are not required to do so, while credit unions need only make such disclosures in a footnote to their monthly financial statements, which are posted on the bulletin boards at the credit union offices. The footnote would indicate that the credit union suffered an investment loss, but would probably not mention Penn Square by name.

headline: U.S. Official in China
abstract: An American Under Secretary of Agriculture, Seeley Lodwick, arrived in Peking today for six days of talks with Chinese officials and to open new American agricultural offices here.

headline: EVENTFUL SUMMER HAS BRITISH ASKING, WHAT NEXT?
abstract: Dazed, stunned, jittery - such are the words Britons are using to describe the welter of conflicting emotions that have been aroused by a recent succession of inauspicious events.   Just when the adulation over the victory in the Falkland Islands had settled into a comfortable tingling of pride, just when the traditionally gentle summer pace seemed to be ascendant, the national self-confidence has been pounded afresh.   ''It's gotten so I'm afraid to pick up the evening paper or turn on the wireless,'' said Mary Palmer as she bought groceries recently. ''Who knows what's going to happen next?''

headline: AUTO SALES BY BIG THREE RISE 16.5%
abstract: New car sales by the nation's three largest auto makers rose 16.5 percent in the mid-September selling period, the Big Three reported today. It was the first year-to-year rise reported since the eight-tenths of 1 percent increase reported for the June 1-10 selling period.   Analysts attributed the unexpected strength in part to the dealer incentive programs ended recently and in part to returning consumer confidence.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Florida confirmed reports that it plans to ground 7 of its 29 jets and lay off hundreds of workers by Labor Day, and said that it also will reduce flights in the United States and Central America.   * American Financial Corp., Cincinnati, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that, together with others, it held or had the right to acquire 8,235,295 shares of Penn Central Corp., or 26.5 percent of the stock outstanding, up from 24.2 percent.   * Asea, a Swedish concern, said it had signed a $350 million contract to build two turn-key high-voltage direct current converter stations for the Intermountain Power Agency of Utah.   * Burroughs Corp. of Detroit said it had been awarded a $144.4 million Air Force contract for lease and maintenance of automatic data processing systems.

headline: PRESIDIO OIL reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW FOR U.N. FORCE TO END BEIRUT IMPASSE
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev today endorsed the use of a United Nations force to end the impasse over the Palestinians trapped in west Beirut and restated Soviet opposition to any involvement of American troops.   The Soviet leader's remarks were obliquely worded, but they appeared to be a commitment to support proposals for the Palestinians' ultimate withdrawal.   At the same time, Mr. Brezhnev appeared to be signaling that, in return for accepting what would amount to a defeat for the Sovietarmed Palestinians, the Soviet leadership expected the United States to drop plans for marines to participate in the operation.   Mr. Brezhnev's remarks, in the form of replies to questions put by the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, are to be published in the Wednesday issue and were circulated tonight by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency.

abstract: * James L. Turner, associate publisher of Newsweek International, coming to Golf magazine as publisher.

headline: STATEMENT BY ISRAEL
abstract: Following is a transcript of the statement issued today by the Israeli Cabinet and read by Cabinet Secretary Dan Meridor:   The Cabinet held a discussion today and passed the following resolution: Ten cease-fires were declared in Lebanon and in the Beirut area since the inception of the operation Peace for Galilee, and all of them were violated by the terrorist organizations.   Throughout, Israel has acceded to the maintenance of the ceasefires on the axiomatic condition that they be mutual and absolute.

headline: AMERICAN OFFICIALS SEE POSSIBILITY OF U.S.-P.L.O. CONTACTS IN BEIRUT
abstract: Administration officials said today that they would probably authorize American officials to have direct contacts with the P.L.O. in the event that American peacekeeping forces were sent to Beirut and an emergency arose affecting the troops' security.    The officials said this ''hypothetical'' situation would be consistent with a previous experience in 1976 when the American Embassy security officer in Beirut was authorized to have contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organzation to help insure the protection of Americans during an outbreak of civil strife.   The Administration insisted anew today that there had been no change in the continuing American refusal to have any direct contacts with the Palestinian group until it meets the American conditions first stated in 1975: Namely, that it recognize the right of Israel to exist and accept United Nations Security Council Resolution 242 of 1967 and 338 of 1973.

headline: Rates Drop a Bit in Quiet Day; Money Data Are Awaited
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly in quiet trading yesterday, as many market participants waited for today's money supply announcement and next week's auctions of new Treasury notes and bonds.   The Federal Reserve was expected to announce this afternoon an increase of several billion dollars in the nation's basic money supply, a development that some traders and analysts say will cause the Fed to make bank reserves scarcer and push the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market higher than the 10.27 percent average of the week ended Sept. 15. But many others said the Fed would tolerate the large increase, at least until it determines whether or not there will be large declines in following weeks.

headline: D'Amato Meets Israelis For Talks on Lebanon
abstract: Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato, Republican from New York, met here today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Mr. D'Amato said that the Prime Minister had given him a letter to President Reagan that he would be delivering Tuesday in Washington. He declined to comment on the content of the message.

headline: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Smith Barney Officer Starting Own Venture
abstract: Charles H. Davison has left his post as vice chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the Wall Street brokerage firm, to go into business for himself.   Mr. Davison, 54, joined Smith Barney in October 1980, a year after he had resigned as deputy chairman and chief operating officer of Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., the nation's largest accounting concern.    Mr. Davison said yesterday that he was not ready to disclose his new project. ''The whole thing hasn't been put together yet,'' he said. ''I want to build my own organization. I've had this in mind for quite some time. I worked it out with Smith Barney to leave, and at the appropriate time I did.''

headline: Nalco Patent Suit
abstract: The Nalco Chemical Company said yesterday that it sued Britain's Allied Colloids and Allied's American subsidiary on July 9 for patent infringement. The dispute is over two Nalco patents dealing with methods for rapidly producing solutions containing certain polymers. Nalco said that the technology covered by the patents is widely used in mining, paper processing and refining.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, whose eight-year-old coalition Government collapsed Friday after the defection of four Free Democratic ministers, has bequeathed to his successors a package of apparently intractable economic problems.   While the officials expected to lead the new Government have sketched their economic views only in broad strokes, and talks between Christian Democrats and Free Democrats to forge a coalition platform as partners in the new Government do not begin until Monday, there are numerous indications that Germany's new leaders will bring about broad shifts in both the tone and content of Bonn's economic policy, bringing it closer to the conservative policies of Britain and the United States.   But despite a certain rapprochement, certain substantive differences are expected to remain. And the potential for continued conflicts with Washington over issues ranging from the Siberian gas pipeline to steel or agricultural trade problems will likely persist.

headline: SENATORS SEEK TO KEEP LIFE POLICIES' HIGH YIELD
abstract: A high-yielding, fast-selling new form of life insurance, whose appeal was jeopardized by an Internal Revenue Service ruling last month, is expected to recover most of its allure as a result of provisions being written into new tax legislation.   The Senate Finance Committee, headed by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is expected to report the final wording of the bill on Thursday.   The measure is ''very favorable'' for most forms of universal life insurance, said David S. Carpenter, president of the Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company. Transamerica, with headquarters in Los Angeles, is a leading seller of the so-called universal policies.

headline: U.S. ASSURES ISRAEL ON TALKS IN BEIRUT
abstract: An American official reportedly told Israeli leaders today that a diplomatic solution to the Lebanese situation was possible.   Morris Draper, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, arrived from Beirut, where Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, has been negotiating with Lebanese leaders in an effort to induce the Palestine Liberation Organization to leave its stronghold in western Beirut and avert an Israeli assault.   According to Israeli officials, Mr. Draper said the negotiations could produce positive results and the Israeli leaders gave the Americans more time. Mr. Draper conferred here with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

headline: A.& P. POSTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday reported its first quarterly profit in more than two years, which it attributed to the benefits of its yearlong revitalization program in which it closed stores and plants, cut its staff by one-third and withdrew from loss markets.   A.& P., which has fallen from the largest in sales to fifth among American food chains in the last five years, had net income of $8.5 million, or 23 cents a share, in the first quarter ended June 19, against a loss of $10.3 million in the same 1981 quarter. Operating net income in the quarter was $5.95 million, but a tax loss carryforward gain of $2.55 million lifted the final net. Sales dropped 20.1 percent, to $1.36 billion, from $1.7 billion.

headline: HABIB RETURNS TO JERUSALEM WITH NEW PEACE PROPOSALS
abstract: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's peace envoy, arrived in Israel tonight with new proposals for the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut.   Mr. Habib, accompanied by Morris Draper, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, returned here amid reports from Lebanon that some of Israel's demands had been rejected. Other reports on the Lebanon peace talks were more optimistic.   Government sources reported tonight that the American envoy would meet Sunday with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other officials before a regularly scheduled session of the Israeli Cabinet.

headline: JAPANESE-FORD STEEL PLANT DEAL
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to sell a controlling interest in its Rouge Steel Company subsidiary to a group of Japanese concerns led by Nippon Kokan, Japan's second-largest steelmaker.   The takeover of Rouge Steel, the nation's eighth-largest steel company, would represent the first major investment by a large Japanese steelmaker in the United States.   The sprawling, 1,200-acre River Rouge complex in Dearborn just southwest of Detroit is a legacy of the first Henry Ford, who decided in the 1920's to build a fully integrated operation, where raw materials go in one end and cars come out the other. It is the only one of its kind in the nation.

headline: Zellerbach Spending Cut
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said today that it had reduced 1982 capital expenditure plans to a maximum of $300 million from $345 million last year.

headline: NEW PHASE IN STRUGGLE ON DEFICITS
abstract: Friday marks the beginning of a new year - the fiscal year 1983 - and it marks as well the beginning of the Reagan Administration's effort to draft a budget for the fiscal year 1984 that will show a shrinking trend in the deficit. For the White House and its Republican allies in Congress, the deliberations promise to be even more painful and divisive than those that characterized the battle over the budget for the fiscal year 1983.   After two years of spending cuts that have caused friction between the Reagan White House and the Republican leadership of the Senate, the Government still faces the prospect of budget deficits well in excess of $100 billion a year - and the trend may be toward bigger deficits unless a sustained economic recovery starts soon.   But Mr. Reagan has promised a narrowing trend in deficits. He made that pledge last autumn when he was forced to acknowledge that he would be unable to make good on his campaign promise to balance the budget by 1984. It was for the sake of reducing future deficits that the President sponsored the 1982 tax act, a $98 billion revenueraising measure that many members of his own party denounced as a violation of the President's commitment to tax relief.

headline: MANILA PANEL FINISHES WORK ON GLOBAL TALKS
abstract: A committee comprising representatives of 47 United Nations countries completed work here today on preparations for proposed global negotiations on international development.   The report is to be sent to New York to the Group of 77, now composed of 122 third-world countries, which is expected to announce before the United Nations General Assembly that the global negotiations will be scheduled sometime in 1983.   ''Everybody here thinks the global negotiations will be launched,'' said Leandro Verceles of the Philippines, who has played a key role in the meetings. ''There is the political will to go ahead with a scheme for integrated development, especially in the light of the world recession,''

headline: 2-Day Wait Expected On Polish Phone Calls
abstract: People in the United States wishing to call friends or relatives in Poland could anticipate, as of Friday night, a wait of two days to get through.

headline: Fire at Australian Hospital
abstract: About 500 patients were evacuated from the Royal Melbourne Hospital today after an electrical fault caused a fire in an elevator shaft, officials said.

headline: WORLD BANK PLANS VARIABLE INTEREST
abstract: The World Bank, which lends money to the world's poorest nations, has decided to make its borrowers pay variable interest rates for the first time.   In a decision announced Friday, the Bank also said it would sell $1.5 billion in short-term notes in the New York money market over the next 12 months. The move is expected to open large new sources of funds for the bank, which has never before borrowed money for periods of less than a year.   The bank, which absorbs $8 billion to $9 billion annually from the world's capital markets, will now adjust its borrowers' interest rates according to the bank's cost of funds every six months.

headline: TAX CONFEREES, PROGRESSING SLOWLY, AGREE ON SEVERAL COMPLIANCE RULES
abstract: The tax bill continued to make slow progress through a House-Senate conference committee today.  In a late evening session, members of the panel agreed to accept most of the 43 provisions in the Senate version of the bill aimed at improving compliance with the tax law, and they also agreed to accept nearly a dozen more items in the same vein as offered by House committee members. The original compliance provisions proposed by the Senate would raise some $8 billion over three years.   The measures approved tonight include provisions that would require reporting of interest on zero-coupon bonds and other ''original discount'' bonds. Also approved were rules that would require registration of most Federal, state, local and private obligations with maturities of more than one year.

headline: CANADIAN UNITY AGENCY COMES UNDER ATTACK
abstract: A Government agency that spends $25 million a year to promote unity and federalism in Canada has come under fire from opposition leaders who say that its activities constitute misdirected propaganda.   The critics, who say that the office's activities have no parallel in any other pluralistic democracy, also contend that the five-yearold agency, the Canadian Unity Information Office, has functioned as a tax-supported information gathering agency for the ruling Liberal Party.   The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau says the agency is a necessary response to separatist pressures in Quebec and elsewhere.   From the office here where he supervises a staff of 90, Daniel Gagnier, the director of the unity office, said that as long as political parties cling to separatist planks in their platforms ''there remains a clear threat to national unity.'' He added that his office was concerned with both parrying regionalism and with forging and stimulating a sense of national consciousness.

headline: A.T.& T.-Philips Talks
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's A.T.& T. International Inc. subsidiary said today that it had started discussions with N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken division of the Netherlands regarding a possible joint effort in telecommunciations outside the United States. It said the initial emphasis would be on digital switching for public networks, but that no agreement had yet been reached.

headline: Greek Premier Discusses Bases With U.S. Envoy
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou discussed issues linked to the future of American military bases in Greece today with the United States Ambassador, Monteagle Stearns, today.   Mr. Stearns, who returned from Washington last week, called on the Prime Minister for talks that lasted for more than an hour, according to sources who had knowledge of the discussions.   They said that the Greek Defense and Foreign Affairs Council would meet later this week or early next week to discuss the issue and that its proposals would be submitted to Washington.

headline: Aetna Money Manager Joins Bridge Capital
abstract: In his 20-year career at Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford, Hoyt J. Goodrich figures he has invested about $4 billion of the insurance company's money. Now Mr. Goodrich has joined Donald P.  Remey in a new company called Bridge Capital Advisors Inc. to do some investing on their own.   Mr. Goodrich, 46, said Bridge Capital would invest in private placement financings for small and medium-sized companies. ''We have an idea to help them out,'' he said.

headline: Mother Teresa on Way To See Order in Beirut
abstract: Mother Teresa, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979, flew to Cyprus today en route to visit six members of her order in east Beirut, a spokeswoman for the order said.   Sister Stella of the Missionaries of Charity said Mother Teresa would take a boat to Beirut when one became available.

headline: Rail Merger Hearing Held
abstract: The proposed merger of the Union Pacific, Missiouri Pacific and Western Pacific railroads was sharply criticized today by competing roads in an all-day hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission.   The merger is supported with certain reservations regarding competition in the Middle West by the Department of Transportation and the Justice Department.

headline: P.L.O. OFFICIAL IN SYRIA FAVORS ARAB LEAGUE PLAN
abstract: A high Palestinian official said here today that any decision to withdraw the guerrilla forces from west Beirut would have to be made by the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the besieged Lebanese capital.   The official, Khaled Fahoum, who is the speaker of the Palestine National Council, the Palestinian movement's 423-member parliament here, did, however, express approval of proposals for the temporary transfer of the guerrillas to northern Lebanon.   These proposals have reportedly been discussed in Washington by an Arab League delegation made up of Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria and the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal.

headline: Bids for Coast Savings Unit
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that 13 commercial banks or bank holding companies and 37 savings and loan associations had submitted bids to acquire the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco.   Fidelity, formerly a savings and loan chartered by California, was converted to a federally chartered savings association in April after financial difficulties forced Federal and state regulators to order the dismissal of its top officers.

headline: Mrs. Peron Barred From Office Forever
abstract: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron may never again serve in any public post in Argentina because she fraudulently used funds from a state-run charity, the country's highest court ruled today.   The Argentine Supreme Court, which tried Mrs. Peron in absentia, also upheld a seven-year prison sentence a federal judge imposed on the former President for misusing public funds.

headline: TUESDAY, AUGUST 10, 1982; Cities Service and Gulf
abstract: Cities Service stock fell $6.875, nearly 20 percent of its value, during hectic trading in reaction to Gulf Oil's surprise decision on Friday to withdraw its merger offer. The decline to $30.375 was less than expected. Cities Service sued Gulf for at least $3 billion in damages and reports circulated that the Allied Corporation had discussed purchasing Cities Service. (Page A1.)   The mood was unexpectedly cheerful at Gulf's headquarters in Pittsburgh. (D1.) On Wall Street, however, professional stock traders calculated that they had lost hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of Gulf's decision. (D6.) And in Washington, F.T.C. aides strongly denied that the agency had caused Gulf's move. (D6.)

headline: 300 Leave Stockholm For March in Soviet
abstract: About 300 antiwar campaigners, most of them Scandinavian women, left Stockholm today for a 900-mile march in the Soviet Union.

headline: CHINA TRADE:NO BED OF ROSES
abstract: Despite China's exuberance about its offshore oil potential, some Western experts say that American involvement in its development may not be an unmitigated bed of roses.   Their reasons range from the pinched cash flow of most companies to tough leasing terms by the Chinese to the unsettled nature of international relations in the area.   ''The appetite for China, while still pretty good, is not as euphoric as it was a year ago,'' Dillard Spriggs, president of Petroleum Analysis Ltd., contends.

headline: FOCUS IS ON OPPOSITION VOTE
abstract: Mexico will hold general elections Sunday in which the presidential candidate of the long-ruling Government party will for the first time face challenges from nominees of both leftist and rightist parties.   But with the victory of the official candidate, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, a foregone conclusion, attention has instead focused on the size of the opposition vote and the number of people who abstain as a measure of popular discontent with the country's acute economic crisis.   This morning, President Jose Lopez Portillo, who will leave office Dec. 1, ''vehemently'' appealed to the 31.5 million registered voters to turn up at the polls ''to decide whom you want as your representatives in Government, in power.''   ''Vote for Mexico,'' he added.

headline: For Allied, Gains May Take Time
abstract: Even before it acquired the Bendix Corporation, the Allied Corporation had convinced Wall Street that the company's decision last year to drop ''Chemical'' from its name made sense.   With a growing oil and gas business and major acquisitions that plunged it into electrical and electronic products, instrumentation and the health field, Allied clearly is not the old chemicals, fibers and plastics company it used to be.   But what is it? Although Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's acquisitive chairman and chief executive officer, has often outlined Allied's long-range goals, analysts said that the changes have come so fast that investors have had a hard time figuring out how to assess Allied's current performance and near-term prospects. Bendix has added to that confusion.

headline: Ziff Sale Accord
abstract: The Ziff Corporation, a diversified media corporation based in New York, said that it had reached preliminary agreement to sell four of its six television stations for about $60 million to a partnership that includes I. Martin Pompadur, the company's president. The four stations are in Augusta, Ga.; Saginaw, Mich.; Rochester, and in Steubenville, Ohio. Ziff, which is privately held, said that it had decided last year to sell its television stations and expand its magazine operations, which are its main business.

headline: Warsaw Is Said to Study Solidarity's Dissolution
abstract: The Polish Government newspaper indicated today that the authorities were considering the full dissolution of the independent labor union Solidarity, suspended with the imposition of martial law last December.   The daily Rzeczpospolita said Solidarity had become associated with ''highly negative facts,'' such as conspiratorial underground activity, illegal leaflets, intimidation of loyal citizens and sabotage.
