headline: Market Place; How to Protect Social Security
abstract: SOCIAL SECURITY has all its eggs in one basket - a basket filled with United States Treasury bonds. Perhaps other baskets, containing common stocks and corporate bonds, would improve the performance of the Social Security Trust Fund and save it from the threat of insolvency.   The problem is pressing. A. Haeworth Robertson, chief actuary of the Social Security Administration until 1978, wrote in ''The Coming Revolution in Social Security'' last year of the agency's $43,000 unfunded liability for every adult between the ages of 20 and 65.   Few believe benefits can or should be cut enough to protect the fund in the years ahead. The obvious method of providing the necessary money is to use securities in the portfolio with higher yields over time, Robert C. Perez concludes.

headline: Schwab Begins A New Service
abstract: Starting today, the discount brokerage firm of Charles Schwab & Company will allow its 300,000 customers to place buy and sell orders on a round-the-clock basis.   This 24-hour service, described as the first of its kind, will apply to orders for stocks, bonds and options.

headline: 25 HONDURAN REBELS SAID TO SEIZE 200 AT MEETING
abstract: About 25 leftist guerrillas raided a meeting at the Chamber of Commerce headquarters tonight and held two Cabinet officials, the Central Bank president and about 200 business leaders hostage, the police said.   The masked intruders, armed with machine guns and rifles, ordered their captives to lie on the floor and gravely wounded a businessman who failed to do so, police spokesman Carlos Quezada Aguilar said.   ''The subversives have not yet demanded anything, only that the authorities not shut off water, telephones and electricity to the building,'' he said after officials spoke by telephone to a guerrilla leader inside.

headline: Albania 'Liquidates' Armed Group of Emigres
abstract: Albania said today that its security forces ''liquidated'' an armed group of emigre Albanians who landed on its shores Saturday night.

headline: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELIS DISMISS OFFICER OPPOSED TO BEIRUT DRIVE
abstract: An Israeli commander who told his superiors last week that he was conscientiously opposed to any invasion of west Beirut said tonight that he had been discharged from the armed forces.   The officer, Col. Eli Geva, had asked to be relieved of his armored brigade command but to stay with his men as a member of the ranks.  He said he had received no reply to this specific request, but had been told by his superiors that the Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen.  Rafael Eytan, had ordered his discharge. The military authorities made no statement tonight on the matter.

headline: Western Airlines
abstract: Western Airlines of Los Angeles announced it had signed a master agreement covering all the debt that had been in technical default because of a violation of loan covenants setting certain debt-toequity ratios and minimum net worth requirements. The company said it had never been behind in payments of principal and interest, and that the lenders had granted interim waivers allowing it to go forth on a ''survival plan'' aimed it restoring it to profitability by restructuring management, gaining wage concessions and establishing a hub-and-spoke route system centered in Salt Lake City.

headline: EGYPTIAN SAYS LEBANON CRISIS 'OBLIGES US' TO BUILD UP FORCES
abstract: Egypt's Defense Minister has declared that what is happening in Lebanon ''obliges us'' to build up the nation's armed forces.   The minister, Field Marshal Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, made this statement on Wednesday at a display of American-made improved Hawk ground-to-air missiles, some of which are expected to be stationed near here.   He and other Egyptian leaders were described by well-placed Egyptian sources as shocked at the extent of the fighting in Lebanon and at the possibility of great bloodshed in west Beirut. He is also said to have indicated concern that despite Egypt's peace treaty with Israel and its friendly ties with the United States, it has been unable to influence either country in the crisis.

headline: ISRAELIS INTERCEPT WATER AND FOOD FOR WEST BEIRUT
abstract: Israeli troops tightened their siege of west Beirut today, preventing food, water and fuel from entering the encircled stronghold of the Palestine Liberation Organization.   While Israeli ground troops blocked almost all traffic into west Beirut, Israeli tanks entrenched in the hillside village of Hadath, overlooking the capital, fired at building and apartment complexes in the Palestinian neighborhoods of Lailake and Burj al-Brajneh.   Reporters who watched the Israeli bombardment said the return fire from the guerrillas hidden inside was sporadic.  The intensified Israeli pressure on west Beirut, where about 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas are trapped along with 500,000 civilians, came as the Israeli Government rejected a formal offer by the P.L.O. to the Lebanese Government to transfer its headquarters and some of its fighters out of Lebanon. The offer was relayed to Israel by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy.

headline: WITHDRAWAL LEAVES MANY QUESTIONS
abstract: The beginning of the Palestinian guerrilla withdrawal from Beirut today has prompted many unanswered questions among foreign diplomats and Palestinian and other Arab officials over the future of Lebanon and the rest of the Middle East. Some of the questions focus on the fear that major military actions may occur over the next few weeks, before the evacuation is completed.   ''The danger potential of the next few weeks cannot be underestimated,'' a Western diplomat said here today as he noted that the potentially fragile withdrawal plan devised by the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, could fall apart for any number of reasons.   In Egyptian circles there is a commitment to the policy of President Hosni Mubarak to press the United States into accepting a new approach toward the Palestinians, specifically trying to move the Reagan Administration toward accepting the idea of Palestinian self-determination.

headline: Hunt Is On in Brussels For Synagogue Raider
abstract: Belgium pressed a nationwide manhunt today and tightened security measures for Jewish neighborhoods after a submachine-gun attack that wounded four people outside the city's main synagogue.   Two security agents, the caretaker of the synagogue and a worshiper were wounded in the attack Saturday at the start of the Jewish New Year. Two were reported in serious condition.

headline: MRS. GANDHI FINISHES TALKS WITH BREZHNEV
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, concluded talks at the Kremlin today and signed a joint declaration, the official press agency Tass reported.   The contents of the declaration were not disclosed.

headline: EXXON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Briton Turns Up on Falklands
abstract: Britain's only missing infantryman in the Falkland Islands fighting has reappeared.

headline: Changes Asked On Farm Trade
abstract: The Common Market Commission today asked the member governments to relax trade rules on agriculture products, giving 123 underdeveloped countries better access to European markets.

headline: HARD-HIT COMPANY PROFITS REACH LOWEST LEVELS IN PERHAPS 5 YEARS
abstract: American companies, plagued by low demand, high interest costs and weakening prices, are reporting dismal quarterly profits, by some estimates the lowest in more than five years.   Not only are earnings down sharply in such industries as chemicals and oil, but steel and other metal companies and airlines also are reporting large losses.   A compilation by The New York Times of the results of 279 major companies shows that 57 percent of them had a loss or a decline in earnings for this year's second quarter compared with the corresponding period of 1981. Gains were recorded by 40 percent, and the rest were unchanged.

headline: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 74 Moslem Rightists Jailed By Turkish Court for Plotting
abstract: A military court has sentenced 74 members of a Turkish extremist Moslem group to up to six years' imprisonment on charges of plotting to establish a religious state.   Twenty-six other defendants facing the same charges were acquitted yesterday by the court in Ankara, which had been hearing the case for more than a year.   Those convicted were members of two branches of Akinciler, a youth movement linked to the right-wing Moslem National Salvation Party.

headline: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Texaco Unit's Earnings Poor
abstract: The first-half oil-business losses of Deutsche Texaco A.G., a Texaco Inc.  subsidiary, are too big to be offset by profits in other areas, according to its managing board's chairman, Armin Schram.   He told a shareholder meeting on Friday that first-half earnings were poor, and he declined to make a forecast for the full year.

headline: CHINA DISCARDS MAOIST VISION AND PUSHES PRAGMATIC PATH
abstract: China's first party congress in five years ended today after a week and a half of activity that discarded the fanaticism of Mao Zedong and ushered in a new era of ideological pragmatism.   After Li Xiannian, a senior Politburo member, declared the 12th congress over, 1,574 delegates and 147 alternates rose in the Great Hall of the People and joined in singing the ''Internationale.''   The party's new leadership will not be announced until Sunday, after the first full meeting of the new Central Committee, and questions lingered about how successful Deng Xiaoping, still China's paramount leader, had been in rejuvenating the ranks. Deng Programs Are Endorsed   The other elders on the Standing Committee of the Politburo, the party's highest circle, failed to join Mr. Deng on a new Central Advisory Committee. The committee's members were announced Friday.  The status of aging figures such as Ye Jianying, who is 85 years old, is expected to become clearer Sunday.

headline: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FLORIDA BANK PLANS A MERGER
abstract: In a move that further complicates the battle for control of the Florida National Banks of Florida, the company is seeking to acquire the Landmark Banking Corporation of Florida, Landmark announced on Friday.   Banking industry analysts say such a merger would make it far more difficult, perhaps impossible, for the Southeast Banking Corporation, the state's largest bank holding company, to succeed in its attempt to acquire Florida National. Southeast Banking's assets total $6.7 billion and Florida National's $2.9 billion.

headline: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N.-SOUTH AFRICA TALKS ON NAMIBIA CONTINUE
abstract: Prime Minister P.W.  Botha said today that South Africa was ready to move for a cease-fire and an internationally supervised election in South-West Africa as soon as Cuban soldiers withdrew from neighboring Angola.   South African and United Nations officials met twice today at United Nations headquarters in New York to try to clarify outstanding political and military aspects of a Western plan for the independence of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.   Mr. Botha said it was ''ridiculous and terrible'' for critics to accuse South Africa of stalling negotiations for independence of the territory.

headline: WARNER AND MCI POST GAINS WHILE CBS AND TIME INC. SLIP
abstract: Warner Communications and the MCI Communications Corporation, two of the nation's fastest-growing communications companies, yesterday reported hefty earnings increases in the second quarter, while Time Inc. and CBS, which are trying to expand into new electronic services, reported slight declines in net income. CBS   CBS said its net income for the second quarter of 1982 dipped by 1.5 percent, to $46.1 million, or $1.64 a share, from $46.8 million, or $1.67 a share, in the comparable period last year.   The 1981 figures included losses from mass-market paperback book publishing that has since been discontinued. Counting continuing operations only, second-quarter net income declined by 4.4 percent, the company said. Revenues increased 4.1 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $988 million.

headline: STATE DEPT. MOVES TO KEEP NAMIBIA ON COURSE
abstract: The State Department renewed efforts over the weekend to prevent a dispute concerning the presence of Cuban soldiers in Angola from endangering negotiations, scheduled to start in New York on Tuesday, that are intended to end the conflict in South-West Africa.   Robert Cabelly, an assistant to Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, arrived in Luanda Saturday for previously unannounced talks with representatives of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the Soviet-armed insurgent group battling South Africa's disputed control of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.   The discussions followed talks in Washington in June between Mr.  Crocker and South African officials. Western sources said the Luanda talks were designed to prevent a further souring of the atmosphere after public exchanges between South Africa and the insurgents over what is termed ''linkage'' by the United States and South Africa of the Namibian issue with a withdrawal of the 15,000 to 20,000 Cuban soldiers stationed in Angola.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has named Herrick A. Drake vice president, claim department, commercial insurance division.   * Bloomingdale's has appointed Russell Stravitz vice president of branch store merchandising.

headline: Kinark Holdings
abstract: The Kinark Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., said that it had executed a letter of intent to sell its Camelot Hotel real estate holdings in Tulsa and Little Rock, Ark., to a major West Coast investment trust.  Robert G. Walker, chairman, said that the value of the transaction was ''in excess of $22 million.''

headline: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINA'S FIRST REPORTED HIJACKING: MIDAIR MELEE ON A DIVING AIRLINER
abstract: As a tourist group from New Jersey looked on aghast, Chinese passengers and crewmen fought a desperate battle in midair Sunday with five hijackers in China's first acknowledged seizure of a domestic airliner.   According to an account pieced together from passengers and from Chinese and Western diplomatic sources, crew members and passengers aboard the Soviet-made Ilyushin Il-18 airliner swung bottles, seat parts and even a mop handle to overwhelm the hijackers, who brandished explosives and knives.   But before that the hijackers reportedly blew a hole in the side of the airliner, and the plane ran so low on fuel as the pilot circled while pretending to be flying to Hong Kong that its two port engines died. Co-Pilot and Navigator Join Fight   In the melee, the co-pilot and the navigator left the cockpit to battle the hijackers as the plane plunged toward the ground. The pilot regained control and pulled the plane out of the dive, but it hit the Shanghai runway so hard that the tires blew out.

headline: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Coast Utility To Cut 16,000
abstract: The Pacific Telephone Company, California's largest private employer, plans to reduce through attrition its nonmanagement payroll by 16,000 workers over the next 18 months, a company spokesman said.   Doug Cambern, assistant vice president for external affairs, said that the plan calls for paring by attrition 5,000 positions by the end of this year and 11,000 more next year in most of California and part of Nevada.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: After the Soviet Pipeline   The initial impact of the Administration's decision to block construction of the Soviet pipeline and to deny high-technology licenses to foreign suppliers who trade with Moscow seems largely confined to the State Department. Experts say it will not be long, however, before the shock waves spread far beyond Foggy Bottom.   American companies are likely to channel more research and development outside the United States, diffusing technology and making it easier for Moscow to acquire, said Harald B. Malmgren, an independent trade consultant. Reactions from Europe and elsewhere may also become more tangible, he said.

headline: Stake in Charan
abstract: Charan Industries, which owns and operates real estate properties, including a chain of bowling centers, said that the Ryan family, its major shareholders, owned 75.3 percent of the 6.6 million new common shares outstanding that were issued in connection with its merger with BT Mortgage Investors on June 18. Before the merger, Charles P.  Ryan Sr., Charles P. Ryan Jr., John J. Ryan and Kevin T. Ryan had owned 100 percent of Charan, which is based in Garden City, L.I.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Seventh emergency special session on the Middle East - 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  And 3 P.M.

headline: Reagan Gives Notice On the Use of Marines
abstract: President Reagan signed documents tonight formally notifying Congress of his deployment of marines to Beirut.   The White House deputy press secretary, Larry Speakes, said Mr.  Reagan signed letters to the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, and the President pro tem of the Senate, Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, notifying them that the Marines were going into Lebanon under provisions of the War Powers Act.

headline: China Said to Convict 'Gang of Four' Backers
abstract: China has convicted eight supporters of the so-called Gang of Four in Shanghai, a pro-Peking newspaper here reported today.

headline: FORBES'S HUNT FOR RICHEST 400
abstract: Leading the list is Daniel Keith Ludwig, builder of a shipping empire, troubled by a bad back for 50 years, but said to be worth more than $2 billion. There are Perry Richardson Bass and Sid Richardson Bass, father and son, oil barons whose joint worth is more than $2 billion. Then come other familiar names: the Hunts and Marvin Davis and David Rockefeller and Paul Mellon - names synonymous with canyons of gold.   They all have the kind of wealth others can only dream about and they are all on the Forbes 400 list, a gossipy compilation of the 400 richest Americans assembled for the latest issue of Forbes magazine.

headline: Magma Mine Shut
abstract: The Magma Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Newmont Mining Corporation, announced it would shut its mine here Sunday for an indefinite period, laying off 1,250 employees but retaining 90. W.L. Parks, executive vice president, said operations were being suspended at the mine because of ''continuing depressed prices and severely reduced market demand for copper.''

headline: Doyle International Up by 2% in Quarter
abstract: Wednesday it was Doyle Dane Bernbach International's chance to announce its earnings, and although they didn't soar, they did inch up.

headline: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Internorth Filing
abstract: Internorth Inc. of Omaha, a natural gas pipeline distributor, said it had increased its stake in the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer of mining and construction equipment, to 9.5 percent of the 20.4 million common shares outstanding. Internorth told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now holds 1.95 million common shares of Bucyrus-Erie, but does not plan to take control of the company. However, it said it may seek representation on the Bucyrus-Erie board if the latter's board and management ''are agreeable to such representation.''

headline: U.S. AIDE ENDS SALVADOR VISIT TIED TO CERTIFICATION
abstract: The Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders, ended a two-day visit to El Salvador today.   Mr. Enders, who arrived Saturday, met with a ''wide range'' of Salvadoran leaders, according to a United States Embassy spokesman here. The spokesman, Don Hamilton, said Mr. Enders's mission was ''obviously related to certification.''

headline: SUIT CHARGES FRAUD AT CONTINENTAL
abstract: A Federal class action suit filed here on behalf of a group of Continental Illinois Corporation shareholders charges the huge bank holding company and its senior executives with ''fraudulently inducing'' the public to buy its stock by systematically masking the company's true financial condition.   The suit, which could have wide repercussions for the American banking system, also names the national accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, the company's accountants.   The action, filed on Thursday in United States District Court, contends that Continental, the nation's sixth-largest banking concern, and several of its senior officers concealed the bank's true financial condition from the public during the period from Feb.15, 1981, to July 29, 1982.   Continental last week reported a loss of $61 million in the second quarter, largely because of its purchase of $1 billion in energy loans from the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which failed on July 5.

headline: Nissan Promotion
abstract: Nissan U.S.A. has announced that it will give away a pair of $250, four-day ticket packages to the Caesars Palace Grand Prix in Las Vegas next month to every buyer of a new Datsun pickup truck in California, Nevada and Arizona until Sept. 7. Datsun is a major sponsor of the race.

headline: No Headline
abstract: KIDNAPPERS IN ZIMBABWE APPEAR PART OF GROUP THAT HAS KILLED 30   HARARE, Zimbabwe, July 28 (AP) - The gunmen holding six foreign tourists hostage in western Zimbabwe are believed to be among about 1,000 supporters of the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo who have slain at least 30 people, ambushed vehicles and attacked isolated farmhouses and stores.   The authorities said today that the police and army troops had lost the trail of the kidnappers after villagers drove cattle across the trail. The villagers in the region have been accused of sheltering the kidnappers, but army officers said they could not be sure whether the cattle were used deliberately to obliterate the trail.

headline: WATER GUNS USED AGAIN IN WARSAW
abstract: The Polish riot police used water cannon in Warsaw today to disperse a few hundred people gathered around a floral cross and mounted heavy security in Gdansk on the day the suspended Solidarity union had designated for the start of a campaign to assert its continued presence.   Apart from the police actions, there was no immediate evidence of any activity by union supporters, except for a couple of Solidarity signs at the Warsaw cross. There were no immediate reports of disturbances in other cities.   The show of force by the police seemed intended to demonstrate the regime's resolve to suppress any activities by the union's underground leadership, which had called for two weeks of pamphleteering building up to nationwide marches on Aug. 31, the second anniversary of Solidarity's founding.

headline: THE CHILDREN REVOLT IN LIVERPOOL'S 'SOUTH BRONX'
abstract: Almost every night for the last two weeks in Toxteth, a racially mixed working-class suburb of this troubled city, cars are stolen and wrecked or empty buildings are set afire. When policemen or firemen arrive, they are taunted and pelted with rocks.   The pattern is similar to one that developed into major violence here last year and then spread to more than 30 of Britain's cities.  But this year in Toxteth the confrontations ''are more skirmishes then riots,'' said Eric Sorenson, a Government official, and in that he saw some hope.

headline: PAYING ASBESTOS DAMAGES
abstract: When the Manville Corporation, the nation's largest asbestos producer, decided three weeks ago to file for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, it argued that the move to shield itself from asbestos litigation was partly the fault of the Government.   ''The Chapter 11 action might not have been necessary if the Government had accepted financial responsibility for its role in causing much of the disease,'' said John A. McKinney, chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. McKinney has made it clear that Manville's strategy involved increasing pressure on the Government to push the growing asbestos compensation problem out of the courts and to help pay the claims of tens of thousands of workers who have sued the company and others in the industry. ''I expect to emerge from this, some system in which the Federal Government pays its share,'' he said.   Mr. McKinney's expectations, however, are not about to be realized soon. To start with, some of his basic assumptions are disputed by lawmakers. Some argue that Government is already paying its share, perhaps more, through workers' compensation, Medicaid and Social Security. Others say flatly that the Government is not to blame for the development of what medical experts have called the nation's worst occupational health disaster.

headline: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for QTr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Brezhnev Off on Vacation
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev left Moscow today for his usual summer vacation, the official press agency Tass reported.  It gave no details of where he was headed, but the 75-year-old Soviet leader normally spends July and August at a retreat in the Crimean peninsula.

headline: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HABIB BEING SENT TO ARAB CAPITALS
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the special Middle East envoy, is being sent by President Reagan to Syria, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and possibly other Arab countries to try to persuade them to accept the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in west Beirut as part of a solution to the Lebanon crisis.   Administration officials said the decision to have Mr. Habib leave Beirut for the weeklong mission, which will include a visit to Israel, was taken when it seemed that the Arabs were not moving quickly enough on working out a way for evacuating the Palestinian forces. It is feared that Israel will lose its patience and move its troops into west Beirut.   Today's Israeli attacks against Syrian and Palestinian positions in eastern Lebanon and west Beirut were regarded by officials as part of Israeli psychological pressure, meant to warn that force would be used, if necessary, to insure the withdrawal of the Palestinians.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Israel is in a quandary about how to get the Palestine Liberation Organization out of Beirut.  The political negotiations seem less promising with each passing day. The military option, with its inevitable bloodshed, seems to grow more complex, more costly and less attractive as time drags on.  But it also grows more likely, especially as rocket and mortar duels between Palestinian and Israeli forces increase daily.   ''The P.L.O. every day raises new conditions and demands,'' said one official in Jerusalem. ''We get nowhere. We are turning around in a circle. We are going backwards instead of forwards. I think it is only a matter of days until we give up this approach.''

headline: DU PONT POSTS SMALL DROP IN QUARTER
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter fell slightly, to $247 million, or $1.03 a share, and that without the inclusion of the results of the recently acquired Conoco Inc., the decline would have been much larger.   With the $7.8 billion acquisition of Conoco last September, Du Pont has been able to avoid the kind of sharp earnings decline that has been suffered by other major chemical companies.   Du Pont, the nation's largest chemical producer, said that net income for the latest quarter compared with earnings of $248 million, or $1.05 a share, in the second quarter of 1981. Sales increased to $8.5 billion from $8.1 billion.

headline: BILL YILEDS PLUMMET TO 2-YEAR LOW
abstract: Yields on Treasury bills plunged yesterday, reaching their lowest levels in two years, as rumors swept Wall Street that major banks in the United States were facing problems on loans to Mexico.   The three-month Treasury bill plummeted a point - one of the sharpest declines in recent memory -to yield slightly less than 7 percent at the end of a tumultuous session.   Its companion security, the six-month bill, fell almost as much in yield. The six-month bill dropped 93 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to return slightly less than 8 1/2 percent to investors.

headline: AEG Creates New Company
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation and financially troubled AEG-Telefunken signed a final agreement for the creation of a jointly owned electronic components company.   The new company, Telefunken Elektronische Bauelemente, is to begin operation Nov.1.

headline: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLISH POLICE CHIEF CAUTIONS ON MARCHES
abstract: Poland's top security official said in a televised speech today that the authorities were equipped and ready to use force to put down anti-Government demonstrations planned for Tuesday.   The official, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, who is the Interior Minister, said the activists behind the demonstrations were being stirred up by the West and were bent on a confrontation with the martial-law regime.   His speech, the first he has delivered directly to the nation, was regarded as the sternest warning so far against political marches on Aug. 31, the second anniversary of the agreement at Gdansk that created the Solidarity trade union, now suspended.   Solidarity leaders have called for a two-week campaign of leaflet distribution and other protest actions, culminating in demonstrations in an attempt to force the regime to release internees and revive the union.

headline: Schlitz Officer Resigns
abstract: The Schlitz Brewing Company's chief executive, Frank J. Sellinger, submitted his resignation today as a full-time employee of the company, effective Saturday, the brewer announced.

headline: TROUBLE INSIDE THE BIG VAULTS
abstract: THE American banking industry has been badly shaken. Two of the nation's largest, most profitable and best-respected banks - Chase Manhattan and Continental Illinois - have done what no money markets banks in recent history have done. They have lost money, plain and simple.   It happened because the banks did what big, smart city banks don't usually do: They made deals worth $100 million, $200 million, even $1 billion with high-flying, obscure concerns that other major banks had turned down flat.   Both Chase Manhattan and Continental invested in the energy boom with Penn Square Bank, a fast-growing Oklahoma City institution that was on the Government's ''problem bank'' list from 1980 until its sudden demise on July 5. Chase also channeled billions of dollars worth of government securities to Drysdale Government Securities Inc., a lilliputian-sized firm that collapsed with a resounding thud in May.

headline: DEVON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WESTERN AIR HAS PROFIT
abstract: Western Airlines Inc., which said last December that it would become profitable by this year's third quarter, today reported second-quarter net earnings of $3.1 million, or 18 cents a share, for the period ending June 30. The earnings, on revenues of $257.6 million, contrasted with a net loss of $8.4 million on revenues of $270 million in the second quarter of 1981.

headline: I.B.M. Sues 3 Computer Makers
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a civil suit in San Francisco's U.S. District Court against Hitachi Ltd., the National Semiconductor Corporation and its subsidiary, National Advanced Systems.   The suit stems from a case in which Hitachi, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and 21 individuals were indicted by a Federal grand jury in California on charges that they conspired to steal confidential documents and materials from the giant computer company last year.

headline: Reagan Praises A Cut in Prime
abstract: President Reagan began applying personal pressure from the White House today to get big city bankers aboard his campaign against high interest rates.

headline: 47 Greeks Defy Ban On Marquis de Sade
abstract: The Government today ordered the arrest and trial of 47 publishers who it said had defied a ban on publishing the works of the Marquis de Sade.   The publishers, supported by the Union of Greek Writers and the International Pen Club, had termed the Government ban on de Sade's works as ''unjustifiable and exhibiting a medieval mentality.'' After protesting to the member governments of the Common Market, they published Greek translations of the books despite the ban.

headline: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: N.B. Cook Corp.
abstract: The N.B. Cook Corporation, a natural resource and real estate concern, said a subsidiary, Trans Canada Enterprises of Texas Inc., had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. No details were given.

headline: By Nellie Anderson
abstract: ONE SUPPLIER'S RISE AND FALL   LOS ANGELES They produced devices to scrub clouds of industrial grit and skim factory waste from water, meeting the demands of a nation newly determined to cleanse itself. But many developers of the pollution control devices of the early 1970's have since died or evolved into new entities.   The Envirotech Corporation, of Menlo Park, Calif., is one such company. Like others in the industry, Envirotech rode the crest of the antipollution wave before falling victim to poor management and a contracting market.

headline: AND DECAFFEINATED
abstract: Last year was a difficult one for the Seven-Up Company. Its market share of the $30 billion soft-drink business dropped below 5 percent for the first time in decades. Volume sales slipped almost 8 percent. And it looked as though the nation's fourth-largest soda manufacturer was about to be buried by Coke and Pepsi, which together control 60 percent of the business.   But Seven-Up's luck has changed dramatically since spring, and the cola kings are now on the run, thanks to an aggressive marketing strategy by Seven-Up.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Healthdyne Inc. said it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of about one million shares, to be made in late August.   * Northwest Bancorp filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of 500,000 shares of adjustable dividend preferred stock with an aggregate value of $25 million, to be underwritten by Salomon Brothers.   * Service Merchandise Co. filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of $35 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2002, to be underwritten by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and J.C. Bradford & Co.

headline: Market Place; Getting China To Pay Debts
abstract: A Federal court in Alabama sent a sobering message last week to g overnments in default on bonds owned by Americans. Ruling in a classa ction brought against China in 1979, Judge U.W. Clemon of the D istrict Court, Northern District of Alabama, held that China must r etire at face amount bonds issued 71 years ago. China has been in d efault on the bonds since 1930. The judge also ruled that interest m ust be paid up to the date of payment.

headline: CHINA'S PARTY MAPS REVISIONS TO END MAO'S RADICAL LEGACY
abstract: China's Communist Party is undertaking a major reformation to erase the radical legacy of Mao Zedong and improve the caliber of its vast membership.   The most dramatic change, announced today, is the abolition of the post of party chairman, a post that became synonymous with Mao. The party will be headed by a general secretary, as in the Soviet Union.   The party leadership also plans to examine anew the qualifications of its nearly 40 million members to expel leftists who have resisted changes and to weed out others who are corrupt or incompetent.

headline: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Building A Station In Space
abstract: WASHINGTON THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration is ready to build a permanent space station when one is authorized. Key elements for its construction were patented this week for the agency.

headline: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CRAIN, R L, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RECOUPING ON AN OPTION
abstract: WHEN a call option is about to die, sell it twice. Then buy a new option on the same stock. Anyone who does that believes the shares underlying the call are going to stop going down and rally strongly.   The customer - or speculator - is using a so-called bull spread. It is designed to reduce risk while offering the hope of above average rates of return. When used in connection with a dying option, it can help an individual reduce or recapture the original cost and even provide a limited profit.

headline: BANKS OF IOWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARAFAT TO DISCUSS REAGAN PLAN
abstract: Yasir Arafat, arriving in Tunis from Greece, called a meeting of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Central Committee for this weekend to discuss President Reagan's Middle East peace proposals.   ''We do not reject them, nor do we criticize them,'' Mr. Arafat, the P.L.O. leader, said in a radio and television interview before leaving Athens.

headline: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Tankers
abstract: Dome Petroleum's Davie Shipbuilding unit sold a fleet of six tankers to two privately held concerns, Sofati Ltee and Soconav, for $43 million. The ships ply the Great Lakes, the St. Lawrence Seaway and Atlantic and Arctic coasts.

headline: Illinois Broker Is Suspended
abstract: An investment house in suburban Oak Brook, Ill., has been ordered shut down temporarily as a result of Federal charges that hundreds of its customers had been defrauded of a total of $30 million in illegal trading.   At a hearing last Thursday, United States District Judge Prentice H. Marshall issued a temporary restraining order suspending operations of Financial Partners Brokerage Ltd. and its president, Robert B. Serhant of Oak Brook.

headline: Europe Steel Aid Assailed
abstract: Dozens of independent Western European steel producers, saying they are being forced into bankruptcy, bitterly attacked state-funded companies today. In a letter to the European Economic Community's industry commissioner, they criticized governments for giving huge subsidies to large steel companies that are intended to offset losses.

headline: 2 ARRESTED IN SILICON VALLEY THEFT CASE
abstract: In the latest of several arrests aimed at curbing the theft of sophisticated technology from companies in California's Silicon Valley, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had arrested two men on charges of attempting to sell stolen electronics hardware to an agent posing as a representative of the Chinese Government.   In an affidavit filed in New York, the agency said the electronics components involved in the case had been stolen from a division of the General Electric Company in San Jose. The parts, worth about $200,000, included integrated circuits, diodes and other components used in the control systems of nuclear plants.

headline: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hood, Hope of Tulsa Wins Shakey's Account
abstract: Hood, Hope & Associates, based in Tulsa, Okla., and the largest ad agency in the state, has been appointed the national agency for Shakey's, the Dallas-based fast-food chain, and will be taking over from Chiat/Day in Los Angeles.   The agency is elated, according to Mark Owens, public relations director, because it was in competition with seven other agencies that were all from Texas, just like the client, and whipped them all.

headline: UNIDENTIFIED RAIDERS ATTACK PRINCIPAL ZIMBABWE AIR BASE
abstract: Raiders attacked Zimbabwe's main air base early today and were said to have destroyed a large part of the country's air force.   There was no indication of who staged the attack, but it appeared certain that the security forces would focus their attention on either the oposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, or South Africa.

headline: THE RETURN OF THE RIGHT
abstract: BACK TO BASICS The Traditionalist Movement That Is Sweeping Grass-Roots America.  By Burton Yale Pines.  348 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.50. By ALAN BRINKLEY   IN the heady days of the 1950's and the early 1960's, when American liberalism seemed securely enthroned, it was easy to dismiss the far right as the fading and obsolete remnant of a vanished past.  Its most prominent organizations, after all, were usually clumsy and embarrassing (witness the John Birch Society). Its leading publications were at best elegantly superficial (National Review) and at worst cranky and intemperate (Human Events). And its carping obsession with Communism was ill advised and politically crippling, for the liberals themselves had effectively pre-empted that issue. It did not seem presumptuous, therefore, when respected critics began to write smugly of the disappearance of a serious right, to celebrate what the historian Eric Goldman once called ''the arrival of a broad consensus in the thinking of Americans about the public issues of the day.''

headline: Ex-Official Suggests Cutting Aid to Israel
abstract: Harold H. Saunders, former Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said today that the withholding of aid from Israel ''might be necessary at some point in the future.''   ''Israel and the United States have been on a collision course for two years now,'' Mr. Saunders said in a broadcast over the Voice of America.

headline: Chase C.D.'s Remain on List
abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has retained certificates of deposit of the Chase Manhattan Bank among those that can be used to settle futures contracts.   The exchange's monthly poll of dealers, conducted today, determines which bank C.D.'s are considered of the highest liquidity and lowest credit risk and trade at identical yields.   There had been conjecture that Chase might be dropped from the list because of its loan exposure to problems at the Penn Square Bank, Drysdale Government Securities and Lombard-Wall Inc.

headline: YEN FALLS TO 5-YEAR LOW AGAINST DOLLAR IN TOKYO
abstract: The yen fell to a five-year low in trading against the dollar here today - finishing at 269.50 yen to the dollar - and Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said ''there were no signs whatever'' that the yen's weakness would end soon.   Bank officials interpreted Mr. Watanabe's remarks as indicating that the Government does not plan to take measures to curb the yen's continuing depreciation against the dollar.   Nevertheless, the Bank of Japan intervened in the market periodically today, selling an estimated $100 million to support the yen. The bank was said to have sold $200 to $300 million yesterday in similar attempts to support the yen.

headline: Market Place; Is It Time Now To Buy Deere?
abstract: THERE is a theory that the time to buy a stock is after a dividend cut. The worst news is out, and there is no way to go but up. Can it be that the depressed shares of Deere & Company are about to qualify as a buy on that basis? By normal considerations, Deere's dividend is threatened because Deere is paying out more than it is earning.   Earnings reported in the most recent quarter fell to a surprisingly low 4 cents a share, compared with estimates of 65 cents. Thus analysts pared their estimates for the year from $2.50.

headline: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUZUKI HINTS JAPAN MAY CITE WAR AGGRESSION IN TEXTBOOKS
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki indicated today that he was prepared to yield to criticism by China and South Korea over the revision of Japanese school textbooks playing down Japanese atrocities in World War II   Mr. Suzuki said he intended to settle the issue ''in a manner acceptable to China'' before his visit next month. A Warning From China   Earlier today China gave a thinly veiled warning that the visit could be disrupted unless a solution was found.

headline: Chrysler Plans A Sporty Car
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would produce a new high-performance car for sale in early 1983 with the help of Carroll Shelby, the sports car driver and designer.

headline: Nabisco to Sell Unit In $155 Million Deal
abstract: Nabisco Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell Julius Wile Sons & Company, its wine and spirits operation, to Whitbread & Company P.L.C., a London-based alcoholic beverage concern, for about $155 million.   The move, analysts said, is part of Nabisco's plan to focus on its packaged foods business, where it is a market leader in cookies and crackers, and to divest itself of unrelated and typically slowergrowth operations.

headline: Hearing for Rights Activists In Chile Has Been Postponed
abstract: A court hearing in Santiago, Chile, that was to consider an appeal by human rights activists concerning their exile from Chile has been postponed until Sept. 21, according to an American lawyer who had planned to observe the hearing.   Judge Marvin Frankel, chairman of the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights and a representative of Americas Watch, a human rights group, twice canceled his departure for Chile when he heard that the hearing had been delayed.   Judge Frankel said that after an initial delay over the weekend, he was boarding a plane at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Monday when a message from Americas Watch informed him of the adjournment.

headline: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLES CHANT 'FREE LECH' AT WARSAW CEREMONIES
abstract: Thousands of Poles gathered at a military cemetery for anniversary ceremonies of the Warsaw uprising in World War II, heard a recorded appeal from the Solidarity union's underground leader today and then broke into chants of ''Free Lech Walesa!''   The gathering at the forested Powazki military cemetery in northern Warsaw to mark the hour and date when, 38 years earlier, the underground Polish home army rose up against Nazi occupiers is among the most prominent of the many anniversaries by which Poles commemorate their difficult history.   About 200,000 Poles died in the abortive revolt, after which the Germans razed large areas of Warsaw. An Air of Defiance   Some 10,000 Poles gathered at 5 P.M. in the section of the cemetery dedicated to victims of the uprising, covering the well-tended tombs with flowers and bathing the tall birches with smoke from thousands of votive candles. But from the outset the gathering took on an air of defiance.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ'S REMARKS TO SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE
abstract: Following are excerpts from the opening statement made yesterday by Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as provided by the White House to The Associated Press, and excerpts from a transcript of the committee's questioning of Mr. Shultz, as recorded by The New York Times from the Cable News Network:   Following are excerpts from the opening statement made yesterday by Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as provided by the White House to The Associated Press, and excerpts from a transcript of the committee's questioning of Mr. Shultz, as recorded by The New York Times from the Cable News Network:   Opening Statement   For the last eight years, I have been with Bechtel, most recently as president of Bechtel Group Inc. Bechtel is a truly remarkable organization, astonishing in the range of its capabilities and impressive in the quality of its people, who bring integrity, intelligence, enthusiasm and drive to their work. I feel privileged to have played a part in Bechtel's activities.   During the last few days, a number of senators have asked me to address myself to the question of my relationship to Bechtel should I become secretary of state. To those questions, I see only one possible answer: none. If I am confirmed, agreements already executed by me will result in my resignation from my officerships in all Bechtel entities. I will retire as an employee, retaining only vested rights to medical and insurance benefits and to assets already accumulated under Bechtel trust and thrift plans.

headline: WAGING CORPORATE WAR BY PROXY
abstract: FOR the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, it was a stunning defeat. Less than two weeks before its annual meeting, the company found out that Alan E. Clore, a British investor, was waging a proxy fight for control of the ailing mining and chemicals concern. Almost before Gulf Resources's top executives could catch their breath, they were ousted in one of the fastest proxy contests on record.   Mr. Clore's victory and its modest price tag of $1.5 million did not escape notice on Wall Street, where he captured the attention of many professionals and investors who rarely give faltering companies such as Gulf Resources a second glance. In short order, merger and acquisition specialists, along with disgruntled shareholders, began to wonder whether they, too, could take over a company with the expenditure of so little money and so little time.   Indeed, in the wake of the Gulf Resources contest, many Wall Street analysts expect a new wave of proxy fights, in which dissident investors, rather than trying to buy a company outright, will seek to wrest the reins from management by winning shareholder support for new corporate strategy.

headline: Investing; PAC MAN THRILLS IN TREASURY BILL FUTURES
abstract: IN much the same way that video games have bewitched teen-agers, a n ew game of trading financial futures is mesmerizing some s peculative-minded adults. The game isn't Pac Man or Missile Command;i t's the Intermarket Spread.  In Pac Man, the object is to eat dots. In the intermarket spread, the object is to capture minuscule changes in the difference between the yields of Treasury bills and bank certificates of deposit - changes that have become far more volatile because of fears about the financial stability of the banking system.  It can be played week to week, day to day, or even hour to hour, and it is loaded with so many thrills and spills that it can be, in the words of William H. Degler, ''highly addictive.''

headline: TEXT OF RESOLUTION BY SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Following is the text of the resolution demanding a new cease-fire in the latest fighting in Lebanon adopted by the Security Council today by a vote of 15 to 0:   THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING its resolutions 508 (1982), 509 (1982), 511 (1982), 512 (1982) and 513 (1982), RECALLING its resolutions 515 (1982) of 29 July 1982, ALARMED by the continuation and intensification of military activities in and around Beirut, TAKING NOTE of the latest massive violations of the cease-fire in and around Beirut, 1. CONFIRMS its previous resolutions and demands an immediate cease-fire, and a cessation of all military activities within Lebanon and across the Lebanese-Israeli border;   2.

headline: Interest Rates Decline Slightly; Speculators Lift Prices
abstract: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday in quiet trading that featured continued good investor demand for corporate and Treasury notes and bonds. Dealers said that securities firms were speculative buyers during the day.   Because the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market traded at 8 7/8 percent and 9 percent most of the day, many analysts said that a cut in the discount rate from 10 1/2 percent was likely at any time. They said that anticipation of the cut could explain some recent buying by speculators, who expect prices to rise after a reduction in the discount rate.

headline: LAWYERS PLAN STRATEGY AGAINST MANVILLE
abstract: Summoned from across the nation, more than 50 attorneys representing thousands of plaintiffs in asbestosrelated personal injury suits against the Manville Corporation flew to this plush South Carolina beach resort over the weekend. After two days of preliminary strategy planning and briefings on bankruptcy law procedures here, the session was to continue in New York on Monday.   The preliminary conference, which ended today, was planned by the Barnwell, S.C., firm of Blatt & Sales so plaintiffs' lawyers could begin mapping a course of action to address what attorneys here called Manville's ''fraudulent'' bankruptcy petition.   Manville executives said when they filed last Thursday for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws that the cost of the 16,500 damage claims pending against the company could not be met and that the company's total liability could reach $2 billion. The effect of the filing has been to suspend the suits and avoid the filing of new ones.

headline: IRVING S. SHAPIRO, ATTORNEY AT LAW
abstract: IT has been more than a year since Irving S. Shapiro was chief executive of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, but executive habits die hard. A lawyer who became prominent in the business world by taking an active role in public policy issues, Mr. Shapiro - now a partner in the Wilmington office of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom - is taking some of his business thinking back to the legal world.   ''You ought to run law firms the way you run a business,'' he contends, and to that end he has successfully urged Skadden, Arps to name a chief executive to handle long-range planning. The post, nothing new to the business world, is a rarity in the legal profession, which is only now, and slowly, beginning to adopt business practices. Skadden, Arps, particularly since Mr. Shapiro has come aboard, is in the vanguard of that movement.   The amiable and unassuming Mr. Shapiro has brought some other rather radical ideas to the 300-lawyer firm that has made its fame and fortune largely on senior partner Joseph E. Flom's aggressive mergers and acquisition practice. While the votes are not all in at Skadden, Arps, the partnership has expressed a willingness to at least think about Mr. Shapiro's ideas.

headline: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1982; The Economy
abstract: A landmark bill to aid ailing thrift institutions was approved by Senate-House conferees. The bill, expected to be approved by both houses this week and signed by President Reagan, gives savings institutions a form of Government subsidy and broad new lending powers like those of commercial banks. It also calls for a new account equivalent to money market funds. (Page A1.)   A permanent unemployment rate of up to 6 1/2 percent is in prospect, according to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. He said retraining programs are needed to bring the rate lower. (D1.)

headline: Bowling Company In Brunswick Bid
abstract: Fair Lanes Inc., a relatively small, Baltimorebased bowling concern with $53.1 million in sales last year, said today that it had acquired 594,202 common shares, or 5.1 percent, of the Brunswick Corporation. It said it intends to swap the stock for Brunswick's bowling center operations, worth more than $125 million.

headline: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PATENTS; Pollutant Is Removed From Gas Streams
abstract: The removal of a pollutant, sulfur dioxide, from gas streams such as those from power plants will be the subject of patent 4,351,810, to be issued next week to the Department of Commerce's National Bureau of Standards.  The inventors, Richard T. Martinez and John T. Herron, chemists at the Bureau of Standards, propose the addition of ozone, a suitable olefin such as propylene and water vapor to the gas stream.

headline: South Africa Gets A Kissinger Warning
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned South Africa today that the world would not wait forever for it to change its racial practices.   ''Those who wish South Africa well, and would like it to take its full place in international affairs, will not be able to find common ground with you as long as the system of institutionalized racial discrimination persists,'' he said.

headline: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SIGNODE PLAN ADVANCES
abstract: The Signode Corporation said today that shareholders had approved a $429.3 million plan to go private. Each of the 8.1 milion shares outstanding is to be exchanged into a right to receive $53, and the company's name is to be changed to Signode Industries.

headline: BRENNAND-PAIGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HEAD OF ITALY'S STOCK COMMISSION QUITS
abstract: Guido Rossi, president of the Italian Companies and Stock Exchange Commission, or Consob, has handed a letter of resignation to Acting Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini, a spokesman for the prime minister said.   The spokesman gave no reason for the resignation, but said that Mr. Spadolini had asked Mr. Rossi to delay his decision ''to give time for clarification of the institutional functions of Consob, and also because of the current political and administrative situation.''   Mr. Rossi, who has been criticized in public by some shareholders for Consob's handling of the Banco Ambrosiano affair, could not be reached for comment.

headline: Malta Envoy Nominated
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he was nominating James Malone Rentschler, a member of the National Security Council staff, to be Ambassador to Malta. Mr. Rentschler, 49 years old, has been with the council as an expert on European affairs since 1978. He is to succeed Joan Margaret Clark, who has been appointed Director General of the Foreign Service.

headline: WAR IN EL SALVADOR THREATENS TO SPREAD
abstract: A joint Honduran-Salvadoran operation against guerrillas in this country has raised fears that the civil war may spread throughout the region.   The entry of Honduras into the war has led to threats from the Salvadoran guerrillas to conduct raids inside Honduras. At the same time, Nicaragua is talking about going to the aid of the Salvadoran rebels and Honduran Army officers appear eager for a justification to attack Nicaragua.

headline: Bomb Blast in Central Paris Wounds 10 on a Cafe Terrace
abstract: At least 10 people were wounded, one of them seriously, when a bomb exploded near Notre Dame Cathedral in central Paris tonight, the police said.

headline: Tosco Holdings
abstract: Kenneth M. Good told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he may sell his 10.6 percent holding in the Tosco Corporation - 2,168,000 shares of common - and that he will continue his 18-month-old effort to gain control of Tosco. He said that he is seeking a third party to make a tender offer for the company and that he had retained Bear, Stears & Company to find such a party and to negotiate the sale of his stock to that party.

headline: PRODUCTION OF SMALL PLANES OFF
abstract: Slumping capital expenditures, high interest rates and the recession have been bad news for many manufacturers, and the general aviation industry is no exception. For the third consecutive year, private and corporate demand for airplanes is falling sharply.   Through the first eight months of 1982, factory shipments of general aviation aircraft - which comprise about 98 percent of the total fleet in the United States - dropped 53 percent from levels a year earlier, to just over 3,000 units. If current trends continue, manufacturers will be hard pressed to ship 5,000 planes this year, a level the industry has not seen since the 1950's.

headline: HOLLYWOOD SEQUELS ARE JUST THE TICKET
abstract: IN the high-risk world of the movies, where millions are gambled on t he fickleness of public taste, there is nothing so comforting as a h it. Only one film in 10 ever makes it to that exaulted rank, and e ven fewer become blockbuster hits -those that gross, say, $40 m illion or more. Given these razor-slim chances, Hollywood of late h as begun to churn out more new movies based on old hits than at any t ime in recent memory. Whether it is ''Jaws II,'' ''Rocky III,'' ' 'Psycho II'' or ''Airplane II,'' Hollywood hopes that when the dice r oll again, a sequel will better the odds.   Sequels are really a story of modern Hollywood economics. Even though this summer has set box office records, the sky-high cost of movie making has increased the penalty of a flop, breeding caution in an industry still reeling from such expensive failures as United Artists' $36 million ''Heaven's Gate.'' With today's films, on average, costing $11.3 million each to produce - and that's before the studio spends millions more for marketing and distribution - movie makers see sequels as a way to lure the public with bait it has swallowed before.

headline: SOVIET EXPELS U.S. WRITER FOR NEWSWEEK
abstract: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today summoned Andrew Nagorski, Moscow correspondent for Newsweek magazine, and informed him that he was being stripped of his accreditation and given ''a reasonable time'' to leave the country. It was the first expulsion of an American reporter since 1977.   An official statement said that Mr. Nagorski had engaged in ''impermissible methods of journalistic activities.'' The American Embassy issued a statement that implied that retaliation was being considered. The statement said: ''We regret that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has taken this action against a responsible, well-qualified American correspondent and chosen to publicize it without giving him a chance to answer the charges. We are currently consulting with the State Department as to what action should be taken in response.''

headline: HEILEMAN, G, BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEXICO SAID TO RESIST CURBS
abstract: Moves to help Mexico out of its financial crisis have been stalled by the apparent reluctance of President Jose Lopez Portillo to agree to austerity measures, officials and bankers at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund said.   Monetary authorities, who are trying to work out a solution to Mexico's severe payments problems, are reported by bankers and officials here to have become deeply frustrated in dealing with Mr.  Lopez Portillo.   ''Nationalism is rearing up in Mexico and the country seems to be dead set against any economic discipline,'' a California banker said.  Above all, bankers and officials here acknowledge that they are confused about developments in Mexico. The Mexican Government has said repeatedly that the foreign banks have agreed to a postponement of principal payments for three months. Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog announced Sunday that this would be extended to 18 months, but he retracted the statement last night.

headline: SATURDAY, JULY 3, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Unemployment remained at 9.5 percent in June, the highest level in 40 years. But the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported another decline in factory jobs last month and a continuing increase in unemployment among adult men, to 8.7 percent. (Page 1.)   The basic measure of the nation's money supply fell within the Federal Reserve Board's annual target range for the first time this year, in the week ended June 23. The Fed said that M-1 fell $2.2 billion in that week, a steeper decline than anticipated. The Fed's target range calls for annual growth of 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 percent in M-1. (27.)

headline: 31 IN CONGRESS ASK BEGIN TO BACK INQUIRY
abstract: Thirty-one of Israel's supporters in the House of Representatives have appealed to Prime Minister Menachem Begin to drop his objections to an impartial investigation into the Beirut killings. Otherwise, they said, ''very grave consequences'' could result in Israeli-American relations.   The letter, which was signed by many New York members of Congress, was meant to be a private message to avoid the appearance of putting pressure on Mr. Begin, one of the signers said today. But the text was made public by one of the signers after it was delivered to the Israeli Embassy on Wednesday.

headline: MARIETTA MEETING ON BENDIX BID
abstract: The 14-member board of the Martin Marietta Corporation will meet in midtown Manhattan today to decide what to do about what it has so far labeled only as an ''unsolicited'' takeover bid from the Bendix Corporation.   In a surprise offer delivered last Wednesday, Bendix offered to buy the big aerospace contractor for $43 a share, or about $1.5 billion.  Martin Marietta, however, is expected to resist a takeover by Bendix - and by William M. Agee, Bendix's highly visible chairman.   What Martin Marietta will do to keep Bendix at bay should become apparent very soon. Wall Street was rife with rumors last Friday that Martin Marietta might turn the cards on Mr. Agee and make a bid for Bendix.

headline: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ohio Bank In New Bid
abstract: Huntington Bancshares said yesterday that it would offer $22.50 a share for the Union Commerce Corporation, after having dropped a hostile bid of $17 earlier this month. Huntington is competing with Union's friendly suitor, Central Bancorp, which is offering $22 a share.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS, PAINE WEBBER ADVANCE
abstract: The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit climbed 7.5 percent from the previous year's level.  The company said that earnings totaled $144 million, or $1.48 a share, in the quarter, up from $134 million, or $1.42 a share, in the corresponding period of 1981.   Consolidated revenues rose to $1.9 billion from $1.8 billion, for a gain of 5.6 percent.  American Express said that its biggest gains came from travelrelated services, which provided net income of $68 million, a 23 percent rise from the previous year, and from international banking services, whose net income rose 25 percent, to $14 million.

headline: 55 Hurt in Canada Rail Crash
abstract: A passenger train and freight train collided head on near here today, derailing several cars and injuring 55 people, according to a hospital spokesman. The police said the passenger train, traveling from London to Toronto, had been carrying about 110 people.

headline: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Queen to Visit Jamaica
abstract: Queen Elizabeth and her husband, Prince Philip, will visit Jamaica next Feb. 13-16, Sir Florizel Glasspole, the Governor General, said today. The royal couple last visited here in 1975.

headline: Swaziland, in Mourning, Seeks a New King
abstract: The inner council of Swaziland's royal household began deliberations today to find a new leader, sources close to the Government said, as the nation started an indefinite period of mourning for King Sobhuza II, who died Saturday.   All sports events and traditional ceremonies were postponed, and flags flew at half-staff throughout the landlocked mountainous country in southern Africa where Sobhuza, the world's longestreigning sovereign, was King for more than 82 years.

headline: ISRAELI PLANES HIT HIDDEN DUMP IN RAID ON BEIRUT
abstract: Israeli warplanes attacked Palestiniancontrolled neighborhoods in west Beirut today for the fifth consecutive day, knocking out what appeared to be a major guerrilla underground ammunition dump.   For the last three days Israeli planes have been concentrating their bombing on a dirt field behind Beirut's once-f@ashionable Spinney's department store, in the seafront Ramlet el Baida neighborhood. Today it became clear why.   Streaking out of a clear afternoon sky, the Israeli jets scored three direct hits on what must have been a large ammunition cache buried behind Spinney's and only a few hundred yards from the Soviet Embassy. It continued to explode, shooting out rockets and bullets in all directions, for at least 90 minutes after the bombs hit. A column of gray smoke spiraled out of the exploding dump and hung over the southern suburbs for much of the afternoon.

headline: No Headline
abstract: IRAN REPORTS SEIZING 60 SQUARE MILES OF IRAQI LAND   LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) - Iran said today that its forces seized 60 square miles of Iraqi territory in a major assault Wednesday night. It said the Iranian troops then drove back a strong Iraqi counterattack.   Iraq acknowledged the Iranian assault, the fifth in 16 days, but said it had forced the Iranians to flee. Neither account could be independently verified.

headline: Panel Votes to Thin Out G.I. Ranks in Europe
abstract: The Senate Defense Appropriations subcommittee voted today to reduce the number of American troops authorized for duty in Europe next year from 350,600 to 331,000.   Although the Reagan Administration opposes the reduction, the subcommittee chairman, Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said the move was needed to cut costs.

headline: Somalis Report Battle With Ethiopian Soldiers
abstract: Somali Government troops killed or wounded 500 Ethiopian soldiers in a battle for a village in the Ogaden border region on Tuesday, a Defense Ministry communique said today.

headline: Executives Shifted At National Steel
abstract: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest producer, yesterday announced a realignment of its top management, including the appointment of James E. Haas, 46 years old, as president, chief executive and a director.   The Pittsburgh company also promoted Richard S. Smith, 60, and George B. Angevine, 64, to the posts of vice chairmen and established a new office of the chairman.   Howard M. Love, who had been president, chief executive and chairman, will remain as chairman.  ''This realignment of the executive office establishes three senior executive positions reporting to me,'' Mr. Love said in a statement. He said it would enable National Steel ''to carry out its mission and strategies for improved financial performance and growth.''

headline: POLISH REBELS SEIZE EMBASSY IN BERN
abstract: Armed men claiming to belong to a Polish resistance group seized Poland's embassy here today and threatened to blow it up if the Warsaw Government did not lift martial law.   In telephone calls to the police and to news organizations, a man who said he was the group's leader declared that three heavily armed men had seized 12 or so Polish diplomats and members of the embassy staff. (One of the hostages, a pregnant woman, was later freed apparently unharmed, according to The Associated Press.)   The groups's leader said he and his followers, whom he described as members of a ''Polish insurgent home army,'' had heavy weapons and about 55 pounds of explosives with which they would blow up the building if the Polish Government refused to meet their demands.
