headline: Regulation
abstract: To the Business Editor No doubt Paul D. MacAvoy's thinking in ''New York City Calls It Regulation'' (Aug. 8) will be dismissed as a simplistic solution - a favorite bureaucratic position - to a complex situation.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Against the backdrop of the normally languid summer holiday season, the center-right party that governed Spain through a difficult transition to parliamentary democracy has fallen apart.   Long in the making, the disintegration of the Union of the Democratic Center was almost completed recently when Adolfo Suarez, who founded the party and as Prime Minister led it to victory in two general elections, announced he was forming another party of his own.    Mr. Suarez was only the best known politician to jump the listing Democratic Center ship. As early parliamentary elections became inevitable for fall, three other factions broke away.

headline: U.S. AND MOSCOW TRADE CHARGES AT MISSILE PARLEY
abstract: The Soviet delegate to the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles said today that the Soviet Union had taken steps to halt its nuclear buildup in Europe and called on the United States to ''act now'' to lower tensions in the area.   But the American negotiator, Paul H. Nitze, said that the United States and its allies had ''serious concerns over the Soviet buildup of intermediate-range nuclear weapons'' despite the Soviet announcement in March of a moratorium on deployment.   The unusual public exchange came as the two delegations arrived for the resumption of the talks Thursday after a two-month summer recess. The talks started Nov. 30.

headline: New Airline Approved
abstract: A Civil Aeronautics Board administrative law judge ruled today that Midwestern Airlines Inc., a proposed new airline, is fit to operate and should receive an air carrier certificate. The airline, based in Lansing, Mich., intends to fly between Lansing, Flint, Saginaw, Grand Rapids and other sites in Michigan and Chicago and Cleveland.

headline: HUMILIATION OF PRIEST FIRES NICARAGUA
abstract: A confusing incident involving a Roman Catholic priest who is the spokesman for the Archbishop of Managua has brought into focus the tense relationship between Nicaragua's Roman Catholic hierarchy and the leftist Government.   Distrust between the church and the Government has historically run deep in Nicaragua, aggravated by acute discord between conservative and liberal sectors within the church itself.   In the most recent incident, the priest, the Rev. Bismarck Carballo, became the center of controversy when a photograph of him, in the nude, was shown on television and printed in a pro-Government newspaper, which also printed an article suggesting that he had been caught in intimate circumstances with a female parishioner.   The priest said he had been paying a pastoral call on the woman when intruders forced him at gunpoint to undress and chased him into the street before waiting photographers.

headline: Soviet Hospital Said to Force Drugs on Peace Group Leader
abstract: A cofounder of Moscow's only independent disarmament group is being administered depressant drugs against his will in the psychiatric hospital where he is being held, his wife said today.   Natasha Batovrin said during a telephone interview that her husband, Sergei, was being given pills four times a day and had been threatened with electric shock treatments if he did not take the medication.

headline: DROUGHT PORTENDS BIG PROBLEMS IN INDONESIA
abstract: There is never much rain this time of year donesia, but the skies here in central Java have been so cloudless since May that the dry-season rice crop is suffering, and for many Javanese the drought will mean serious trouble.   Reports of tens of thousands of damaged acres in central Java alone have reminded Western agricultural experts that the Indonesian Government's predictions last year of imminent self-sufficiency in food were premature.   A normal dry-season rice crop produces a quarter or more of the year's total in Indonesia. But the Minister of Agriculture announced recently that production this year would probably not equal 1981's despite a record wet-season harvest.

headline: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN NAMES AIDE TO FIGHT A-ARMS SPREAD
abstract: The White House announced today that President Reagan would nominate Richard T. Kennedy as Ambassador at Large and special adviser on nuclear energy affairs and on preventing the spread of nuclear weapons.   The appointment was also announced at the State Department by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said the move reflected the priority he and President Reagan give to curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.   ''This subject is of such immense importance that we have to have somebody paying attention to it full time,'' Mr. Shultz said of the decision to fill the post, which has been vacant since Gerard C.  Smith resigned after President Carter was defeated.

headline: NEW TIME, NEW TASK FOR HEAD OF PACIFIC ISLE
abstract: Michael Somare, who led Papua New Guinea to independence from Australia in 1975 and who was named Prime Minister on Monday, has returned to power at a time of serious economic and political difficulties.   The country's commodity-based economy is faltering, Australia is anxious to reduce aid to the former colony and relations are tense with Indonesia, which shares the border that divides the island of New Guinea.   The Parliament that returned Mr. Somare to office was elected after a particularly arduous process. Voters, most of whom are illiterate, took three weeks to cast ballots, many traveling to the polls on foot, through some of the world's most inhospitable jungles. When their candidates failed to win, there were several reports of selfmutilation, the traditional reaction to shame. At least six battles were reported fought with spears, axes and bows and arrows in the highlands.

headline: PHONE INDUSTRY BILL FACES UPHILL FIGHT
abstract: A House bill that would reorganize the telephone and data communications industries, placing new restrictions on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, comes up Tuesday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The bill's chances of passage appear to be fading.   Nevertheless, the bill's principal author - Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado - and his staff say they can probably get the bill through the committee in a week and onto the House floor before the end of August, despite the delaying tactics of the bill's opponents.   But there are several reasons why that may not happen and why Congress, after five years of trying, may again fail to adopt the first comprehensive rewriting of telephone legislation since 1934.  The reasons include these:   - The Reagan Administration (with William F. Baxter, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, as its principal spokesman) has come out strongly against the bill in the last month. The Administration contends that the bill is, at best, unnecessary and that it may make harmful changes in the antitrust settlement that Mr. Baxter negotiated with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last January. Under the settlement, A.T.& T. agreed to get rid of its 22 regional telephone companies.

headline: Big Japan Bankruptcy
abstract: The Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today that the filing for protection from creditors by a construction machinery trader, Nakamichi Inc., with total estimated debts of over $100 million, was the largest Japanese corporate failure this year. Figures compiled by the research company are used by the Bank of Japan in its official bankruptcy statistics. Nakamichi is based in Tokyo and has capital of about $1.3 million.

headline: Around the World; Transit Workers Begin Strike in Montreal
abstract: Bus and subway operators began a strike today, leaving 600,000 commuters without public transportation.

headline: R.J. REYNOLDS IN BIG JUMP
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the world's largest cigarette producer, yesterday reported second-quarter profits of $295 million, or $2.74 a share, the highest in its history and a 48.2 percent increase over the $199 million, or $1.82 a share, reported in the 1981 period.  Sales in the quarter were $3.12 billion, 5.1 percent higher than the $2.97 billion reported a year earlier.   Reynolds noted that current earnings were swollen by a $172.7 million cash award - 87 cents a share - received for oilfield properties originally owned by its Aminoil USA unit, after they were nationalized by Kuwait in 1978.   Operating profits excluding the award were $405 million, up a more modest 7.4 percent from $377 million in the 1981 quarter.  ''Reynolds escalated ad spending on tobacco and Del Monte, which penalized earnings by $17 million, or 8 cents a share after taxes,'' said Diana K. Temple, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''If you added the 8 cents to operating earnings'' of $1.87 a share, she continued, operating income would be $1.95 a share, ''or about what I expected.''

headline: Vion to Sue F.B.I.  On Computer Ban
abstract: A Washington-based company that wanted to supply computers made by Hitachi Ltd. to the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it was planning to sue the bureau for illegally denying it a contract.   In a case that has raised eyebrows in the computer industry, the F.B.I. last month announced that it would not award a contract to the Vion Corporation, the lowest bidder, because the Hitachi computers included in the bid contained technology stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation.   The F.B.I. contract went instead to I.B.M., which had bid $17.1 million, about $1 million more than Vion's price. Reasons Called Political   Vion asserts that the contract was for equipment already on the market and therefore did not contain technology that Hitachi has recently been accused of stealing. The company charges that the F.B.I. denied it the contract for political reasons and to avoid embarrassment.

headline: Personal Finance; HOW SAFE IS YOUR MONEY?
abstract: WITH the collapse of the Penn Square Bank, many bank depositors are w ondering just how safe their money is and how Federal deposit i nsurance works. The question is particularly important for the c ustomers of credit unions and savings and loan associations, some ofw hich have millions of dollars of uninsured deposits in the n owdefunct Oklahoma City bank.   Credit union involvement has been particularly widespread. A total of 132 federally insured credit unions have $104 million of uninsured deposits in Penn Square. (Uninsured deposits are balances in excess of $100,000.) There are eight credit unions in New York State alone that have almost $10 million of such deposits. Based on the current assessment of the Penn Square situation by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, each depositor, including the big institutions, should get 80 cents on each dollar, but it may take several years. Meanwhile, the deposits are earning no interest.   As far as Federal regulators know, none of the institutions with uninsured deposits in the bank have formally notified their depositors of the loss. Commercial banks and savings and loan associations are not required to do so, while credit unions need only make such disclosures in a footnote to their monthly financial statements, which are posted on the bulletin boards at the credit union offices. The footnote would indicate that the credit union suffered an investment loss, but would probably not mention Penn Square by name.

headline: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SYRIA SAYS IT WILL STAY IN LEBANON AS LONG AS ISRAELIS ARE IN BEIRUT
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad has refused to withdraw Syrian forces from Lebanon in response to what he terms an Israeli ''ultimatum'' as long as Israel's invasion forces remain in Beirut.   The Syrian leader made this assertion in a speech Sunday night at a gathering of the country's Moslem religious leaders, but the message was clearly directed to a broader audience, coming on the eve of Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam's arrival in Washington for talks with President Reagan and other American officials on the crisis in Lebanon.   Mr. Khaddam and his Saudi Arabian counterpart, Prince Saud al-Faisal, who is accompanying him, have been delegated by the Arab League to urge the Reagan Administration to reconsider its Middle East policy and persuade Israel to withdraw.

headline: Buyer for Barton
abstract: Barton Brands Ltd. said the BBL Acquisition Company, a subsidiary of Amalgamated Distilled Products, London, had agreed to buy it for $38 million in cash and had deposited an initial $3.5 million with an escrow agent. An autumn closing is expected, and Barton's present management will continue to operate it.

headline: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FORD SHUTS DOWN 4 SOUTH AFRICA PLANTS
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's South African subsidiary in Port Elizabeth closed all four of its factories today because of a series of strikes by black workers.   The company's industrial relations director, Fred Ferreira, said there had been a ''mass walkout'' at the company's Neave plant in the city this morning. He said there had been ''several walkouts'' over the last eight days.

headline: BOND RALLY SPARKING OPTIMISM
abstract: The market for government securities forged its strongest two-day rally of 1982 last Thursday and Friday, adding fuel to what has become a virtual consensus that interest rates will move lower over the weeks ahead.   This sudden change in sentiment was underscored late last week by the language that Wall Street understands best - rising prices and falling yields for securities.   Dealers say this rally was so powerful, in fact, that some profittaking is quite possible at the onset of a new trading week.  Meanwhile, a weak economy, the reaction to the failure of a Wall Street securities firm and an obliging Federal Reserve Board all have combined to produce a fresh sense of optimism in the fixed-income community.

headline: WEINBERGER DEFENDS HIS PLAN ON A PROTRACTED NUCLEAR WAR
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration had formulated a plan to wage a protracted nuclear war to avert what he called a ''hair-trigger situation.''   In a further defense of a doctrine that has stirred widespread criticism since it was disclosed in May, Mr. Weinberger said in an interview that the United States must avoid being forced to choose between firing its entire force of nuclear weapons immediately after any Soviet attack or letting it be destroyed. Otherwise, he said, ''that makes for much more of a hair-trigger situation.''

headline: Advertising; Chrysler Is Adding 2d Agency
abstract: THE Chrysler Corporation, all of whose advertising has been done by Kenyon & Eckhardt since 1979, when it consolidated its business in the biggest account switch in history, confirmed Friday it is looking for a second agency.   It is understood the company feels that it is over its financial hurdles, that the account has grown too big for one agency (with some $250 million in the marketing budget) and that there is a need for separate agencies to handle the competing Dodge and Chrysler-Plymouth dealers.

headline: BOLIVIANS FIND A PATRON IN REPUTED DRUG CHIEF
abstract: At the weathered airport where the doors swing freely in the hot prairie wind, pilots in blue jeans and baseball caps lounge around waiting for their next $100,000 fares to clandestine Colombian airstrips.   In town, young men who strut the main square in fine-grained cowboy boots and raise its dust with new motorcycles perch themselves on wooden bleachers around a cockfighting ring and throw $10,000 bets on tables that until recently saw only small peso wagers.   The source of this largesse, according to townspeople, narcotics agents, former associates, relatives and drug enforcement authorities in Bolivia and the United States, is Roberto Suarez Gomez, who is somewhere in the vast surrounding pampas of Bolivia's Beni department on one of his many properties that they say are devoted to the cocaine trade.   To the residents of Santa Ana, he is Papito, or Daddy, the remote cattle town's most cherished figure, who buys food for the poor, restores churches, strings colored lights in the plaza at Christmas, passes out sewing machines to women and paves village streets.   He is referred to with the honorific Don before his name and is frequently compared to Robin Hood.  To narcotics agents and other operators in the booming business, he is the padrino, or godfather, said to be the biggest drug dealer in Bolivia and therefore quite likely in the world.

headline: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOUSE UNIT EXPECTED TO BACK CARIBBEAN AID FUNDS TODAY
abstract: President Reagan was informed today that a compromise version of his $350 million aid package for Central America would be approved Thursday by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.   But the committee chairman, Representative Clement J. Zablocki, Democrat of Wisconsin, said it might not be easy to insure passage by the House.   Speaking with reporters after the committee had met with Mr.  Reagan, the chairman said some legislators might have reservations about spending the money on Caribbean Basin nations when there are economic problems in the United States.

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY THEY NOW HEAR ARAFAT MAY NOT WANT TO WITHDRAW TO SYRIA
abstract: United States officials said today that they had received indications that leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization might be reluctant to go to Syria in the planned withdrawal of their forces from west Beirut. The officials also said moderate Arab nations had serious political reservations about the prospect of the guerrillas' going to Syria.   Although Syria said Tuesday that it was willing to accept all of the guerrillas, the American officials said Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O.  leader, and other Palestinians would prefer to leave for a nation such as Tunisia.   The officials said they had received the information from a variety of diplomatic sources over the last 24 hours.

headline: INTRUDER REPORTED SEIZED AT QUEEN'S SCOTTISH ESTATE
abstract: A woman shouting ''I must see the Queen!'' entered the grounds of the royal family's Scottish Highlands estate while Queen Elizabeth II was in residence, The Sun reported today.   The newspaper said that the woman, who was in her 40's, slipped unnoticed onto the grounds of Balmoral Castle sometime over the weekend and was arrested, but that details of the incident were being kept secret.

headline: Labor Maverick: Ray Rogers; AN ORGANIZER BESET BY PROBLEMS
abstract: AMONTH ago, labor activist Ray Rogers was preparing to announce new, bold actions to help 1,600 m embers of the International Association of Machinists in a bitter s trike against the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, a major m achine tool maker based in North Kingstown, R.I.   Mr. Rogers, who helped formulate the aggressive anticorporate strategies that forced J.P. Stevens & Company several years ago to recognize the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers union at 10 of its 80 plants, is given to audacious tactics. Looking as burly and aggressive as he did when he played guard during his high school football days, the 38-year-old Mr. Rogers has a ''them'' and ''us'' philosophy that is sometimes alien to union leaders today. He has earned the reputation of a man who will ignore protocal, fashion new rules and design slashing attacks on corporations and their executives.   But on Aug. 18, the day Mr. Rogers planned to disclose that a broad coalition of labor had come out in strong support for the strikers and that there would be a widened attack on business institutions tied to Brown & Sharpe, it was announced, instead, that Mr. Rogers's two-month contract with the union was not being extended. The union said only that Mr. Rogers's contract had been fulfilled. In essence, it seems accurate to say, Mr. Rogers was dismissed.

headline: McDONNELL FEE ON SALE QUESTIONED
abstract: A senior Navy admiral has questioned the legality of a $4 million fee that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation plans to pay a Spanish consultant for helping to sell F-18 jet fighters to the Spanish Government.   Vice Adm. E.R. Seymour, the head of the Naval Air Systems Command, said in a Feb. 5 letter to the Chief of Naval Operations then, Adm.  Thomas B. Hayward, that the terms of an agreement between McDonnell Douglas and its Spanish agent, Compania Aeronautica Espanola, appeared to exceed limits set by Government regulations.   The main issue centers on whether the payment to the agent is made out of the company's profits or whether it is counted as part of the price of the $3.1 billion contract that is being financed with Government credits.

headline: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up 9.83, to 893.30
abstract: A late rally in blue chip issues sent the Dow Jones industrial average ahead by 9.83 points yesterday to 893.30, its highest closing level in a year. Trading volume slowed markedly from the recent hectic pace.   After running behind by 7 points at 10:30 A.M., the industrial average began to improve steadily; half an hour before the close, the Dow was ahead less than 4 points.   Thanks to the final burst, the industrials swept past last Thursday's high - which had capped a gain of 115 1/2 points in 10 sessions - to reach their best closing level since 899.26 on Aug. 26, 1981. Last Friday, when turnover on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 74.4 million shares, the Dow fell nearly 9 points.

headline: Nicaraguan Troops Said to Kill 96 Rebels
abstract: Nicaraguan troops killed 96 right-wing guerrillas in two weeks of fighting in the northeastern part of the country, the deputy army commander, Ramon Macis, said today.

headline: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: E.F. Hutton Chairman Adds Two Presidential Titles
abstract: Robert Fomon, chairman and chief executive officer of E.F. Hutton & Company, the brokerage house, and its parent, the E.F. Hutton Group, yesterday was also named president of both companies.   In those posts, Mr. Fomon, 56 years old, succeeds George L. Ball, 43, who resigned this week to head a new Prudential Insurance Company subsidiary that includes the Bache Group and other brokerage and investment operations.   ''It feels very challenging,'' Mr. Fomon said, to get back the titles of president, which he had from 1970 until 1977, when Mr. Ball took them over. Mr. Fomon said he would be putting in longer work hours and that he would be getting back into ''the retail end of the business, which was always my first love and the part of the business that I have been in the longest.''

headline: U.S. Markets Closed
abstract: United States stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Foreign markets are open.

headline: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ADVANCED MONITORING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kaiser Accord On Texaco Gas
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed to pay Texaco higher prices for future deliveries of natural gas under an existing contract and in turn Texaco Inc. will pay it about $181 million in cash.   The company said it expects to record most, if not all, the proceeds as a nonrecurring gain in its third-quarter results.

headline: Amoco Suspends Shale Oil Project
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that the Rio Blanco Oil Shale Company of Aurora, Colo., jointly owned by Indiana Standard and the Gulf Oil Corporation, would suspend operations indefinitely.   The suspension leaves only Union Oil, which is operating in western Colorado, actively proceeding with a commercial shale oil development.

headline: Massey Bankers Devise Debt Plan
abstract: International bankers have worked out a tentative refinancing package for debt-laden Massey-Ferguson Inc., but banking sources say that the farm equipment giant must reduce its operations.

headline: Magazine Revenues Up, But Pages Show a Drop
abstract: Magazine advertising revenues rose 6 percent in July, to $210.7 million, compared with $198 million a year ago, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Pages declined 1 percent, to 7,828 from 7,922 in July 1981, for the bureau's 113 members.

headline: Market Place; New Wrinkle In Municipals
abstract: IN the bond market, hardship has become the mother of innovation.  Municipals have been as hard hit as the rest of the bond market by violent fluctuations in interest rates, and long-term tax-exempts have been designed to reduce the uncertainties.   New compound-interest bonds represent the latest thrust. Also known as municipal multipliers, these tax-exempt bonds guarantee today's high rates of return for 15 to 20 years. They do not pay periodic interest.

headline: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada Cement
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. had agreed to divest itself of its Chattanooga, Tenn., plant. The F.T.C. said the move would settle charges that the company's acquisition of General Portland Inc. in January had impaired competition among cement companies in the Southeastern United States. The RC Cement Company agreed to buy the facility.

headline: G.E. NAMES SONY IN SUIT OVER PATENT
abstract: The General Electric Company filed suit yesterday against the Sony Corporation, contending that a plastic used for the housing of Sony consumer electronics products, including its video cassette recorder, infringed upon G.E.'s patent.   The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Sony Corporation of Japan, the Sony Corporation of America and Asahi-Dow Ltd., the Japanese company that, according to the suit, supplies Sony with a material known as Xyron that infringes on G.E.'s 1978 patent for a plastic it calls Noryl.

headline: World Copper Output Talks
abstract: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru has ruled out cuts in world copper production as a means of raising currently depressed prices but says exporting nations have to agree to a minimum export price for the metal.   Commenting at a meeting of the Inter-Governmental Council of Copper Exporting Countries, called Cipec, in Lima, President Belaunde said none of the eight member countries wants to reduce production.

headline: ZECKENDORF PROJECT ON UPPER BROADWAY
abstract: The late William Zeckendorf flashed across the postwar real estate scene, a man of great plans and broad visions. His company, Webb & Knapp, ultimately collapsed, but more permanent monuments survive. In New York they include the United Nations headquarters, Park West Village, Lincoln Towers and Kips Bay Plaza.   He was also an outgoing bon vivant, ''a public man with an aura about him,'' his son says admiringly.  No aura surrounds the son, who is named for his father, learned the real estate business at his father's side and dropped the ''Jr.'' from his name upon his father's death. But in his own more subdued fashion the current William Zeckendorf, now 52 years old, is leaving his mark as a developer.

headline: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: XEROX'S NEW LINE OF COPIERS
abstract: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced the first of a new family of copiers that it said would eventually replace its entire product line and help it compete with Japanese companies.   The introduction came a day after Xerox announced its entry into the insurance business through the $1.6 billion acquisition of Crum & Forster, a move that raised doubts on Wall Street about the company's commitment to its basic copier business.   Xerox officials said the timing of the two announcements was coincidental, but they did take advantage of the product announcement to try to dispel such doubts.   ''This is the most significant announcement Xerox has made in many years, including the announcement we made yesterday,'' the executive vice president, William F. Glavin, said in introducing the new copier.

headline: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * Neil J. Katz has been appointed senior vice president-marketing at Revlon Inc.  ADVERTISING

headline: TROUBLED WIENERWLD: A PERSONAL LOSS, TOO
abstract: In 1955, a young Austrian-born waiter invested $4,000 of his savings in a modest Munich restaurant specializing in split roast chicken. He later called the restaurant Wienerwald. By last year, the former waiter, Friedrich Jahn, had developed a worldwide complex of 88 subsidiaries operating more than 1,500 restaurants and a host of related companies in 18 countries.

headline: 3 Blacks Are Guilty In Pretoria Treason Trial
abstract: Three black nationalists were convicted of high treason and murder today for attacks on police stations in which 4 people were killed and 12 injured.

headline: Move Upheld On Fidelity
abstract: The United States Government legally seized the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of Oakland, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today, reversing a lower court.   Federal District Judge Spencer Williams had ruled in June that hasty bureaucrats had illegally placed the financial institution, with $2.9 billion in assets and 81 branches, in receivership on April 13.

headline: Tosco Plans to Sell Gasoline Refinery
abstract: The Tosco Corporation of Los Angeles, one of the nation's largest independent gasoline refiners, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Bakersfield, Calif., refinery to Koch Industries of Wichita, Kan., for about $150 million. Tosco said the facility can refine 40,000 barrels a day.

headline: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hyatt Hotel Unit Names Chief Operating Officer
abstract: Bernd Chorengel has been elected executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Hyatt International Corporation, the international hotel chain owned and operated by the Pritzker family of Chicago.   Mr. Chorengel, 38, will succeed Colgate F. Holmes, 47, in the No.2 position behind Jay Pritzker, the company's chief executive officer.  Mr. Holmes announced his resignation last month to become president of Monarch Hotels, which is owned by the Atlanta-based W.B. Johnson Properties.

headline: SECURITIES SALE RULE EXTENDED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended for one year the so-called shelf-registration rule for bringing new securities to market. The rule, originally adopted in March, was extended one year beyond its original expiration date of Dec. 10, 1982.   Under the rule, known as Rule 415, corporations planning public stock offerings are allowed to sell their new shares through underwriters, brokers, or directly to the public without going through investment banking firms and without the lengthy waiting times required under the old registration rules. They need only file a master disclosure statement, known as a shelf registration, which covers many future securities issues.

headline: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RETAIL SALES GAINED 1% IN JULY
abstract: The nation's retail sales rebounded a bit in July, rising by 1 percent after plunging 3.3 percent in the previous month, the Government reported today. However, the July sales pace was still weak and gave little indication of an economic recovery.   ''The numbers are not so low that we're going to say we're not going to have a recovery,'' said Sandra Shaber, director of consumer economics for Chase Econometrics in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ''But if we don't get more significant improvement in August and September, it would be very bad news indeed,'' she added.

headline: S.E.C. IS CRITICIZED FOR CITICORP STAND
abstract: A former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division told a Congressional panel today that the S.E.C. would become ''irrelevant'' if it were to adopt some of the arguments it used last year in deciding not to bring an enforcement action against Citicorp.   Stanley Sporkin, now the general counsel for the Central Intelligence Agency, also labeled as ''laughable'' one of the concepts put forward by some S.E.C. officials as a reason not to bring action against Citicorp for failing to adequately disclose its foreign currency dealings. A 3-Year Investigation   Much of the hearing before the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce revolved around the findings of the S.E.C.'s three-year investigation. Thomson von Stein, the S.E.C. attorney who wrote the report summarizing the investigation, confirmed the investigation's findings: that Citibank had shifted hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign currency transactions, many of which were questionable, between 1973 and 1980 through offshore units; that the bank had disguised billions of dollars in loans and other transactions to evade tax and currency laws as well as banking regulations in several European countries, and that Citicorp's disclosures of these actions were misleading and inadequate.

headline: Dow Advances 4.38, to 792.43
abstract: The stock market advanced broadly yesterday as interest rates plunged, but late profit taking and rumors of oil price cuts erased some of the earlier gains.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up almost 13 points at 1:30 P.M., closed ahead 4.38 points to 792.43. On Friday, the bluechip barometer soared 11.13 points after having dropped more than 40 points in the previous eight sessions.

headline: Honduran Commander Confirms Border Move
abstract: The commander of the Honduran armed forces confirmed today that he sent troops into disputed territory along the border with El Salvador last month. He said this was done to keep Salvadoran guerrillas out of Honduras.   Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez said he dispatched the troops after learning that the Salvadoran Army was about to begin an antiguerrilla offensive in El Salvador's northern frontier province of Morazan.

headline: COOPERS IN TIE
abstract: Coopers & Lybrand, the large international accounting and consulting firm, said that it had reached a merger agreement with Shaye, Lutz, Schwartz & King, one of Albany's oldest accounting firms, for an undisclosed sum. The merger, which will take effect in October, will allow Coopers & Lybrand to expand its practice in the Albany area, especially in state government-related business, according to Robert Hilliard, spokesman for the company.

headline: Platinum and Copper Continue to Weaken
abstract: Precious and base metals futures prices eased further yesterday as traders' concern about the economy deepened.  At the close of the New York exchanges, spot August copper futures slipped a further 0.35 cent a pound, to another life-of-contract low at 57.75 cents. The decline in copper futures reflects another spate of price reductions by producers who are hard pressed to find customers, according to metals merchants.

headline: AEG Hurts German Stocks
abstract: West German stock prices tumbled today in one of the sharpest falls on record as investors, shaken by the problems of AEG-Telefunken, the giant electrical group, sought refuge in the strong dollar.   Senior dealers said the mood was one of gathering pessimism as shares lost 2 percent of their value across the board. The Commerzbank index of 60 shares fell 13 points, to a seven-year low of 650.2.

headline: Lonrho Ends Fraser Bid
abstract: Lonrho Ltd. said today that it was ending its bid for the House of Fraser, which owns Harrods stores.  Lonrho, which has 29.9 percent of Fraser, said it dropped its $435 million offer for the rest because of Fraser's unsatisfactory earnings.

headline: GENERAL MILLS OFF
abstract: The General Electric Company, one of the first major companies to report results for the second quarter of 1982, said that net income in the period rose 6.7 percent despite a 4.7 percent decline in sales.   Analysts termed the gain outstanding in view of the recessiondepressed results reported by many corporate giants in recent quarters.   G.E., a diversified high-technology company and the nation's biggest producer of electrical products, said that net income in the latest three months rose to $465 million, or $2.05 a share, from $436 million, or $1.92 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped to $6.63 billion from $6.96 billion.

headline: PEPSICO GAINS 13.8%
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's leading producer of photographic equipment, reported yesterday that the cost of introducing new products and currency fluctuations depressed net earnings in the second quarter by 12.7 percent. Sales were flat, the company said.   For the second quarter, worldwide sales were $2.43 billion, up slightly from $2.42 billion reported for the same period last year.  Net earnings were $248.3 million, or $1.52 a share, compared with $284.5 million, or $1.77 a share, in 1981. Earnings from operations declined 19.7 percent, to $389.3 million, from $485.1 million

headline: Vistron Closings
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said its Vistron Corporation subsidiary would close its Lima, Ohio, ammonia, urea and carbon dioxide plants indefinitely. The company said that the plants were operating at a loss but that it would use the facilities as a terminal to provide customers with ammonia and urea from other producers. Workers at the plant will be reassigned to maintenance duties.

headline: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: E.E.C. Holds Talks in U.S.
abstract: European Economic Community officials today held what were described as positive but uneventful talks with Reagan Administration officials on issues that have strained American-European relations.   Administration sources were skeptical about any kind of major agreement being announced before the Common Market officials fly back to Brussels on Saturday.

headline: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for QTr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ITALIAN TO FORM A NEW COALITION
abstract: Italy's two-week Government crisis appeared to be close to a final resolution today with an announcement by Prime Minister-designate Giovanni Spadolini that he would form a five-party coalition pledged to economic restraint and changes in parliamentary rules.   Mr. Spadolini, who belongs to the Republican Party, said Friday night that two weeks of talks had produced a basis for returning a center-left coalition to power as Italy's 42d government since World War II.   He is expected to present a proposed cabinet to President Sandro Pertini early next week and, barring disputes over the allocation of ministries among coalition members, the new cabinet could be sworn in as early as Tuesday, political sources said.

headline: Tetley Inc. Acquisition
abstract: Tetley Inc., the United States subsidiary of Allied-Lyons P.L.C., has acquired S.A. Schonbrunn & Company for about $17 million cash from the American Maize-Products Company, Allied-Lyons said today.

headline: RTC TRANSPORATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW AT 930.46, 13-MONTH HIGH
abstract: A late rally enabled the stock market to post a moderate gain yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest closing level in more than a year.   The industrial average, which was off 2.20 points at 2:30 P.M., closed 7.45 points higher, at 930.46. Analysts said the upsurge resulted mostly from increased institutional buying.

headline: STRANGE TIMES FOR COAL
abstract: These are strange times in the coal mines. Compared to a year ago, when the 72-day strike by the United Mine Workers virtually wiped out output in the second quarter, production is up, and is likely to exceed 1981 year-end levels, suggesting that demand remains strong.  Yet analysts and industry officials alike say conditions are in fact quite weak, and could remain that way for another year or more.

headline: Erdos & Morgan Heads Receive Parlin Award
abstract: Paul L. Erdos and Arthur J. Morgan, founders of the New York market research firm of the same name, have been named recipients of the Charles Coolidge Parlin award, a leading market research honor that is awarded by the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Marketing Association and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.    Erdos & Morgan Inc., formed in 1947, was the first marketing research organization to specialize in mail surveys. The pair, who are also authors of Professional Mail Surveys, have established new standards for response rates, averaging 60 percent and, in some instances, 80 percent.

headline: HONDURAN REBELS STILL HOLDING 80
abstract: Leftist guerrillas continued to hold about 80 business and Government leaders hostage here today as more details of their demands became known.   The hostages include most of Honduras's major economic figures, including the Ministers of the Economy and the Treasury and the president of the Central Bank.   One hostage, a businessman, escaped this morning from the rear of the Chamber of Commerce building, where they have been held since Friday evening. The guerrillas released four more hostages this evening.

headline: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JULY SALES WERE WEAK IN CITY
abstract: Major department stores in New York City are slogging through their most difficult summer in more than five years, according to results of a spot-check yesterday. The data show that combined July sales for seven of the city's largest retailers rose only 1.7 percent from the same month last year while advance August business results showed an even weaker performance.   Including results from the retailers' suburban stores, however, the companies' total combined sales rose 5 percent from the 1981 period. Stores participating in the spot-check include the Macy New York division of R.H. Macy & Company; Bloomingdale's; Abraham & Straus; the Gimbel New York division of the Batus Retail division of Batus Inc.; Saks Fifth Avenue; Lord & Taylor, and B. Altman & Company.

headline: PANAMA'S ARMY CHIEF KEEPS POST
abstract: Panama's President, Ricardo de la Espriella, confirmed Brig. Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes as commander of the country's 10,000-member national guard tonight just 48 hours after the officer unexpectedly offered to resign.   An official statement said the President had accepted a recommendation from the guard's nine-member General Staff that General Paredes stay on as commander ''as long as the executive power deems it necessary'' even though he is due for mandatory retirement this month after 25 years' active service.

headline: MAROCS ASSERTS U.S. SOMETIMES FORGETS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos arrived here today for talks with President Reagan and other Administration leaders concerning American economic aid and military bases in the Philippines.   Mr. Marcos's Philippine Airlines jet touched down shortly after 11 A.M. at Andrews Air Force Base, where in brief remarks to State Department officials and about 100 Filipino-American well-wishers, he reminded Americans of their debt to the Philippines.   ''I bring the fraternal greetings,'' Mr. Marcos said, ''of the 50 million Filipinos who are your friends and have been your friends in the most critical days of the past and continue to maintain the reservoir of good will for America and the Americans - even if you occasionally forget about them.'' Last Visit Was 16 Years Ago   Mr. Marcos last visited Washington 16 years ago, shortly after he was elected president. In 1972, he established martial law in the Philippines, creating an authoritarian regime that has drawn criticism at home and abroad.

headline: FACTORY ORDERS UP 1.5% IN MAY
abstract: Orders for new manufactured goods rose 1.5 percent in May while shipments for the month advanced 2.6 percent, the largest one-month gain since October 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.   At the same time, the department reported that the value of inventories of unsold goods fell 1 percent in May, to $271.5 billion, marking the fifth decline in the last six months. Such declines are considered a sign of future economic strength on the ground that inventories will have to be rebuilt eventually through new orders.

headline: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Wendy's Sues Burger King
abstract: Wendy's International Inc. has filed a $25 million lawsuit against Burger King, charging that advertisements that tout the Burger King Whopper hamburger as better tasting than Wendy's are ''false, misleading and deceptive.''   The Wendy's suit, filed in United States District Court in Columbus, seeks damages and corrective advertising.

headline: HOOK DRUGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Behind Japan's Trade Disputes
abstract: TOKYO THERE are many apparent contradictions in the Japanese economy. In them lie reasons for both the nation's prowess and its problems as an international trade partner.  First, many foreigners believe that because land and food are very expensive in Japan the Japanese standard of living must be under constant pressure.  Indeed, land prices are high, but this is because of the density of economic activities. The size of Japan is only one twenty-fifth that of the United States, but its gross national product is two-fifths that of America. The G.N.P. per acre in Japan is thus 10 times as large as that of the United States. Agriculture is land-intensive too, raising the price for farm commodities.

headline: ISRAELIS ARE GIVING TALKS MORE TIME
abstract: Israeli Government sources said today that the Cabinet had decided to give the American negotiator, Philip C. Habib, and the Lebanese authorities more time to arrange an evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut.   ''The Government still believes there is a possibility of removing the guerrillas peacefully,'' Dan Meridor, the Cabinet Secretary, said, ''and we have given the Americans more rope to do so.''   But other informants said that some ministers at the Cabinet meeting had been skeptical about the ability of the Palestine Liberation Organization to reach a decision acceptable to all its factions.   After the meeting, the Cabinet issued only a terse, two-line statement saying it had held ''a discussion on security and political matters'' and would meet again this week.

headline: Security Pacific Plans Takeover
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Green Tree Acceptance Inc., a subsidiary of Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association of Minneapolis, for an undisclosed price.

headline: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mexico Sets Float of Peso
abstract: The Government in effect devalued the Mexican peso late today, allowing the currency to float to a new trading level based on supply and demand for most dollar transactions, the Finance Ministry announced.   It said it would fix a rate of 49 to 50 pesos to the dollar for certain unspecified essential products.

headline: PUTTING THE BOSS IN TV COMMERCIALS
abstract: Sports and show business celebrities have traditionally promoted a wide range of products on television. But a new group of glamorous spokesmen has taken to the airwaves - key corporate executives.   High-powered corporate leaders like Frank Borman of Eastern Airlines, Lee A. Iacocca of Chrysler, David Mahoney of Avis Rent-a-Car and Frank Sellinger of Schlitz Brewing have attempted to combat slumping sales and declining consumer confidence in today's recessionary economy by starring in commercials for their respective companies.   The rationale behind these advertising campaigns is simple. Many marketing experts believe that the C.E.O. is a highly credible commercial spokesman, especially in hard times such as these, because he is personally tied to his company's fate. Consumer research studies indicate that the public believes a C.E.O. will deliver on promises of better service or improved quality rather than face the prospect of poor corporate performance and possible dismissal.

headline: Fujitsu Develops New 64K Chip
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd. said it had developed the world's smallest and fastest 64K dynamic random access memory chip, with deliveries starting next month. The new chip, 15 percent smaller than the present smallest chip, has a data output speed of 100 nanosecond (a nanosecond is one-billionth of second), a 20 percent improvement.   Meanwhile, I.B.M. Japan Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation, said it will start making 64K random chips in Japan later this year, but did not disclose capacity.

headline: G.M. to Idle 1,100
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it will begin laying off 1,100 Buick division workers for about four months beginning Friday because of production cuts mandated by poor sales. The layoffs are not related to the rail strike, which has not affected Buick operations, a spokesman said. Workers will be called back no later than Jan. 31, and earlier if sales pick up.

headline: HABIB'S INTEGRITY HAILED BY U.S. AND ISRAEL LOBBY
abstract: The White House, the State Department, several members of Congress and a spokesman for the Israeli lobby voiced confidence today in President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib.   They issued statements after Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, suggested on Sunday that Mr. Habib should resign because of a business relationship with the Bechtel Group Inc., a construction company with large Saudi contracts.   Mr. Habib, who resigned as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs in 1978 because of a heart attack, has undertaken a number of special missions for President Carter and President Reagan. Mr.  Habib has been in the Middle East for several weeks, trying to mediate in the Lebanese crisis.  He met with King Hussein of Jordan in London today.

headline: Johns-Manville
abstract: Johns-Manville Canada Inc. said it had applied for a $35 million grant from the Canadian Government to resume expansion work at its asbestos mine in Quebec. The company, a subsidiary of the Denverbased Johns-Manville Corporation, suspended expansion work in two sections of its open-pit mine in February, laying off 150 workers.

headline: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLICEMEN IN MEXICO FACING TRIAL IN CASE OF MISSING AMERICAN
abstract: A judge in Sinaloa state has ruled that seven policemen must be brought to trial immediately in connection with the disappearance of a University of Colorado professor, Nicholas W. Schrock.   The attorney general of Sinaloa, Jorge Chavez Castro, said that Estrada Lopez, the criminal court judge in San Ignacio, ruled after a two-day investigation that the evidence against the seven men was sufficient to warrant a trial. The charges range from murder to criminal irresponsibility.

headline: Fairchild Unit Asks Trade Action
abstract: Fairchild Industries said its Fairchild Swearingen Corporation subsidiary had petitioned the Department of Commerce to impose countervailing duties against a Brazilian aircraft maker, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica.   Fairchild said it had lost ''millions of dollars'' in sales to the Brazilian company, which is 51 percent owned by the Brazilian Government and which Fairchild said had received subsidies for the development, production and sales of turboprop aircraft.

headline: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Begin Aides Worry Over Lengthy Role; News Analysis
abstract: Whatever the outcome of the siege of west Beirut, it is becoming apparent that Israeli troops are going to have to remain in Lebanon for some time to guarantee the political achievements of their invasion.   In Washington and Jerusalem, there is much talk of the need for a strong and stable Lebanese Government to extend its control over the country once the Palestinians have been disarmed or destroyed as a fighting force. But seven years of civil war, sharpened by outside Arab and Israeli involvement, have left the Lebanese Government, and its army and police, in ruins. No Abrupt Withdrawal   Prime Minister Menachem Begin and other Israeli officials insist that they have no designs on Lebanese territory, and Israeli military men say they hope their soldiers can be home soon.

headline: REPUBLIC AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. REPORTEDLY KNEW OF BANK'S TROUBLES
abstract: Federal bank regulators knew for more than two years that the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma was in serious trouble, but were unable to prevent its collapse last Monday, banking sources said yesterday.   Early in 1980, the Comptroller of the Currency, the arm of the Treasury Department that regulates federally chartered banks, had placed Penn Square on a list of problem banks and ordered the bank's management and directors to correct the problems, the sources said.   Between the beginning of 1980 and the failure last Monday, the sources said, Penn Square was subject to five examinations by the Comptroller's office, including the one that led to its closing. Yet, except for a short period, Penn Square's downward trend continued.

headline: Antitrust Move On Pabst Set
abstract: The Justice Department said today that it was prepared to file a court challenge to the proposed takeover of the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee by a Minneapolis businessman, Irwin L. Jacobs.   Pabst, which has agreed to acquire the Olympia Brewing Company of Tumwater, Wash., opposes the Jacobs bid and said today that as a result of a lawsuit it had already filed, a Federal judge in Delaware on Wednesday had blocked at least for now the proposed acquisition.

headline: STALKING NEW TAXES
abstract: Provisions of a bill to reduce the budget deficit through new taxes were approved by the Senate Finance Committee.

headline: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AID ADMINISTRATOR ARRIVES IN BEIRUT
abstract: The United States' top foreign aid official arrived in Beirut today to discuss the extent of American participation in an international reconstruction effort in Lebanon.   State Department officials said the official, M. Peter McPherson, who heads the Agency for International Development, would be in Beirut for three days to confer with the Lebanese President-elect, Bashir Gemayel, American Embassy officials and United Nations relief workers.   On his return here later in the week, he will report to President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz on the situation and make recommendations on what the United States should contribute to rehabilitation efforts.   In an interview on Friday, Mr. McPherson said that ''we are talking to a number of other countries on what they are doing,'' but that it was premature to be specific.

headline: New Orders Down 0.3% in June; Durables Off A Sharp 1.9%
abstract: New orders for manufacturers' goods declined by three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today in another negative signal for economic recovery.   Factory orders, which can indicate how well manufacturers are likely to be doing in coming months, had risen 1 percent in May after falling by the same amount in April.   The report said that June orders for durable goods - relatively expensive and long-lasting items often bought on credit - were down a sharp 1.9 percent, a reflection of continuing high interest rates during that month. Orders for nondurables were up 1.3 percent.

headline: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: National Medical Buys Care Group
abstract: National Medical Enterprises Inc., the hospital management corporation, announced it had aquired First Washington Group Inc., and its subsidiary, Psychiatric Institutes of America, for approximately $100 million.

headline: ISRAEL MAY NOT DEMAND MULTINATIONAL FORCE
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel might not demand the deployment of a multinational force along the Lebanese border if some security arrangement can be achieved with the Government of Lebanon.   Asked in an interview on Israeli radio whether Israel might be able to do without a multinational force, he said, ''Yes, such a possibility does exist.''   The Government had previously argued that some force, preferably an American-led force, would be necessary to keep a zone 25 miles north of the Israeli border clear of Palestinian guerrillas. A United Nations force is seen as undesirable by Israeli officials, who have accused the present United Nations peacekeeping force of being ineffective in screening out infiltrators.

headline: Dow Off 0.64; Volume Shrinks
abstract: Stock prices eased slightly yesterday mainly because of concern over interest rates and the increasing tension in the Middle East.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off 8.01 points at noon, ended the session off only 0.64 point, to 916.30. Analysts said the late recovery was helped by the moderate improvement in the bond markets yesterday, where prices rose about half a point.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bekins Co. said its Ace Termite and Pest Control Co. subsidiary had acquired Bead Termite Control Co. of North Hollywood, Calif., for an undisclosed price.   * Bell Canada said a Quebec court had approved the company's reorganization plan, under which a parent company, Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., will be formed to head a group of 80 subsidiaries.   * Beneficial Corp. said its Peoples Bank and Trust Co. subsidiary had agreed in principle to acquire First National Bank of Denver's $40 million credit card portfolio for an undisclosed price.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Air Florida Posts Loss
abstract: Air Florida System Inc. announced today a loss of $15.7 million in the second quarter of this year, in contrast to a profit of $6.3 million, or 42 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Second-quarter revenues were $73.6 million, down 9.5 percent from $81.3 million in the 1981 quarter. ''The generally reduced travel demand, caused by the poor economic climate, has resulted in a drop of 8.9 points in passenger load factor, from 65.4 percent in the 1981 second quarter to 56.5 percent in the second quarter of 1982,'' said Donald Lloyd-Jones, its president.

headline: STATEMENT BY WHITE HOUSE
abstract: Following is the text of a statement issued today at the White House on the United States reaction to Israel's latest attack on west Beirut:   The President was shocked this morning when he learned of the new heavy Israeli bombardment of west Beirut. As a result, the President telephoned Prime Minister Begin concerning the most recent bombing and shelling in Beirut.

headline: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Auto Layoffs Grow With G.M. Cutback
abstract: DETROIT (AP) - Indefinite layoffs among auto workers rose to 216,697 this week, the major auto makers said today, largely because of 3,000 new furloughs at the General Motors Corporation.   Officials at G.M. and the United Auto Workers union said that they expected more layoffs in coming weeks as the cutbacks at G.M.  assembly plants affect parts plants.

headline: COMPRESSORS LEAVE LE HAVRE FOR SOVIET
abstract: Three days behind schedule and at the center of a potentially bitter French-American confrontation, three giant compressors were swung aboard the 5,280-ton French freighter Borodine this morning, en route to the Baltic city of Riga for use in the Siberian natural gas pipeline.   The 60-ton compressors, built by the French subsidiary of Dresser Industries, marked the first shipment of such equipment from Western suppliers since President Reagan forbade American companies and their overseas affiliates to supply machinery for the 3,700-mile pipeline.   In Washington, the Reagan Administration announced today that because of the shipment, it was banning not only Dresser France but also France's Creusot-Loire from commerce with the United States.  Neither company would comment.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The international force of American, French and Italian troops that will take up peacekeeping duties in Beirut will face far more complicated and hazardous military problems than those encountered by the units that supervised the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization forces, according to United States and NATO military analysts.   The officials emphasized that the changed conditions in the city could require a larger force than that was now contemplated.  Possible remnants of the original Palestinian forces in Beirut, hundreds of Palestinians in northern Lebanon and strong guerrilla forces across the ''porous'' Syrian border and with Syrian forces in the Bekaa Valley were cited as conditions that argue against a short operation.   Analysts in this country and at Atlantic alliance headquarters in Brussels seriously question the ability of the regular Lebanese forces to contain the Christian Phalangist militia, various Moslem militias and any revival of P.L.O. activity.

headline: FISCHER & PORTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 6 Savings Banks Face Depletion of Surpluses
abstract: Six New York City savings banks are in danger of running out of surplus funds within a year, according to second-quarter earnings figures released yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.   Government authorities usually have merged such troubled institutions into stronger banks before the surpluses are depleted.  All deposits in savings banks are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and no depositor has lost any money as a result of such mergers.

headline: Advertising; The Race In Quartz Watches
abstract: ONE certainly doesn't have to convince Japanese marketers of the power of television advertising. They've tried it. They like it.  That certainly applies to K. Hattori & Company, marketer of the Seiko watch, which was introduced into the United States 12 years ago and now has over 47 percent of the quality watch market, nudging Swiss-made Omega out of the lead.

headline: S.& P. Drops Bank Ratings
abstract: The debt ratings of three major banks that disclosed loan losses from their involvment with now-failed Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma were lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: HRT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for 13 weeks to July 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OAKBROOK CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CATCHING THE TREND IN FARMLAND
abstract: THE contrast between International Harvester and Deere could not be s harper. International Harvester is mired in $4.2 billion of debt a nd expects to lose some $1 billion this year. Deere, in the No.1 p osition, has maintained a record of consistent profitability and m anufacturing innovation and has earned the reputation of being one o f the nation's best-run companies.   There is no watershed ''bad decision'' at Harvester. Rather, Harvester executives, in the decades following World War II, allowed the company to slip from the No.1 spot by letting costs climb, overinvesting in too many businesses and making some bad strategic moves.

headline: RAIL STRIKE, SECOND IN A WEEK, STRANDS THOUSANDS IN BRITAIN
abstract: A nationwide rail strike stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers across Britain for a second day today, but management for British Rail said there were increasing signs that the walkout might be broken.   In other job actions, Arthur Scargill, the militant new leader of the National Union of Mine Workers, told 250,000 union delegates in Inverness, Scotland, that the union was prepared to strike over the planned shutdown of coal mines. He said coal miners should be paid the same as members of Parliament and physicians.

headline: PATENTS; Method to Produce Growth Hormone
abstract: Genentech Inc., a genetic engineering company in South San Francisco, received a patent this week for a method of creating a microorganism that can be used in producing a human hormone useful in growth promotion.

headline: Bozell & Jacobs Studies Rogers & Cowan Link
abstract: Bozell & Jacobs, the country's 18th-largest advertising agency, is having ''serious'' merger discussions with Rogers & Cowan, the Beverly Hills, Calif., public relations firm, Charles D. Peebler Jr., the B.& J. chief executive confirmed in a telephone interview the other day.   B.& J. has its own public relations arm and, Mr. Peebler said, he has been eager to increase its size.
