headline: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: E.E.C. OFFER TO CURB STEEL SALES REJECTED BY U.S.
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today rejected a proposal, made just hours earlier, from four members of the European Economic Community to cut their steel exports to the United States in an effort to settle a growing trade dispute.   The offer was an attempt to stop the United States from imposing penalty duties on steel because of government subsides that allowed the European products to be sold here at lower prices than American competitors.   The European offer - which was a 10 percent reduction in the four countries' market share - was a last miinute effort to beat a Saturday midnight deadline, and was presented to Mr. Baldrige late this afternoon.

headline: U.S. INDICTS MITSUI UNIT FOR FRAUD
abstract: In a major crackdown on Japanese steel imports, a Federal grand jury today indicted a subsidiary of one of Japan's largest companies and three of its employees on charges of fraud and making false statements in a conspiracy to sell steel below market prices.   The indictment against Mitsui & Company (U.S.A.), a subsidiary of the big Japanese trading company, was the second major case in less than a month in which Japanese companies were accused of dishonest trade practices. Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Company have each been indicted on charges of trying to steal computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation.   ''A signal is being sent out by the Administration to all persons who do business with the United States that these are the rules and failure to comply with the rules and American laws may result in criminal prosecution,'' United States Attorney Joseph Russoniello said at a news conference. He denied, however, that the Justice Department was targeting Japanese companies for investigation.

headline: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Northern Ireland Protestants Mark Battle of Boyne of 1690
abstract: Thousands of Orangemen paraded through the streets of Belfast today amid tight security to mark the anniversary of the victory of Protestant forces over Roman Catholics at the Batttle of the Boyne in 1690.   More than 2,000 Orange Order lodges, led by the Rev. Martin Smyth, grand master of the Orange Order and Member of Parliament for South Belfast, marched through the Northern Ireland capital as bands played loyalist tunes.

headline: Arco in Alaska Bid
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company was the major bidder in a state oil and gas lease sale that saw only three oil companies and a group of Alaskan businessmen bidding on 39 of the 218 tracts offered.

headline: P.L.O. AIDE KILLED IN PARIS BOMBING
abstract: A Palestinian guerrilla leader was killed here today when three men tossed a bomb into his car as he was leaving for work.   Fadel el-Dani, deputy director of the Palestine Liberation Organization's office in Paris, was starting his car outside his home in southeastern Paris when the men drew alongside in another car and threw the bomb through an open window, witnesses said.   The blast, seen by dozens of drivers and pedestrians, killed the 38-year-old Mr. Dani instantly and destroyed the car, but nobody else was hurt, the police said.

headline: SOMALIA REPORTS AN INCURSION FROM ETHIOPIA
abstract: Somalia said today that Ethiopia had attacked two border settlements and that 60 Ethiopian soldiers had been killed in one of the communities.   The Somali radio said 60 Ethiopians had been killed, many wounded and two tanks and two artillery carriers destroyed in Ballanbale, in the Mudugh region of Somalia. The radio said Somalia had 3 dead and 12 wounded.

headline: U.S. Planning Aid at Border
abstract: As much as $200 million in loans and guarantees will be available to companies near the Mexican border that were hurt by the devaluation of the peso, the Small Business Administration said today.   ''Our goal is to help these businesses survive this period of economic shock,'' James C. Sanders, the agency's administrator, said.

headline: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EL SALVADOR'S LAND PROGRAM SEEMS TO RUN OUT OF STEAM
abstract: Eight weeks after the Reagan Administration certified that the Salvadoran Government was making progress in its efforts to redistribute land, agricultural experts and union leaders say the program has bogged down abruptly under renewed pressures from rightist officials.   Only 200 provisional titles to land have been given to peasants since July 28, when the Administration certified that El Salvador was making ''continued progress'' in carrying out the land program, according to Government officials. Before certification, in June and July, as many as 4,000 provisional titles, and possibly far more, were given to peasants.   ''It's obvious to me that, after certification, there's a lack of interest in completing the program,'' Deputy Agricultural Minister Jorge A. Pena Solano said. ''Before certification we wanted to give an impression to the American people and Government how fast we were giving the titles. Now certification is over.''

headline: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARAB NATIONS ENDORSE A P.L.O. PULLOUT
abstract: The Arab League announced a plan today calling for the Palestine Liberation Organization to leave west Beirut after it receives guarantees for its safe passage out of Lebanon and for the future security of Palestinian refugees remaining in Lebanon.   The plan, issued after two days of talks in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, between the foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Syria, Algeria, Lebanon and a representative of the P.L.O., marked the first time the Arab countries have endorsed a withdrawal of the Palestinian forces from Lebanon. P.L.O. Aide Signs Document   Because a P.L.O. representative, Farouk al-Kaddoumi, was a signer of the document, it also puts the P.L.O. on record publicly as committed to a withdrawal from west Beirut provided the proper safeguards can be arranged.   The Arab League said in a statement that ''the P.L.O. is to announce a decision to move its armed forces from Beirut and define guarantees for this move, along with guarantees to be worked out between the P.L.O. and the Lebanese Government for the security of the Palestinian refugees.'' (The P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, outlined a plan to Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan to withdraw the guerrillas in west Beirut to Syria, Jordan, Iraq and Egypt, according to Lebanese Government and Palestinian sources quoted by Reuters.The Palestinian sources said the withdrawal envisaged a one-week planning period and three weeks for the actual move.)

headline: POPULATION PLANNING IS DEBATED IN PHILIPPINES
abstract: In the Philippines, where families of 10 or more are common, the church and the Government are battling again over the issues of contraception and abortion.   Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila and an outspoken critic of the Marcos Government, is waging a campaign to prevent the imposition of population-control policies. ''The Philippine Government does not follow the church,'' Cardinal Sin said recently, ''despite the fact that the Philippine population is predominantly and overwhelmingly Catholic and therefore bound under pain of sin to obey the teachings of the Catholic Church.''   Last Sunday, priests throughout Manila preached sermons about the sanctity of life and the blessing of motherhood. The church protests followed an announcement on July 6 by Prime Minister Cesar Virata that steps must be taken immediately to prevent the Philippine population, now at 50 million, from eventually exceeding 115 million, the upper limit of the country's resources.

headline: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dean at Tuck School Stepping Down Early
abstract: The Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College will be getting a new dean one year earlier than expected.  Richard R. West announced yesterday that he would step down from the position next summer, instead of at the end of his second four-year term in 1984.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NEW MALL STRESSES OLD VIRTUES
abstract: An in-town Miami shopping mall built around chic boutiques and old-world shopping elegance may evolve into a nationwide chain of similar centers if the developers have their way.   Edward J. DeBartolo, one of the nation's leading shopping center developers, and Kenneth Treister, a Miami architect and center owner, say that upscale, European-style centers similar to their Miami prototype would be feasible in several other American cities. The prototype, Mayfair in the Grove, has been open for three years.   ''We can see an application of this concept in a number of cities, such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York, Chicago and Washington, each of which represents a strong attraction to tourists,'' Mr.  DeBartolo said in a recent telephone interview.

headline: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. WALKS OUT AS ATOM PARLEY BARS THE ISRAELIS
abstract: The United States and other Western countries withdrew their delegations from the final sessions of the annual general conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna today in protest after the agency voted to withdraw Israel's credentials.   The walkout was in part ceremonial, since the agency had nearly completed its week of meetings.  In a statement issued here, the State Department termed the vote to reject Israel's credentials ''unjustifiable and illegal'' and said that the United States was ''reassessing'' further participation in the 110-member United Nations agency. 'Could Have Ramifications'   The officials said there would be no further public comment until a full assessment had been conducted, but added, ''The action of the United States could have ramifications for the whole U.N. system.''

headline: Hope Voiced by Egyptian
abstract: Egypt's Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, expressed hope today that the election of Bashir Gemayel as President of Lebanon would bring unity in that country. Declaring that the election was an internal matter for the Lebanese, Mr. Ali said, ''What matters is the unity of the Lebanese people and we hope they will be able to rebuild their country.''

headline: PATENTS; How to Paint a Ceiling Without Dropcloths
abstract: Frank C. Martucci of Fort Lee, N.J., has found a way a man can paint the ceiling without spilling paint on himself or the furniture. He was granted patent 4,337,002 this week for a dripless paint roller with a guard.  The patent also describes a paint-metering pan that permits a selected amount of paint to come in contact with the roller.

headline: SENATE PANEL APPROVES BILL TO AID THRIFT UNITS
abstract: A bill that would provide Federal assistance to the nation's ailing savings institutions and broaden their powers overcame a major obstacle today when the Senate Banking Committee voted unanimously to report the legislation to the floor for further action.   The measure is a scaled-down version of a draft bill that was abruptly withdrawn earlier this month after the lawmakers disagreed on its scope. The bill approved today does not include a controversial provision that would have allowed banks and savings institutions to expand into the securities business.

headline: U.N. Gets Falkland Issue
abstract: Argentina and 19 other Latin American countries today submitted the Falkland Islands question to the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly session that opens Sept. 21. They said in a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the 157-nation organization should call on Britain and Argentina to renew negotiations as soon as possible under United Nations auspices to settle their differences about the territory.

headline: Excerpts from testimony, page A12.
abstract: Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz said today that the Lebanese crisis had made it ''painfully and totally clear'' that the ''legitimate needs and problems'' of the Palestinian people must be resolved urgently if there ever is to be peace in the Middle East.   Without deviating directly from official American policy toward the region, Mr. Shultz nevertheless went considerably further in expressing sympathy for the Palestinians than any member of the Reagan Administration has done publicly. He also said the Lebanese crisis underscored the importance to American security of close ties with friendly Arab states.   In some seven hours of testimony on the first day of his confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Shultz balanced those remarks by stressing that Israel was the United States' ''closest friend'' in the Middle East and that no one ''should dispute the depth and durability of America's commitment to the security of Israel or of our readiness to assure that Israel has the necessary means to defend herself.'' Criticism of Israel   ''I share in this deep and enduring commitment,'' he said. ''And more, I recognize that democratic Israel shares with us a deep commitment to the security of the West.''

headline: UNITED SERVICES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ST PAUL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Notifies Congress Of Supplies for Taiwan
abstract: The Reagan Administration formally notified Congress today that it intended to supply Taiwan with 60 F5-E and F5-F jet fighters over the next two and a half years.   The Pentagon sent a notice to the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., hours after the White House announced the decision. The deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said the planes would be co-produced by the United States and Taiwan.,i05

headline: Advertising; A Call To Enter Cable Now
abstract: WHILE everybody else has been frolicking in the Hamptons, Robert H. Alter, president of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau, has been sticking to his desk - and sounding a stern warning.   ''Advertising must look ahead,'' he said the other day, and adapt to ''the very dramatic changes that are taking place'' in the television industry.   Speaking from his Third Avenue office, out of sight of sea and sand, he suggested that advertising people do not look far enough ahead.

headline: BEGELMAN REMOVED AS CHIEF OF UNITED ARTISTS
abstract: David Begelman was removed today as chairman and chief executive officer of United Artists, the second major movie studio he has been forced to leave.   Mr. Begelman resigned under pressure from Columbia Pictures in 1978 some months after he had been accused of embezzling $61,008 from Columbia by forging checks and of taking an additional $23,000 in improperly documented expenses. He pleaded no contest to those charges.   Although no reason was given for his latest departure, most of the 11 films that were made by United Artists under Mr. Begelman's leadership have failed to make money at the box office.

headline: West Bank Town in Uproar
abstract: Disturbances continued for a third day in the Israeli-occupied West Bank town of Nablus today as Arab youths threw stones at Israeli soldiers and many merchants closed their shops to protest Friday's death of a 17-year-old Arab youth who was shot and killed by an Israeli soldier.

headline: JUDGE SIGNS PACT THAT SPLITS BELL
abstract: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene today signed a consent agreement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, setting into motion a plan to separate A.T.& T. from its 22 fully owned telephone companies in 18 months.   Officials at A.T.& T. said the company expects to present to the Justice Department complete, detailed plans for the divestiture well before the six months allowed under the terms of today's agreement.   Today's action by Judge Greene marked the end of an eight-year antitrust battle between the Government and Bell, a confrontation that reached its climax in January when the two adversaries announced a settlement. On Monday Judge Greene cleared the way for today's denouement by rejecting a Government request that he limit the ability of Bell's local companies to sell switchboards and related equipment once they split off from their parent.

headline: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Purex Statement Is Delayed by Suit
abstract: Purex Industries, which will be aquired by a private company if shareholders approve an agreement reached in January, said it would delay mailing its proxy statement for the shareholders' meeting because of new information concerning a suit involving Purex.

headline: American to Lease 20 McDonnell Jets
abstract: In an unusual transaction, American Airlines said it had agreed to rent 20 twin-jet Super 80 aircraft, beginning in May. Financial details of the accord, with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation, were not disclosed.

headline: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reagan to Meet Indonesian
abstract: President Reagan is scheduled to confer at the White House Monday with the Indonesian Defense Minister, Mohammed Jusuf, the White House announced today.

headline: ARGENTINA SETTING MODERATE COURSE
abstract: Argentina, which will be arguing its claim to the Falklands in the United Nations General Assembly this week for the first time since losing its battle for the islands to Britain, is pursuing a much more moderate foreign policy than the West had feared at war's end.   The leaders who led Argentina into the war have all been succeeded by military subordinates. The transitional Government is led by Maj.  Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, a modest, grandfatherly figure who has promised elections by March 1984.   The country's foreign policy is under the direction of Juan Ramon Aguirre Lanari, the new Foreign Minister, who is scheduled to meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in New York Monday and address the General Assembly sometime this week.

headline: Market Place; Wary Outlook For Stock Rise
abstract: INVESTORS who feel that a major new bull market has got under way and already left them behind might think twice before joining the rush to buy.   Institutions fueled last week's rally, and their traditional type of holdings appears to have done best. That is, the 30 bellwether companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average gained slightly more than 10 percent on average.   The New York Stock Exchange index was also up an impressive 8.5 percent for the week. But that index is weighted by market value, with the most heavily capitalized companies on the Big Board dominating the index. The 50 largest issues account for almost 40 percent of all value. As for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, it rose 9.21 points last week, to 113.

headline: Around the World; Thousands Aiding Police In London Bomb Cases
abstract: Police officials investigating Tuesday's bombings here, believed to be the work of Irish nationalists, reported today they had received 2,500 offers of assistance in response to appeals for help.   The appeal by Scotland Yard was directed to ''landlords, landladies and other possible witnesses, or vacationers who might have taken film at or near the scene.''

headline: MEXICO PROTESTS TO GUATEMALA ON INCURSIONS
abstract: Mexico for the first time has protested publicly about recent incursions into Mexican territory by Guatemalan troops involved in counterinsurgency operations in border regions.   In a letter delivered last week and made public here over the weekend, Mexico's Foreign Minister, Jorge Castaneda de la Rosa, also referred specifically to the disappearance - and apparently the murder - last year of a Mexican Vice Consul stationed in the Guatemalan border town of Malacatan.   Mr. Castaneda said Mexico was requesting that ''clear and absolute instructions be given to Guatemalan troops and paramilitary elements that operate in the frontier zone to respect scrupulously Mexican territory and to abstain from entering it or firing at persons on the Mexican side of the frontier.''

headline: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to May 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GUNMEN AT EMBASSY SET NEW DEADLINE
abstract: Gunmen holding the Polish Embassy here have freed all but five of their 13 hostages and extended for 48 hours their deadline for Poland to lift martial law, Swiss officials said early today.   The gunmen, described as militant Polish nationalists, said on seizing the embassy Monday morning that they would blow up the building and their hostages unless Poland complied with their demands by 10 A.M. today (4 A.M., New York time). The new deadline is Friday morning.   The gunmen, who also demanded that Poland free all political prisoners, released one hostage Monday night, three on Tuesday and four early today. The agreement to extend the deadline and let most hostages go followed negotiations in which the Rev. Josef Maria Bochenski, an 80-year-old Polish-born Dominican priest, played an important part. He spent an hour in the embassy negotiating with the gunmen on Tuesday.

headline: Mitsui Guilty Pleas
abstract: Three employees of Mitsui & Company (USA), the American marketing section of the Japanese company, pleaded guilty today to charges of helping Mitsui to sell steel products in the United States at prices lower than those allowed under trade laws. The three employees, Tsuneo Namiki, 48 years old; Takeo Teraoka, 47, and Katsumi Arai, 44, were allowed to return to Japan. The men will be on probation for 18 months.

headline: CHINA ASSAILS JAPAN'S BOOKS ON 30'S INVASION
abstract: China has mounted angry objections to what it says are distortions in new Japanese textbooks about Japan's invasion of the Chinese mainland before World War II.   People's Daily and four other prominent newspapers have run commentaries complaining that Japanese youth were being spared the harsh details of Japanese aggression and wartime brutality in China.   Their criticisms, which followed other expressions of Chinese unhappiness, implied that relations between China and Japan might be affected if the offending textbooks were not revised. Bitter memories remain of Japanese aggression and wartime occupation in China.

headline: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLAND CHARGES WEST'S BROADCASTS ARE AIMED AT CONTINUING TENSION   WARSAW, Aug. 23 (By United Press International) - The Polish authorities said today that they had lodged a formal protest against Western radio broadcasts, and they warned the Polish people that not even minor protest demonstrations could be tolerated.   These statements, published in the official press, were apparently aimed at heading off possible disorders on Aug. 31, the second anniversary of the founding of the independent union Solidarity.   Similar warnings against demonstrations have been appearing almost daily since calls for mass rallies on the annniverary were made by underground leaders of Solidarity, which was suspended last Dec. 13 with the declaration of martial law.

headline: U.S. RATES STIR HOPE AT I.M.F.
abstract: Finance ministers and commercial bankers, convening here for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, expressed relief today that the United States economy finally appears to be turning up.   ''The recent easing of U.S. interest rates could become a major turning point'' in the world economic situation, Manfred Lahnstein, West Germany's Finance Minister, told the conference, which was in its second day.   Faster economic growth in America helps other countries chiefly through the effects of trade. As the world's biggest importer, the United States has a crucial role in the economies of many developing countries. By importing more oil from Mexico, for example, America is easing that country's mountainous debt burden.

headline: Panhandle Seeking Algeria Compliance
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, a diversified energy company based in Houston, said that it had begun arbitration proceedings to force Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil company, to fullfill a contract signed in 1975 that called for deliveries of 3.3 trillion cubic feet of gas over a 20-year period. The deliveries were to have started last August.

headline: Alcoa Plans a Sale
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America said it agreed in principle to sell its Alcas Cutlery Corporation unit in Olean, N.Y., to a group of Alcas officers.

headline: Searle Issues Angina Item
abstract: G.D. Searle & Company, the drug producer, today introduced a nitroglycerin patch for treating angina.  The new adhesive pad is like one also introduced today by a joint venture of Becton, Dickinson & Company and the Ciba-Geigy Corporation.

headline: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SHARON, THE ISRAELI STRATEGIST, LEARNED HIS VALUES AS YOUTH, GUN IN HAND
abstract: Several years ago Prime Minister Menachem Begin said jokingly that, if he made Ariel Sharon the Defense Minister, Mr. Sharon might surround the Prime Minister's office with tanks.   Mr. Sharon got the job anyway, in August 1981, and since then the portly retired general, now 54 years old, has become one of the most powerful and controversial figures in Israel. His prominence and notoriety have grown rapidly and simultaneously since he conceived and carried out the invasion of Lebanon starting on June 6.   Today he appeared to have suffered the first serious setback in his public career when Mr. Begin and the Cabinet stopped the bombing of west Beirut to let negotiations for the withdrawal of the Palestinians continue.

headline: Seafirst Loan Is Past Due
abstract: The Seafirst Corporation, already beset by loan losses from the collapse of Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City, said a Mexican conglomerate has fallen behind on payments on $40 million in loans from the bank.   Seafirst, the holding company for Seattle-First National Bank, has already charged off $7 million to $8 million of the loans. More than $20 million of the loans to Grupo Industrial Alfa were put in the bank's nonperforming category, which means no interest or principal has been paid for 90 days, Art Merrick, a vice president, said.

headline: Advertising
abstract: THE world's first television commercial generated entirely by computers had its preview on both coasts last week, and, while the Japanese were involved, the technology was American.  The 30-second spot for a new line of advanced writing instruments (formerly known as pens) made by Pentel, a Japanese multinational, was produced for Triton Advertising by Cineflex, a subsidiary of Pacific Electric Pictures in Los Angeles.  The spot also has a computer-generated soundtrack created by Craig Harris, who did sound effects for ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind.'' The agency considered using a mechanical voice-over, too, ''but it just got too hokey,'' said Robert Friedman, president of Triton.

headline: FRUITLESS OIL DRILLING IN GEORGES BANK HALTS
abstract: Oil exploration in the Georges Bank came to a halt last week, leaving behind eight dry holes and diminished hopes for finding oil or natural gas off the New England coast.   The announcement by the Shell Oil Company that its rig, the Zapata Saratoga, would leave the exploration area 160 miles southeast of Cape Cod means a temporary end to drilling in one of the world's richest fishing grounds. Oil companies have spent 14 months and $1 billion seeking oil in the area. The money has been spent on drilling operations and the cost of leasing the tracts from the Government.

headline: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SURVIVOR: JESUS SILVA HERZOG
abstract: When Jesus Silva Herzog strode into the ornate Panamerican Hall in Mexico's Finance Ministry last Tuesday evening, he exuded a quiet confidence that seemed almost out of harmony with the unprecedented economic crisis that he had been assigned to manage.   But, addressing a crowded room as well as a nationwide radio and television audience, the 47-year-old minister spoke with a clarity and frankness that soothed the tattered nerves of bankers and businessmen and left them with the impression that the Government had at last drawn up a strategy to deal with the crisis.   ''He sounded as if he was telling the truth,'' one foreign financial analyst said, ''and this was a relief to businessmen who felt they had been repeatedly deceived about what was really going on.''   Having raised $2 billion in Washington last weekend, he then flew to New York on Wednesday to prepare for today's meeting with Mexico's principal creditor banks at which he urged postponment of $10 billion in principal payments and asked for additional credits of $1 billion.

headline: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Microbes Made Into Endorphin
abstract: WASHINGTON A method of synthesizing beta endorphin, a potentially valuable medication, from microbes has been invented by staff members at the University of California in San Francisco.  Patent 4,350,764 was issued to the university this week.

headline: Cheyenne Pipeline
abstract: The Husky Oil Company said it had purchased the Cheyenne Pipeline from the Cheyenne Pipeline Company. Terms were not disclosed. The main line of the system is a 209-mile, 6-inch pipeline with a 22,000-barrel-a-day capacity from Cheyenne, Wyo., to North Platte, Neb.

headline: Outlook for Telefunken
abstract: AEG-Telefunken expects a $400 million loss in 1982 before a return to profitability in 1984, the financial newspaper Boersen-Zeitung said today. It cited a 260-page report presented to the company's bankers Tuesday. An AEG spokesman declined to comment.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONTANA-DAKOTA UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Salvador Insurgents Cut Vital Rail Link
abstract: Guerrillas have destroyed a railroad trestle in eastern El Salvador, severing the only rail link to the region, the authorities said today.

headline: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARBARA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.P.S. DELIVERS A CHALLENGE
abstract: In the last 10 years, the Federal Express Corporation has made a name and a lot of money in the overnight package delivery business.  But Federal Express, the pioneer of the $2 billion-a-year industry, as well as a handful of other established companies in the field are now facing a formidable new challenger: United Parcel Service of America.   Last week, United Parcel, the nation's largest commercial delivery service, began offering overnight parcel shipments at prices that, in many cases, are half those charged by Federal Express and the other major overnight carriers. United Parcel inaugurated its new service with 24 company-owned aircraft in 24 cities, a promise to deliver parcels by 3 P.M. the following day, and a deliberately low-key approach.

headline: NICARAGUA-HONDURAS CLASHES SAID TO INCREASE ALONG BORDER
abstract: Border skirmishing between Nicaraguan and Honduran forces has increased recently, causing renewed fears of wider conflict in Central America, according to United States military analysts.   ''There's an awful lot of rhetoric,'' one analyst said, ''and a lot of confusion. It's not clear who's doing what to whom.'' But the analysts said the United States had independent confirmation from Central America that the fighting had intensified.

headline: IRANIAN INVADERS SAID TO PENETRATE 10 MILES INTO IRAQ
abstract: American officials reported today that Iranian troops had penetrated 6 to 10 miles into Iraq in what they described as the initial phase of an invasion.   Defense Department officials said Iranian armored units began the offensive by attacking southern Iraqi border positions Tuesday night and appeared to be driving toward Basra, Iraq's second largest city, 14 miles west of the border.   The invading forces appeared to be east-northeast of the city. Iran said they were nine miles from Basra. Iraq said its forces had halted the drive at a point six miles inside the country.

headline: Hess's Family Appeals For Ex-Nazi's Release
abstract: The family of Rudolf Hess, the former Nazi leader, has appealed to his British, French, American and Soviet jailers in West Berlin for his release on humanitarian grounds.   Mr. Hess, 88 years old and the last prisoner in the Spandau War Crimes Prison, was taken two days ago to the British military hospital in West Berlin after developing pleurisy.

headline: Executive At Schroder Branches Out
abstract: An expert on international finance has decided to take the plunge and open his own company. Geoffrey Bell, 42, has spent much of his time advising governments and central banks on the investment of their international reserves. Now he plans to concentrate on advising a limited number of businesses based in the United States, Venezuela and Britain.

headline: SHULTZ URGES BEGIN TO ACCEPT U.S. PLEDGE
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, has urged Israel to accept United States guarantees that Palestinian guerrillas will leave Lebanon if Israel agrees to the plan for their withdrawal drawn up by the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib.   Administration officials said Mr. Shultz's letter, which was read today at an Israeli Cabinet meeting, dealt with the ''practical arrangements'' of the departure of the 6,000 to 9,000 Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut.   Implicit in the Secretary of State's message, the officials added, was that if Israel agrees to the Habib plan, United States relations with Israel will take a positive turn after weeks of intense strain. 'Businesslike Letter'   A State Department aide said the Shultz letter was ''generally positive.'' An Israeli official in Washington said it was a ''friendly, businesslike letter.''

headline: FORCED SALE OF SECURITIES IS OPPOSED BY LOMBARD
abstract: Lombard-Wall Inc., the third dealer in Government securities to fail since May, cautioned yesterday that the forced sale of Treasury securities tied up in Lombard's bankruptcy proceedings could result in ''major losses'' for some of its creditors and ''unwarranted'' windfall profits for others.   The losses or profits would occur depending on the interest rate in effect at the time the transactions took place.  In papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, Lombard urged the court to permit the company to continue operations so that its losses could be recouped. Lombard-Wall Inc.  and Lombard-Wall Money Markets Inc., a subsidiary, asked the court on Thursday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act while they reorganize. Debts claimed by Lombard-Wall's 10 largest unsecured creditors totaled $107.8 million.

headline: ARGENTINA RELIEVES DEFEATED OFFICERS OF POSTS
abstract: The repercussions of Argentina's defeat on the Falkland Islands continued here as the army relieved the senior commanders directly involved in the campaign of their posts today.   The army announced in a communique late Monday night that Brig.  Gen. Mario Menendez, three other brigadier generals and two colonels were being put at the temporary disposal of the army's chief, Lieut.  Gen. Cristino Nicolaides, today. Eight lieutenant colonels and 10 majors were being reassigned, the statement said.

headline: G.M. Will Close Alabama Plant
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it would close a plant in Tuscaloosa, Ala., and consolidate work at two Detroit sites into other plants in moves that could idle up to 1,910 workers. G.M. said the Rochester Products division in Tuscaloosa was not needed because production of its emission devices and carburetors could be moved to Rochester.   Meanwhile, officials at G.M.'s Oklahoma City plant said a seasonal two-week layoff for 2,800 auto workers had been stretched to four weeks because of poor car sales. The first shift now will remain off duty until Sept. 20.

headline: POLES SET OFF ON PILGRIMAGE WITH PRAYER AND JUBILATION
abstract: Singing, laughing, waving and praying, tens of thousands of Poles, young and old, set out on foot today from the heart of Warsaw on the nation's holiest and oldest pilgrimage, a nine-day walk to Czestochowa, seat of Poland's revered national icon, the Black Madonna.   Spirits were high, the sky was cloudless, the pace was brisk and the hats were as varied as the generations and backgrounds of the marchers as the three-mile-long column stretched through the city in disciplined units.   There were children in strollers, nuns with running shoes and straw hats, bearded youths in T-shirts, old women carrying parasols, priests with modish embroidered stoles, people on crutches and musicians with guitars and accordions. For the 110-mile march, they were all ''brothers'' and ''sisters.''

headline: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW JOB ROTATION WORKS FOR JAPANESE
abstract: In his 26 years with the Toyo Kogyo Company, Mitsuji Muraoka has been an accountant, a plant designer, an efficiency watchdog, a materials-handling specialist and a computer systems manager.   The zigzagging career that Mr. Muraoka, a 50-year-old division manager, has experienced at Toyo Kogyo, the producer of Mazda cars and Japan's third-largest auto maker, is not unusual in Japan.   A management employee in a large Japanese company will typically move into new jobs in different fields repeatedly during his career, at intervals ranging from two to seven years.   American and European corporations also have programs of job rotation to broaden the experience and training of their managers.  But the Japanese-style shuffling of people into new disciplines every few years is a practice that is rare in Western corporations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Zimbabweans Hopeful On Hunt for Hostages
abstract: Security forces searching for six foreign tourists, including two Americans, taken hostage by Zimbabwean gunmen believe they are closing in on the gang, sources close to the search said today.   But the massed forces of soldiers and policemen complained that local people in the remote corner of the troubled Matabeleland Province were feeding and hiding the gunmen and were giving the national forces no assistance.

headline: CONDOMINIUM RESTORING LIFE TO A QUEENS COMPLEX
abstract: People who come to look at the condominiums that went on sale two weeks ago off Cloverdale Boulevard in the Bayside section of Queens may not realize that they are standing in the midst of a housing resurrection. But they are.   The development is called Parkridge. The Sidney Kalikow Development Corporation, the builder, is offering 20 models at prices from $60,000 to $173,000. There will be 179 condominiums in all, many of them duplexes and 56 of them with balconies. Occupancy is to begin in September.

headline: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said its acquisition of Geosource Inc. had been approved by Geosource stockholders.   * Aristar Inc., Miami, said its Blazer Financial Corp. affiliate had purchased the consumer finance and credit life insurance business of Commercial Securities Co. on undisclosed terms.

headline: Market Place; Tax-Exempts: Caution Urged
abstract: INVESTORS are racing to lock up double-digit returns in tax-exempts and, in some cases, may be doing so without regard to safety. That's the viewpoint of one professional who follows this market closely. He is Sylvan Feldstein, a vice president and bond analyst for Moody's Investors Service. Mr. Feldstein says there are many good bonds offering yields in excess of 10 percent even now.   But in the past few days, he said, buyers appear to have become less discriminating and are focusing on highest possible yields without determining how insulated the bonds may be from economic adversity.

headline: FOR THE PRINCESS'S FAMILY, THE PARTING IS FORLORN
abstract: Princess Grace of Monaco was brought back by her family today to the cathedral where she was married and her children were baptized.   Looking devastated with sadness, her husband, Prince Rainier, wept again and again as he and Prince Albert and Princess Caroline led the funeral cortege through the pink and ocher streets of the principality to a funeral mass at the Romanesque-style cathedral.   The dark wood coffin of the Princess, who died at the age of 52 on Tuesday after an automobile crash, was later placed in the Chapel of the Princes near the altar where she, as Grace Kelly, the film actress, was married to the Prince 26 years ago.   A palace spokesman said that her interment in the family crypt would take place in a few days.

headline: DON'T LET INDUSTRY SHIRK ITS DUTY
abstract: THE startling decision by the Manville Corporation to file for reorganization under Chapter 11 oft he Bankruptcy Act will hopefully accelerate the creation of a p rocess for assuring that victims of asbestos diseases receive a dequate compensation on a timely basis.  State workers' compensation programs ought to be providing workers with benefits for their occupational disabilities. Yet, because those procedures were designed for traumatic injuries, not subtle diseases, relatively few workers have actually collected compensation benefits for occupational diseases.  Frustrated by delays and obstruction, workers turn to litigation, not against their employers (which is generally prohibited by compensation law), but against third parties like Manville which supplied the employers with the dangerous substance. Today, there are 16,500 suits against Manville, and the total may add 32,000 more as the long latent asbestosis, mesothelioma and lung cancers manifest themselves. Manville's action is largely an effort to evade thousands of law suits filed by severely ill workers who have turned to litigation because the current system has failed them.

headline: Bowater Will Shut Mill for 16 Days
abstract: The Bowater Southern Paper Corporation said it would close its Calhoun plant, the largest newsprint producing mill in the United States, for 16 days beginning Aug. 22 to reduce inventories.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Brussels Site Of Steel Talks
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and Under Secretary Lionel Olmer were to leave Washington tonight for Brussels in an attempt to get an agreement to hold down exports of steel to the United States.   They will meet Viscount Etienne Davignon, who is in charge of industrial problems on the European Commission, the executive body for the 10 countries in the European Economic Community.

headline: HOLLYWOOD'S LOVELY BUT LONELY LADY
abstract: Hollywood, where she had been a queen before she left to become a princess, reacted with distress and dismay today to the death of Princess Grace of Monaco.   Frank Sinatra, her co-star in her last movie, M-G-M's ''High Society'' in 1956, and her close friend, issued a statement describing the Princess as ''a gracious, wonderful woman who was a princess from the moment she was born.'' Mr. Sinatra said he was ''stunned, shocked, and totally grief-stricken.''   James Stewart, who co-starred with her in Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' in 1954, described her death as ''shocking and tragic.'' Through a spokesman, Mr. Stewart went on to say: ''She was a most accomplished and extremely popular actress. When she assumed the duties of royalty, she did an equally masterful job. Throughout both of her careers, she had one basic attribute - Class!''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan is trying to transform the shock and horror of events in Lebanon into new pressure for the withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian forces from Lebanon and renewed Arab-Israeli negotiations in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, Administration officials said today.   The essential first step is gaining Israeli acceptance of the proposed international peacekeeping force.  At stake, according to the officials, are future American relations with the Government of Menachem Begin and the credibility of the United States in the Arab world. Displeasure With Begin   The officials indicated that if Israel did not agree to withdraw its troops from the Beirut area and accept the international force, Mr. Reagan was prepared to go very far, without specifying what that meant, toward making clear his displeasure with the Begin Government as now constituted.

headline: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Carrier Layoffs
abstract: The Carrier Corporation announced the furlough of 433 production workers, bringing to 1,100 the number of employees laid off since May.

headline: Civil Servants Strike In British Columbia
abstract: Government workers here walked off the job here today for the second time in less than a month.   The one-day general walkout by the 40,000-member British Columbia Government Employees Union came after government and union negotiators rejected each other's terms for a return to the bargaining table.

headline: Careers; Training The Future Managers
abstract: AT a time of relatively high unemployment for middle managers, there is a shortage of teachers in business schools to train future managers. The shortage of holders of Ph.D's in business school subjects has grown so severe in recent years that a panel was set up in 1980 by the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business to study the problem.   A few months ago, Dr. Robert S. Kaplan, dean of the Carnegie-Mellon University Graduate School of Industrial Administration; Dr. Lyman W. Porter, dean of the Graduate School of Management of the University of California at Irvine, and Dr. Kenneth R. Smith, dean of the College of Business and Public Administration of the University of Arizona, released their findings.

headline: ICL Wins Order
abstract: ICL said today that it had an order worth more thatn $35 million from Britain's Inland Revenue for nearly 18,000 desk-top video display units. The order marks the second stage of the computerization of the revenue's pay-as-you-earn tax collection system, it added.

headline: Ethiopia Reportedly Attacks Somali Positions on 2 Fronts
abstract: Ethiopian troops and warplanes attacked Somali positions on two fronts today, prompting an urgent Somali appeal for aid in halting an 11-day-old Ethiopian advance, the Somali press agency reported.   Thousands of Somalis marched here in the capital shouting anti-Ethiopian slogans, the press agency said.

headline: GRAND MET'S CHAIRMAN TO SHIFT TO QUIETER POST
abstract: Sir Maxwell Joseph plans to retire next March as group chairman of Grand Metropolitan, the British business empire that includes hotels and restaurants.   Sir Maxwell, 72, is to be succeeded as chairman by Stanley Grinstead, 57, who has been deputy chairman and group managing director since 1980, the year Grand Met acquired the Liggett Group, with its tobacco, wine, spirits and pet food interests. Last year Grand Met bought the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation from Pan American World Airways..   ''There comes a time in everyone's life,'' Sir Maxwell observed this week, ''when it is sensible to hand on some of one's responsibilities and to lighten the working load.''

headline: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX ROSE BY 13% IN JULY
abstract: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.3 percent in July, the fourth monthly increase in a row, the Commerce Department reported today.   The rise in the index, which followed a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in June, was generally expected and provided another sign that the economy might be at the threshold of a sluggish recovery, according to several economists.   Despite this glimmer of optimism, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, in a statement released with the index, cautioned that there would be few signs of any upturn this quarter, contrary to earlier Administration projections.   ''Key coincident indicators, such as payroll employment, industrial production and real G.N.P., are unlikely to show much change for the third quarter,'' he said.

headline: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BROOKLYN CHURCHES GAIN CITY HELP FOR NEW HOMES
abstract: When an ecumenical coalition of 36 churches asked the city last month to help it build 5,000 single-family town houses in the Ocean Hill, Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn, the Koch administration was respectfully - but deeply - skeptical.   Respectful, because the four-year-old coalition, known as East Brooklyn Churches, has worked assiduously to stabilize and restore the three blighted neighborhoods. And because its effort is supported by the leaders of several religious denominations, including Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, and Bishop Robert C. Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.   But skeptical, too, because these neighborhoods' devastation, which rivals that of the South Bronx, seemed to make it unlikely that even the 1,000 homes planned for the first stage of the project could be sold. And because the coalition's pledge to establish a $12 million construction loan fund from contributions by the denominations seemed too good to be true. And also because the coalition wanted the city to lend buyers of the first 1,000 homes $10,000 each - a total of $10 million -to reduce the homes' purchase price.

headline: Czechs Bar a Polish Bishop After Visit to West Germany
abstract: A Polish bishop traveling home from West Germany was refused entry into Czechoslovakia by border guards today, the border police said.

headline: U.N. SUPPORTS PLAN TO SEND TROOPS IN
abstract: United Nations officials said tonight that they were pleased that Western forces would go to Beirut but expressed disappointment that the United Nations would again be bypassed.   Aides here had hoped that troops sent to protect Beirut's Moslems would be drawn from the United Nations peacekeepers in southern Lebanon and would fly the United Nations flag. Officials questioned whether the American, French and Italian force would stay in Lebanon long enough to restore order and whether they had as much experience as the United Nations troops in dealing with the myriad Lebanese armies and factions.

headline: U.S. FEARS NEW BURST IN FIGHTING
abstract: President Reagan said tonight that the ''cowardly assassination'' of President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon was a ''shock to the American people and to civilized men and women everywhere.''   In an unusually sharp statement, Mr. Reagan added, ''We condemn the perpetrators of this heinous crime against Lebanon and against their cause of peace in the Middle East.''   The White House statement, issued late tonight, expressed deepest sympathy to the Gemayel family, and said, ''The tragedy will be all the greater if men in countries friendly to Lebanon permit disorder to continue in this war-torn country.'' 'U.S. Stands By Lebanon'   Mr. Reagan added that the ''U.S. Government stands by Lebanon with its full support in its hour of need.'' American officials said earlier that the assassination raised the possibility of new fighting in that country between Mr. Gemayel's Christian Phalangist forces and Moslem leftists.

headline: NEW HEAD IS NAMED AT THE ZIFF CORPORATION
abstract: Philip B. Korsant was named president of the Ziff Corporation yesterday, succeeding I. Martin Pompadur, who announced last week that he was stepping down to purchase four of Ziff's television stations.   Mr. Korsant, 39, had been executive vice president of the privately owned media company. William Ziff, who is 52 and took over the presidency when he was just 24, remains chairman of the corporation.

headline: 57 West Bank Students Arrested in Jerusalem
abstract: The police today arrested 57 Bir Zeit University students who were among many who had gathered at East Jerusalem high school buildings to carry on with classes because their campus was closed last week.

headline: Noranda Mines
abstract: The Scott Paper Company said it had contracted to allow Noranda Exploration Inc., a unit of Noranda Mines Ltd., to explore about 130,000 acres of land owned by Scott in Maine for deposits of copper, lead and zinc. Noranda has exploration rights for 10 years under the contract.

headline: BASF Acquisition
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission let stand today a ruling allowing the BASF Wyandotte Corporation to acquire the Chemetron Pigments division of the Allegheny Ludlum International Corporation.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., has elected to its board Rocco C. Siciliano, chairman and chief executive officer of Ticor, Los Angeles.   * Armstrong Laboratories Inc., West Roxbury, Mass., has elected to its board of directors Dr. Seymour M. Farber, an expert on chest diseases and problems of the aging.   * Ashland Oil Inc. announces the election at a subsidiary, the Integon Corporation, of James R. Ridley, president, to the additional post of chief executive officer, succeeding Carl A. Dull Jr., who remains chairman until he retires in February.

headline: AMSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Playboy Posts a Loss
abstract: Playboy Enterprises said yesterday it lost $21.3 million in its fourth quarter, ended June 30, on sales of $52.6 million, compared with earnings of $3.1 million on sales of $56.3 million the year before. For the year, Playboy lost $51.7 million on sales of $210.1 million, compared with earnings of $13.7 million on sales of $221.5 million the year before. The 1982 loss included a $15 million writeoff from costs related to its Atlantic City casino and a $20.5 million write-off from discontinued book publishing and resort operations.

headline: HAITIAN LABOR: DOMINICANS RELY ON IT
abstract: Despite an unemployment rate of nearly 30 percent, the Dominican Republic relies largely on a supply of cheap Haitian labor to harvest its main cash crop, sugar.   The use of Haitian migrant workers has existed here in various forms for decades. But it has recently been creating growing numbers of social, economic and political problems for the Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti.   While the situation is widely known, its sensitivity is such that Government and sugar-company officials will generally speak about it only with a promise of anonymity.

headline: HEADS OF RHONE-POULENC AND AIR FRANCE RESIGN
abstract: The head of Rhone-Poulenc, the big French chemical group that was nationalized earlier this year, has resigned in protest against the Socialist Government's policies.   In a letter submitted to the Government on June 18 and released today, the executive, Jean Gandois, described the Government's economic policy as ''contradictory'' and ''unrealistic.''

headline: Times Co. Plans to Buy Sarasota Newspaper
abstract: The New York Times Company has agreed in principle to purchase The Sarasota Herald-Tribune, a morning and Sunday newspaper published in Sarasota, Fla., from Lindsay Newspapers Inc.   The announcement was made jointly yesterday by David Lindsay Jr., president and editor of Lindsay Newspapers, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer of the Times Company.   The purchase is subject to the execution of a definitive contract and to the approval by the boards of directors of both companies and the shareholders of Lindsay Newspapers. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

headline: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.B.M. 'STING' ROLE ASSAILED BY HITACHI
abstract: In a brief to be filed in the Federal court here Wednesday, lawyers for Japan's Hitachi Ltd. accuse the International Business Machines Corporation of playing an ''improper role in orchestrating a criminal investigation and resulting indictment for anticompetitive and other purposes.''   The brief, made available by the company today, is the latest legal move in a criminal case growing out of a ''sting'' operation conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in California's Silicon Valley late last year and in 1982. The operation resulted in indictments against Hitachi Ltd., Mitsubishi Ltd. and 21 individuals on charges that they stole secret documents and computer equipment from I.B.M.   Both of the big Japanese electronics concerns have pleaded not guilty to the charges.  The Hitachi brief is being filed in response to a motion filed by I.B.M., Palyn Associates, a Silicon Valley electronics consulting concern, and the Federal Government that seeks to quash subpoena powers that the court earlier granted to Hitachi. The subpoenas, granted to Hitachi under discovery rules of evidence, are intended to ascertain the extent of I.B.M.'s role in the F.B.I. ''sting'' operation.

headline: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Bloc in Corsican Election Won by Autonomy Movement
abstract: The Corsican autonomy movement captured eight key seats in elections for a new regional assembly designed to make this Mediterranean island more independent from France, election officials said today.

headline: ABBOTT RISES 17.3% IN PERIOD
abstract: Abbott Laboratories reported yesterday that rising sales of its hospital and laboratory products helped lift net income in the second quarter of 1982 by 17.3 percent.   The diversified producer of health-care products and prescription drugs said that net income in the second quarter was $71.2 million, or 58 cents a share, up from $60.7 million, or 49 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 12.1 percent, to $649 million from $578.8 million.

headline: SWANK INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BENDIX SEEKS TO BLOCK MARIETTA BID
abstract: The Bendix Corporation, announcing yesterday that it had purchased some 70 percent of the Martin Marietta Corporation's stock for at least $1.2 billion in cash, will go into the Federal District Court in Baltimore today in an attempt to enjoin Marietta from trying to take over Bendix.   Wall Street sources said, meanwhile, that they had heard that an unidentified company friendly to Bendix might offer to purchase some 10 percent of Bendix that it would later swap for Bendix assets.   Such an offer would gain time for Bendix because Marietta would be unable to buy on Thursday the Bendix shares that have been tendered to it, as its offer currently provides. By law, any new bidder for a company automatically extends tender offer deadlines by 10 business days so that stockholders can study the new situation.

headline: F.T.C. Delays Tie
abstract: Conagra Inc. and the Peavey Company said they had agreed with the Federal Trade Commission to delay, until at least July 20, the completion of their $180 million merger.

headline: Market Place; Overlooked Retail Chain
abstract: THE Wards Company is so little known in Wall Street that the shares have eased in the strongest rally in stock market history. Yesterday, the shares closed at 10 7/8, down 1/8, on the American Stock Exchange. They traded as high as 11 1/2 in July.   What little national publicity Wards, which has no relation to Montgomery Ward & Company, has had in recent years concerned large losses in the mid-1970's on leased appliance departments at three discount chains that failed.   But in seven years, Wards has shifted from appliances to consumer electronics, which now make up 80 percent of sales. Rapidly growing, Wards now has four retail chains with 100 outlets, twice the total in 1975.

headline: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Abitibi Layoffs
abstract: Abitibi-Price Ltd. will lay off 800 workers at its newsprint mill in Grand Falls, Newfoundland, for two weeks starting July 25 to reduce inventories, a company spokesman said. The mill had been closed for two weeks in June.

headline: QUICK & REILLY ACQUIRES COLIN, HOCHSTIN ASSETS
abstract: Quick & Reilly Inc., the nation's second-largest discount brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had acquired for $2.8 million the assets of Colin, Hochstin Company, a small institutional brokerage and specialist in trading the stocks of 27 companies on the New York Stock Exchange.   The acquisition came 10 days after Justin Colin, a senior partner in Colin, Hochstin, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Although the brokerage firm was not formally a party to the reorganization, a Colin, Hochstin spokesman said that Mr. Colin's bankruptcy petition carried the threat that his capital in the firm would be seized by the court.

headline: POLITICS ON FRENCH TV: NOT HOW MUCH BUT WHOSE
abstract: A year and a half into Socialism, French television has not become so politicized that it could not offer 40 minutes of its taxpayer-s@upported time recently for the definitive program on the history of the garter belt. But the politics is there.    In the last two weeks the basic issue of how much the Government has to do with setting the political tone of the national television networks has come angrily to the surface with a series of managerial appointments, the removal of a news program anchorman and what had the appearance of a cooperative agreement between the news division of one of the networks and L'Humanite, the official organ of the French Communist Party.   The question of who ran French television, particularly the news programs, basically never existed through the de Gaulle, Pompidou and Giscard d'Estaing years - the Government did.

headline: RUSSIANS SEEKING SUN, SEA AND CURES
abstract: The palms, glittering sea and scented air here speak of languid leisure. But vacationing Russians are just as likely to be talking of sulfur baths and physiotherapy.   To the tens of thousands of people who descend on Sochi in organized droves, the prescribed 24-day stay is hardly meant to be all sun and fun. That may be the fashion in the capitalist West, the doctors say, but here the goal is to refurbish and regenerate the bodies and minds of the working masses.

headline: Around the World; Death on Tennis Grounds Ends English Manhunt
abstract: A 17-day hunt by hundreds of armed British policemen ended today when Barry Prudom, suspected of three killings, was shot dead outside the Yorkshire town of Malton.   The search, which had become a national preoccupation, began on June 17 with the shooting of a police officer in Harrogate.

headline: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Amoco Funds Distribution
abstract: The Department of Energy said today that it would conduct a public hearing Sept. 22 to take comments on its proposal for the distribution of funds from the 1980 settlement of the Amoco Oil Company's product overcharges. Amoco is a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

headline: WRIGHT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MISLED ON FALKLANDS, BRITISH PRESS SAYS
abstract: British reporters who covered the Falkland war told a parliamentary inquiry today that official briefings had ranged from erratic to purposely misleading. In one case, an admiral was said to have sought to have reporters file false information to confuse the enemy.   Testifying before a House of Commons committee looking into the Defense Ministry's handling of press coverage, Robert McGowan of The Daily Express said reporters had been told that casualties were ''minimal'' after one Argentine bombing attack when, in fact, 50 British soldiers died.

headline: Hong Kong to Detain Refugees From Vietnam
abstract: Hong Kong officials said today that Vietnamese refugees who come to Hong Kong would be ''detained indefinitely.''

headline: Article 112739 -- No Title
abstract: The Bendix Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of automotive components and production machinery, offered today to acquire the Martin Marietta Corporation for a combination of cash and stock valued at about $1.6 billion.   The unsolicited offer for Martin Marietta, a producer of advanced aerospace products, cement and aluminum, was the first major acquisition attempt by Bendix since it was rebuffed in an apparent effort to gain control of the RCA Corporation.   Bendix, which already holds a 4.5 percent interest in Martin Marietta, said it would offer $43 a share in cash for approximately 45 percent of the company's 37.5 million shares. The remaining 50 percent would be acquired via an exchange of stock, Bendix said, at a ratio of .82 shares of Bendix stock for each share of Martin Marietta.

headline: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Massey Extends Summer Closing
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. announced it would extend the summer shutdown of its plants in Brantford, Ont., and Toronto because of the continuing slump in the farm-machinery market.

headline: Six Missing on Mount Blanc
abstract: Italian and French rescue teams searched today for six climbers, including an American, missing on Mount Blanc. The teams, supported by helicopters but hampered by bad weather, did not report any sightings, the police in this northern Italian town said. A Boston lawyer identified as Brenten Young, 31 years old, vanished Sunday on the Italian side of the mountain, the police said.

headline: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HONDURAS REPORTED TO SEIZE REBEL ARMS
abstract: After two battles with Honduran rebels in the capital of Tegucigalpa, Honduran Government forces have uncovered a large cache of arms and other equipment, United States military analysts said today. The analysts said the equipment was apparently intended for shipment to leftist insurgents in El Salvador.   They said Honduran troops had also found clandestine radio equipment and large quantities of Marxist propaganda in raids on two hideouts in the city Friday. News dispatches from Tegucigalpa said the Honduran forces had fired automatic rifles, bazookas and hand grenades in attacking the insurgents.

headline: Reagan to Meet Dominican
abstract: President Reagan will meet July 15 with Jacobo Majluta Azar, the new President of the Dominican Republic, a White House spokesman said today. Mr. Majluta assumed the presidency after Antonio Guzman died Saturday of what was reported to be a selfinflicted bullet wound in the head.

headline: I.M.F.'s Pakistan Loan
abstract: The International Monetary Fund said today it would lend Pakistan $198 million to help cover its 10 percent decline in export earnings over the last year.

headline: Text of Cabinet statement, page A4.
abstract: The Israeli Government said tonight that it would not heed calls to withdraw its troops to Sunday's cease-fire lines in west Beirut as long as the Palestine Liberation Organization forces remained in Lebanon.   ''The arrangements for the deployment of Israeli forces,'' a Cabinet spokesman said, ''will be determined following the departure of the terrorist organizations operating in Beirut beyond the Lebanese border on the principle that all foreign forces will leave the sovereign territory of Lebanon.''   At a five-hour meeting at the office of Prime Minister Menachem Begin that ended just before midnight, the Cabinet also rejected a request by the United Nations Security Council that it be allowed to send additional cease-fire monitors to Beirut.

headline: Young Beirut Victims To Visit Pennsylvania
abstract: A group of Lebanese and Palestinian children injured in Israeli bombing raids on Beirut will be flown to the United States for hospital treatment in western Pennsylvania, it was announced today.   Dr. William J. Monsour, chairman of the local chapter of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, said that about 50 children, the first of about 3,000 who are to be flown to hospitals in the United States, would be treated at Monsour Medical Center in Jeannette, Westmoreland County.

headline: POLE GOES HOME VOLUNTARILY TO FACE PLOT CHARGES
abstract: A leading dissident intellectual flew home today to voluntarily face charges by the military authorities of plotting to overthrow the Polish Government by force.   ''My friends are all inside and I should be with them,'' Jan Jozef Lipski, a history professor who was receiving medical treatment in London, told welcomers at the airport. ''I must return.''

headline: FIDELITY MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canadian Oil Deal
abstract: The Canadian Government-owned Petro-Canada is planning to buy as much as $300 million of oil from Petroleos Mexicanos through a syndicated financing facility, banking sources said. Arranged by the Royal Bank of Canada, the nine-month facility would allow Pemex to receive the full amount of the contract immediately, with banks later collecting the money from Petro-Canada.

headline: ANY ROLE FOR P.L.O. WITHIN LEBANON BARRED BY ISRAEL
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet decided today to reject any peace proposal that would leave the Palestine Liberation Organization with a political or organizational presence in Lebanon.   In a communique issued after discussions of the continuing political negotiations in Beirut, the Cabinet declared: ''The Government of Israel categorically rejects any proposal for any sort of presence - political, organizational or 'token' military - of the terrorists in Lebanon. All of them, without exception, must leave Lebanon.''   The statement did not represent a change in Israel's position, but was apparently a response to reports here that the P.L.O. had offered to withdraw some of its fighters if it were permitted to retain a political office and a unit in the Lebanese army. It was not possible to confirm these reports.

headline: Economic Scene; Fiscal Policy: Oh, So Simple
abstract: HOW would you go about explaining fiscal policy to the students in Economics 1 on the basis of these recent developments: - President Reagan rides shotgun atop a red stagecoach around an arena in Billings, Mont., urges the roaring crowd to support a bill to raise taxes by $99 billion and says that if he could have corrected the nation's economic problems during his first year in office, he would go back to show business as a magician, adding: ''You know, it might be more fun pulling rabbits out of hats than jackasses out of the way in Washington.''   - Lyn Nofziger, a former assistant to the President, joins Representative Jack Kemp of New York to fight the $99 billion tax increase, then rejoins Mr. Reagan to lead the fight for it, saying his earlier opposition was ''pure stupidity.''   - Mr. Nofziger calls Representative Kemp ''a little fanatical,'' several White House aides denounce him, Larry Speakes calls him ''a good man,'' President Reagan calls him to the White House, the former Buffalo Bills quarterback leaves by the back door to evade reporters and photographers, and President Reagan, when asked by reporters whether he thought Mr. Kemp's opposition to the tax bill stemmed from Presidential aspirations, says, ''I didn't know the job was up for grabs.''

headline: Measuring the Size of the Tax Bill
abstract: There is little disagreement that the $98.3 billion tax bill is immense.  But is it the biggest ever? It has frequently been called that in recent weeks, but Administration officials reject the title.

headline: ISRAELIS KEEP REMINDING BEIRUT THAT SIEGE IS ON
abstract: At leisurely intervals, the Israeli shells lofted down from the hills here above Beirut's airport and crashed into the battered apartment buildings below.   In a courtyard of St. Anthony's School, where the Israelis have established a command center, three soldiers played volleyball. As groups of soldiers and journalists watched the shelling, a radio played an old Beatles' song, ''Eight Days a Week.''   In the latest phase of the campaign against the Palestinians holed up in the western side of the capital, it was what military people call a day of ''softening up.'' For the record, the Israeli military spokesman, Barry Swersky, said the shelling was in retaliation for a bazooka attack on an Israeli position Saturday afternoon.

headline: Randolph Consultants Is to Be Reactivated
abstract: Charles C. Randolph Jr. has decided to reactivate Randolph Consultants, which had once worked for both Dow Jones and Hachette, the French publisher.

headline: Turkey Says It Will Stop Terrorism by Armenians
abstract: The military Government vowed today to take action abroad to stop Armenian terrorists from staging attacks such as the slaying nine days ago of Col. Attila Altikat, Turkey's military attache in Canada.   Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen did not say how Turkey would intervene outside its borders to combat Armenian terrorists, who have killed 23 Turkish officials abroad and seven inside the country since 1973.

headline: JERSEYAN SURVIVES AIR CRASH
abstract: A New Jersey pilot escaped injury after bailing out moments before his Air Force OV-10 Bronco airplane crash-landed on th runway after a training flight, a spokesman said here today. First Lieut. Paul C. Westerfield, 27 years old, from Chatam, N.J., was the only person aboard the plane, the spokesman said.

headline: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSOLIDATED REFINING CO INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Watching Small Issues
abstract: WHEN the stock market began kicking up its heels last month, famous blue-chip companies with large capitalizations won new favor with pension funds and other institutional investors. These stocks range from Merck and General Electric to Eastman Kodak and International Business Machines - all giants in their respective fields and all, incidentally, components in the Dow Jones industrial average.   ''These big caps,'' one broker points out, ''can easily absorb large amounts of cash.'' The rationale here is that pension funds and other institutions can snap up blocks of, say, 50,000 shares without disturbing prices unduly. And that, incidentally, is a great comfort to institutions (as well as their brokers) when they feel the urge to commit cash to equities.

headline: ALGOMA STEEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Respite for Rates?   These days, the merest scent of good news is considered a good omen in the credit markets.  The source of the current wave of optimism is the Federal Reserve.  Encouraged by three consecutive weekly declines in the nation's basic money supply and worried about signs that the economy sagged again last month, the Fed has been pumping money into the banking system, fueling speculation that the long-awaited decline in interest rates may be at hand.   Analysts do not dispute that the Fed has been more accomodating lately; but some say underlying fundamentals make it unlikely the trend will last long, nor will it have much positive impact on rates. If the Fed adds too much to the money supply, it will renew inflation fears.

headline: Move by Wienerwald Unit
abstract: The West German unit of the Swiss-based Wienerwald restaurant chain said today that it was following its parent company into bankruptcy proceedings.   Wienerwald G.m.b.H. will offer to pay 40 percent of its creditors' claims under a request for protection from creditors submitted to Munich's District Court, a court spokesman said.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Comtex Scientific Corp. said its Electronic Mail Corp. subsidiary had completed a public offering of 800,000 common shares through D.H. Blair & Co.   * El Paso Co. said its El Paso Natural Gas Co. subsidiary have filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of $75 million of cumulative preferred stock for $25 a share through Merrill Lynch, White Weld Capital Markets Group.   * Enserch Crop. said it would offer 1.5 million shares of its adjustable rate cumulative preferred stock series D at $50 each through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: ECONOMY AGGRAVATES BUDGET WOES
abstract: Mayor Koch, his gubernatorial ambitions shattered, is returning full time to the problems of New York City, some of which grew more acute during his unsuccessful five-month campaign for the Democratic nomination. Of particular concern to many officials is a deteriorating economic picture, which has magnified the city's budget woes.   Absent from City Hall often during his race against Lieut. Gov.  Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Koch returns at a time when there are likely to be some changes in his administration. A handful of commissioners are reported to be preparing to leave, some at the Mayor's urging as he reassesses his policies and the performance of city agencies.   Other top officials, including all three of his Deputy Mayors - Nathan Leventhal, Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Karen N. Gerard - said they were not sure how long they would stay in government.

headline: Schmidt Cites AEG Leaders
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today attributed the financial troubles of AEG-Telefunken to years of bad management, but said pay cuts could help revive it.   In a radio interview published by the Government press office, Mr.  Schmidt said the problems of West German industry are exaggerated.  ''The great difficulties of the AEG group, after years of inadequate management by the managing and supervisory boards, naturally contribute a lot to a worsening of the general atmosphere,'' he said.
