headline: Accounts
abstract: * The New Jersey Devils, a new National Hockey League team, to Keyes Martin, Springfield, N.J.   * GAF Broadcasting Company to Shaw & Todd Inc. for its classical music radio station, WNCN-FM.

headline: Couple Arrested at Vatican
abstract: A man and a woman apparently armed with a knife and a replica of a pistol were arrested in St. Peter's Square today, minutes before Pope John Paul II's weekly general audience.Police sources said the two were stopped as they passed through metal detection equipment set up at entrances to the square.

headline: TEACHERS REJECT ISRAELI DEMAND
abstract: Twenty-eight foreign professors at a Palestinian university in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, including some Americans, refused an Israeli demand today that they sign a statement promising not to support Palestinian guerrilla groups.   The professors at al-Najah University in Nablus told reporters they were defying a new Israeli regulation to sign the statements as part of their work permit applications.

headline: R.J. REYNOLDS WINS HEUBLEIN
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette producer, and Heublein Inc., owner of Kentucky Fried Chicken and the nation's top producer of vodka and mixed cocktails, have agreed to a merger valued at $1.3 billion in which Reynolds will acquire Heublein for cash and securities.   For Reynolds, the acquisition represents a doubling of its already sizable foods and beverages business. The company, which acquired the Del Monte Corporation in 1979, has recently expressed interest in increasing its involvement in consumer goods, especially in dominant brands. Concern Over General Cinema   The merger agreement apparently releases Heublein from concern over an unfriendly takeover attempt by the General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest movie theater chain and independent soft-drink bottler. General Cinema acquired 18.9 percent of Heublein stock earlier this year.

headline: Washington Watch; Possible Gain For Citicorp
abstract: WASHINGTON CITICORP'S costly bid to acquire a California savings and loan association is beginning to look more and more like a bargain, some industry analysts say.   The Federal Home Loan Bank Board's approval last week of Citicorp's proposal to acquire the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco was welcomed by analysts of bank stocks, who saw it as a significant crack in the barriers limiting interstate banking. Still, the cost to Citicorp - $143 million higher than any other bid - seemed to some analysts a bit too dear, even for a chance to break into the lucrative California retail market. Citicorp initially is paying $80 million, and it will assume certain other costs in a complicated transaction.

headline: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: Trade Law Commission Working Group on New International Eco- nomic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

headline: P.L.O. OFFICIAL REPORTS SHIFT ON ISRAEL
abstract: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that he could state officially that the P.L.O. was prepared to recognize Israel ''on a reciprocal basis.''   Accordingly, the official, Issam Sartawi, who is an adviser to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O.'s leader, called on the United States Government to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization and to deal with it directly.   (Mr. Arafat said Tuesday in a televised interview with CBS News in west Beirut that direct talks with the United States held ''one of the main keys to the resolution of the crisis.'' On the indirect negotiations with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, Mr.  Arafat said: ''To negotiate with five or six channels, that method would not be accurate.''

headline: Telefunken Aid Cleared
abstract: The way has been cleared for granting AEG-Telefunken, the electrical goods maker, the export guarantees that it needs to solve a cash crisis, the West German Economics Ministry said. In a statement Friday, the ministry said that all remaining questions had been settled with consortium banks for guarantees of up to $248 million, giving the company time to carry out its longer-term recovery plans.

headline: ARMS POLICIES QUESTIONED WITHIN SOVIET
abstract: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that questions had been raised within the Soviet Union about its decision to renounce the first use of nuclear weapons.   Writing in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, he conceded that the decision, announced June 15 in the United Nations, had been taken despite the United States' plans for an arms buildup and its crusade against the Soviet bloc through propaganda and economic sanctions.   ''In their totality, the actions of the United States are aimed at creating prerequisites for a struggle to destroy socialism as a socio-political system,'' Marshal Ustinov said in an unusually long statement on nuclear doctrine that took up a full page in Pravda.   The article, which was keyed to the conclusion of the United Nations' special session on disarmament in New York, listed various proposed and existing American weapons systems, from neutron bombs to the MX intercontinental missile and the B-1 bomber.

headline: WASHINGTON HAILS LEBANON OUTCOME
abstract: Administration officials said today that they regarded the election of Bashir Gemayel as Lebanon's new President as a positive development because it could hasten the pullout of Syrian and Israeli soldiers from Lebanon.   Although the election by Lebanon's Parliament of the military leader of the Maronite Christians was strongly opposed by leftists and many Moslems in Lebanon, the view in Washington was that Mr.  Gemayel can be expected to give priority to asking the Syrians to leave the Bekaa Valley.   Mr. Gemayel's close ties with Israel - his election was warmly welcomed by Prime Minister Menachem Begin today - should also make it easier to bring about the withdrawal of the Israelis, officials said.    President Reagan, vacationing in California, sent a congratulatory message to Mr. Gemayel within hours of his election. The White House said the United States would ''work closely with the new Government in the complex and difficult task ahead.''

headline: U.S. SEIZES COMPUTERS IN GERMANY
abstract: In a continuing effort to block the illegal export of strategic high-technology equipment to Communist countries, the United States Commissioner of Customs said he has seized $400,000 worth of American-made computers in West Germany that were believed to be en route to the Soviet Union.   But the head of the Toronto company that purchased and exported the equipment denied in a telephone interview today that the computers were destined for the Soviet Union or that they were strategically important.   ''That's incorrect,'' Glen Langdon, the president of MLPI Business Systems Inc. of Canada, said of the computers' alleged destination.  Mr. Langdon also said that the computers have ''been on the market since 1975'' and were ''as significant strategically as sending over a Dodge Dart.''

headline: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Begin and Sharon Get; Less Backing in; Poll
abstract: An opinion poll disclosed today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon still appear to have the backing of the Israeli public, although their popularity has declined markedly in the aftermath of the mass slaying of Palestinian civilians in Beirut by Lebanese militiamen.   The poll, conducted last Wednesday and Thursday by the Dahaf Research Institute for the Hebrew monthly publication Monitim, showed Mr. Begin was favored by 50 percent as ''most suited for Prime Minister.''

headline: Chem-Nuclear
abstract: Waste Management Inc., which last week began a hostile takeover bid for Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc., said a Federal judge in South Carolina had issued a temporary order Friday to restrain Chem-Nuclear from issuing any stock that might block Waste Management's bid.  Chem-Nuclear, which disposes of chemical and low-level nuclear waste, has one million preferred voting shares held in reserve; if issued, the shares would increase the number of voting shares outstanding by more than 13 percent. Waste Management is involved in the disposal of solid waste.

headline: Macy's Net Rises 44.1% In Quarter
abstract: R.H. Macy & Company Inc., which operates 92 department stores in 13 states, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter ended July 31 increased by 44.1 percent, to a record $32.9 million, or $1 a share, from $22.8 million, or 69 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 13.8 percent, to $692.4 million, from $608.3 million.   Mortimer B. Leavitt, a Macy's vice president, said that in the latest quarter and year gross margins held up and the company was able to offset increases in interest expense with gains in productivity. Comparable store sales, or sales by those stores in operation at least a year, increased 9.8 percent in the quarter and 7.7 percent in the year.'' He added that inventories were 15 percent higher than a year ago.

headline: UNITS FROM FRANCE AND ITALY ARRIVE IN 2 BEIRUT CAMPS
abstract: French and Italian soldiers today entered the two Palestinian refugee camps where hundreds of Palestinians were killed by Lebanese Christian militiamen more than a week ago.   The soldiers, members of a multin@ational force that is to include United States marines, took up security duties in the Shatila and Sabra camps this morning on the southern outskirts of West Beirut.   They did so a day after Israeli troops virtually completed their withdrawal from West Beirut. Small Israeli units remained behind the walls of the port and at the international airport in the suburbs south of the city.

headline: Patents; High-Pressure Water Used to Destroy Wastes
abstract: Michael Modell, president of Modar Inc., Natick, Mass., was granted a patent this week on processes for destruction of hazardous organic wastes, such as PCB's, and the production of energy.

headline: Icahn Offer to Buy Rest of Bayswater
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, a New York financier, said the Icahn Acquisition Corporation, which he owns, would offer today to pay $13 for each of the common shares of the Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation that it does not already own.   As of July 27, Mr. Icahn owned about 67.1 percent of Bayswater Realty's 1,043,000 common shares outstanding.

headline: Bolivian General Strike Protests Military Rule
abstract: A nationwide general strike began early today despite a threat by the military Government to dismiss every worker who participates.

headline: U.S. STEEL EARNINGS FALL 97.4%
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, citing the ''severe impact'' of the recession on its steel operations, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plummeted 97.4 percent, to $4.3 million.   The nation's biggest steel producer said that results for the quarter were buoyed by the operations of the Marathon Oil Company, which U.S. Steel acquired last March for about $6.6 billion. Gains by the Marathon unit more than offset the significant losses from its steel operations, said David M. Roderick, the company's chairman.   U.S. Steel said that net income in the latest three months equaled 5 cents a share. In the second quarter of 1981, the Pittsburgh-based concern reported earnings of $167.6 million, or $1.89 a share. Sales for the latest three months advanced 34.6 percent, to $5.1 billion from $3.79 billion.

headline: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCOTT LAD FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARTILLERY FIRE THUNDERS IN HILLS SOUTH OF BEIRUT
abstract: On the outskirts of this hilly town south of Beirut, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian guerrillas have been exchanging artillery and small arms fire since Sunday.   Israeli tanks and armored personnel carriers were entrenched around the Lebanese University's Science Faculty Building, which runs almost parallel to Beirut International Airport abutting the Mediterranean Sea in the west.   Not 300 yards away, the Palestinians fired relentlessly. The Israelis said the guerrillas had entered the area during the night prompting the latest break in the cease-fire.

headline: Times Co. Awards Contract to Xerox
abstract: The New York Times Company and the Xerox Corporation said that, under a contract awarded by the Times Company, Xerox would develop an experimental electronic editing and layout system for The New York Times.   The system, Xerox's first for newspaper layout design, will apply Xerox technologies now in use in the office information processing field.   The system will provide for text editing and layout adjustment before typesetting, the companies said, and a prototype will be installed for testing starting in the fourth quarter of 1982.

headline: THE FRENCH ROTOR MAKER THAT DEFIED REAGAN
abstract: ATLANTIQUE, the diversified French engineering group that builds everything from pasta factories to the world's fastest train, is at the center of efforts to frustrate President Reagan's attempt to halt construction of a new Soviet pipeline.   In defiance of an American ban, the French Government has ordered Alsthom-Atlantique to supply the huge rotors, which it makes under license from General Electric, for turbine-powered compressor plants that will send Siberian natural gas through a 3,700-mile pipeline into Western European factories and homes. Without these large compressors, the project as originally planned would be doomed.   The spoiler role is one that Alsthom-Atlantique, the only European company with the technology to build the rotors, would rather not play.   ''Of course we have to do what the Government decides, but we don't want a row with the Americans,'' said Roger Chalvon-Demersay, a senior Alsthom-Atlantique executive, stressing that the company has worked closely with General Electric since the end of World War II.  And there were rumors in Paris that the company had fought behind the scenes to delay the French Government's order while European governments continued diplomatic efforts to bring about a White House change of heart.

headline: U.S. PRESSING SALVADOR FOR CHANGES
abstract: State Department officials, voicing uneasiness over human rights and the pace of land redistribution in El Salvador, said today that the Reagan Administration had stepped up pressure on the Salvadoran Government for social and economic changes.   A ranking department official said that ''plenty of pressure'' was being applied to elected Salvadoran officials by American diplomats.  The diplomats, he said, had pointed out that Congress had grown resistant, if not hostile, to military aid for El Salvador unless the nation moves ahead on its land redistribution program, human rights efforts and the investigation into the murders in 1980 and 1981 of six Americans, including four churchwomen.   Administration efforts have taken on a new urgency because the 1982 foreign aid authorization for El Salvador largely conditions American military and economic aid there on President Reagan's certifying to Congress that the nation is making progress on economic and political changes.  The certification, stipulated by Congress, must reach the House and Senate by July 28.

headline: PRESIDENT MAKES BIPARTISAN APPEAL FOR TAX PROGRAM
abstract: President Reagan appealed tonight to Republicans as well as Democrats to put aside partisan misgivings and support a $98.3 billion tax increase he described as ''not perfect in the eyes of any one of us'' but essential to economic recovery.   In an unusual television speech marking a significant change of theme for his Transcript of address is on page D16. Administration, Mr. Reagan acknowledged that the bill was ''not politically popular'' and that he himself had in the past opposed increasing taxes as a way of reducing the Federal deficit.   ''Why, then, do I support it?'' Mr. Reagan asked. ''I support it because it's right for America. I support it because it's fair. I support it because it will, when combined with our cuts in Government spending, reduce interest rates and put more Americans back to work again.''

headline: ISRAELI CENSORS CRACK DOWN ON THE ARAB PRESS
abstract: Israeli security officials have closed down a Palestinian press service here at a time of heavy Israeli censorship of the Arab press.   Since Israel's invasion of Lebanon, Arab editors have complained that Israeli censorship has virtually forced them to fill their papers by translating Hebrew reports and commentaries from the Israeli press.   In recent weeks, however, the Arab press has been barred from publishing many of these features even though they have already appeared in Israeli papers, according to the Arab editors.

headline: MARIETTA DRAWS 75% OF BENDIX
abstract: The takeover struggle pitting the Bendix Corporation against the Martin Marietta Corporation and the United Technologies Corporation intensified yesterday when Martin Marietta announced that about 75 percent of Bendix's outstanding stock had been tendered by the Thursday midnight deadline.   Bendix had announced earlier this week that 58 percent of Marietta's shares had been received in response to its $48-a-share bid, which was announced on Aug. 25 and prompted Marietta to go after Bendix in defense, with a $75-a-share bid.   A source close to the struggle said of the Bendix and Marietta tenders, ''It's now crystal clear that each company will have more than 50 percent of the shares of the other That brings us back to the question: Will each pull the trigger?'' Tangle of Laws   The resolution depends on the respective withdrawal deadlines for the bids, he added, as well as the tangle of state and Federal laws in which the quarrel is rapidly becoming ensnarled. Barring legal obstacles, Bendix will be free to purchase Marietta shares next Friday, while Marietta must wait until Sept. 23 to buy the Bendix stock tendered.

headline: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: China Calls Hanoi Move On Cambodia a Trick
abstract: The Chinese Foreign Ministry, responding to Vietnam's announcement that it would withdraw a ''significant'' number of troops from Cambodia, said tonight that if Vietnam was really sincere in wanting to resolve the Cambodian question it should withdraw all of its troops and comply with United Nations resolutions.   The Foreign Ministry said Hanoi's announcement Wednesday was a trick to mislead public opinion just as a new Cambodian united front had been formed against Hanoi.

headline: Bendix Shares Jump by $2.625
abstract: The Bendix Corporation's shares jumped $2.625, to $58.50, on the New York Stock Exchange as sentiment spread that the Martin Marietta Corporation might take in a partner in its $1.5 billion takeover bid for Bendix.   Bendix offered last week to pay $43 a share for 45 percent of Marietta, prompting Marietta five days later to offer $75 a share for 50.3 percent of Bendix.

headline: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HELIX TECHNOLOGY REGAINS
abstract: ''Every company should go through what we went through. It teaches you to manage cash.'' Thus does Frank Gabron, president and chairman of the Helix Technology Corporation, reflect on his company's recent ordeal.  Helix, a leading maker of cryogenic, or ultralow-temperature, equipment for the military and for the semiconductor industry, had a loss of $2.9 million in 1979, followed by a $5.8 million loss in 1980.   The company's troubles began when it decided to diversify into nuclear power just before that industry stumbled to a virtual halt.  In late 1980 and early 1981, Mr. Gabron recalls, Helix was existing ''day to day'' and came very close to filing for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: Seychelles Backs Effort To Recover Diego Garcia
abstract: The Seychelles has thrown its support behind Mauritius' campaign for the return of Diego Garcia atoll, which Britain leases to the United States as a military base.

headline: Italian Output Climbs
abstract: Italian industrial output, seasonally adjusted, rose 3 percent in July after declining 4.2 percent in June, Istat, the national statistics institute, said. The June output reflected the impact of a one-day general strike that month.

headline: ARGENTINES ARE SEEKING WAYS TO OVERCOME SERIES OF LOSSES
abstract: One month after its forces surrendered in Stanley, Argentina is a changed nation searching for a new direction.  The defeat in the Falklands combined with an economic recession, three-digit inflation, the imposition of Government control over a free-market economy, political confusion, international isolation and even the loss in the World Cup last week have left many Argentines demoralized about their past and questioning the future. A mood of uncertainty hangs over the country.   ''I feel dizzy,'' a businessman said. ''All the traumatic shocks came together at once.'' Gone are the signs of nationalistic euphoria that existed during the war -the rousing television advertisements, the billboards declaring ''Las Malvinas son Argentinas,'' using the Argentine name for the Falklands.

headline: U.S. Reassures Jordan
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reaffirmed United States support for Jordan today in a message to King Hussein marking the 30th year of his reign. Mr. Shultz also told the King that the United States ''will not rest until we have achieved a just and comprehensive peace in your troubled area.''

headline: Rohm & Haas Sale
abstract: The Rohm & Haas Company said it agreed in principle to sell its Consolidated Biomedical Laboratories Inc. subsidiary to Hoffmann-La Roche A.G. for undisclosed terms. The company said the sale was expected to be completed in September or October.

headline: FILMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hobbies Corp.  In Chapter 11
abstract: The General Hobbies Corporation of Philadelphia has announced that it, and its subsidiary, Associated Hobby Manufacturers Inc., have filed petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Limiting American cruise missiles may now have become the main Soviet goal in the strategic arms reduction talks in Geneva. At the same time, the Soviet Union seems to be laying the groundwork for deploying large numbers of its own cruise missiles.   This is the judgment of Administration officials involved in the two sets of Soviet-American talks in Geneva on limiting strategic or intercontinental nuclear weapons and on reducing medium-range missiles deployed in Europe. This view seems to be supported by statements made in an interview in Moscow by Maj. Gen. Viktor Starodubov, a member of the negotiating team in the strategic arms talks.

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUG. 4, 1982; The Economy
abstract: David A. Stockman said there must be big new spending cuts in social programs next year if there is to be a long-term economic recovery. The budget director told a Senate panel that spending will have to be reduced ''in a major way'' to bring deficits down and that the only way to do so is to cut entitlement programs. He did not mention Social Security, but it is the largest such program. (Page A1.)   A Senate-House conference committee began work on a Senate tax bill aimed at raising $98 billion in tax revenues over the next three years. Both parties indicated that a heavy campaign by President Reagan may be necessary if the bill is to become law. A key problem facing the panel is how to fashion a compromise bill that will pass the House, where many Representatives oppose any tax increases in this election year. (D1.)

headline: Blue Circle Investment
abstract: Blue Circle Industries said today it planned to spend the equivalent of more than $25.7 million in the next two years on a continuing program to improve works and depots.  It said the improvements are part of a $171.5 million, five-year investment plan to strengthen cement making and distribution operations in Britain.

headline: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST JUMPS TO RECORD LEVEL
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest jumped 25 percent, or 24.1 million shares, in the month ended Sept.  15, to a record 120.5 million shares.   The previous high was set last May 14 when the short interest totaled 103.6 million shares.  On Sept. 15 of last year short interest totaled 66 million shares.  In the latest period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange rose 1 million shares, to 8.5 million.  A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.   The following Big Board companies show large changes:   (pls pickup agate 1st add, etc.)

headline: ARMS CONTROL TALKS PENDING
abstract: There are several arms control negotiations pending. Following is a list of those talks.  Strategic Arms Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing limitation of long-range nuclear delivery systems.

headline: Pager Dumping Inquiry
abstract: The Commerce Department said today that it was investigating charges by the Motorola Corporation that Japanese companies are dumping electronic pagers in the United States market at less than fair value.

headline: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Film Company Names Begelman as President
abstract: David Begelman, who lost his job last month as chairman of the United Artists production division of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, has been named president of a small, independent motion picture production company, Sherwood Productions.   Alan E. Salke, Sherwood's chairman and chief executive officer, announced Mr. Begelman's appointment in a brief statement and did not respond to a reporter's request for elaboration.

headline: U.S. GENERAL ACCLAIMS ISRAELIS
abstract: A retired United States general says he believes that the Israeli Army was at ''its professional best'' in Lebanon and that it tried hard to be ''discriminating and careful'' in civilian areas.   Lieut. Gen. Harry W.O. Kinnard was one of six retired American generals who visited Lebanese battlefields and Israel last month on a visit organized by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.  General Kinnard, who organized and was the first commander in Vietnam of the First Cavalry Division, gave his impressions in an interview here last week.

headline: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Commodore Rises 96.4%
abstract: Commodore International Ltd., an integrated manufacturer of advanced microcomputer systems, reported that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 increased 96.4 percent, to $16.3 million, or $1.06 a share, from $8.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the same period last year.

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOLAR POWER RACE AT JERSEY CONCERN
abstract: The company's office doesn't look like much, just a onestory brick structure with a series of hastily built extensions tumbling out the back. Inside, Zoltan J. Kiss, a one-time professional soccer player whose preceding business venture ended in a bankruptcy filing, munches on a sandwich at his desk while explaining how his six-year-old company lost about $1 a share in the past year.   Despite its losses, Mr. Kiss and his company are driven by the conviction that their field of sun-powered electricity is now capable of broad commercial use, although it is generally thought that such applications are decades away. And Mr. Kiss is also convinced that his Chronar Corporation may beat even the mighty Japanese to the punch. Mr. Kiss is president of Chronar, which has 45 employees.

headline: No Headline
abstract: FRENCH REGRETFUL AT BEGIN REMARKS   PARIS, Aug. 11 (AP) - Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that his Government regretted Prime Minister Menachem Begin's suggestion that the President of France had helped create an atmosphere that encouraged terrorist attacks against Jews.   Mr. Begin, in a statement Tuesday in Jerusalem, alluded to President Francois Mitterrand when he said that a terrorist attack in a Jewish neighborhood in which six people were killed had resulted from ''horrendous talk about Oradour.'' He was apparently speaking about a statement attributed to Mr. Mitterrand in early July that compared the Israeli assaults on Beirut to a Nazi wartime massacre of 600 French civilians in Oradour-sur-Glane.   Mr. Cheysson said that Mr. Begin's remarks had been made ''under the shock of emotion.'' Mr. Cheysson's comment came as Jews here held a rally tonight near Notre Dame Cathedral to protest anti-Semitic terrorism. They also held a memorial service at a heavily guarded synagogue for victims of the attack Monday, which occurred at a Jewish restaurant on a corner of the Rue des Rosiers.

headline: CHAIRMAN APPOINTED AT COMMUTER AIRCRAFT
abstract: David Tod, 56, a former partner at the Prescott, Ball & Turben brokerage firm, has been named chairman of the Commuter Aircraft Corporation, a company in Youngstown, Ohio, that plans to manufacture the CAC-100, a 50-seat, four-engine airliner for commuter airlines.  He was already a director and an investor in the company.   Mr. Tod, a native of Ohio and a 1949 graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is also chairman of the McDonald Steel Corporation and president and chairman of Torent Inc., a Youngstown venture-capital concern. As chairman of Commuter Aircraft, he succeeds Lynn Bollinger, 68, who chose not to stand for re-election when his term ended last week.

headline: U.S. SAYS 1,200 MARINES MAY JOIN BEIRUT FORCE
abstract: The number of United States Marines expected to land in Beirut this week could reach 1,200, a State Department spokesman said today.   A Pentagon official said, however, that the number would depend on final boundaries of an area of responsibility to be assigned to the Marines by a three-nation committee still deliberating in Beirut.   The Pentagon official said the Marines would be given more freedom of action in protecting human life and public order than they were permitted in August when 800 Marines were stationed in the Beirut port area to help oversee the withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization forces.   The Pentagon official said that the Marines would not only be able to defend themselves against possible hostile fire but would be authorized by the rules of engagement to keep ''organized forces'' such as the Lebanese Christian Phalangist units that massacred Palestinian and Lebanese civilians in West Beirut refugee camps from ''coming back through the lines.''

headline: U.S. Counts On Savings Bond Move; Rate Rise Seen As Aid on Debt
abstract: The Treasury, faced with the prospect of huge budget deficits, is counting on a reversal of the current big cash drain from United States savings bonds to help solve its financing problems.   Savings bonds have long paid a much lower rate of interest than marketable Government securities and other top-quality investments but it now appears they may once again become attractive to buyers.   The Senate Finance Committee approved late last week a Treasury proposal to raise the yield on savings bonds, now a maximum of 9 percent over eight years, to 85 percent of the rate paid on five-year Treasury notes. If this formula were to be put into effect now, the savings bond rate would jump to 11.8 percent.

headline: Israeli Airport Strike Is Called To Support El Al Employees
abstract: Israel's general federation of labor decided today to shut down Ben-Gurion Airport next Saturday until darkness in solidarity with employees of El Al Israel Airlines who say they face losses of income and jobs because of the Government's decision to ground the national airline on the Sabbath.   The strike was called by a special committee formed by the union's central committee.

headline: COMMODITY WATCHDOG CRITICIZED
abstract: After an eight-month investigation, a Senate subcommittee today issued a report saying that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is unable to protect the public from the ''recent tide'' of commodity fraud that has cost investors more than $1 billion in the last five years.   The report, by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, called for increased prosecution of commodity fraud by the states, a continued ban on commodity options and more tools for the commission to fight fraud.   The seven-year-old C.F.T.C. has come under severe and persistent criticism from several Congressional committees as well as some industry participants and faces possible extinction - or merger with the Securities and Exchange Commission - when its Congressional mandate expires on Sept.30.

headline: LURE OF U.S. INVESTMENTS
abstract: Foreign investment in United States securities and other financial instruments rose sharply during the first five months of 1982, even though short-and long-term interest rates were generally lower during that period than in the last six months of 1981. The rise is a major reason why the dollar defied expectations of many analysts and stayed at near-record levels.   In the September issue of World Financial Markets, international economists at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company calculate that between January and May of this year $25.6 billion worth of foreign capital was deposited in various United States financial instruments, a 54.2 percent rise from the total during the last half of 1981. At the same time, deposits in West Germany and Japan, two countries whose currencies have dropped sharply in relation to the dollar, registered large net outflows.

headline: Dole to Offer Sweeping Income Tax Revision
abstract: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, announced today that he would prepare a proposal for a far-reaching revision of the Federal income tax that would lower individuals' tax rates across-the-board and simplify taxes by eliminating most deductions and tax credits.   The Kansas Republican, going beyond earlier statements, also raised the possibility that he would propose a similar revision of the corporate income tax.

headline: HEALTH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Empire Oil Petition
abstract: The Empire Oil and Gas Company has announced that it has filed a Chapter 11 petition for protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: PEAT, MARWICK SETTLES IN N.S.M. HOLDERS SUIT
abstract: Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. has agreed to pay nearly $6.4 million to the former shareholders of the National Student Marketing Corporation, settling the last major portion of a 12-year-old class action against the former marketing company and its auditors and legal counsel. The company's high-flying stock collapsed amid disclosures of securities fraud in 1970.   The lawsuit, on behalf of all those who owned N.S.M. stock between April 1968 and February 1972, was scheduled for trial in Federal District Court in Washington, D.C. this fall. All the major defendants have now settled out of court, however, so the action is unlikely to be tried.

headline: SEYCHELLES REBELLION IS REPORTED QUELLED
abstract: Before news emerged that their rebellion had been crushed, army mutineers in the Seychelles were reported today to have appealed for assistance to some disparate and unlikely sources - South Africa for one and the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, for another.   The appeals, made by telephone to journalists in Britain and South Africa, illustrated the desperation of the rebellious soldiers who on Tuesday occupied the Government radio station in the scattered, Indian Ocean islands, complaining to reporters who got in touch with them that they had been ''treated like pigs'' by their officers.   Only 17 days ago, air force men from the same low ranks as the Seychelles mutineers staged an abortive coup in Kenya, and the coincidence of the two uprisings will probably cause other African leaders to look with unease at the nether ranks of their armed forces.   The Seychelles, a group of 92 coral islands 1,300 miles off the African coast, is a former British colony that achieved independence in 1976. Its population of 66,000 is predominantly Creole.

headline: OREGON PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Talks On Asset Sale
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which is heavily in debt, may soon negotiate the sale of assets valued at $1 billion (Canadian) or more.   Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., nearly one-half owned by Dome and its affiliate, Dome Canada Ltd., is evaluating Dome's United States properties, John Beddome, senior vice president of Transcanada, said today.

headline: ENDS AT 824.87
abstract: The stock market continued to rally in heavy trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 10.75 points, to close at 824.87. Energy issues, however, dropped sharply, reflecting investors' concern about lower oil prices.   Analysts attributed the strong market at least in part to the Federal Reserve Board's announcement after the close of trading Friday that the nation's basic money supply had fallen $3.7 billion.  The decline gave investors some hope that the Fed would ease its monetary policy and let interest rates drop, now that the money supply is well within the Federal Reserve's growth targets for 1982.

headline: Cadillac Fairview
abstract: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it had agreed to sell 10,931 apartment units for $270 million (Canadian) to the Greymac Credit Corporation. It said the sale is expected to close by Nov. 16, and that once the sale is completed, it will have disposed of the bulk of its apartment portfolio.

headline: ANALYSTS SEE MARKET'S CLIMB CONTINUING
abstract: Wall Street analysts interviewed yesterday were generally optimistic that the stock market would continue to climb, helped by companies that sell essentials, such as drugs, or can profit from lower interest rates, like the auto makers.   Other favorites include selected cyclical stocks, such as those of broadcasting and publishing companies, that stand to shine with any improvement in consumer spending, and industries, like food processing, that can benefit if commodity prices stay depressed.   Energy issues, however, were at the bottom of almost every analyst's list because of the oil glut and the new prospect of stable prices for Mexican oil.   The bullish views were expressed despite some predictions that the decline in interest rates signaled continued weakness in the economy, not recovery. It was last week's long-awaited drop in interest rates that sparked the market rally, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing by 81.24 points in the week. It jumped another 21.88 points, to 891.17, yesterday.

headline: All of Panama's Dailies Return, With Censorship
abstract: The last three of Panama's eight newspapers ordered closed when President Aristides Royo resigned July 30 began publishing today, censored by Government ''moralizers.''

headline: HOW TO HELP AID THE VICTIMS OF THE FIGHTING IN LEBANON
abstract: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon.  Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects   According to Leon Marion, a spokesman for the American Council of Voluntary Agencies for Foreign Services, an umbrella group, all of the organizations now have people working in Lebanon. Mr. Marion suggested that since the agencies have projects throughout the world, donors wishing to do so can specify that their contributions go to the Lebanon programs.

headline: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN SENDS ADVISER ON A MISSION TO MEXICO
abstract: President Reagan today sent William P.  Clark, the national security adviser, to Mexico City to attend Independence Day festivities, confer with Mexican leaders and raise the possibility of a meeting soon between Mr. Reagan and Mexico's President-elect.   In his first diplomatic mission since becoming national security adviser earlier this year, Mr. Clark met this afternoon with President Jose Lopez Portillo and President-elect Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, who takes office Dec. 1.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * DuPont Co.'s offering of $150 million of three-year notes was assigned a 12 1/8 percent coupon and priced at par through the First Boston Corp.   * Detroit Edison Co. filed a registration statement covering the offering of 6 million shares of common through Morgan Stanley & Co.

headline: PROSPECTS FOR SOVIET GRAIN PACT
abstract: The question of renewing this country's grain trade agreement with the Soviet Union is a politically explosive issue that has divided the Administration and increased the worries of American farmers. It is a matter likely to be raised Monday when Agriculture Secretary John R. Block meets with President Reagan to discuss the depressed farm economy.   The current bilateral pact, already extended from last year, expires Sept. 30. It obligates the Soviet Union to buy a minimum of six million metric tons of wheat and corn from the United States annually. It also provides that the Russians may buy up to eight million tons without consultation and then may buy as much more as the United States agrees is available to them.

headline: BRAZIL MOURNS ITS FALLEN SOCCER TEAM
abstract: Flags have been flown at half-staff throughout Brazil for the last two days, and though the act honors President Antonio Guzman of the Dominican Republic, who died Sunday, it could easily be taken as an emblem of the national spirit here.   On Monday, the last day the Brazilian standard fluttered from the top of the staff, the Brazilian soccer team fell to unexpected defeat by Italy in World Cup play in Spain.   The nation promptly went into a state of mourning.  In the city of Fortaleza, 20-year-old Nilton Teixeira watched the Italians make the deciding goal, put a revolver to his temples and shot himself dead. A young student in Brasilia slit her wrists but survived. Around the country hospitals reported a rash of coronary cases linked to the game.

headline: ECONOMY EXPANDS AT 1.7% RATE
abstract: The nation's gross national product rose in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.7 percent after adjustment for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today, the first upturn in this key indicator since last summer.   The increase surprised many economists, leaving them divided over whether the recession was over and what the outlook might be for a recovery.   Some economists who had expected a small improvement in the G.N.P, which measures the total value of the nation's goods and services, were surprised that the increase was much larger. Others, who recently predicted a decline, contended that the recession was not over, despite the increase for the April-to-June quarter.

headline: FRANCE AND EGYPT OFFER PLAN AT U.N. FOR DISARMED P.L.O.
abstract: France and Egypt have joined forces to seek a Security Council resolution designed to help preserve the Palestine Liberation Organization as a largely disarmed political force in the Middle East.   Envoys from the two nations circulated a draft document today that the 15 Council members began studying.  According to those familiar with it, the first section resembles a French proposal that was vetoed by the United States last Saturday.  This portion of the draft calls for Israeli forces to pull back from Beirut as a first step toward a withdrawal from Lebanon. It directs lightly armed P.L.O. guerrillas to move into camps somewhere outside the Lebanese capital. The P.L.O. would give up its heavy weapons but apparently remain in Lebanon.

headline: Congress Budget Office Losing Chief
abstract: Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office since it was established in 1975, will return to the the Brookings Institution next year to head its economic studies program, Brookings announced today.   Mrs. Rivlin, who previously served two stints at the research center, will replace Joseph Pechman, who has directed economic studies for the past 20 years.   No successor for Mrs. Rivlin at the Budget Office has been named, but a leading candidate is believed to be Rudolph G. Penner, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.

headline: Hilton Casino Plan
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said it expects to begin construction of a $225 million, 634-room hotel and casino in Atlantic City by early next year. The company said the project was suspended in January 1981 because of high interest rates.

headline: HIGH PALESTINIAN OFFICER SURRENDERS TO THE ISRAELIS
abstract: A Palestinian guerrilla commander in southern Lebanon surrendered to Israeli forces this week because, he said, he believed the military phase of the Palestine Liberation Organization's struggle for a homeland was over.   The Israeli radio said today that the commander, Assad Suleiman Abdel Khader, whom it described as one of the founders of Al Fatah, the major guerrilla organization, surrendered to Israeli soldiers in the southern Lebanese coastal city of Sidon, site of the P.L.O.'s former headquarters for the area.   The prisoner, who is known in the guerrilla movement as Salah Taamri, was quoted as having said that he was certain Yasir Arafat, head of both the P.L.O. and Al Fatah, would also face reality and conclude that the only way to save the Palestinian people was for the P.L.O. to leave west Beirut and continue the struggle against Israel by peaceful means rather than military force.

headline: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Commodities
abstract: Contrary Energy Futures   THE energy futures market last week again defied followers of fundamental and technical guidelines as it whipsawed traders in both camps. In fact, no other markets have behaved as perversely as those in heating oil and leaded gasoline futures during the last nine months.   For example, between Nov. 1 and March 31, a period that included a record cold wave in January, prices of heating oil futures plunged from $1.03 to 81 cents a gallon. From April 1 to mid-June, prices then shot up to 96 cents before declining to 91.52 cents last Friday, based on the spot August contract.

headline: Consumers Power
abstract: The Consumers Power Company said it had filed a petition with the Federal Economic Regulatory Administration asking it to halt the importing of liquefied natural gas from Algeria by one of its suppliers, the Trunkline Gas Company, a unit of the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company. The petition, similar to one filed by the Michigan Public Service Commission, asked the agency to suspend Trunkline's import license and following public hearings to withdraw permanently the license to bring Algerian liquefied natural gas into the United States.

headline: Bid for Scherer
abstract: The R.P. Scherer Corporation said its board had unanimously decided that the FMC Corporation's $90.2 million tender offer for it was inadequate and not in the company's best interest. It urged shareholders to reject it.

headline: Better Homes Promises To Rerun Certain Ads
abstract: Better Homes & Gardens has an offer that may be hard to refuse.

headline: Qaddafi Urges Suicide For Arafat Guerrillas
abstract: Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has advised the 5,000 Palestinian guerrillas besieged in Beirut by Israeli forces to commit suicide.

headline: Around the World; Zimbabwe's Opposition Is Accused of Gun Attack
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today linked the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, with a gun attack on his official residence last week.   He said at a news conference that Mr. Nkomo's party was responsible for the June 24 raid, in which one of the attackers was reportedly killed.   ''Therefore the inference can be drawn that Nkomo was responsible,'' he said, adding, ''Whether Nkomo had a direct hand in it will be established by police.''

headline: I.C.I. Deal in Spain
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries is adding to its titanium dioxide interests in Spain in a $20 million deal, an I.C.I. spokesman said today. Explosivos Rio Tinto is selling its 55 percent stake in Titanio S.A. to Tioxide Group, the other shareholder. Tioxide Group itself is jointly held by I.C.I. and Lead Industries.

headline: ENERGY ISSUES DECLINE
abstract: The stock market beat a broad retreat yesterday, with selling particularly evident in energy takeover candidates and in companies reporting lower quarterly profits or omitting dividends. Posting its sixth straight decline, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 10.94 points, to 811.83.   Volume expanded to 53.8 million shares from Tuesday's 45.7 million.  The scale of the setback was underscored by the ratio of losers to gainers: 1,252 issues declined on the New York Stock Exchange, while only 272 stocks advanced.

headline: RESTRUCTURING OF ARMOUR SET
abstract: The Greyhound Corporation, operator of the nation's largest bus system, said yesterday that it planned to reorganize its Armour & Company meat-processing and consumer products subsidiary.   Greyhound said that the reorganization, which will be accomplished by converting Armour preferred stock into Greyhound preferred stock and assuming Armour's publicly held debentures, was part of the company's program to reduce expenses and ''reposition Armour for more successful operations.''   Armour will continue to be a wholly owned subsidiary of Greyhound, which holds 100 percent of Armour's voting stock. At present, a small amount of Armour redeemable preferred stock is in public hands, but the owners of those shares have no voting rights.

headline: Venezuela to Seek Loan
abstract: Venezuela plans to ask foreign banks soon for a two- to five-year loan of between $600 million and $800 million, Ignacio Sandoval, director of public finances, said today in an interview.

headline: 75 House Members Seek Ban On Military Aid to El Salvador
abstract: Seventy-five House members co-sponsored a resolution today to suspend military aid to El Salvador and declare President Reagan's report of progress on human rights and land redistribution ''null and void.''

headline: FORMER STABLES NOW CO-OP IN BROOKLYN'S PARK SLOPE
abstract: In its ambiance as a neighborhood, in its stock of stately Victorian brownstones, and in its prices, both for the brownstones and for apartments, Brooklyn's Park Slope has few peers in New York City.   And as more affluent newcomers have settled in the area - bounded by Fourth Avenue on the east, Prospect Park West on the west, Flatbush Avenue on the north and the Prospect Expressway on the south - the residents of Park Slope have become less defensive about not living in Manhattan and more aggressive in extolling the advantages of their Brooklyn address.   So, too, have developers. Among them are Sol and Allan Arker and Howard I. Simon. The three men are principals of the Sterling and Fleetwood Company, which is turning three low-rise, turn-of-thecentury buildings on Sterling Place in Park Slope into 45 cooperative apartments.

headline: Western Union
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said it had agreed with British Telecom International to provide a public message service that will link the Mailgram service that Western Union provides in the United States with the Telemessage service that British Telecom provides in Britain. Users will have access to both systems, starting early next year, Western Union said.

headline: DIGITAL RECORDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CITIES SERVICE REJECTED HIGHER OCCIDENTAL OFFER
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation told management of the Cities Service Company that it would consider paying as much as $52 a share for the company if the Cities board supported its takeover attempt, Occidental disclosed yesterday.   Although Cities Service management would not consider the sweetened proposal, which Occidental said was made in advance of the formal $50-a-share offer that got underway yesterday, Cities shares soared $5.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, to end the day at $43.875, on a volume of 2.4 million shares.   Wall Street traders said the advance was aided by reports that negotiations with other suitors appeared to be quickening in a bid to head off Occidental's unwelcome offer.

headline: 4 Gunmen Kill 3 Supporters Of Pakistan's Military Leader
abstract: A member of the Pakistani military Government's civilian advisory council and two of his staff were shot dead today, official sources said.   Zahoorul Hasan Bhopali, a 37-year-old politician expelled from his party for joining the council, died in a hospital after four men burst into his office and opened fire with a submachine gun and revolvers. The gunmen escaped, the sources said.

headline: Chief for Chicago Board
abstract: Thomas R. Donovan was appointed president and chief executive officer of the Chicago Board of Trade, effective immediately, the exchange announced today. He joined the board's staff as vice president and secretary in 1979 and was later named executive vice president and secretary.

headline: 5 Hijackers Thwarted On a Chinese Airliner
abstract: Five hijackers were overpowered today when they tried to force the crew of a Chinese airliner to fly from China to Taiwan.   Japan's Foreign Ministry, quoting reports from diplomats in China, said the hijackers were beaten to death by passengers and the copilot. But China's official press agency said they were captured alive after a fight with the passengers and crew.

headline: MRS. GANDHI, ON EVE OF U.S. TRIP, DENIES INDIA IS IN SOVIET CAMP
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who will visit the United States next week, today disputed the idea that India belonged to the Soviet camp.   ''American perceptions have not been correct because they have been constantly trying to propagate the theory that we are in the Soviet camp, which we have never been at any stage,'' Mrs. Gandhi said in an interview.   On her visit, the 64-year-old Indian leader is expected to try to combat the pro-Soviet image that India has gained under her rule and that of her father, Jawaharlal Nehru.

headline: POLISH LEADER VISITS BREZHNEV IN CRIMEA
abstract: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, flew to the Crimea today for a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev and told the Soviet leader that the current unrest in Poland was being fomented from outside, mainly from the United States.   The meeting, at the Black Sea retreat where Mr. Brezhnev is vacationing, was one of a series that the Soviet leader holds each summer with leaders of the Eastern European countries. But concern over the situation in Poland was reflected in the official description of the trip as ''a short working visit,'' whereas other visitors who saw Mr. Brezhnev were described as being on vacation.   The account given by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, made no mention of the clashes that occurred last week in several Polish cities and flared up again today in Warsaw. But General Jaruzelski appeared to have given a sobering account of continuing resistance to martial law that, at least in the Tass version, omitted the assurances he gave in March about the Polish authorities' ability to ''tackle the threat with our own forces,'' as he put it then.

headline: FORECAST QUESTIONED
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in a controversial midyear economic review that has been rejected by some of the President's top economist aides, predicts a recovery this year and next that is more optimistic than other forecasts.   According to figures provided by an Administration official, the review, which is to be made public Friday, also forecasts that the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1983, beginning Oct.1, will be $115 billion, and that the deficits will decline to $92.6 billion in 1984 and $73.6 billion in 1985.   The deficit projection for the fiscal year 1983 is higher that the $110 billion figure mentioned a few days ago by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. It is also out of line with an estimate this week by the Congressional Budget Office, which said the deficits in each of the next three fiscal years would range from $140 billion to $160 billion.

headline: Volvo Bus Order
abstract: A.B. Volvo said today that it had received an order valued at the equivalent of $48 million to supply Lima, Peru, with 400 buses.

headline: SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Harvester Sale
abstract: The International Harvester Company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell segments of its parts remanufacturing operations to Champion Parts Rebuilders Inc. of Chicago. Champion would pay cash for certain inventories and equipment in Illinois, Texas and Georgia, and it would supply the parts to Harvester, which would distribute them. The price was not disclosed, but Champion indicated that its annual sales would grow about $6 million under the agreement.

headline: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MRS. GHANDI SAYS GOAL IN U.S. IS TO 'CLEAR UP MISCONCEPTIONS'
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that she was hoping to ''clear up a lot of misconceptions'' about India during her trip to the United States, and added that her visit with President Reagan had been ''very good.''   Mrs. Gandhi, in the aftermath of her meetings with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, held a series of news conferences today, met officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and served as host at a dinner in honor of Vice President Bush.   At a morning meeting with reporters at the Madison Hotel, Mrs.  Gandhi spoke in detail about what she termed the ''misconceptions'' about India. ''The question that's most often asked is, 'Why has she come?' '' Mrs. Gandhi said. ''Well, my main reason was that I was very kindly invited by the President, and I thought it would have been extremely discourteous not to accept.''

headline: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American General Corp., Houston, has elected William B. Pardue to the new position of executive vice president and Robert O. Purcifull to president and chief executive officer of the American General Life Insurance Company subsidiary.   * APL Corp. announced that Leonard Leifert, chief financial officer, is assuming the additional responsibilities of chief operating officer following the resignation of Harold L. Schwartz Jr.    * Chanel Inc. has appointed Sanford J. Roland vice presidentdepartment and specialty store sales.

headline: EL SALVADOR REPORTS ITS CASUALTIES
abstract: Government troops had 3,801 casualties - estimated at more than one-fifth the army's strength - fighting leftist guerrillas in the 12-month period ending June 30, Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia said today.   A Westerner said this represented 21 percent of the army's personnel, which he estimated at 18,000 officers and men.

headline: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business and the Law; Asbestos Now Company Peril
abstract: THE recent disclosure of the financial problems of two major asbestos companies has focused new attention on legislative proposals that would remove from the courts thousands of lawsuits arising from asbestos-related health problems.   Last week, the Manville Corporation, the largest asbestos producer in the country, omitted its quarterly dividend, and admitted for the first time that the continuing flood of asbestos litigation, which cost it $8.6 million in the first half of the year, was imperiling its financial health. Because it is impossible to estimate Manville's potential liability in the thousands of claims against it, the company's auditors have for two years qualified their opinion of Manville's annual report.   A week before Manville's announcement, the Chicago-based UNR Industries filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, citing 17,000 claims against it related to asbestos pipe insulation it had not made since 1962. Since the beginning of 1980, the company has spent more than $26 million on asbestos litigation, according to David S. Leavitt, UNR's chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DR PEPPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Curfew Ends in Warsaw; Discos to Reopen
abstract: Poland's martial law authorities ended a two-month curfew in Warsaw today and said they would also reopen discos and student clubs.   The curfew has been in effect since May 4, when policemen clashed in the capital and in other Polish cities with demonstrators who celebrated a national holiday.

headline: FALKLAND AFTERMATH: A NAVAL DEBATE
abstract: One of the legacies of the Falkland Islands war is the debate now under way in Britain over the use of aluminum superstructures in Royal Navy ships. It is an argument of interest to the United States Navy, which also uses aluminum in naval superstructures.   The sinking of the destroyer Sheffield was the starting point for the debate. The first reports of the action inaccurately said that the Sheffield had been destroyed by a fire in her aluminum upper works. The ship, however, was of all-steel construction. So was the destroyer Coventry, which was also lost in the South Atlantic conflict.

headline: Bell Measure Advances
abstract: The House Energy and Commerce Committee, resuming work today on a complex telephone measure, beat back an attempt to relax the standards that will determine how long the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is singled out for special regulation.   By a 22-15 vote, the panel rejected an amendment offered by Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, Republican of New Jersey, that would have removed A.T.& T.'s classification as the nation's ''dominant carrier'' once its ownership share of long-distance facilities dropped to 60 percent.

headline: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Aug 14
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Microscopic Analysis Without Using Slides
abstract: Slideless microscopy, with which blood and urine can be analyzed as they flow, was patented this week for International Remote Imaging Systems Inc. of Chatsworth, Calif.

headline: POLISH PROTESTERS IN SEVERAL CITIES ROUTED BY POLICE
abstract: Polish riot policemen fired barrages of tear-gas grenades here and in other cities today to break up demonstrations called by underground Solidarity leaders.   There were reports of clashes in Gdansk, Wroclaw, Cracow and its steel-making suburb of Nowa Huta. Government spokesmen also reported unrest in Szczecin, Przemysl, Czestochowa and Rzeszow. Parts of Gdansk were still said to be under the control of demonstrators late in the evening.

headline: Shift at Mark Controls
abstract: The Mark Controls Corporation of Evanston, Ill., said yesterday that its president, Joseph L. Casey, 45 years old, would resign in mid-September to operate Rubicon Inc., a company he recently formed.

headline: STEIGER TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Air Florida Accord
abstract: Air Florida said it had reached agreement in principle with its major lenders to provide additional working capital based on a plan that shows the company regaining profitability by the first quarter of 1983. Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, president of the airline, said the agreements provide for advances of approximately $6.8 million to satisfy payments on guaranteed debt and deferral of $9.2 million in lease payments for its five Boeing 727-200 aircraft.

headline: PAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWAYS SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr toJune 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Earnings Down At Greyhound
abstract: The Greyhound Corporation today reported second-quarter net income of $27.6 million, or 63 cents a share, down 12 percent from $31.4 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier.  Revenues fell 8.3 percent, to $1.1 billion from $1.2 billion.

headline: D'Arcy Names Director For Creative Services
abstract: D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago has hired Gary J. Horton as director of creative services and has appointed Lawrence D. Senten, executive vice president, to the new position of director of strategic planning.

headline: Conde Nast Studies Women's View on Cars
abstract: The woman driver wants a car that is safe, relatively inexpensive, has extended warranties and service plans and is easy to handle.  That is the conclusion of a major study recently conducted by Conde Nast on the women's market for cars.

headline: Japanese, Fearing Floods, Flee River Valleys
abstract: Thousands of Japanese families left their homes in river valleys tonight to escape expected heavy overnight flooding in the wake of a typhoon, designated Bess, the police said.   Weather forecasters warned that rising rivers could overflow banks because of the large volume of rain that fell Monday in the mountains on the main island of Honshu.

headline: TransCanada Bid Rumored
abstract: Reports spread through the oil industry yesterday that Petro-Canada, the Canadian Government oil company, might acquire TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., which is the exclusive shipper of Alberta gas to eastern Canada.   Officials of privately owned oil and gas companies said that if Petro-Canada were to acquire TransCanada, it would be able to dominate the Canadian natural gas business.

headline: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FED GUIDES FOR BANK MERGERS
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board gave the go-ahead yesterday for banking companies in one state to invest in the nonvoting stock of banks in other states. But the Fed issued strict regulations to assure that the purchasing bank would not gain control over the bank being acquired.   Bankers predicted that the ruling would lead to a flood of proposals for such interstate mergers. They said the Federal Reserve felt obliged to issue guidelines because of the large number of inquiries it was receiving.

headline: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENVOY FROM POPE REACHES LEBANON
abstract: Mother Teresa arrived in Lebanon today as an envoy of Pope John Paul II and said she wanted to go wherever she was needed, even to west Beirut.   ''I have come to see my sisters, please let me pass,'' the 71-year-old, Albanian-born nun said after getting off a ship in the port of Junieh, a resort 10 miles north of Beirut.   Shortly after she arrived at a convent near Beirut, Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization gunners fired at each other.

headline: Hewlett Rises 32.9% in Period
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that quarterly earnings topped $100 million for the first time, and increased 32.9 percent compared with the third quarter of 1981.

headline: TRIAL IN HAITI PUTS THE FOCUS ON RIGHTS
abstract: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 26 -The Haitian Government will begin a retrial Friday of 22 political figures who were seized in 1980 for anti-Government activities.   The new trial, coupled with recent arrests of people opposed to the Government, has focused attention on what is broadly termed the human rights situation here, and the outcome is expected to be seen as an indication of the Government's views toward liberalization of Haiti's long-restrictive society. Several representatives of international human rights groups are expected to be present for the trial.   The 22 who will be retried include Sylvio Claude, the leader of Haiti's tiny Christian Democratic group, and 21 associates who were arrested and charged with conspiracy against the Government and arson in a roundup of those viewed as opposing the Government in November 1980. Last March Haiti's high court overturned their sentences of 15 years at hard labor and ordered a new trial on the ground that the original punishment was inappropriate.

headline: HLH PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE MODERATE BROTHER
abstract: Searching for a presidential nominee who might be a ''consensus candidate,'' the Lebanese Christian Phalangist Party has proposed 40-year-old Amin Gemayel, the brother of the slain President-elect.   It seemed to many when the party's political bureau advanced Amin's name Thursday night that he would have little difficulty in winning the election to be held by Parliament for a successor to President Elias Sarkis, whose six-year term is due to end next Thursday. Today Amin's supporters still thought he would win, even though a rival candidate appeared who might split the vote.   The National Liberal Party today named its 82-year-old leader, former President Camille Chamoun, to oppose him in the race.  Mr.  Chamoun and his party had helped make Amin's late brother, Bashir, the President-elect on Aug. 23.  There was no immediate explanation of why the former President decided to make the race himself against a Gemayel who was being pictured as the ''consensus candidate.''

headline: Advertising; Weekday Coupons For Food
abstract: OP COUPONING INC., already the biggest distributor of manufacturers' cents-off coupons through its 29 annual run-of-press black-and-white newspaper ads, will be adding even greater capacity next year when it begins a schedule of 10 annual four-color inserts on Best Foods Day.   Best Foods Day is traditionally either Wednesday or Thursday and that's when supermarkets try to stimulate the greatest sales with specials as shoppers prepare for the weekends.   And, although coupon-carrying color inserts are common on Sundays, such a phenomenon during the week is all but unheard of.  The exception was Adserts, introduced last November by McGill/Jensen, a Minneapolis four-color commercial printer, and printed one more time in January. Oscar Carlson, its president, said his problems arose when he tried to fill up his third edition and found many advertisers hesitant because they hadn't gotten results yet. ''And you may not get results for six to eight months in this business,'' he said.

headline: POLES FREE MORE DETAINEES AND OPEN TELEPHONE LINKS
abstract: The Polish authorities freed more political prisoners today and reopened international telephone lines to the public in a further relaxation of martial law.   At least 14 people, most of them members of the suspended Solidarity union, were seen leaving Warsaw's Bialoleka Prison. Polish sources also said that most of the female prisoners held in Goldap, in northeast Poland near the Soviet border, were either freed or about to go free.

headline: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Burroughs Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a shelf registration statement covering $100 million of debt securities.   * C.I.T. Financial Corp., a subsidiary of RCA Corp., said it had amended its registration statement for $200 million of medium-term notes, originally filed on July 19 with the S.E.C.   * Collins Foods International Inc. disclosed that its wholly owned subsidiary, Sizzler Restaurants International Inc., is contemplating a public offering of common stock in the early fall.

headline: Central Bancorp Offer for Union
abstract: Central Bancorp Inc. said that 59.7 percent of the Union Commerce Corporation's common stock outstanding had been tendered under its offer of $25 a share. The Cincinnati concern added that it was extending the offer for up to 61.3 percent of the stock to Sept. 10 from Aug. 13.

headline: DECLINE IN SPENDING PLANS SEEN
abstract: The combination of high interest rates and sluggish sales in key markets is forcing reductions - and in some cases deep cuts - in planned spending for new factories and equipment across a broad spectrum of American industry.   In recent weeks, companies in fields that are feeling the harshest impact of the recession have announced that they were reducing their earlier projections of capital spending this year and deferring projects in midstream.   In the steel industry, for example, some of the cuts have been dramatic. ''In effect, we're turning off the faucet,'' asserted Harry Holiday, chairman of Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-largest steel manufacturer, in a meeting with New York securities analysts last week. He said the company, which had earlier projected $570 million in capital spending in 1982, now planned to spend about $370 million this year and less than $300 million in 1983.

headline: Manila Formally Charges 68 With Subversion
abstract: The Government today formally charged 68 people, most of them labor leaders, with plotting to mount an insurrection during President Ferdinand E. Marcos's visit to the United States later this month.   The Government-owned Philippine News Agency said 33 suspects had been arrested and detained since mid-August and 35 others were still being sought by the authorities.

headline: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets to open 37th session at 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: QUAKER STATE OIL REFINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cal Fed Cuts Home Interest
abstract: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association said today that it had lowered its variable rate on 30-year conventional home mortgages a full percentage point, to 15 percent.   Robert R. Dockson, chairman of Cal Fed, said the change was made as a result of last month's Supreme Court decision allowing thrift institutions to enforce ''due on sale'' mortgage clauses.

headline: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 300 LEGIONNAIRES GIVEN SEND-OFF FOR BEIRUT
abstract: About 300 members of the French Foreign Legion left a military base in Corsica today to serve as the first contingent of the multinational peacekeeping force in Beirut.   The departure was widely heralded and included a review of the troops by Charles Hernu, the Minister of Defense, and Gen. Janou Lacaze, the army Chief of Staff.   ''Everything must be done to avoid lapses in discipline and excesses, and you, legionnaires, I count on you to demonstrate the professionalism of French troops,'' Mr. Hernu told the men as they lined the runway.   Five planes - a DC-8 marked with the French presidential seal, three Transall transports and an Air France 747 cargo jet - carried the men and equipment from the Corsican base at Calvi to Larnaca in Cyprus, where they will transfer to three French warships for the rest of the journey to Lebanon.

headline: U.S. Reviews Japan Jet Pact
abstract: The United States Justice Department has started a ''routine, preliminary investigation'' into a joint Britain-Japan project for development of a new aircraft engine on suspicion the project might violate American antitrust law if an American company joins the group, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.   Yoshikazu Gotoh, of the ministry's Aircraft and Weapons Section, said the project, first started in 1979, called for development of an engine for a new 150-seat jetliner in a joint venture by Britain's Rolls-Royce and Japan's Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Kawasaki Heavy Industries.

headline: LAWSON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN LOOKS AT GRISLY SIDE OF ITS PAST
abstract: The best-selling book in Japan this year is an account of a Japanese germ warfare unit based in Manchuria that killed 3,000 Chinese, Koreans and Russians in biological experiments in World War II.   Since publication in December, 1,140,000 copies of the book, ''Gluttony of the Devil,'' by Seiichi Morimura, have been sold.  Mr. Morimura has completed a sequel, to be published this month, on how 2,600 members of the 731st Epidemic Prevention and Water Supply Headquarters unit in Harbin escaped discovery after the war. He said they were protected by American occupation forces against prosecution on war crimes charges in return for data on germ warfare.

headline: U.S. IS HOLDING UP PEKING ATOM TALKS
abstract: The United States is holding up a nuclear cooperation agreement with China because of suspicions that the Chinese are giving nuclear aid to Pakistan and other nations thought to be developing nuclear weapons, according to Government and industry officials.   The Government officials said they were disturbed by intelligence reports suggesting that China had helped Pakistan in trying to develop a capacity to enrich uranium for weapon use.   The officials said China was also believed to have sold lowenriched uranium to South Africa through private parties. They said Chinese sales of heavy water, required for reactors that use natural uranium, were believed to have been made to Argentina and possibly India.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CAIRO REPORTED TO SHIFT ON P.L.O.
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak appeared today to have altered Egypt's policy of categorical refusal to give haven to any of the Palestinian fighters now trapped in west Beirut by the Israeli Army.   Mr. Mubarak was quoted as having said that Egypt would give refuge to some of the Palestinians if there was a prior guarantee by the United States of the establiment of a permanent homeland for the Palestinians.

headline: U.S. Steel Mill
