abstract: The Bank of Nova Scotia said it had arranged a $690 million (United States) syndicated loan for the United States Steel Corporation's Fairfield Works, a seamless-pipe mill in Alabama that the company closed in June. The bank said the agreement had been signed with the General Electric Credit Corporation and involved financing from 16 other banks. The plant will be purchased and leased back to U.S. Steel, with lease financing arranged by General Electric Credit.

headline: M.P.'S BACK BEGIN IN CLASH WITH U.S.
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that if the Reagan plan for the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip had been put forth as the American position four years ago Israel would never have signed the Camp David accords that led to peace with Egypt.   Mr. Shamir said President Reagan's plan had disturbed the delicate balance of the peace process, undermining the accords and damaging the prospects for their success.   The Foreign Minister, who opposed the Camp David framework when it was worked out in 1978, spoke on behalf of the Israeli Government during a debate in Parliament on the United States proposals. Begin Backed in Parliament   Parliament then voted 50 to 36 to endorse the Begin Government's opposition to the Reagan plan, which calls for Palestinian rule in the West Bank and Gaza in association with Jordan. The plan also urges a freeze on Israeli settlements in the occupied territories.

headline: Penn Square Asset Sale Due
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation hopes to begin soliciting bids for the purchase of $69.4 million in Penn Square Bank installment and real estate loans in 10 days to two weeks, an F.D.I.C. spokesman, Alan Whitney, said today.   He added that a package of $36.9 million in the failed bank's securities was being prepared for sale.

headline: Around the World; Wife of Hunger Striker Flies to Soviet Capital
abstract: Elena Balovlenkov, the American wife of a Soviet hunger striker who is pressing for the right to leave the Soviet Union, flew into Moscow today and said she wanted to talk him out of his fast.   Mrs. Balovlenkov, who is 29 years old, brought their two-year-old daughter Katrina with her and said she hoped her husband's first sight of the girl would help to persuade him to abandon his protest.

headline: MICHIGAN SUGAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Coffee Producers Set Export Limit in London
abstract: Coffee-producing nations, with the backing of consuming countries, agreed today to continue to limit the amount of coffee entering the world market.

headline: Harvester Rebates
abstract: The International Harvester Company said it had extended a program of cash rebates and low-interest financing on sales of new farm equipment to July 27. The rebates were slightly increased to a range of $500 to $3,500 on most farm tractors.

headline: INTEREST PLUNGES, ELEVATING STOCKS TO A RECORD GAIN
abstract: High interest rates, which have stymied economic growth, broke sharply yesterday, sending the stock market in a burst of euphoria to its largest one-day gain in history. The volume of trading was the second largest on record.   Bond prices also soared as hopes grew that a recent plunge in interest rates for Treasury bills and other short-term borrowings had spread to the long-term markets that finance job-creating investment in housing and new plants. The rate decline was attributed to the persistent recession and the prospect of shrinking demand for business loans.   Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange responded with a roar of appreciation as stocks, which had lost out to high interest rates in the competition for investors' funds, soared in price.  The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 38.81 points, a record rise, to 831.24. Yesterday's volume of 92.86 million shares came within 20,000 shares of the record set in January 1981.

headline: PANHANDLE SKED TO JUSTIFY GAS DEAL
abstract: The Government, concerned about rising natural gas prices, ordered the Panhandle Eastern Corporation today to justify its plans to import costly gas in liquefied form from Algeria.   The move by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is the latest reflection of growing public resistance to rising gas prices, despite abundant supplies.   The commission, by a 4-to-0 vote, gave Panhandle one week to prove that the liquefied natural gas it has contracted to import from Sonatrach, the Algerian state oil and gas company, was in the public interest.   The price of this gas is about $7 per 1,000 cubic feet, compared with the $4.94 that American companies pay for conventional gas imports from Canada and Mexico. The $7 is more than twice the average price for domestically produced gas at the wellhead.

headline: NITRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Mexico Alters View On Debt
abstract: Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, today backed away from a statement that his Government had decided to suspend all principal payments on its huge debt falling due over the next 17 months.   After a round of intense negotiations here, he said no such agreement had been reached with creditors.  Today's statement did say that Mexico had negotiated an arrangement with bank creditors to postpone principal payments covering about $10 billion of debt due between Aug. 23 and Nov. 23.   The original remarks were made by Mr. Silva Herzog on Sunday in a briefing here to Mexican reporters.But today's statement, described as a clarification and issued by the Mexican delegation to the International Monetary Fund conference here, said that apart from the 90-day rollover, ''No other arrangements of any nature have been made, nor have any been suggested by any party.''

headline: Banks Adjust Mortgages
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fourthlargest commercial bank, has announced that it has lowered the interest rates on conventional mortgage and cooperative apartment loans by half a percentage point.   Citibank, the second-largest bank, disclosed that it would begin offering today a home mortgage on which the interest rate is adjusted every six months, based on changes in the rate at the Government's weekly auction of six-month Treasury bills.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS STANCE HAS NOT CHANGED
abstract: Ranking Israeli officials said today that Israel had not received any new proposals for the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon. At the same time, the officials stressed that Israel's position on any P.L.O. evacuation remained unchanged.   A senior Foreign Ministry official defined Israel's position as requiring ''a clear, unequivocal statement that the P.L.O. is leaving Beirut, without conditions or time frame.''   Otherwise, the official said, Israel would maintain its policy of responding with force to what it considers P.L.O. violations of the cease-fire. These responses have recently taken the form of attacks by planes, artillery and tanks and sporadic advances into west Beirut.

headline: Technology; The Scales Of the 1980's
abstract: AS the nation's largest diaper service, the Blessings Corporation had a productivity problem. The Piscataway, N.J., company operates 25 laundry and distribution plants from Connecticut to California. It says it has 70,000 mothers on its client list. Each week, the company cleans, packages and distributes from 60 to 80 fresh diapers to each mother and picks up the soiled ones from the previous week.   The company's problem in 1980 was this: It not only had to wash more than 5 million dirty diapers a week, it had to count and fold them.

headline: ARAFAT IN GREECE IN SNUB TO ARABS
abstract: Yasir Arafat, wearing a combat uniform and vowing continued resistance to what he described as the ''barbarian, savage'' Israelis, arrived here today to a warm reception.   A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization said Mr.  Arafat chose Greece instead of an Arab country as his first stop to express discontent with the Arab world and to stress that the Athens Government had offered more help than any other country.   The P.L.O. leader, wearing the traditional Palestinian black and white headscarf as he came off the Greek ferry Atlantis, flashed victory signs and warmly embraced Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, who was on hand with most of his Government. A naval guard of honor played martial tunes as a crowd of over a thousand Greek and Arab demonstrators chanted ''Revolution until victory!'' and ''Down with Zionism, victory to the P.L.O.!''

headline: E.E.C. Inflation Figures
abstract: The consumer price index for the 10-member European Economic Community rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent from May to June, the community's statistics agency reported today. Greece had the biggest jump in inflation during the month - 2.6 percent -followed by Luxembourg with 1.1 percent, and West Germany and Italy, each with 1 percent.

headline: POLLUTION CONTROL INDUSTRY IN PERIL
abstract: WASHINGTON COMBUSTION Equipment Associates, a promising young Stamford, Conn., company in the promising pollution control business, was flying high in the mid-1970's, reaching peak sales of $150 million. By 1980, although its sales were still $140.5 million, its losses had swollen to $23.6 million and in October that year, it filed a bankruptcy petition.   While the fate of Combustion Equipment is an extreme example, it is nonetheless representative of the nation's deeply troubled and demoralized pollution control industry, which until just a few years ago was riding the wings of a new national concern for environmental controls. Most companies in the industry today are experiencing sharp drops in sales and profits, layoffs and other retrenchments.   The situation today is, indeed, dramatically different from 1976, when Federal support of environmental cleanup was strong, and an estimated $16 billion was spent on cleaning the nation's air and water. From 1970 to 1975, orders for new air and water pollution control equipment were rising at an average rate of 20 percent a year. But by 1980, new orders had fallen to one-tenth of their 1976 pace.

headline: Advertising; Expanding Geriatrics Market
abstract: WITH the golden-age gang the fastest-growing segment of the American population, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. couldn't very well expect to keep the gerontology field to itself.   The big publishing company includes in its titles Geriatrics, a 36-year-old magazine for the medical field, that has been without any important competition. But now that the over-65 set has increased from 4 percent in 1900 to 11 percent today, and they are purchasing 38 percent of all pharmaceuticals (the prescription part alone being worth more than $12.5 billion a year), reaching the people who recommend or prescribe the drugs becomes that much more important.

headline: A U.S. EDUCATOR IS SEIZED IN BEIRUT
abstract: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped the acting president of the American University of Beirut from the campus in west Beirut today, a university spokesman said.   The spokesman said that the university president, David Dodge, 60 years old, was walking home from his office at about 6:30 P.M. when he was abducted at gunpoint.   Witnesses reported that at least two men armed with pistols threatened the American educator, forced him into a red automobile and sped away from the campus, according to the spokesman, Radwan Mawlawi.   Mr. Mawlawi, who is also director general of Lebanon's Information Ministry, said there was no indication who the kidnappers were. At American University of Beirut offices in New York, a spokesman said he had been told by the State Department that it did not know who was responsible, or whether Mr. Dodge had been injured in the abduction.

headline: STORE SALES OFF BY 0.9% IN AUGUST
abstract: Sales by retail outlets in the United States fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today. The results reversed a rise in July and punctured hopes that the 10 percent income tax cut of July 1 would spur sales and help pull the nation out of recession.   The main reason for the seasonally adjusted decline from July was poor sales of auto dealers, the department said. August sales would have edged up one-tenth of 1 percent from July if a 5.6 percent drop in car sales had been excluded.

headline: Baghdad's Strongman
abstract: Saddam Hussein, President and iron-fisted ruler of Iraq, is nothing if not tough. In his youth he was the only one in his revolutionary cell to escape after an attempt to assassinate a dictator. He cut a bullet out of his leg with a penknife and made his way on a donkey across the desert to Syria. On another occasion he held off an overwhelming force of policemen assaulting his hideout until he ran out of bullets for his pistol.

headline: DOCUMENTS ARE SUBPOENAED IN DRYSDALE GOVERNMENT CASE
abstract: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office has subpoenaed the books and records of Drysdale Government Securites Inc. and its bankrupt parent, Drysdale Securities Inc., as part of an investigation into possible criminal activity in connection with the collapse of Drysdale Government last May.   Jeffrey Hoffman, an attorney for Dennis Ruppert, controller of Drysdale Securities, said yesterday that his client had accepted the subpoenas last Friday.   ''We can neither confirm or deny the existence of an investigation,'' Robert Morgenthau, the District Attorney, said.

headline: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMF Selling Division
abstract: AMF Inc. said yesterday it had agreed definitively to sell its Des Moines-based lawn and garden division to a group of nine managers led by William I. Brown, division president, for cash and securities. The amount was not disclosed. The sale is part of the company's plan to redeploy assets.

headline: G.O.P. WINS KEY VOTES IN SENATE ON TAX BILL
abstract: The Republican majority in the Senate defeated several attempts by Democrats today to change the tax increases and spending cuts brought to the floor by the Finance Committee.   The voting appeared to set the stage for Senate approval Thursday of the bill largely as it was written, which would be a victory for the Reagan Administration.   In the House, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, conferred for the second time in 24 hours with the Democratic chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, on a bill to be drafted in the House, which traditionally originates tax legislation. ''We're not in great disagreement,'' Mr. Conable said.

headline: Softsoap's Maker Decides on a Shop
abstract: Minnetonka Inc., a very important and successful holdout, finally has decided to take unto itself an advertising agency. And after being courted by scores of agencies since it introduced Softsoap in 1978, it has chosen Advertising to Women without any agency competition.

headline: Chrysler Retooling
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it would spend $80 million retooling its Jefferson assembly plant for production of 1983 model ''E''-body, four-door family sedans. It said production would begin in the first week of August, and that 60 cars an hour -Dodges and Chryslers - would be produced on two shifts.  Chrysler said the plant would employ 4,700 and have an estimated annual payroll of $180 million.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Last Thursday, almost at the moment that the agreement on west Beirut was being accepted in Jerusalem, delegates to what was billed as an emergency session of the General Assembly here were voting to hold a $5.7 million, 12-day conference in Paris next August to talk about the Palestinian question. This episode illustrates what one Western diplomat called the ''monumental irrelevance'' of the United Nations in the crisis over Lebanon. There is a pervasive sense of frustration in corridors and offices here.   The Assembly's vote on holding the conference followed more than two months of ineffective efforts by the Security Council, the most powerful body in the world organization to deal with the problem of Lebanon.

headline: AFTER THE SHELLING STOPS, ARABS TAKE TO THE STREET
abstract: In this battered town just south of west Beirut, people were out on the main street today after 16 hours of shelling between Israelis and Palestinians on Sunday,   The barrages ended late Sunday night as another cease-fire took effect. In the meantime, little was occurring in the complicated negotiations to end the siege of Beirut.   Reagan Administration officials will meet with two Arab Foreign Ministers, Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria and Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, concerning Israel's demand that the Palestine Liberation Organization leave Lebanon.

headline: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNIMATION INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., has named to vice president Richard C. Gozon, president of the Paper Products Group; Edward Jay Phillips, president of the Wine and Spirits Group; John Sellors Jr., president of the Specialty Manufacturers Group, and George R. Shelley, president of the Foodservice Equipment Group.   * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Frank J. Toner senior vice president, corporate human resources and development.

headline: Bethlehem Starts New Steel Group
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced that it would establish a new steel group, effective Oct.1.  Bethlehem said that the group would be led by Walter F. Williams, who would continue as president and chief operating officer of the parent corporation. It would have three departments led by newly elected group executive vice presidents: D. Sheldon Arnot, in charge of steel sales; Paul A. Henschen, in charge of steel services, and Edward H. Kottcamp Jr., in charge of steel production.

headline: Kornhauser & Calene
abstract: Let's all drink a toast to the crowd at Kornhauser & Calene who have just been awarded the business from Laird & Company, alcoholic beverage importers of Scobeyville, N.J. Most of the $1 million budget will be put behind Grande Cantina Classico Brut, which the agency says is the only sparkling Italian Soave Classico wine marketed in the United States. Previously the advertising was handled in-house with freelance help.

headline: ARAB WOMEN END THEIR FAST
abstract: A group of Arab women, including the wives of several Arab ambassadors, decided today to end their eightday-old hunger strike protesting Israel's blockade of food and electricity to west Beirut.   Hala Maksoud, spokesman for the group, said recent events in Lebanon had overtaken the purpose of the hunger strike.

headline: Sawdon & Bess Wins A Wendy's Account
abstract: Wendy's International has named Sawdon & Bess the advertising agency for its Northeast region (New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island). The region, comprising about 90 restaurants, was previously handled by Savitt Tobias Balk, which had to relinquish the $1.5 million account because of a conflict resulting from its acquisition in July by Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, agency for the local McDonald's business.

headline: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TALE OF SAUDI MONEY-CHANGER
abstract: The affairs of a Saudi Arabian money-changer who apparently lost millions of dollars speculating in gold and silver are under scrutiny by a Government-appointed committee, according to British and Saudi Arabian officials.   The appointment of the committee has raised modest hopes among creditors located mostly in Belgium and Britain that the debts of the Abdullah Saleh al-Rajhi Company - perhaps as much as $300 million - may be repaid.   Until the appointment of the committee by the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, the closure of the company in mid-July after a year of difficulties had sent the creditors scurrying to protect the collateral they had for their loans. Company Closed for Audit   ''The company was closed down temporarily to see if its assets are enough to cover its debts,'' a foreign diplomat in Riyadh said in a telephone interview. ''It may have sufficient assets to pay off its debts.''

headline: CLOROX CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE SURVIVOR OF REBELLION
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi, who appears to have weathered Kenya's first attempted coup since the East African nation became independent in 1963, speaks often of his country's special need for domestic unity.   ''Tribalism,'' the 57-year-old former school teacher has said at countless ribbon-cuttings and other ceremonies over the last few years, ''can be a menace to a young nation like Kenya.''   But at the same time, Mr. Moi, who has served as President since the death of Jomo Kenyatta in 1978, owes his office in large part to tribalism: In a nation where the Kikuyu tribal group is dominant in almost every area of life and the members of the Luo tribe are their chief - and often bitter - rivals, Mr. Moi is neither Kikuyu nor Luo, but a member of the small Tugen tribe of the minority Kalenjin group, one of Kenya's 70 distinct tribal groupings.   It was in recognition of this tribal diversity - and the fear that most of the tribes felt for the dominant Kikuyus long headed by Mr.  Kenyatta - that the Kenyan Constitution reserved the vice presidency for a non-Kikuyu.

headline: Gulfstream Banks In NCNB Link
abstract: Gulfstream Banks of Boca Raton, Fla., said shareholders had voted overwhelmingly to approve its acquisition by the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., for $89 million.

headline: Arafat at Burial of Aide
abstract: Yasir Arafat marched at the head of 200,000 mourners today as Brig. Saad Sayel, the operations chief of Mr. Arafat's Al Fatah guerrillas who was slain in an ambush Monday, was buried in a refugee camp near here, the Palestine Liberation Organization press agency Wafa reported. ''The revolution will continue to victory,'' the agency quoted Mr. Arafat as saying in a eulogy.

headline: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bell 'Express Call'
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would begin trials of a new domestic service - 30-second long-distance calls from special pay phones to any point in the United States for 50 cents. Starting in California in December, the new ''Express Call'' service will be extended to New York, Massachusetts and Michigan by Jan. 31.

headline: ANTIWAR MINORITY REMAINS VOCAL AND VISIBLE AND SMALL
abstract: Two months after Israel invaded Lebanon, the majority of Israeli citizens still support the war. But a small, vocal and visible minority persists.   The minority includes groups ranging from Peace Now, a broad-based organization started four years ago by Army reserve officers, to small blocs of political leftists and women formed specifically to oppose the war in Lebanon.   The groups hold occasional rallies and demonstrations, but their activities are usually overshadowed by public interest in the progress of the siege of Beirut, especially since the Israelis stepped up their attacks this week.

headline: Hitachi Supercomputer
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. says it will put its new supercomputer on display by the end of September, denying earlier reports that marketing of the machine was being delayed because of Hitachi's reported involvement in a computer espionage case.  Supercomputers, which generally cost $10 million or more, are designed for the highspeed processing of huge mathematical calculations, such as those used in scientific research. Takeo Mano, a Hitachi spokesman, said his remarks on the computer's introduction had been misinterpreted by reporters in translating his comments into English from Japanese and that Hitachi's supercomputer would be on the market by October.

headline: THE WEEKS OF WAR AND NEGOTIATION IN LEBANON
abstract: June 6. Israeli forces - 25,000 troops and 250 planes - invade southern Lebanon by land, sea and air to destroy Palestine Liberation Organization military bases. By nightfall, the main targets - Tyre, Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and Kawkaba - are all besieged. June 7. Prime Minister Menachem Begin says the Israeli Army has been ordered to push the Palestinians 25 males back from the border, to put them out of artillery range of Israel. Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, meets with Mr. Begin and asks for a ceasefire and the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. June 8. Israeli forces capture Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and several other Palestinian strongholds and sweep north toward Beirut. Syria says some of its forces engaged Israelis in ground and air battles.

headline: BOMBAY RIOTER IS KILLED IN SECOND DAY OF REVOLT
abstract: Indian troops shot and killed a rioter in the second day of a police rebellion in Bombay today, but were able to begin restoring order in the city, the authorities said.    The latest casualty brought the two-day death toll to five. More than 100 people have been injured in the arson and looting.  Babasaheb Bhosale, chief minister of Maharashtra State, where Bombay is situated, said that despite renewed violence in some areas, the city was ''fast returning to normal.''

headline: Sumitomo Corp. Names President of U.S. Unit
abstract: The Sumitomo Corporation, one of Japan's largest trading companies, has established a subsidiary to market Japanese computers in the United States and named Ken Uchihashi as its president.   Mr. Uchihashi, 42 years old, is also manager of Sumitomo's electronics export section in Tokyo.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Manville Corporation's decision to file for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act has been at least as trying for the financial institutions and suppliers to which it owes money as for the company itself.   In fact, at least in the short run, Manville's bold strategy for dealing with the thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits seems to be causing less hardship for Manville than for the vast network of other companies affected by the bankruptcy petition - and in the long run, the bankruptcy may shift some of the legal liability onto those companies.   One of the immediate effects of any Chapter 11 filing is to stop the company from making any further payment on its debt until a plan for reorganization is approved by the court.   According to the bankruptcy petition, this leaves the Prudential Insurance Company waiting for $68 million; the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, $36 million, and the Bank of America, Chemical Bank and Citibank, N.A. $20 million each.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at noon.   General Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.   Third Conference on the Law of the Sea - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Dumping Complaint
abstract: Hercules Inc. said today the United States International Trade Commission had determined that the company's antidumping complaint against nitrocellulose imported from France merited further investigation. The substance is used mainly in the production of paints, finishes, printing inks and coatings.

headline: Credit Card Policy Ruling
abstract: A Federal court today ruled against the American Express Company's policy of automatically canceling women's supplementary credit cards when their husbands die.   The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit sent the case, brought by Virginia F. Miller, back to Federal District Court in Phoenix for further action.

headline: Chrysler Begins Search For Additional Agency
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was beginning a ''closed and confidential'' search that should turn up an agency for its Dodge division within the next 30 to 45 days.

headline: G.M. Sets Layoffs
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said 1,300 hourly workers at its Hydra-matic division plant at Ypsilanti, Mich., would be laid off indefinitely starting Monday because of poor car sales. John T. Lynch, a G.M. spokesman, said the move would leave 8,700 workers at the Willow Run plant. The facility produces automatic transmissions for cars and trucks.

headline: TAIWANESE SEEM UNMOVED BY U.S.-CHINA ACCORD
abstract: Patrick Lin presented the view apparently held by most Taiwanese on the agreement between Washington and Peking in which the Reagan Administration agreed to limit future arms sales to Taiwan.   ''Nothing will change as a result of this communique,'' said Mr.  Lin, who runs a small electronics plant in Hsinchu, 40 miles south of here. ''And it was no surprise.''   Like many Taiwanese, Mr. Lin noted that the communique, which was released Tuesday, was simply further evidence of Taiwan's isolation from other governments, its need for self-reliance and the necessity of diversifying its arms supplies.

headline: THRIFT UNIT AID FALTERS IN SENATE
abstract: A bill that would provide Federal assistance to the nation's ailing savings institutions and broaden their powers faltered in the Senate today.   A meeting of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee to consider a 145-page draft of the bill, sponsored by Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, was abruptly canceled after the lawmakers disagreed over how broad the legislation should be. The disagreement developed after an alternative and far narrower measure surfaced.   The Garn measure would authorize Government-guaranteed promissory notes to bolster the net worth of ailing savings and loan associations and savings banks. The notes would be issued to a thrift institution if its net worth -the amount by which assets exceed liabilities - fell below a certain level. The notes could only be called if the institution actually failed.

headline: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GLOSSER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Tesoro Plans Stock Purchase
abstract: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it is offering to pay $22 a share for 4 million of its common shares. If more than 4 million shares are tendered, Tesoro, at its option, may purchase up to an additional million shares, it added.

headline: Buffalo Will Be Goldome Bank in '83
abstract: The Buffalo Savings Bank, the second largest in the nation, announced yesterday that it will change its name early next year to the Goldome Bank. The name represents the gold dome on the bank's headquarters building in downtown Buffalo.

headline: U.N. OFFICIAL ASSAILS KILLINGS IN LEBANON, NOT IN AFGHANISTAN
abstract: Imre Hollai of Hungary, the new President of the General Assembly, today discounted the Sovietinflicted deaths in Afghanistan but deplored the massacre in Beirut.   ''The killings in Aghanistan are largely exaggerated compared to what is happening in Lebanon,'' Mr. Hollai said at a news conference.

headline: Montedison-China Deal
abstract: Montedison, Italy's largest petrochemical group, said today that it had signed an agreement with the Shanghai Investment and Trust Corporation for joint ventures in China. Montedison exports fertilizers, chemicals and pharmaceuticals to China.

headline: McDonnell Order
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has been awarded a $421.4 million contract to start production of the first 12 AV-8B short-takeoff attack planes, the Navy announced. The Marine Corps plans to buy 340 of the planes.

headline: U.N. BODY AGAIN BIDS ISRAEL ADMIT CEASE FIRE MONITORS
abstract: The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to renew its demand that Israel permit United Nations officers to monitor the recurring cease-fires in Beirut.   The United States succeeded in softening some of the references to Israel's behavior and then joined the 14 other members in voting for the text.   Among other changes, the Americans persuaded the Council to voice ''serious concern about continued military activities'' in Beirut instead of singling out Israeli action.

headline: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HACKENSACK WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israeli Speaker Is Boycotted In Vienna Atom Agency Talks
abstract: Arab and African delegates to a nuclear conference, some wearing black mourning bands, walked out today when the head of the Israeli delegation stood to address the opening session.   Later all delegates to the annual conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency stood for a minute's silence to commemorate the massacre of Palestinians in West Beirut.   The weeklong conference, which coincides with the agency's 25th anniversary, will consider suspending Israel from the agency for not complying with a United Nations resolution demanding inspections of all Israeli nuclear installations.

headline: REGAN ASSERTS U.S. WILL SHARPLY EASE PIPELINE SANCTIONS
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration would sharply reduce the scope of sanctions it had applied against two French companies that shipped equipment to the Soviet Union for its natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.   In what would be a substantial easing of penalties imposed by the United States for indirect export of its technology, the sanctions would affect only oil and gas equipment and would no longer bar corporate violators from receiving any United States products.   In their ''original pristine form,'' Mr. Regan said at a briefing, the sanctions ''were a little too sweeping without giving the precise definition of what was meant.'' He said the modification he and other Administration officials had urged on President Reagan was not a relaxation but ''a clarification.''

headline: 4 'NEW JAPANS' MOUNTING INDUSTRIAL CHALLENGE
abstract: While the attention of the Western world has largely been taken up by the unarguable success of Japan, first in basic industries and increasingly in high technology, East Asian experts warn that Japan is simply the leading edge of a far broader economic challenge on the horizon.   That challenge centers in the growing economic might of the four ''new Japans,'' Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, all of which are moving out of labor-intensive industries, such as textiles, footwear and mundane electronics items, into higher-technology industries.   These states have modeled their industrial development policies after those of Japan. As Lee Kuan Yew, Prime Minister of Singapore, puts it: ''The Japanese have got it right.''   The inherent strengths of the five nations combined have led one of the believers in the area's future, Mike Mansfield, the United States Ambassador to Japan, to predict that the world is entering ''the century of the Pacific,'' and that this has far-reaching economic and strategic implications for the United States.

headline: Seemala Gains Giddings Stake
abstract: The Seemala Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission it had acquired 1,038,500 shares, or 10 percent, of the common stock of Giddings and Lewis Inc. in connection with risk arbitrage and other activities.   The stock was acquired on the open market between July 6 and July 19 for $28.3 million, it said. Based on the $30 a share that AMCA International Ltd. has agreed to pay for Giddings and Lewis, the holding can be sold for $31.2 million, for a profit of $2.9 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Ruston Faces Pemex Bribe Charge
abstract: The Justice Department filed criminal charges today against Ruston Gas Turbines Inc. of Houston in connection with a reported scheme to bribe officials of Mexico's state-owned oil company in exchange for contracts. The one-count Federal information was filed against the Texas subsidiary of Ruston Gas Turbines P.L.C., a British company,   No individuals were charged as defendants, although two former officials of Petroleos Mexicanos were named but not charged.

headline: TALCUM COMPANY CALLS STUDY ON CANCER LINK INCONCLUSIVE
abstract: A major talcum powder manufacturer, while criticizing a recent study linking the use of talcum powder by women to ovarian cancer, said it would further investigate any possible relationship between cosmetic-grade talc and the development of disease.   The study, published in the Aug. 15 issue of the journal Cancer, found that women who dusted their genitals and sanitary napkins with talcum powder were three times as likely to develop cancer as women who did not.   The cases studied involved 215 women diagnosed as having ovarian cancer in Boston hospitals from November 1978 to September 1981.  About 43 percent of the women said they dusted talc on their genitals or on sanitary napkins, s against about 28 percent of a control group of similar background, age and marital status who said they did not use talc.

headline: DOW EASES IN HEAVY VOLUME
abstract: With institutional investors making huge portfolio switches in the final session of the second quarter, New York Stock Exchange volume soared yesterday to 65.3 million shares, the heaviest turnover in nearly eight weeks. Many stock prices rose slightly.   ''It was a day dominated by portfolio switching and window dressing by institutions,'' stated Charles M. Lewis of Shearson/American Express Inc.

headline: PRIME RATE DECREASE MAY LAG
abstract: The prime lending rate is widely expected to decline later this year, but analysts said that problems in the banking system might keep this rate from falling as much as others.   The economic benefit of lower interest rates, the analysts said, will come largely in the bond market, where the sales of issues due in more than 10 years during July and August equals the total for all of 1981 and the first six months of this year. Sales of long-term bonds relieve companies from the pressure and risk of renewing shortterm borrowings frequently at interest rates that can fluctuate widely.   Because of fears that many troubled foreign borrowers and domestic companies will stop making interest payments, ''banks may be slower than normal to reduce the prime rate until the dimensions of the problem are better understood,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank.

headline: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HARVESTER TO SELL UNIT TO DRESSER INDUSTRIES
abstract: The International Harvester Company, continuing to pare down in its desperate bid for survival, said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its money-losing construction equipment business to Dresser Industries, a diversified supplier of industrial products and services.   Dresser is now caught in the middle of a dispute between the French Government and the Reagan Administration over the sale of equipment for the construction of the controversial gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.   The companies did not disclose terms of the sale, but Wall Street analysts said that Dresser would pay about $150 million in cash for the Harvester division. Cash-starved Harvester said the unit had assets of about $580 million, meaning the company would take a big write-off.

headline: Purchasers' Index Gains
abstract: The economy continued to decline in June, but at a slower pace than in May, according to the National Association of Purchasing Managers.  The association's index, which is based on a survey of new orders, production, employment, vendor performance and inventories, rose to 39.6 percent last month, somewhat better than the 35 percent performance in May, and about the same percentage set in April.

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLAND REINSTATES TIMES REPORTER   WARSAW, Aug. 25 (AP) - The Foreign Ministry restored the press credentials today of John Darnton, the Warsaw bureau chief of The New York Times.   Mr. Darnton won the 1981 Pulitzer Prize for foreign reporting during a long-term assignment here that ended in July.

headline: MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. IS 'EXTREMELY GRATIFIED' BY ISRAELI CABINET APPROVAL
abstract: The White House said today that it was ''extremely gratified'' by the Israeli Cabinet's approval of the evacuation plan for west Beirut and said that this ''sets the stage'' for the beginning of the withdrawal of Palestinian and Syrian forces as early as this weekend.   Last-minute details still have to be worked out, delaying at least until Friday a formal carrying out of the plan negotiated by Philip C. Habib, the special envoy.   Under the plan the United States, France and Italy are contributing troops to a force that will insure the evacuation. Today the Lebanese Government formally asked the three countries to participate.   President Reagan, who has already agreed in principle to the involvement of some 800 marines, is expected to make an announcement on Friday, informing Congress under the War Powers Act of their participation for about 30 days. The French and Italian Governments are supposed to issue similar statements. Until the force is established, the plan cannot go into effect, State Department officials said.

headline: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIRST BANKSHARES CORP SOUTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bayer Order Modified
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had modified a 1980 consent order so that Bayer A.G.'s Miles Laboratories would not have to divest itself of its American allergenic-extract business.

headline: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chicago Exchange Hires Wall St. Aide
abstract: William J. Brodsky, executive vice president for operations at the American Stock Exchange, is forsaking Wall Street for Chicago. He has been named chief operating officer and executive vice president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.   Mr. Brodsky, 38 years old, has spent his whole career on Wall Street, as has his father, Irwin Brodsky, a member of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields's legal department.

headline: Olin's Chlorine Price Up
abstract: The Olin Corporation has announced that it is increasing its off-list prices of chlorine by $30 a ton, effective immediately for spot customers and according to terms for contract customers.

headline: Carrier Seeks To Cut Flights
abstract: The Atlanta Express Airlines Corporation said it had applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to suspend 55 percent of its scheduled flights immediately.   It said that it needs immediate financing to continue operations and that it would continue to seek an operating agreement or business combination with other airlines.

headline: A DUTCH SHIP RESUMES DUMPING NUCLEAR WASTE OFF NORTHERN SPAIN
abstract: A Dutch freighter resumed dumping nuclear waste into the Atlantic Ocean north of Spain today despite a protest by environmentalists, who say high radioactivity has been measured near the crew quarters of the ship.   Radio reports from the Sirius, a ship of the Greenpeace environmentalist organization, said the freighter Scheldeborg dumped nuclear waste for the first time since a protestor narrowly escaped injury in an accident Sunday.   A Greenpeace spokesman in Amsterdam said readings for radioactivity were taken around the Scheldeborg from a rubber dinghy. She said a reading of 4.5 millirems per hour was registered in an aft hold next to the crew quarters. That meant, she said, that the crewmen had been exposed to more radioactivity in five days than is allowed civilians in one year under Dutch law.

headline: Commodities; Distortions Attract the Arbitrager
abstract: ARBITRAGE, one of the oldest methods of trading in commodities, is the most important of the random factors that influence prices in all futures markets. It helps keep markets liquid during dull periods and smoothes out the price peaks and valleys when they are volatile.   While arbitrage operations affect every futures trader's fortunes, few can participate in these lightning quick deals. At best, the average futures trader can only use the common form of arbitrage: the spread, also known as the straddle. Spreads have long been used by conservative futures traders who prefer to try to take what they consider to be limited risks, rather than face the much greater odds that attend taking ''straight'' positions in a commodity.

headline: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A HOUSE DIVIDED AGAINST ITSELF
abstract: The conservative movement in American has ''radicalized'' itself, and therein lie the seeds of its own demise, says Kevin T. Phillips in his new book, ''Post-Conservative America,'' published by Random House. The author, whose earlier writings foresaw the ascendency of the Republican party that culminated with President Reagan's 1980 election victory, says now that the contradictory and reactionary strains within Reaganism -supply-side economics and monetarism, among others - are a product of Republican politicians looking back in nostalgia for answers to present problems, rather than looking forward with a new vision.   An excerpt from his book is followed by a response from Paul Craig Roberts, a supply-side economist who resigned in February as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy. WHEN the first histories of the 1980's are written, the place of the radical transformation of c onservative economics will be as important as that of any other t ransformation - geographical, cultural or institutional. As the 1 970's opened, conservative economic theories were outsider credos b arely taken seriously by either the Republican Administration of R ichard Nixon or the business community; in 1981, monetarism, s upply-side economics and gold currency convertibility were r ecognized as the official economic theology of a new revolutionary c onservative government...

headline: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: McCoy Industries
abstract: McCoy Industries, a wood products manufacturer, said it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: A TAX INCREASE OF $99 BILLION VOTED IN SENATE
abstract: At the end of an all-night session that frayed tempers, the Senate early today passed the largest revenueraising bill ever approved by either house of Congress.   Over the next three fiscal years, the bill would recover for the Government $99 billion of the tax cuts that Congess approved a year ago. Those cuts, over a three-year period ending in the fiscal year 1985, were to total $435 billion, the largest ever enacted.   Before passing the bill at 4:48 A.M., the Senate adopted a surprise floor amendment that would halve the deductions that companies can take for business meals and entertainment other than that on overnight trips away from home.

headline: Tass Reports Polish Clashes
abstract: The Soviet Government's press agency, Tass, in its first report on Friday's clashes in Poland, said today that the disturbances had been caused by ''adventurist groups.'' The report was based on a Polish Interior Ministry statement.

headline: EQUATORIAL GUINEA APPROVES A LIBERAL CHARTER
abstract: Voters in Equatorial Guinea, a tiny West African country, have approved a Constitution that on paper is one of the most liberal in Africa.   The vote in this nation of 250,000 came three years after the execution of the dictator Nguema Masie Biyoto, formerly Francisco Macias Nguema. His 11-year rule was marked by random arrests, torture and executions.

headline: South African Bishop Warns Of 'Armageddon' for Blacks
abstract: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa said today that the plight of blacks in his country had worsened since the death of a jailed black activist five years ago.   The Anglican prelate, who was here to visit his daughter and her American husband, said the situation had become ''far worse'' since the death of the black, Steven Biko.   ''I'm afraid that unless something happens quickly, we may be faced with Armageddon,'' he said in an interview.

headline: Mobil Wins Round In Coastal Fight
abstract: In the latest ruling affecting a six-year-old battle between the Mobil Corporation and the Coastal Petroleum Company over mineral mining rights, a Florida court ruled that Coastal did not have the rights to phosphate that was mined by Mobil under its own leases from 14,755 acres that also fall under Coastal's 1941 minerals lease with the state.

headline: BLUE BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; The Bargains In Technology
abstract: IN better times, would-be investors in high-technology shares complain that the high price-earnings ratios commanded by the group dim hopes of stock market gains. But in this era of bargain prices, these issues are selling at lower multiples relative to growth prospects than other shares.   Yet, few investors seem to notice. A recent comment on investor attitudes during bear markets has particular relevance for the group. In the latest issue of ''The Shopping List,'' Oppenheimer & Company's Norman Weinger and E. Michael Metz write:   ''Equities are a unique commodity. Demand is stimulated by high and rising prices, while buyers virtually desert the bazaar'' when there are ''bargain sales at distress prices.''

headline: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DICKENSON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Holders Approve Takeover by Best
abstract: The Best Products Company, the nation's largest catalogue showroom retailer, said its accquisition of Modern Merchandising Inc. had been approved by the shareholders of both companies.

headline: ISRAELIS PRESSING FOR PEACE TREATY WITH THE LEBANESE
abstract: Israel has started to press President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon to move toward negotiating a formal peace treaty as a way of guaranteeing the security of the Israeli-Lebanese border.   Otherwise, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon has said, Israel would have to place southern Lebanon in ''a special status.'' He has not defined this term, but it is believed to mean control by a pro-Israeli Christian militia and possibly some Israeli military presence, at least in the form of periodic patrols.   ''If a future Lebanese government signs a peace treaty with Israel,'' the Defense Minister said Monday night, ''Lebanon will certainly be territorially united. But if there is a government in Lebanon that for any reason does not sign a treaty, then there will certainly be a special status in south Lebanon along the 40-kilometer security strip Israel needs.''

headline: THURSDAY, AUGUST 26, 1982; International
abstract: The Reagan Administration said that penalties would be applied if a French subsidiary of Dresser Industries went ahead with a shipment of compressors for use in a Siberian natural gas pipeline. However, the State Department sought to limit its retaliation to the Dresser-France subsidiary and to avoid a worsening of relations with the French Government. (Page A1.)   Mexico's financial crisis has led oil specialists to predict that the country will be forced to raise production to sharply higher levels, thus applying further downward pressure on world oil prices.  These analysts said Mexico's leaders may decide to raise exports by as much as 1.3 million barrels a day by 1985. (D1.)

headline: Mitsubishi Unit Posts a Loss
abstract: The Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company, citing higher operating expenses in a period of declining sales, said today that its loss in the six months ended June 30 more than tripled from its loss in the 1981 first half.   The chemicals concern said its first-half loss swelled to 9.18 billion yen from 2.88 billion yen in the first half of 1981.

headline: IT WILL HELP SAVE OUR AUTO INDUSTRY
abstract: Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars? Malcolm Baldrige and Douglas A. Fraser have often locked horns over issues of trade and industry. Again, the Commerce Secretary and president of the United Auto Workers union are at odds, this time over proposed legislation that would, in effect, require major foreign-car companies such as Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen, to make most of the vehicles for the American market in this country.   Proponents bill the legislation as a way to get the domestic auto industry moving again and stop the loss of jobs in the auto sector.  The Reagan Administration has raised the red flag of trade wars plus increased inflation if the local-content legislation is passed.

headline: Cooper Calls Off Talks
abstract: Cooper Industries said today that it had agreed to end talks on the possible purchase of the United Technologies Corporation's Elliott Company subsidiary. No reason was given.

headline: Technology; Computerized Job Matching
abstract: ACALIFORNIA entrepreneur, Tom A. Papke, is convinced that computers w ill soon play a much bigger role in show business. In early July, w orking with a staff of five salesmen from an office in his H ollywood condominium, he formed a new company called International C omputer Casting.   ''There's a great need to organize talent,'' Mr. Papke says. ''We intend to build an international computer network, or a kind of data base for the industry.''

headline: PATENTS; Electronic Card Game Developed by Rockwell
abstract: An electronic blackjack card game for hand-held operation was patented this week for the Rockwell International Corporation, El Segundo, Calif., a company better known for aerospace and automotive inventions.  Patent 4,339,134, granted Gary W. Macheel, describes a keyboard having keys for selection of playing decisions and the placement of bets in accordance with blackjack rules. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  To get a copy of a patent, send the number and 50 cents to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

headline: Market Place; Unlikely Way To Get Results
abstract: WHEN Michael B. O'Higgins isn't committed to money market funds or Treasury securities, his clients' $32 million is invested in stocks that are components of the Dow Jones industrial average. Unpromising as that investing strategy may seem, Mr. O'Higgins has used it to get an average annual return of 21 percent over the last four and a half years. This performance put Mr. O'Higgins among the top 10 percent of all money managers in the midyear A.G. Becker Institutional Funds Survey.   Mr. O'Higgins, who lives and works in Loudonville, a suburb of Albany, rarely journeys south to confer in Wall Street, and he doesn't envy the electronic equipment used by his peers there.  Operating out of his home with the help of a part-time secretary and a pencil instead of a computer, he uses cable television and its 15-minute delayed tape at $8.75 a month instead of a $400-a-month quote machine.

headline: Low Inflation in Japan
abstract: Japan had the world's lowest inflation rate last year, 4.7 percent, down from 7.1 percent in 1980, the International Labor Organization reported today. Argentina had the highest inflation, 131.3 percent, up from 87.6 percent.

headline: TURKISH DIPLOMAT IS SLAIN IN OTTAWA
abstract: A Turkish diplomat was shot and killed here today as he stopped his car at a light during the morning rush hour. Soon after the slaying a caller to the police in Montreal asserted that the killing was carried out under the orders of an Armenian nationalist group.   The Ottawa police said that, according to more than a dozen witnesses, a man appearing to be in his 30's left one of the cars backed up at a major intersection, walked to the car being driven by Col. Atilla Altikat, the Turkish military attache, and fired several shots through the front passenger window. The gunman fled after dropping his weapon, a Browning 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol, into the victim's car.

headline: Head of Troubled Mego Is Convicted of Fraud
abstract: The chairman of Mego International, a New York-based toy company in bankruptcy proceedings, was convicted yesterday on Federal charges that he had defrauded the company and its stockholders in transactions stemming from the sale of inventory.   Martin B. Abrams, 38 years old, was found guilty in United States District Court in Manhattan. The jurors had deliberated four days following a seven-week trial.

headline: Exxon and Tosco Sued
abstract: A California partnership, Parachute Joint Venture Ltd., has sued the Exxon Corporation and the Tosco Corporation for $58 million on charges that the energy companies misled it on the Colony shale oil project's future.

headline: SOCAL, SUN, CITIES SERVICE FALL
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits had plummeted 57.3 percent from a year earlier, the steepest decline reported by an American partner in the Arabian American Oil Company.   Socal, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, is more dependent on Saudi Arabian crude oil than its three Aramco partners, Exxon, Mobil and Texaco, which reported declines in second-quarter earnings of 51.5 percent, 55.7 percent and 45 percent, respectively.   Socal's earnings for the second quarter were $263 million, or 77 cents a share, down from $616 million, or $1.80, in the 1981 period.  The 1981 period was the second best in the company's history. The company's revenues declined 14.6 percent, to $9.37 billion, from $10.98 billion.

headline: Westinghouse Sets Sale of Lamp Units
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Westinghouse Lamp business to the North American Philips Corporation for $200 million in cash and notes.   The agreement involves 11 Westinghouse manufacturing plants - 10 in the United States and one in Mexico -that make light bulbs and fluorescent lights for consumers and industrial and automotive markets.

headline: Article 030428 -- No Title
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it lost $16.1 million in the second quarter of 1982 as a result of its dealings with a small New York securities firm and an Oklahoma City bank that failed.   The bank holding company also disclosed in a memorandum to its officers that it had reshuffled its senior management as a result of its transactions with the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City and Drysdale Government Securities Inc.   In the reorganization, an executive vice president and a senior vice president were asked to resign, another executive vice president was demoted, and resignations were accepted from seven lower-ranking officers. Assets of $77.8 Billion   It was the first time, at least in recent history, that one of the nation's 10 largest banks reported a quarterly loss. The Chase Manhattan Corporation, with total assets of $77.8 billion, is the third-largest banking organization in the United States, following the BankAmerica Corporation and Citicorp. It owns the Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third-largest bank.

headline: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES FEARS HAVE EBBED
abstract: For public-sector unions, 1982 has been a good deal less disappointing than many of their leaders gloomily expected last Labor Day.   At that time, many top unionists in all branches of the civil service feared that governors, mayors and agency heads, convinced that a ''get tough'' policy toward Government unions was a high road to acclaim from voters and taxpayers, might emulate President Reagan's firing of 11,400 striking Federal air traffic controllers, which ultimately led to their union's destruction.   These apprehensions have proved almost totally unfounded. No punitive spirit seems to be operating elsewhere in governmental employee relations. On the contrary, just three weeks ago, New York State's Public Employment Relations Board canceled, after only three months, an order barring automatic checkoff of union dues for a teachers' union that had struck illegally in 1975.

headline: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: American Woman Kidnapped in Salvador
abstract: An American woman and her father, one of El Salvador's most important industrialists, were kidnapped from their homes in the capital, relatives said today.   A United States Embassy spokesman said the mission was searching for Patricia Cuellar, 24 years old, who was born in Washington, lived in El Salvador most of her life and disappeared Tuesday.

headline: BELL: A VINDICATION OF OUR STAND
abstract: JUDGE HAROLD H. GREENE, in his ruling last week on the consent decree agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Department of Justice, has given further evidence that government policy is coming to terms - and to a common understanding -with the issues that must be resolved as the nation's vitally important telecommunications industry undergoes a technological and structural transformation.  In accepting the basic framework of the proposed decree as being ''plainly in the public interest,'' (within the definition of the Tunney Act) Judge Greene has affirmed the consensus that has slowly, sometimes painfully, emerged in recent years. It has seen pervasive regulation give way to competition as the preferred means of governing the telecommunications industry in this country.  The judge has attached conditions to his approval, suggesting modifications of the original agreement that would, in effect, relieve the local phone companies of some of the restrictions placed on them after divestiture from A.T.& T.  We will, naturally, discuss those modifications with the Justice Department, but as this is written, it is not possible to say whether they will, in the end, be acceptable to A.T.& T. or to Justice.

headline: Shift Is Fought on Oil Tax
abstract: Producers of Prudhoe Bay crude oil say a Congressional proposal seeking repeal of an adjustment under the ''windfall profits'' tax law relating to the tariff on oil shipments is discriminatory because they would be the only producers affected.   Oil company sources said the proposal would allow industry to assume all risk, with the Government siphoning all the profits.

headline: G.I. Is Killed in Maneuvers
abstract: An American soldier on maneuvers was killed today when he was hit by a swinging tank gun, the United States Army said. The soldier's name was withheld pending notification of next of kin.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * American Hospital Supply Corporation filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for as much as $400 million of debt securities.   * Applied Magnetics Corporation plans to buy up to 250,000 of its 5.2 million outstanding shares over the next six months.

headline: 2 Lionel Chiefs Are Replaced
abstract: The Lionel Corporation, the electronics parts manufacturer and toy retailer that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, has replaced its two top officers under pressure from creditors.

headline: 3 Koreans Dead in Typhoon
abstract: At least three South Koreans were killed and five were missing in heavy rains caused by a typhoon in the last two days, the police said today. Rain damaged more than 1,000 houses, leaving more than 5,000 people homeless.  Crops were flooded and roads and communications cut in the eastern part of the country.

headline: ADACORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EARNINGS FALL 51.5% AT EXXON
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, citing sharp losses in its European markets, reduced worldwide demand for petroleum products and a continuing oversupply of oil, said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter fell 51.5 percent from a year earlier.   Three other major oil companies, Texaco Inc., the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), also reported lower second-quarter earnings. Texaco said that its net income had fallen 45.1 percent, Indiana Standard reported a 30.9 percent drop and Sohio said its net income had declined 1.1 percent.   Exxon's earnings were its lowest for any quarter since the second quarter of 1979, when it reported net income of $830 million. For Texaco the results were the lowest since 1979's first quarter, when it earned $303.9 million.

headline: Boeing Jet Order
abstract: The Boeing Company said it had received an $88 milion order for four 727-200 planes from the Turkish airline Turk Hava Yollari. One of the aircraft was delivered last month, Boeing said, and the other three will be delivered by the end of September.

headline: French Spending Plan
abstract: The Industry Ministry has announced the way in which the 9.91 billion francs earmarked for French nationalized industries this year will be allocated. It said 2.4 billion francs would go to the steel sector, another 2.4 billion to Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A., 1.26 billion to Rhone-Poulenc S.A., 400 million to Cie Saint-Gobain S.A., 850 million to Cie Generale d'Electricite S.A., 600 million to Thomson-Brandt S.A., 850 million to CII-Honeywell Bull S.A., 600 million to CDF-Chimie S.A. and 200 million to Enterprise Miniere et Chimique S.A. The French franc is worth slightly less than 15 cents in United States money.

headline: CANADA OFFER BY CHRYSLER
abstract: (AP) - Chrysler Canada Ltd. is offering to sell its unprofitable spring plant and equipment to Local 444 of the United Automobile Workers for $1.   Workers said the offer was a trick to force acceptance of wage and benefit concessions and posted a 'Factory For Sale' sign outside one plant building.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * John Blair & Company to Needham, Harper & Steers/New York for Radio Stations WHDH and WCOZ, Boston.

headline: 2 Banks Seek Michigan Unit
abstract: A New York savings bank and a Michigan bank holding company today confirmed that they are bidding for Michigan's fourth-largest savings and loan association.   The institutions - the Erie Savings Bank of Buffalo and the Bloomfield Hills-based Michigan National Corporation -have submitted their offers to Federal regulators to acquire American Federal Savings and Loan Association, of Southfield, officials of both banks said.

headline: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Companies Merge Mobile-Phone Bid
abstract: The Graphic Scanning Corporation of Teaneck, N.J., said its subsidiary, Cellular Mobile Systems of Wisconsin Inc., had agreed with the Westel-Milwaukee Company to combine their competing proposals for establishing a cellular mobile telephone system in Milwaukee.

headline: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Honduran Soldiers Accused Of Abusing American Woman
abstract: An undisclosed number of Honduran soldiers and intelligence agents are under investigation for the reported assault of a 31-year-old American woman last month, an armed forces statement said Wednesday.   The woman, Cynthia Lee Morin, who is a refugee worker from Los Angeles, told the United States Embassy that she and a Guatemalan doctor, Augusto Giron Tovar, had been beaten by a military patrol near the Mayan ruins at Copan on the frontier with Guatemala.

headline: Japanese Cite Gains in U.S.
abstract: More than 70 percent of the Japanese manufacturing companies operating in the United States have reported doing brisk business despite the recession, a semiofficial trade promoting agency has disclosed.   A survey conducted in March by the agency, the Japan External Trade Organization, covered 167 Japanese companies out of 225 operating in the United States.

headline: Vatican Bank's Head Is Reported Resigning
abstract: An Italian newspaper said today that Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, the president of the Vatican Bank criticized for reported involvement with an Italian bank under investigation, has offered his resignation to Pope John Paul II.   Archbishop Marcinkus resigned from his bank post and from the presidency of the Pontifical Commission for the State of Vatican City, the Turin daily La Stampa said.

headline: Ambrosiano Shake-Up
abstract: Roberto Rosone, managing director of the Banco Ambrosiano, a Milan bank at the heart of an Italian financial scandal involving the Vatican, said today that he had received notice of dismissal from the three state-appointed commissioners running the bank, but that he intended to stay at his post. He was commenting on a report in a weekly magazine that said both he and the joint general manager, Filippo Leoni, had received dismissal letters and that Mr. Leoni had agreed to leave. Mr. Rosone said, ''My contract gives me the right to 12 months' notice.''

headline: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WALL STREET GOES INTERNATIONAL
abstract: F oreign investors are pumping money into the heart of this nation's financial center in amounts never seen before:   * A group of Arabs was so impressed with the way Smith Barney makes money - the ''old fashioned'' way - that it bought 25 percent of the old line Wall Street investment house.   * Oppenheimer & Company, an investment banking firm known for its bold deal making, has struck a deal that eventually will put it in the hands of a British financial conglomerate.   * Two major European investors have increased their stake in Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker Inc. and now own more than 50 percent of the New York securities firm.   The phenomenon, not entirely new, has intensified dramatically in recent months, and even in recent weeks. It is bringing fresh capital to a Wall Street where, many say, there is a crying need for it. And it is confirming what some believe is the inevitable internationalization not only of Wall Street, but of financial activities throughout the Western world.

headline: Technology; Cooling Air Efficiently
abstract: WITH the hot, humid days of midsummer upon us, and with offices and households using huge amounts of electricity to run their airconditioners, it may be wise to review the lessons learned during the energy crisis of 1974 and the conservation efforts that followed.    The lessons concern not only a new sense of discipline in energy use, but also an urgent need for more efficient machinery. Detroit has been hard pressed to produce more fuel-efficient cars, and the manufacturers of air-conditioning systems have faced an equally challenging problem.   Consider, for example, the Federal Government's order in 1979 that its office buildings across the country be heated to no more than 68 degrees in the winter and cooled to no lower than 78 degrees in the summer. Although the rule still applies, it has been widely judged a failure because of the inefficiency of the complicated air-treatment systems in large office buildings.

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARCO IS THE FIRST U.S. OIL CONCERN TO WIN OFFSHORE CHINA CONTRACT
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company today became the first American oil concern to win China's permission to start drilling for oil offshore.   A contract signed today, awarded in partnership with the Santa Fe International Corporation, covers a 3,500-square-mile block in the South China Sea just south of Hainan Island.   Qin Wencai, president of China's National Offshore Oil Corporation, signed the accord in the Great Hall of the People with Robert O. Anderson, Arco's chairman, and Paul Ravesies, president of Arco's international oil and gas subsidiary.   Arco holds an 80 percent interest in the concession and Santa Fe, a drilling and construction concern, holds 20 percent. This means that Arco will put up four-fifths of the costs in return for four-fifths of the foreign profits while Santa Fe will have the remaining onefifth. Both companies are based in Los Angeles.

headline: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OPEC SESSION FAILS TO REACH ACCORD ON CURBING OUTPUT
abstract: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a two-day meeting late tonight in disarray over how to hold down production and prevent prices from falling.   For the first time, a meeting of the 13-member cartel failed to reach any form of agreement. This meant that production limits that were in effect would now be voided, at least temporarily.   The loss of the limits raises the prospect of higher output from several OPEC members and the possibility of considerable downward pressure on oil prices. Experts declined to predict tonight whether the pressure would result in a broad price break.

headline: Iowa Paper Going Public
abstract: Shares in The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company will be sold on the open market for the first time, the paper reported today.   A letter to stockholders said that a brokerage firm, which was not identified, was expected to begin public trading in the stock later this month.

headline: SFN COS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SANTA FE DIRECTOR IN INSIDER TRADING AGREEMENT
abstract: A director of the Santa Fe International Corporation has agreed to return $278,750 in profits he had made from stock purchased in the company two weeks before it was taken over, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday.   The consent agreement, to a permanent injunction issued by United States District Court Judge William C. Connor in Manhattan, bars the director, Darius N. Keaton, from any future practices that violate Federal securities laws. In signing the decree, Mr. Keaton neither denied nor admitted the allegations.

headline: LOCAL PHONE UNITS ARE SEEN BENEFITING FROM MODIFICATIONS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's 22 local operating companies would retain some of their most basic businesses and customers would get a break on future rate increases if the changes requested by Judge Harold Greene yesterday in the proposed settlement of the antitrust suit against A.T.&T. go through.   Those were some of the early conclusions drawn by telephone industry analysts following Judge Greene's ruling, which asked for 10 modifications to the antitrust settlement announced Jan. 8 by the telephone company and the Justice Department.   The most significant changes for the Bell companies were three alterations that would most likely provide them with millions of dollars of additional revenues and help them hold down telephone rates, analysts said.   Under the changes, the units, to be divested under the antitrust settlement, would be allowed to keep the lucrative Yellow Pages business rather than cede it to A.T.&T., as the January settlement stated. They would also retain the right to market customer premise equipment - such as telephones and private switching systems - though they could not make the gear.

headline: Dexter to Shut Plant
abstract: The Dexter Lock Company, a 73-year-old door hardware manufacturer, is closing its Grand Rapids plant and consolidating the operation with an Auburn, Ala., facility, a plant official said today.

headline: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The 1982 Tax Law Second article of a series appearing periodically
abstract: In the Reagan Administration's hunt for new tax revenues, the average taxpayer was left relatively unscathed. But Congress did take aim at a few selected areas affecting individuals, and none was more controversial or bitterly opposed than extending tax withholding to interest and dividends.   These new withholding provisions will likely affect more tax returns than any other measure in the tax bill, but they are also relatively straightforward. Beginning next July 1, companies and financial institutions will be required to withhold 10 percent of interest and dividend payments to individuals, much as employers now withhold from paychecks. The new law also extends withholding to payments to pensioners.

headline: Careers; The Need For Water Managers
abstract: THE ponds, fountains and reflecting pools that are an increasingly prominent part of the urban landscape may be one pleasant precursor of what could be a major problem in the late 1980's - water.   Indeed, the vulnerability of water supplies has been dramatically illustrated in recent weeks. In Jersey City, for example, a water main break cut the supply to an entire urban population for several days while, in Lebanon, Israeli troops who control West Beirut's water supply have been able to interrupt the flow of water into that city at will.   And last year, in New York and many other areas throughout the Northeast, a serious drought led to depleted reservoirs and to water rationing for millions of residents.

headline: FEISTY NOVA SCOTIA READY FOR ITS SHIP TO COME IN
abstract: This staid old dowager of a city, which once grew rich as she pursued cod and Calvinism, is raising her skirts and prancing these days as large offshore gas deposits promise to reverse the recent decades of shabby gentility and poorcousin status within the Canadian union.   The prospect of restored fortunes is also placing new strains on the historically cool relations between the province and Ottawa, the seat of a nominally federated country.   Last week, the Mobil Corporation formally applied for Government permission to begin building a 183-mile pipeline to carry gas from its large find off the so-called Scotian shelf. That is the first of what are believed to be many rich fields off Sable Isand, a thin, menacing shoal off which for centuries ships have capsized and sunk.

headline: ISRAEL ASSERTS IT STILL PREFERS PEACEFUL OUTCOME IN BEIRUT
abstract: Israel assured the United States today that it continued to favor a diplomatic solution for the evacuation of Palestinian forces from Beirut.   Israel's military command declared that a new cease-fire went into effect at 5 P.M. today (11 A.M., New York time) after a day of the heaviest bombardment of Beirut since the Lebanese invasion began June 6.   Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in the course of the weekly Cabinet meeting, instructed Ambassador Moshe Arens to tell the United States Government of Israel's readiness to abide by a cease-fire. Israel attached ''the explicit condition'' that it be ''absolute and mutual.''

headline: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
