headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES * Arizona Chemical Co., Fairlawn, N.J., a joint venture of the American Cyanamid Company and the International Paper Company, has elected Donald E. Stiling president and chief executive officer, succeeding J.A. Schmidlein, who was appointed vice chairman until his retirement.
abstract: * Bankers Trust Co. announced the appointment of James M. Barry, Diane Berman, Joseph DiGrazia Jr., Andrew Gogates Jr., John Herron, Jeremy Hyland, Nigel Key, Gifford R. Lehman, Joseph J. Perticone, Christine L. Porter, John A. Rotante and Henry S. Wolff to vice president.   * John Bath & Co., Worcester, Mass., has named William W. Burnham vice president-sales.   * Big V Supermarkets Inc., Florida, N.Y., has named J.J. Madera Jr. vice president-real estate/general counsel.

headline: HUSSEIN SAYS THEY FOUGHT WELL
abstract: A group of 265 Palestinians, several of them carrying a large portrait of Yasir Arafat, stepped onto Jordanian soil today and were embraced by King Hussein.   ''You have held the flag high and fought well for your rights,'' the King told the Palestinians during a brief ceremony a military airport. ''It's still a long struggle, but we are sure of victory.''   The Palestinians, part of the first contingent of 397 guerrillas who left Lebanon by ferry on Saturday, arrived from Cyprus in two Boeing jetliners, a 707 and a 727, which were chartered by the Palestine Liberation Organization and the United Nations, according to one of the pilots. Another 707 took a group of Iraqi-based Palestine Liberation Army men, believed to number 132, directly to Iraq.

headline: BEGIN FAVORS EARLY VOTE TO TEST VIEWS ON U.S. PLAN
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that he favored early parliamentary elections to test the opposition Labor Party's assertions that the Israeli people supported President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.   Mr. Begin said the proposal, which his Government rejected, provided an ''opening move'' in a drive ''to unseat our Government.'' He made the statements in an interview with the army magazine Bamahaneh; excerpts were made public tonight by his office.  ''The American move was a familar tactic,'' Mr. Begin was quoted as saying. ''If anyone does not agree with Washington's current policy, it tries to get rid of him.''

headline: BUSINESS AND THE REAGAN PLAN
abstract: Executives at some of the nation's largest companies are finding President Reagan's economic program bitter medicine, but remain convinced that it is the country's best bet for a long-term cure of lingering economic ills.   Although many economists appear disillusioned with the program, and its practical benefits remain somewhat elusive, the executives said that they were inclined to stick with the plan, entering its second stage today. The economy would be even more likely to thrive, they said in interviews this week, if the President and Congress could reduce Federal deficits and bring down interest rates as a result.   ''If you're looking long term, I believe that Reagan's economic program is very, very good for the United States,'' said Jack F.  Reichert, president and chief executive of the Brunswick Corporation of Skokie, Ill., makers of recreational equipment and technical products. ''As painful as it is, in the long run, it is going to lead to a stronger industrial economy.''

headline: Pope Puts Opus Dei Society Under a Personal Appointee
abstract: Pope John Paul II will place Opus Dei, the Roman Catholic organization of priests and lay people, under the guidance of a priest whom the Pope will appoint, a Vatican spokesman announced today.

headline: P.L.O. TALKS RESUME ON DETAILS OF PLAN FOR WITHDRAWING
abstract: Israel's Defense Minister said he would accept a decision restricting military action in Beirut. Page 5.   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 13 - Negotiations on withdrawing the Palestine Liberation Organization from west Beirut resumed today.  The P.L.O. leadership sent the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, a list of the guerrillas to be pulled out and the Arab countries willing to accept them.

headline: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Texas Oil, Petrofina Sign Drilling Pact
abstract: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation and American Petrofina Inc. said they had signed a letter of intent yesterday to start a $136 million drilling and development program involving about 5.4 million net undeveloped acres of leaseholdings currently held by a subsidiary of Texas Oil.   Under the proposed agreement, which was to take effect Aug. 31, American Petrofina would acquire an undivided 25 percent interest in most of the acreage held by Texas Oil for five cash payments totaling $136 million over four years, with the latter payments dependent on achieving certain performance goals.

headline: REAGAN OUTLINES HIS STAND ON JEWISH SETTLEMENTS
abstract: The United States has told Israel and Arab countries privately that although it wants a freeze on new Israeli settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, it will oppose any Arab efforts to dismantle the existing Jewish settlements.   In a previously unpublished list of American ''talking points'' conveyed to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and some Arab leaders before President Reagan's speech on the Middle East last week, the United States further declared that it would not alter its refusal to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization until the P.L.O. met the often-stated American conditions that it recognize Israel's right to exist and Security Council Resolutions 242 of 1967 and 338 of 1973.   The Israeli Government has expressed strong opposition both to points made in Mr. Reagan's speech and to some of the specific ideas not mentioned in the President's speech but conveyed by Ambassador Samuel W. Lewis to Mr. Begin privately.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHRYSLER LOAN BID IN JAPAN REPORTED
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been unable to borrow from private financial institutions since its brush with bankruptcy, is apparently seeking financing in Japan, with the assistance of the United States Government.   An article published in the Aug. 24 issue of the Japan Economic Journal, an English-language version of a leading Japanese business newspaper, reported that Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, had requested that the Japanese Government provide the company with $300 million to $500 million in export financing.

headline: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 10
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Gemayel Said to Plan U.S. Trip To Visit U.N. and See Reagan
abstract: The Lebanese television said today that President Amin Gemayel was expected to go to New York sometime next month to address the United Nations General Assembly.   It attributed the report to informed sources and quoted them as saying Mr. Gemayel would also go to Washington for talks with President Reagan.   The report said President Gemayel would stop in Paris to confer with President Francois Mitterrand and on his return trip from the United States would visit Pope John Paul II at the Vatican.

headline: U.S. PUSHES TO GET CUBANS OUT OF ANGOLA
abstract: The United States has sent a high-ranking State Department official to Angola in a renewed effort to bring about the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola -the key remaining problem holding up an agreement on the independence of South-West Africa, State Department officials said today.   The mission to Angola followed earlier unpublicized discussions in Geneva last Monday by high-ranking United States and Soviet officials on southern Africa, officials said.   The talks in Geneva and the mission to Angola were not directly related, officials said. But they said that both were crucial with negotiations intensifying on producing a long-sought agreement for ending South Africa's control over South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.

headline: Airline Heads Open Talks
abstract: Top executives from 60 airlines opened emergency talks here today to consider ways of fighting growing losses, high interest rates and reduced-price ticket sales.   Faced with estimated losses of $1.87 billion this year, participants at the two-day meeting will review possible fare increases, ways to cut operating costs and steps to restrict ticket discounting, which reduces airline earnings.

headline: ALMY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: A Different Response   What a difference three months makes. Last May, the collapse of Drysdale Government Securities sent tremors through the credit markets and sent interest rates higher. Response to the latest crack in an increasingly leaky financial system - the failure of Lombard-Wall Inc. - has been altogether different, as key rates declined. And analysts say further reductions are likely.   Slowly but surely, short-term credit demand is beginning to ease.  In the past month, the volume of business loans has risen by 9.7 percent, far below the average 19.1 percent increase of the first half of the year.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S SICK ECONOMY
abstract: Less than two years after attaining one of the highest economic growth rates in the world, South Africa is bracing itself for its deepest recession since the 1930's.   The slump in the price of gold, which edged below $300 an ounce in late June and has since recovered to only about $310, is the latest in a series of punishing blows for the South African economy. Gold accounts for almost half of the nation's export earnings, and the mines - which produce more than 70 percent of the gold mined in the non-Communist world -are by far the largest single source of Government tax revenues.   Other key exports, such as diamonds, manganese and sugar, are also in the doldrums, while drought has wilted a third of the corn crop, South Africa's most important farm commodity.

headline: Turkish Socialist Gets Two Months in Jail
abstract: A Turkish military court sentenced former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit to two months and 27 days in jail today for an article he had written for the West German weekly magazine Der Spiegel and an interview he had given to Dutch television.   He was accused of violating a decree of Turkey's ruling military junta that bans all former politicians from making political statements and commenting on the past, present and future of Turkey.

headline: Liberian Expects French Aid
abstract: The Liberian head of Government, Samuel K. Doe, said today after conferring with President Francois Mitterrand that he had obtained French economic aid for Liberia.  ''We now hope to receive aid from France very soon,'' he said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Life Insurance Co., Wilmington, Del., a subsidiary of American International Group, has appointed Richard M. Frantz vice president for investments.   * Applied Devices Corp., Palm Beach, Fla., has elected to its board Alfred diScipio, Martin Dubilier and Malcolm K. Fleschner.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American High Speed Rail Corp. said it had retained First Boston Corp. as its financial adviser in arranging a $2 billion financing for the construction of the first high-speed railroad in the United States.   * Clevepak Corp. of White Plains said about 990,000 Torin Corp.  shares, or about 96 percent, had been validly tendered under its recent merger offer.   * Energy Clinic Corp. of Concord, Calif., said its shareholders had approved acquisition of the company's assets and continuing business by Servamatic Solar Systems Inc.

headline: Pope to Meet Arafat, Vatican Aide Reports
abstract: Pope John Paul II will meet Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, next week, the Vatican confirmed today.

headline: AFTERMATH AT PENN SQUARE
abstract: ''I was in the oilfields 10 years ago when banks were failing,'' said Howard Bottger, an oilfield worker, standing in line with hundreds of other depositors of the failed Penn Square Bank here.   Another depositor, Othel Griffis, said: ''That was horrible then. A lot of people were jumping out of windows, but I lived in a rural area and the banks took care of people through the back door.''

headline: IRANIAN ARMY POISED FOR INVASION OF IRAQ, U.S. OFFICIALS ASSERT
abstract: Administration officials said today that large numbers of Iranian troops had moved close to the Iraqi border and might invade in the next few days.   Based on intelligence information reaching Washington, the officials said, many Iranian divisions are poised to attack the Iraqi port of Basra. The officials said that they were uncertain, however, whether Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had made the political decision to launch the attack.

headline: Technology; Preserving Memories
abstract: IMAGINE how much less useful tape recorders would be if the tape were automatically erased every time the recorder was turned off.  This has been the case with computer memory chips: Most computer memory chips lose their memory when the computer is turned off or when there is a sudden loss of power. There are chips that are like record albums and can store information permanently, but, like records, that information cannot be changed.   Now, however, new memory chips are emerging that are both alterable and able to retain information without electrical power.  The chips, the silicon equivalents of tape recorders, promise to open up vast new applications.

headline: OPEC IS SAID TO PLAN FRIDAY PARLEY ON OUTPUT
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency ministers' meeting in Vienna on Friday to review its oil output ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day, a senior Oil Ministry official here said today.   The ministers also were expected to discuss demands by Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states that African members of OPEC raise the price of their high-quality crude oil by at least $1.50 a barrel, the oil industry weekly Middle East Economic Survey said.   The ceiling, under which OPEC's 13 members were assigned individual quotas, was imposed in March to defend the group's base price of $34 a barrel in the face of the world's severest oil glut.

headline: Papua New Guinea Gets Former Leader Back
abstract: Michael Somare, Papua New Guinea's first Prime Minister, returned to office today after two and a half years in opposition.

headline: Colonial Sets Property Accord
abstract: The Colonial Commercial Corportion, which filed in May for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it had resolved litigation with Transexpo Inc. and the King International Corporation.

headline: Japan Plans to Increase Its Purchases of Arms
abstract: The Japanese Cabinet announced today a new fiveyear plan for arms purchases in the next five years that is higher than current spending but appears unlikely to satisfy the United States.   The new program calls for at least $17.6 billion in spending on weapons from 1983 to 1987, an increase of more than 60 percent over the 1978-82 expenditure of about $10.8 billion.

headline: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AT THE FRONT, P.L.O. DIGS IN FOR BIG BATTLE
abstract: Yasir Arafat was out touring the Palestine Liberation Organization's front-line bunker recently when one of the fighters leaning behind a red dirt barricade asked him whether it was true that the P.L.O. was withdrawing from Beirut.   ''What do you think?'' Mr. Arafat replied.  ''I think that if you order us to withdraw I will shoot you with this gun,'' the guerrilla said. Guerrillas Are Not Optimistic   Mr. Arafat chuckled. But the conversation summed up one of his big problems: how to negotiate a withdrawal of the P.L.O. from Lebanon that could be sold to his fighters as a victory.

headline: Telecom in Trinidad
abstract: A subsidiary of Northern Telecom Ltd.  won a contract to upgrade and expand the Trinidad and Tobago telephone network, the company said today. The first phase covers installation of equipment in the Port of Spain area.

headline: RCA Videodisks
abstract: The RCA Corporation said today that it was accelerating an expansion program at its Indianapolis videodisk plant because of the strength of the market. RCA said videodisk owners who have had their sets for more than 12 months have accumulated an average of 32 disks each.

headline: Fluor Quarter Profit Up 87%
abstract: The Fluor Corporation said today that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose 87 percent from a year earlier on a 27 percent gain in revenue.

headline: Severance Pacts Halted at Burnup
abstract: Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, has won a temporary court order blocking 17 executives of Burnup & Sims Inc. from bailing out with hefty ''golden parachute'' severance agreements because of his move to control the company.   For several years Summit Systems, a subsidiary of Mr. Posner's Sharon Steel Corporation, held 25 percent of the stock of Burnup & Sims, a Fort Lauderdale-area telecommunications and soft drink conglomerate.

headline: HABIB IS WORKING TO COMPLETE PACT ON P.L.O. PULLOUT
abstract: Jordanians have mixed emotions about the prospect of receiving Palestinian fighters. Page A15.   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17 - Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, sought today to complete an agreement for evacuating Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut, but officials involved in the talks said at least one more day might be required for an accord.    Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon indicated that the remaining differences could be worked out tonight or early Wednesday before a meeting of the Lebanese Cabinet. At the meeting the Cabinet may set a withdrawal date and ask for French, American and Italian troops to oversee the evacuation of Palestinian and Syrian forces from west Beirut.

headline: I.T.T. UNIT INVOLVED IN IRAN EMBARGO INQUIRY
abstract: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it had begun an investigation into charges that the Blackburn division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation circumvented the 1980 embargo against trade with Iran by shipping electrical equipment to that country during the hostage crisis.   A Treasury spokesman, Robert Levine, said the investigation was ordered after officials of I.T.T.'s Washington office presented the department on Wednesday with documents containing evidence of a violation of the embargo.   Mr. Levine added that the investigation, conducted by the department's foreign assets control division, was being coordinated with an internal investigation by I.T.T. itself. If officials of the Blackburn division, based in St. Louis, are found to have violated the embargo, he added, they could face prosecution and maximum penalties of 10-year prison terms and $50,000 fines.

headline: A California Retailer Expands Into Banking
abstract: Customers browsing through the bedroom sets and living room displays in Richard A. McMahan's California furniture stores soon will find something unexpected - bank tellers and loan officers of the newly founded Western Family Bank.   ''Over 35 years in the business, I've seen our customers use other financial institutions to make purchases,'' said Mr. McMahan, 56, president of the family-owned furniture company.

headline: Irish Government Wins A Vote of Confidence
abstract: The Irish Republic's four-month-old minority government won a crucial vote of confidence in Parliament today and defeated an attempt to force the second general election this year.

headline: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

headline: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; TROUBLE AT THE FLAT EARTH SOCIETY
abstract: (The following is an abbreviated version of the address delivered to the Flat Earth Society by the chairman of the Navigational Reserve System.) FLAT EARTH delegates, welcome. We are witnessing troubled times in t he steerage of our nation. Profound intellectual confusion a ccompanies increasing disruption of the communications network. The b urden of tolls and traffic rules is growing; accidents are on the i ncrease; fundamental navigational principles are being challenged.

headline: COLLAPSE OF WALL ST. CONCERN STIRS STUDY OF STATE AGENCIES' INVESTING
abstract: The collapse of a small government-securities concern has set off a wide re-examination of how New York State agencies should invest cash they have on hand.   The State Comptroller's office said yesterday it was considering the establishment of uniform guidelines for the state's authorities.  Until now, the different authorities have decided on their investment practices independently of the state, as they are empowered to do.   At the same time, the State Dormitory Authority said it had established a new, stricter policy of its own. That agency lent nearly $300 million of its excess cash to the concern that entered bankruptcy proceedings last week, Lombard Wall Money Markets Inc. The concern is a subsidiary of Lombard Wall Inc., which also filed bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Henry Ford 2d Retires Oct.1
abstract: Henry Ford 2d, former Ford Motor Company chairman, will retire Oct. 1 as an employee and officer of the auto maker that carries his name but will remain on the company's board of directors and serve as a consultant, Philip Caldwell, chairman, announced today.   Mr. Ford, who reached the usual retirement age of 65 on Sept. 4, retired as chairman in March 1980.

headline: Pan Am Benefits
abstract: Pan American World Airways announced it had sold $14 million worth of tax benefits on three Boeing 727-221 aircraft on which it took delivery in April. Pan Am did not disclose the name of the buyer or provide other details of the transaction, which occurred June 30.

headline: REAGAN PLANS TO TELL CONGRESS ISRAEL MAY HAVE VIOLATED ARMS RESTRICTIONS
abstract: The Reagan Administration plans to inform Congress in the next day or so that it has determined that Israel might have violated its arms agreements with the United States by using American-made military equipment during its invasion of Lebanon, Administration officials and Congressional sources said today.   Under the Arms Export Control Act, the Administration has the authority to suspend all military aid to Israel if it is found to be in substantial violation of a 1952 military assistance agreement.   But two State Department officials, in a closed meeting with a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, reportedly said today that there was no inclination to halt military shipments to Israel.

headline: Harvester Asks More Loan Aid
abstract: Top officers of the International Harvester Company asked its lenders today for more concessions in paying off its $4.2 billion debt to help keeping the giant farm implement concern going.

headline: Market Place; How Analysts Regard Exxon
abstract: SHARES of the Exxon Corporation traded yesterday at 26 1/8, their lowest price in more than two years, before finishing at 26 1/2, unchanged for the session, in heavy trading. Apparently several analysts' reduced estimates of Exxon earnings have affected the stock.   At its annual dividend rate of $3 a share, the world's largest oil enterprise provides a yield exceeding 11 percent. Exxon, notes Merrill Lynch, ''offers the highest yield of any oil company.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Soars in Tokyo, But Retreats Elsewhere   (By The Associated Press) - The value of the American dollar rose sharply in Tokyo yesterday, reaching nearly a five-year peak in relation to the Japanese yen.  Later, it retreated in Europe and the United States as American interest rates plunged.  Gold fell slightly in Europe but later rallied for a gain of 50 cents an ounce in United States trading.  Currency dealers in Tokyo said traders were worried about the financial crisis in Mexico and by developments in the Middle East.

headline: Fluor Is Awarded A $200 Million Job
abstract: The Fluor Corporation said it had won a $200 million contract from the Atlantic Richfield Company's subsidiary in Dubai, the United Arab Emirates, for the first phase of an oil and gas processing plant in the Margham field.

headline: HARRIED SOVIET RIGHTS UNIT DISBANDS
abstract: A group of Soviet dissidents that monitored Soviet violations of human rights announced today that it was disbanding because of arrests and deportations.   ''Document 195'' announcing the end of the so-called Helsinki group was given to reporters by Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D.  Sakharov, the physicist, along with a statement that the authorities were preparing to charge Sofiya V. Kallistratova, a 75-year-old lawyer, with spreading slander against the Soviet state.   Miss Bonner, Miss Kallistratova and Naum Meiman, a 70-year-old physicist barred from emigrating, were the last active members of a group that in its heyday in the late 1970's was the spearhead of the Soviet rights movement.   The Moscow group to Promote Observance of the Helsinki Agreements in the U.S.S.R., as the group styled itself, issued a stream of statements reporting on rights violations, law abuses, trials of political activists and world affairs.

headline: Purex Merger Is Approved
abstract: Shareholders of Purex Industries approved the merger of Purex into a new privately held corporation known as Purex Industries Inc.  organized by the investment banking firm of Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen Ltd.

headline: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION FALLS 0.5%
abstract: Industrial production dropped five-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today, reflecting the continuing decline in the economy and signaling a delay in the longpromised recovery until late fall or early winter.   ''The recovery may be in sight, but we don't have evidence that the turning point has been reached,'' said Theodore Torda, the senior economist in the Commerce Department. ''The recovery has been postponed to the fourth quarter.''   The Reagan Administration, hoping for a rebound by the crucial offyear Congressional elections, had promised a strong recovery in the second quarter and, when that did not materialize, a recovery in the third quarter. Just last week in Kansas, President Reagan said, ''Yes, the recovery has been sighted.'' And Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has predicted that there would be relatively strong growth this quarter. But today Mr. Torda said ''you can flip a coin'' over whether the third quarter will show a small minus or a small plus.  The White House had no official comment.

headline: Du Pont Delaying Salary Increases
abstract: The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would delay salary increases another three months, beginning in August, for management and professional employees.

headline: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE EDSEL: REQUIEM FOR A FLOP
abstract: Twenty-five years ago today, after a drumbeat of hoopla and fanfare unmatched in the history of the auto industry, Ford introduced the Edsel.   It was more than a new car: It was to be an entire division of the Ford Motor Company. It was an attempt by Ford to move into the uppermiddle-class market, to steal away some of the buyers of the Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs that had given General Motors a competitive edge since the 1920's.

headline: Fifth Man Guilty In Seychelles Plot
abstract: A South African who said he was an intelligence agent for the South African Government was found guilty of treason today in connection with last year's bungled coup in the Seychelles and will learn Tuesday if he will hang or go to jail.

headline: Thais Say Vietnamese Pulled Back in Cambodia
abstract: Vietnamese forces in Cambodia abandoned their forward positions near the Thai border early this month, Thai military sources said today.

headline: JUDGE CANNOT SCRUTINIZE I.B.M. CASE, COURT SAYS
abstract: A Federal appeals panel barred a judge yesterday from inquiring into the dismissal of an antitrust suit that the Justice Department had filed against the International Business Machines Corporation.   The ruling blocked United States District Judge David N. Edelstein, whom I.B.M. had accused of bias, from deciding whether hearings should be held to study the effect of dropping the case.   ''Judge Edelstein has abused his power by continuing a lawsuit which the parties have sought eagerly to dismiss,'' the opinion by the Second United States Court of Appeals said.

headline: SATURDAY, AUGUST 7, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The unemployment rate rose in July to 9.8 percent of the labor force, a postwar record, the Labor Department reported. Overall employment held steady at 99,732,000, but an additional 360,000 workers went onto the jobless rolls, bringing the total to 10.8 million. The sharp rise in July followed two months in which the rate remained steady at 9.5 percent. (Page 1.) The jobless rate in New York City fell to 9.7 percent. (44.)   The battle over the tax bill intensified, prompting President Reagan to postpone a two-week California vacation so he could be on the scene to press for passage. His decision came as conservative Republicans and portions of the business community indicated they would seek to kill the bill. (33.)

headline: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. CALLS ISRAELI ACT A 'VIOLATION' AND DEMANDS IMMEDIATE PULLOUT
abstract: The United States demanded today that Israel withdraw its military forces from west Beirut immediately. It charged that the entry of the troops was a ''clear violation'' of the ceasefire agreement negotiated last month.   The Reagan Administration said the Israeli military takeover in west Beirut was also ''contrary to assurances'' given by Israel to the United States on Wednesday.   The Israeli Cabinet said tonight that the troops would remain in west Beirut until the Lebanese Army was able to insure security in the city.

headline: SALES GAIN
abstract: Volkswagenwerk, Western Europe's largest German auto maker, reported today that net income for the first half of the year fell 4 percent, to 100 million marks, or about $40.5 million, from 104 million marks, or about $42.2 million, a year earlier. Sales for the period rose 16.5 percent, to 15.5 billion marks, which is approximately $6.28 billion, from 13.3 billion marks, or about $5.39 billion, in the 1981 first half.  Percentage changes are calculated from United States dollars.

headline: SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS RISE BY 7.4%
abstract: About 36 million retired Social Security recipients will join the nation's working population this week in receiving fatter checks, when their inflation-indexed benefits rise 7.4 percent. The cost-of-living adjustments will cost the hardpressed Social Security Administration $11.3 billion in the coming fiscal year.   Beginning Thursday, the maximum benefit for a single worker retiring at age 65 will increase to $729 a month, from $679. The maximum benefit for a couple consisting of a worker retiring in 1982 and a nonworking spouse goes to $1,093, from $1,018.

headline: United Carolina
abstract: The United Carolina Bancshares Corporation of Whiteville, N.C., said it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from the First Union Corporation totaling $86 million in stock, cash and notes. The bank said it would review the offer.

headline: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Soviet Honors East German
abstract: The Soviet Union today awarded the East German leader, Erich Honecker, the title of Hero of the Soviet Union, Moscow's highest state honor, to mark his 70th birthday Wednesday. In a personal message of greetings, President Leonid I.  Brezhnev described him as a sincere friend of the Soviet Union who had made a big personal contribution to strengthening friendship and cooperation between peoples of the two countries.

headline: Paris Postpones Talks On Nuclear Fuel for India
abstract: The French Foreign Ministry said today that talks with India on the delivery of fuel for India's nuclear power plants had been postponed indefinitely, apparently because of disagreement over appropriate safeguards.

headline: Bonn to Back AEG Loans
abstract: The West German Government announced today that it had decided to guarantee up to $440 million in new bank loans to insolvent AEG-Telefunken A.G.   Otto Lambsdorff, Economics Minister, said the Cabinet ''took note with approval'' of the decision by the Economics and Finance Ministries to assist AEG, which is West Germany's second-largest producer of electrical and electronic products.   The company announced in early August that it did not have enough cash to meet its obligations and petitioned to have the courts supervise a restructuring of its operations.

headline: Southern Pacific
abstract: The Southern Pacific Company said that it would lay off 1,200 railroad employees in the next month because of a decline in its railroad operations. It said that railroad loadings for the most recent four weeks were down 17.6 percent from a year ago, and that it expected business to continue at a low level for the rest of the year because of the recession. The layoffs will be spread across its 14-state territory, Southern Pacific said.

headline: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mao's Widow Expected To Get Sentence Eased
abstract: Chairman Hu Yaobang of the Chinese Commuinist Party said today that he expects a court to reduce the death sentence of Mao's widow, Jiang Qing, when it comes up for review early next year.   Chairman Hu told French journalists that Miss Jiang's two years' of imprisonment on charges of persecution and political intrigue had not softened her attitude and she remained an ''enemy of the people.''

headline: U.S. IRKED AS ISRAEL SEEMS TO BALK AT PULLOUT OF TROOPS FROM BEIRUT
abstract: Despite Israel's consent today to the landing of American, Italian and French forces in Beirut, Administration officials expressed irritation at Israel's seeming refusal to agree to President Reagan's demand for an immediate withdrawal of its troops from Beirut.   The Israeli Cabinet action, in not posing any objection to the three-nation force re-entering the Lebanese capital, allowed plans to go ahead for its landing later this week, the State Department said.   But White House and State Department officials said that the Administration remained concerned that the Israelis had avoided giving a clear-cut statement on when Israeli forces would be withdrawn.   Meanwhile, the decision by the Israeli Cabinet against a special inquiry into the Beirut massacre fueled Congressional criticism of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government and reduced prospects for previously proposed increases in American aid. (Page A16.)

headline: APPLE IS UP 27.7%
abstract: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a slight gain in secondquarter earnings, based partly on improved performance at its NBC and Hertz units. Analysts said the results were slightly better than expected and somewhat encouraging for the problem-plagued company.   Earnings for the three months rose 2.5 percent, to $60.5 million, or 58 cents a share, from $59 million, or 56 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues climbed 5.1 percent, to $2.06 billion from $1.96 billion.

headline: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT VW OF AMERICA
abstract: James W. McLernon resigned as president and chief executive officer of Volkswagen of America today, apparently as a result of the company's severely depressed sales.   Mr. McLernon, whose background is mostly in manufacturing, will be succeeded by Noel Phillips, who was VW of America's executive vice president for sales and marketing from 1978 to 1980. Mr. Phillips, a native of South Africa, is currently managing director of the McCarthy Group, an automotive products company in South Africa.   No reason was given for the resignation of Mr. McLernon, who is 55 years old. A statement said Mr. McLernon ''gave no indication of his future plans.'' He was not available for comment.

headline: FOREIGN POLICY ISSUES MAY AFFECT OUTCOME OF SOME FALL RACES
abstract: Politicians typically say foreign policy does not swing Congressional elections nationwide, and this year is no exception. But there are about a dozen races for the House of Representatives and at least one for the Senate where such issues as a freeze on nuclear weapons and rising military spending could tip the balance.   Moreover, three Republican Representatives, including Robert H.  Michel, the House minority leader, have been put on the defensive in central Illinois because of the job losses caused by another foreign policy issue - President Reagan's embargo on the sale of American equipment for the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.   And the President's new Middle East peace proposal could develop into a touchy campaign issue for Republican incumbents in a few heavily Jewish districts if it causes sustained tensions with Israel.

headline: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Portec Chairman Pushes Factories of the Future
abstract: Just as the world is growing accustomed to the high-technology ''office of the future,'' Thomas J. Guendel, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based Portec Inc., is among those trying to push the factory of the future.   ''Automated factories are already commonplace in Europe,'' said the 55-year-old Mr. Guendel.

headline: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PLANE MAKERS PROTEST BRAZIL IMPORT
abstract: American makers of commuter aircraft have squared off against a Brazilian manufacturer, saying that they will charge before the International Trade Commission on Wednesday that the Brazilian Government unfairly subsidizes a popular 18-seat turboprop plane for export to the United States.   The Swearingen Corporation, a subsidiary of Fairchild Industries, is the chief spokesman for the American case. The Brazilian company is Embraer of Brazil, maker of the Bandeirante plane. Langhorne Bond, former chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, represents the Brazilians.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: South African officials are the soul of modesty when asked how the question of removing Cuban troops from Angola has come to be the final and crucial issue determining whether the drawn-out Western effort to achieve a settlement in South-West Africa will finally succeed. The credit should not go to them, they say, but to the Reagan Administration.   The question of a Cuban withdrawal was never an issue in the seemingly interminable negotiations that South Africa held with five Western nations for four years, starting in 1977, over the future of the territory.   It remained in the background, as far as the South Africans were concerned, until June of last year when William P. Clark, who was then Deputy Secretary of State, visited here.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Modern Money Management
abstract: DURING the bear market of the early 1970's, money managers were pleased if they ''outperformed'' the stock market, even if they lost, say, a third of client assets, so long as prices overall were down more.   These days aggressive money managers don't crow unless their performance exceeds the remarkable returns available in money market instruments in this time of high interest rates. That's because clients can equal those returns by buying those securities directly.

headline: P.L.O. HEARS DETAILS OF MASSACRE AND VOWS GREATER STRUGGLE
abstract: The 47-member executive council of the Palestine Liberation Organization, after hearing what it called ''detailed reports'' on the massacre of civilians in Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut, vowed today to ''intensify its armed struggle in the occupied Palestinian and Arab territories.''   The council, which ended a one-day session last night, also said the P.L.O. would ''punish'' those who committed the killings, which have been attributed to Lebanese Christian militiamen.   In a communique issued here this morning, the council endorsed the decisions of the Arab League conference in Fez, Morocco, that put forward an eight-point program for an overall Middle East settlement.    The communique said the Arab League decisions were not in conflict with past positions of the P.L.O., and it stressed that the Arab leaders had confirmed that the organization was the sole representative of the Palestinian people.

headline: Around the World; Somali-Ethiopian Battle Reported to Continue
abstract: Fighting appeared to be continuing along Somalia's border with Ethiopia today despite Somalia's assertion that it had beaten back an invasion force after two weeks of fighting.   The official Somali press agency said Somali gunners shot down one of eight Soviet-made MIG fighters today that had attacked Galcaio, capital of Mudug region, where much of the fighting has taken place.

headline: THRIFT UNIT REGULATOR SUSPENDED
abstract: The top regulator of California's savings and loan industry was suspended late Wednesday, eight days before she planned to encourage the Federal Reserve Board to block Citicorp's plan to acquire a major California thrift unit.   The regulator, Linda Tsao Yang, was ordered this morning by Lynn Schenk, California's Secretary of Business, Transportation and Housing, to work solely in her Sacramento office ''until further notice.''   The night before, Miss Schenk notified Mrs. Yang in a one-sentence memo that she was assuming all of Mrs. Yang's duties as commissioner of California's department of savings and loans, Mrs. Yang said today in an interview.

headline: Bank Tie Rejected
abstract: The First National Bank at Lubbock said its stockholders had rejected the bank's proposed acquisition by the Mercantile Texas Corporation. The vote of 62 percent favoring the merger fell short of the two-thirds vote required for approval, the bank said.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LONDON CUTS CURBS AROUND FALKLANDS
abstract: Britain eased its 200-mile sea and air blockade around the Falkland Islands today, asking Argentina to keep its warships and military aircraft at least 150 miles away to reduce ''misunderstandings or inadvertent clashes.''   The blockade was imposed a few days after Britain ordered a large task force to the South Atlantic to challenge Argentina's invasion of the islands. It was later extended to within 12 miles of the Argentine coast.

headline: Patents; A Method for Sorting Microscopic Particles
abstract: An improved method for the sorting of body cells or other small particles is covered by patent 4,347,935, issued this week to the Department of Energy.

headline: BOEING 767: A CAUTIOUS DEBUT
abstract: The first commercial flight of Boeing's 767, United Airlines Flight 1767 from Chicago to Denver, will be made on Wednesday with a champagne christening and appropriate festivities.  But because of the industry's generally poor financial condition and other factors, such as weakening oil prices and European competition, the 767 is being introduced into an atmosphere filled more with uncertainty than proud anticipation.   The Boeing Company has not received an order for the 767 since July 1981. The aircraft's assembly area, adjacent to the assembly lines for 747's in a cavernous plant north of Seattle in Everett, Wash., is turning out just two 767's a month, instead of the dozen anticipated when production planning began after United Airlines placed its order in 1978.

headline: China Begins Census, The Biggest in History
abstract: China began the largest census in history today, using American computers and five million interviewers.

headline: Gabriel's Video Games At Cunningham
abstract: Cunningham & Walsh, one of the Mickleberry companies, has become the agency for CBS Video Games, a new division of Gabriel Industries, whose video game cartridges should be coming to market in the fall.   Since a lot of television advertising will be used, involved optimists are talking about a budget of $10 million to $12 million.  Nadler & Larimer, also a Mickleberry company, is the regular Gabriel agency.

headline: Chromalloy Credits
abstract: The Chromalloy American Corporation said it had signed a credit agreement with eight American banks, providing for a four-year revolving credit, followed by a four-year unsecured term loan covering a total of $140 million. Chromalloy said the banks include the Irving Trust Company, Security Pacific National Bank, North Carolina National Bank and the National Bank of Chicago, and said that the funds would be used for general corporate purposes.

headline: AEG-Telefunken Loan
abstract: The bank consortium that has come to the rescue of AEG-Telefunken A.G. three times is showing increasing signs of strain over current negotiations for urgent financial aid, banking sources said today. The 24 banks in the consortium, which holds half of AEG's shares, saw a few banks decline to participate in further credits.

headline: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Lamborghinis Return
abstract: After a seven-year absence, Lamborghini will enter the United States car market this year with two models, one bearing a $98,500 price tag and the other $55,000.

headline: Texas Instruments In I.B.M. Venture
abstract: Texas Instruments and the International Business Machines Corporation have entered a joint agreement to develop sophisticated integrated circuit silicon chips for use in business office networks that will link computers and office machines, the companies announced jointly.   A Texas Instruments spokesman, Dan Garza, said that under the agreement Texas Instruments would design to I.B.M.'s specifications very-large-scale integration chips mountable on a printed circuit card.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ANGERS A ZULU MODERATE
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha is engaged in a growing legal and political dispute with the leader of the Zulus, the largest black ethnic group in South Africa. The issue is its decision to excise a fragment of the Zulu ''homeland'' and cede it to the neighboring kingdom of Swaziland.   Twice in one week early this month, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, who is head of government in the fragmented state called KwaZulu and leader of what is said to be the largest black political movement in the country, has successfully gone to the courts to block proclamations of the white central Government.   The first proclamation, made under a law called the Black States Consitutions Act, removed from KwaZulu's jurisdiction a strip of territory called Ingwavuma that is wedged between Mozambique's southern border and Swaziland's southeastern corner. If the Government's plan to give Ingwavuma to Swaziland goes through as part of a larger transfer of land and population that also involves the Swazi ethnic homeland of KaNgwane, it would give the landlocked kingdom an outlet to the Indian Ocean.

headline: 'HANDS TO WORK, HEARTS TO GOD'
abstract: THE SHAKER HOLY LAND A Community Portrait.  By Edward R. Horgan.  Foreword by Faith Andrews.  Introduction by Robert F.W. Meader.  Illustrated. 224 pp. Harvard, Mass.: The Harvard Common Press. $15.95. RADICAL SECTS OF REVOLUTIONARY NEW ENGLAND By Stephen A. Marini.  213 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $16.50.

headline: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: South Korea President On a Visit to Canada
abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea visited Montreal today for a hospital meeting with about 200 Canadian veterans of the Korean War.   Almost 27,000 Canadian soldiers served in South Korea during the war and more than 500 were killed.  Mr. Chun is in Canada for a three-day visit on his way home from an African trip in which he made stops in Kenya, Nigeria, Gabon and Senegal.

headline: HUTTON'S PRESIDENT GOES TO PRUDENTIAL
abstract: George L. Ball, widely viewed as one of the most effective and innovative managers on Wall Street, resigned yesterday as president of the E.F. Hutton Group Inc. to head a new Prudential Insurance Company subsidiary that includes the Bache Group Inc. and the rest of Prudential's growing investment and brokerage operations. The Ball appointment, which took Wall Street by surprise, was hailed by some analysts as offering a badly needed solution to the troubles at Bache, which was acquired by Prudential in June 1981.   ''It's a recognition that something had to be done,'' said Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services. ''The Bache numbers have never been up to the standards of Hutton, which is among the best.''   Mr. Ball, 43, will be chief executive of Prudential Capital & Investment Services Inc., a newly formed holding company responsible for Prudential's wholly owned subsidiaries, Bache Group Inc., the brokerage operation, and Prucapital, formed in January to handle investment banking and corporate loans.

headline: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAEL UNIVERSITIES ARE LOSING STUDENTS AND AID TO FIGHTING
abstract: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has led to sharp reductions in the number of male students at Israeli universities and to cutbacks in government aid that threaten to end some academic programs, according to one leading educator.   Shlomo Gazit, President of Ben-Gurion University and former Director of Military Intelligence, said Friday that a quarter of the 5,200 students at the university had been drafted since the invasion, leaving the school with a high proportion of Israeli women and Palestinian students.   The need for more soldiers in Lebanon has also depleted the faculty, Mr. Gazit said.  Universities in northern Israel, nearer Lebanon, he said, had been affected more than those in the South. Ben-Gurion is in the southernmost part of Israel.

headline: Alcoa Trims Fees
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America said it had reduced or eliminated certain extra charges for aluminum sheet and plate products, resulting in price cuts of 6 to 15 percent effective Wednesday. The products affected are used mainly in aerospace applications.

headline: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Asbestos Suits Cleared To Proceed; Asbestos Suits Cleared
abstract: Asbestos-related damage suits against more than a dozen companies can proceed, despite a stay in cases involving two other corporations that filed for reorganization, a Federal judge has ruled.   Chief United States District Judge Robert F. Peckham granted a stay of proceedings on Tuesday in 70 cases involving the Manville Corporation and Unarco Industries, but said action against codefendants would ''proceed unabated.''

headline: Spy on the Teacher, Khomeini Tells Students
abstract: Millions of Iranian students started the new academic year today with a message from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urging students to spy on their teachers and classmates, the national press agency reported.   The Ayatollah, declaring that his country would not tolerate Western or Eastern ways of thinking, renewed calls for the expulsion of leftist students, according to the report carried on the Teheran radio and monitored here.   ''Students should closely and in an unbiased manner watch the behavior of their teachers and report the deviated teachers to the authorities,'' the Ayatollah said, adding that it was their Islamic duty to spy on their classmates and secretly tell security forces about those whose dedication to Islamic values was in doubt.

headline: Indiana Offers Harvester Aid
abstract: The State of Indiana offered to provide $31 million in financial assistance to the International Harvester Company to keep its truck operations in Fort Wayne.   State officials said the package would provide $3.5 million for Harvester's Scout plant, $9 million for its parts distribution center, and $18.5 million for its axle and transmission plant at Fort Wayne and personal property at Indianapolis.

headline: COMPETITION SPURS LONDON'S BROKERS
abstract: On the London Stock Exchange, the only bright thing for brokers these days is high share prices. Growing competition may result in the elimination of fixed commission rates and the securities market could be restructured.   ''It's not a crisis,'' said H.H. Cove, an analyst at Scrimgeour, Kemp-Gee & Company, a major brokerage firm. ''But the long, slow pressures of the past decade may be coming to a climax.''

headline: Kroger Plans Cuts
abstract: the Kroger Company said it would close or sell 140 food stores in 1982 to 1983, resulting in an earnings gain.

headline: Tax Shelters
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''The Continued Appeal of Tax Shelters'' (Aug. 8) pointed out how shelters lure many people because of their ability to generate large write-offs that can ''offset income from other sources, such as salary and dividends, that would otherwise be heavily taxed.''   The article fails to mention that tax shelters also appeal to the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: No U.S. Mercenaries In Falklands, British Say
abstract: The Ministry of Defense today rejected a newspaper report today that United States mercenaries fought alongside Argentine soldiers in the Falklands conflict.

headline: Further Layoffs At Inco Sites
abstract: Inco Ltd. said it would lay off 1,185 salaried workers in the Ontario division beginning Jan. 24 because of market conditions, and cut office staffs by 80 in the Toronto area, 90 in New York and 45 in Manitoba. The Ontario division is on a production shutdown until Oct. 4.   The work force at Inco's nickel refinery in Clydach, Wales, will be reduced by 80 persons, and the refinery, which has been shut down since May 10, will remain closed until market conditions justify restarting it.

headline: Energy Sources
abstract: Energy Sources Inc. of Dallas said that as a result of losses incurred this year it is in technical default of certain covenants of its loans with banks and others, and has presented its bank with a plan to reduce the deficiency. The company also reported a thirdquarter loss of $4.5 million compared with a deficit of $518,000 a year earlier. As a result of its losses, the company said it it had reduced its staff by 25 percent, cut salaries 10 percent to 15 percent, realigned management, halted a planned coal project and withdrawn from a merger deal with Energy Sources Exchange Inc.

headline: Newsweek and Prince Switch Their Agencies
abstract: Leber Katz Partners has been appointed the agency for Newsweek magazine.

headline: HUSSEIN FORESEES MIDEAST 'DISASTER' IN PRESENT COURSE
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that there would be a ''real disaster'' in the Middle East unless movement was made soon toward a solution of the Palestinian problem and a just and durable peace.   The King, speaking in an interview here, said he would consider any new American peace initiative that went beyond the terms of the Camp David accords. At the same time, he said he was convinced that the Reagan Administration was ''very concerned'' over recent developments in Lebanon.   ''As far as we are concerned, we think that a new initiative, a new process, will have to be born of the need to move rapidly towards the establishment of a just and durable solution,'' the King said, adding that the Camp David process was ''totally unacceptable'' to Jordan.

headline: Young & Rubicam Given Long Lines Task
abstract: The Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has named Young & Rubicam to handle the introduction of two new products: credit cards and gift certificates.   Advertising for the gift certificates will begin in the pre-Christmas period, while the credit cards are to be introduced in late fall.

headline: Leftist Honduran Group Admits Bombings
abstract: Authorities said that a leftist group, the Lorenzo Salazar Command, took responsibility today for the bombing of three United States companies here Wednesday night.

headline: Inland's Chief Picks His Heir-Designate
abstract: Frederick G. Jaicks, chairman and chief executive of the Inland Steel Company, has picked a successor to run the nation's seventhlargest steel maker. The company said yesterday that Mr.  Jaicks, 64 years old, would recommend to the company's directors at their October meeting that they designate Frank W. Luerssen, president, to be chief executive officer effective Dec. 1, 1982.

headline: Somalia Says It Killed 350 Ethiopians on Border
abstract: Somalia said today its forces killed up to 350 Ethiopian troops and wounded more than 50 in heavy fighting in the Galdogob and Balambal areas on Thursday and Friday.   The Mogadishu radio, monitored by the BBC, said 25 Somalis were killed and 64 wounded in the fighting.

headline: POPE POSTPONES VISIT TO SPAIN UNTIL AFTER OCTOBER ELECTIONS
abstract: Pope John Paul II has postponed his visit to Spain until after the country's Oct. 28 elections to avoid interfering in the political campaigning, the Vatican announced today.   The deputy Vatican press spokesman, the Rev. Pierfranco Pastore, said the Pope's trip would start Oct. 31, three days after the election.   A church spokesman in Madrid said the Pope's program, which was to have taken place Oct. 14-22, would involve all of the 16 previously planned stops.

headline: Sunshine Biscuits Quits Marsteller
abstract: Marsteller Inc. said that it had received a letter of termination from Sunshine Biscuits, a subsidiary of American Brands and a client for the past three years.1979.
