headline: Blue Bell Division Head Gets Top Corporate Job
abstract: Blue Bell Inc., the nation's second-biggest jeans maker after Levi Strauss & Company, announced yesterday that Edward J. Bauman, president of the company's Red Kap divison, had been named corporate president and chief operating officer, a member of the management committee and a director.   The board's nominating committee also recommended that Mr. Bauman, 58, become chief executive at the company's annual meeting on Feb. 2.  L. Kimsey Mann, 66, currently president and chief executive, was named chairman and will remain as chief executive until the February meeting. Mr. Mann is currently serving beyond retirement age at the request of the board.   Mr. Bauman said Mr. Mann had organized a corporate strategy committee six months ago that has just reported to the board.  ''Hopefully, it will be a turning point for Blue Bell,'' Mr. Bauman said. ''Domestically we're in excellent shape; the international operations are down.''

headline: Article 043316 -- No Title
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today reported a net income of $560 million, or $1.82 a share, in the second quarter, exceeding most expectations within the industry and the financial community.   The earnings came on an after-tax operating profit of $429.1 million from the sale of cars and trucks and a profit of $130.9 million from G.M.'s unconsolidated subsidiaries, primarily the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the auto financing arm.   The second-quarter net income was 8.7 percent larger than the $515 million, or $1.72 a share, G.M. reported for the second quarter of 1981 and came despite a decline in the number of cars and trucks sold. Domestic sales fell sharply in June, after G.M. ended a program of reduced interest rates on auto loans.

headline: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Postal Financial
abstract: The St. Paul Companies said it had sold its Postal Financial Corporation unit of Sioux City, Iowa, to the Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest bankholding company, for $27 million. Postal Financial has more than 50 offices in 14 states and had 1981 year-end receivables of $350 million. The Federal Reserve Board approved the sale on Aug. 17.

headline: Fire in Vienna Disco Kills 3
abstract: Three people were killed and one was injured early today in a fire that broke out in a downtown discotheque. Authorities said the three died from smoke inhalation, and a woman was injured when she jumped from the second story.

headline: CONTROL DATA OFF 21%
abstract: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its net income rose 19.9 percent, primarily because of special gains related to the sale of part of its stake in its French affiliate, CII-Honeywell Bull.   Honeywell said its net income for the quarter ended July 4 rose to $85.6 million, or $3.83 a share, from $71.4 million, or $3.15 a share, recorded in the second quarter of 1981.

headline: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ERITREAN SAYS REBELS AWAIT ETHIOPIAN BUILDUP
abstract: An Eritrean rebel leader says that Ethiopian troops in the troubled province are incapable of starting a new offensive and are playing for time until they can build up their forces there.   Amdemicael Kahsai, a member of the central committee of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, said in an interview that since the failure of an Ethiopian offensive against the rebels in May, ''military operations for Ethiopia have been taken over by the Soviets.'' He said there were now about 800 Soviet advisers in Eritrea.   The Eritrean rebels have been fighting for the independence of their province since the territory was annexed by the Government of Emperor Haile Selassie in 1962. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front maintains a permanent office in New York as the Eritrean Relief Committee.

headline: Arab Peace Plan Criticized
abstract: The American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israeli lobbying group that had expressed some support for President Reagan's Middle East plan, said today that the Arab League's peace proposals were a ''crushing disappointment.'' The group said the Arabs should ''be told in no uncertain terms that their position is totally unacceptable, that there can be no negotiations on the basis of the Fez communique, and that there can be no progress until they declare their willingness to recognize Israel and negotiate directly with it.''

headline: WURLITZER PRESIDENT ADDS TITLE OF CHIEF
abstract: George B. Howell, 63-year-old president of the Wurlitzer Company, assumed the additional post of chief executive officer yesterday, succeeding William A. Rolfing, 66, who will remain a director.   The appointment completes a management reorganization that started with the resignation in April 1980 of William N. Herleman, the chairman, president and chief executive officer, who was 52. After he left, Mr. Rolfing, then executive vice president, was elected to succeed him in all three posts but with the understanding that others would soon be found to fill the posts. Mr. Rolfing was scheduled to retire this year.

headline: APPLE FIGHTING COUNTERFEITS IN ORIENT
abstract: An Apple II home computer, with programs, was recently advertised in New York for $1,895. That was a reduction from $2,604.  In Hong Kong, however, what looks like the same thing sells for as little as $300.   The growing demand for home computers has pitted Apple Computer Inc. against Asia's irreverent counterfeiters, who have begun to turn out computers in the equivalent of a garage.

headline: Reuters Plans Radio Service
abstract: Reuters, the international news service, announced yesterday that it would start a radio network this autumn with reports of financial and commodity news.

headline: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: B.C. Resources
abstract: The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation said its timber unit would extend the closing of its Prince Rupert-Skeena pulp mill for two weeks or more. The plant was to have reopened Sept. 7, after a nineweek break. The company will also extend the shutdown of its northern mills.

headline: 2 Seers Are Pointing To Increased Optimism
abstract: And now for the good news. Some light was discovered at the end of the tunnel not only by Ogilvy & Mather, but also by Craig Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

headline: 2 HOLDERS WIDEN ROLE IN BECKER
abstract: Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker Inc., which recently disclosed that it has been losing money, announced yesterday that its two major European shareholders would exercise options to increase their joint holdings to more than 50 percent, thus taking control of the investment company.   The 89-year-old firm also said that ''discussions'' were taking place regarding changes in management. But Suzanne Pederson, a senior vice president, said there would be no comment until after a board meeting next Friday on a report that Ira T. Wender, the firm's president and chief executive officer, would be replaced.

headline: De Sade Gets His Due From Greek Socialists
abstract: The Socialist Government introduced legislation today liberalizing the laws on indecent publications and legalizing the works of the Marquis de Sade, after a publisher was sentenced to two years in prison for distributing them.   Forty-seven other Greek publishers have been ordered to stand trial for the same offense and thousands of de Sade's books were burned by the police last week after a court ruled that the works were sexually perverted.

headline: Finance Briefs
abstract: * Beneficial Corp. said its Beneficial Securities Inc. subsidiary had won approval from the S.E.C. and other Government agencies to sell notes and other company securities directly to investors.   * Cominco Ltd. will offer $50 million of series D preferred shares through Wood Gundy Ltd.   * Commercial Credit Co., a Control Data Corp. subsidiary, filed with the S.E.C. for $200 million of medium-term senior notes, second series, in denominations of $1,000 with a $10,000 minimum investment.

headline: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW MEXICO LINED UP CREDITS
abstract: When Agriculture Secretary John R. Block invited Deputy Treasury Secretary R.T. McNamar for a jog on Aug. 14, the farm chief had no idea that the run would cost the Commodity Credit Corporation $1 billion in loan guarantees.   Part of what later became nearly a $10 billion aid package for Mexico was wrapped up by the two joggers as they passed Fletcher's Boat House on the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal towpath that hot Saturday morning.   Today, some further aspects of that Treasury-inspired package were disclosed, with an announcement from the Federal Reserve Board that central banks of the leading industrial countries will provide Mexico with $1.85 billion of short-term credits.   The day before the billion-dollar jog, Mr. McNamar and other key United States officials had been meeting with Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog. Mr. Silva Herzog had flown to Washington the night before to report that his country's currency holdings were insufficient to cover even a month's imports.

headline: SIKHS EAGER FOR MRS. GHANDI'S VISIT
abstract: At the Gurdwara Sikh temple in Queens yesterday, Jaspir Bhatia, a Long Island engineer, exchanged his drafting tools for a broom to prepare for today's visit by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.   Inside the former Methodist church at 95-30 118th Street in Richmond Hill, the follower of the Sikh faith, one of 8,000 who live in the region, swept the entrance hall, checked three newly installed air-conditioners and answered phone calls from volunteers offering help or outsiders requesting information about the visit.   Mrs. Gandhi returned to New York from Washington in the early afternoon for meetings with Indian scientists, Indian businessmen and leaders of Indian groups in the United States, as well as a session with American professors and writers. The Prime Minister, composed and on time, shuttled from one meeting room to another at the Hotel Carlyle, where she is staying, to answer questions from the invited guests and to hear their views.

headline: Europeans Angered On Steel
abstract: The European Economic Community reacted angrily today to the Reagan Administration's rejection of a proposal to resolve a dispute over price levels of European steel exports to the United States.   A statement from the Common Market's executive commission said that the Commerce Department's reasons for rejecting the offer were ''inexact and questionable.''   It complained that the Administration had refused to make any counterproposals or to even say what its minimum demands would be.  ''We've asked them what the bottom line was for them and they haven't come up with anything,'' said Hugo Paemen, chief assistant to the Common Market's industry commissioner, Etienne Davignon.

headline: LEBANESE REPORT 40 KILLED IN RAIDS
abstract: The Lebanese state-run radio reported that 40 people were killed or wounded during Israeli air attacks today.   The radio said that the areas of Bwarej, Saad Nayel, Shtaura, Taalabaia, Mureijat, Hazarta and Tarshish were attacked and that Syrian, Palestinian and Lebanese leftist positions were all hit.   Lebanese militia positions were said to have been hit by the Israelis today also. Near Dhur el Shueir, for instance, which several Beirut radio stations reported was attacked today by Israeli jets, the National Syrian Social Party, a Lebanese group involved in a gun battle yesterday with the police, have a camp.

headline: Deficit Tops $100 Billion
abstract: For the first year ever, the Federal deficit has soared past $100 billion, the Treasury Department says.  With a month still to go in the fiscal year 1982, the deficit stands at $108.95 billion, according to a Treasury report issued last Friday.

headline: Nedbank Branch Here
abstract: Nedbank Ltd. said today it would establish a full banking branch in New York, making it the first South African bank to operate a full branch in that city. Nedbank has had a representative office in New York since 1958.

headline: Syrian and Saudi Aides Meet
abstract: Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria arrived today in Taif, Saudi Arabia, for talks with Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi Foreign Minister. There has been speculation that Syria is reluctant to attend a coming Arab summit meeting on Lebanon because of reports that the conference may renew discussions of a Saudi peace plan implicitly conceding Israel's right to exist.

headline: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-Soviet Trade Grows
abstract: Trade between the Soviet Union and the United States almost doubled in the first quarter of 1982 from the comparable period a year earlier because of resumed grain sales by the United States, according to statistics issued by the Soviet Union today.   The figures from the Ministry of Foreign Trade showed that the trade rose to $1.37 billion, almost all of which, $1.32 billion, represented Soviet imports from the United States.

headline: Israeli Reservists Ask Not to Go to Lebanon
abstract: A petition asking not to be sent for military reserve duty in Lebanon, signed by 1,000 officers and soldiers, was delivered today to Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, the radio said.   Two lieutenant colonels and six majors were among those who signed the petition, which was put out by Yesh Gvul (There Is a Border), a group formed by reserve soldiers who oppose the war.

headline: LIFE IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Lions Kill Swede
abstract: A man identified only as a 42-year-old Stockholm resident wandered outside his car in a wild animal preserve today and was killed by three lions, the police said.

headline: German Parts for Pipeline
abstract: West German industry plans to defy a United States ban by shipping compressor stations this week for the Soviet natural gas pipeline, West German officials and Western diplomats said today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: CROWD STONES THE AMERICAN EMBASSY IN SYRIA   DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 9 (AP) - Several hundred people protesting the Israeli invasion of Lebanon entered the United States Embassy grounds today and pelted the building with stones before staging other demonstrations at the Saudi Arabian and Jordanian Embassies.   The official Syrian press agency said thousands of people attended the protest organized by the Palestinian Trade Federation. Witnesses estimated the crowd that attacked the United States Embassy at 300 to 400 people.

headline: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NORFOLK SOUTHERN RY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 6, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. AND MEXICO: MAJOR RIFT EMERGES
abstract: Senior Mexican officials are upset at what they say is an orchestrated effort by the Reagan Administration to exploit the country's economic crisis and promote criticism of Mexico by news organizations.   The issue marks the first serious rift in United States-Mexican relations since President Reagan took office.  In the view of foreign diplomats, it reflects the heightened sensitivity of the Government of President Jose Lopez Portillo to criticism since the economic crisis erupted here this year.   The indignation began when officials viewed an hourlong, ABC-TV special, ''Mexico: Times of Crisis.'' In the July 25 program, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, referred to fears that Central America's troubles could ''spill over'' into Mexico.

headline: Amoco Extending Discount Program
abstract: The Amoco Oil Company said it would offer discounts for cash purchases at gas stations throughout its system.

headline: Belmoral Mines
abstract: Belmoral Mines Ltd. said the Continental Illinois Bank of Canada, based in Toronto, had called in loans totaling about $30 million (Canadian) and taken over operation of its mines. Belmoral owns gold-mining properties in Quebec and has a 50 percent interest in claims in the Whitehorse mining district of the Yukon.

headline: HOUSE UNIT CLEARS WAY FOR TAX BILL VOTE TODAY
abstract: The House Rules Committee today cleared the way for House consideration of the $98.3 billion tax bill Thursday morning, and said it would allow four hours of debate.   The panel rejected efforts by Congressmen opposed to certain provisions in the bill to permit separate consideration of these items. Under the decision by the rules committee, the bill must now be voted on in its entirety.   Meanwhile, the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, has indicated his willingness for the Senate to take up the bill on Thursday, if it is passed by the House.  Previously, it was thought that the House might not complete its deliberations until late Thursday, and it was expected that the Senate would begin its own debate on Friday.

headline: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEST GERMANY'S COALITION BROKE MUCH NEW GROUND
abstract: The West German coalition of the large Social Democratic Party and the much smaller Free Democratic Party lasted 13 years, the longest in the history of the German Federal Republic, providing stability and growth in a nation burdened with a dark history.   The coalition, always headed by Social Democratic Chancellors, first by Willy Brandt and then by Helmut Schmidt, broke new ground in both foreign and domestic policy before finally coming apart under the strain of the country's worsening financial situation.   Its most memorable and durable achievement was Ostpolitik, the policy initiatives of the early 1970's that improved relations with the Soviet Union and its allies, paved the way for the 1971 Berlin agreement calming that cold war troublespot and recognized the division of the country by establishing relations with the Communist Government of East Germany.   Together, these initiatives complemented the integration of the young Federal Republic into the Western community, an effort begun by the Christian Democratic Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, who worked successfully to end Germany's historic enmity with France.

headline: No Headline
abstract: EGYPTIANS PRAISE 'POSITIVE ASPECTS' IN REAGAN'S PLAN   CAIRO, Sept. 4 (By Reuters) - The Egyptian Government said today that President Reagan's Middle East plan contained ''positive aspects'' and could provide momentum to the peace process.   The announcement was made after a Cabinet meeting that discussed the outcome of talks earlier today between President Hosni Mubarak and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.   It was Egypt's official response to the Reagan plan announced Wednesday.  (In Amman, a Government official said that the plan had put ''Jordan on the spot,'' but that it had eased Jordan's fear of internal destabilization by Israel or by Palestinian extremists backed by Syria. Page 12.)

headline: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bell Turned Down On Data Link Rate
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission refused to approve rates for a data transmission service by an unregulated subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Capri's Boatmen on Strike
abstract: A strike by boatmen kept hundreds of tourists from the scenic Blue Grotto today, officials said.  Meanwhile, the boatmen's union threatened a total blockade of the resort island off Naples unless its members are given a share of a recent increase in ticket prices.

headline: EGYPT URGES U.S. TO AGREE TO PALESTINIAN SELF RULE
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak, in a statement published here today, said that Egypt would find it ''most difficult'' to resume negotiations on Palestinian self-rule with Israel unless the United States agreed to ''the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination.''   He also said that it would be necessary for Israel to stop establishing Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.   It was the most definitive statement to date of Egypt's views on reviving the stalemated negotiations on Palestinian autonomy.  Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who at his news conference on Friday refused to endorse ''self-determination,'' said today that he would ''not bite'' on the Egyptian formulation because it was tantamount to agreeing to an independent Palestinian state.

headline: WILLIAMS COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIGGER BANKS ARE HURT BY FAILURE IN OKLAHOMA
abstract: The failure over the weekend of the relatively small Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which had about $190 million in uninsured deposits, is causing large losses at banks across the country, possibly as large as $240 million for the Continental Illinois Corporation alone.   Penn Square, which had deposits of only $465 million, was highly aggressive in lending to the oil and gas industry and sold more than $2 billion of such loans to other banks. With the energy business in recession, it has become questionable whether many of these loans to independent oil and gas developers will be repaid.   Federal officials declined to comment on whether fraud might have been involved in the bank's failure. Banking sources questioned whether some of the collateral that Penn Square had said was behind some of the loans was actually there.

headline: LEBANESE ARE SHARPLY SPLIT OVER TIES WITH ISRAEL
abstract: Lebanese Christians and Moslems, until recently divided over the presence here of Palestinian guerrillas, now appear to be just as sharply split in their attitudes toward Israel.   With the Palestine Liberation Organization officially out of Beirut, the Lebanese have been left with the prospect of a continuing Israeli occupation. They must also deal with the overall issue of future relations with Israel.   Lebanese Christians have been visiting Israel in increasing numbers and speaking out in favor of a treaty between the two countries. But Moslems have repeatedly warned that such a treaty would lead to the partition of Lebanon.

headline: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RUSSIANS CALL THE TUNE EVEN IN LAND OF KAZAKHS
abstract: ATA, U.S.S.R. - At the turn of the year this pleasant, treelined city nestling beneath the soaring Ala-tau mountains celebrated the birth of its millionth citizen.   The baby boy's father, a carpenter, and his mother, a plasterer, were rewarded with an apartment in one of the new buildings springing up around town.   By doubling its population in barely 20 years, the city provided a benchmark of the progress it has made as the capital of the Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan.   Two years ago Leonid I. Brezhnev visited the city on the 60th anniversary of the establishment of Communist power and said that ''figuratively speaking, the republic itself has made a space flight,'' a reference to the fact that all Soviet manned space flights have begun at the Baikonur launching site at Leninsk, 750 miles northwest of here.

headline: SALVADORAN EXILES OFFER TO GO HOME IF POLITICAL FREEDOM IS ASSURED
abstract: A Salvadoran leftist opposition leader says he and his associates are prepared to return home ''to work for a political settlement'' if access to the press and other freedoms are guaranteed.   Ruben Zamora, general secretary of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, made the statement Thursday in an interview here. His front is a political group aligned with the Farbundo Marti guerrillas fighting in El Salvador.

headline: Braniff Fares On American
abstract: American Airlines said today it had honored nearly 37,000 Braniff International tickets since Braniff filed in May for protection under bankruptcy law.   The face value of the tickets was about $5 million, but American collected only about $600,000, said an American spokesman, Paul Haney.

headline: IRAN OBJECTS TO OPEC OUTPUT QUOTA
abstract: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began arriving here today for what promises to be a stormy consultative session on the issue of adjusting their individual production ceilings.   Seyyed Mohamed Gharazi, Iran's oil minister, told reporters after his arrival that his country could no longer accept the 1.2-millionbarrel-a-day production quota set by OPEC last March for his country and would increase its output to 3 million barrels.   He told reporters that he approved of the overall production ceiling, but, if necessary, Saudi Arabia would have to make room in the market for the increase by cutting its own output of 7 million barrels a day.

headline: New Products: A Record Tally
abstract: June was the biggest month for new product introductions since Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, began monitoring introductions of food and drug products back in 1964. Does that reflect an optimism about the economy or is it merely a result of heavy spring rains? Mr. Friedman is not willing to go out on a limb.

headline: Cyanamid Cuts
abstract: The American Cyanamid Company said second-quarter operating earnings would be reduced by $5 million as a result of sales of certain pigment and rubber chemicals businesses.  The action will result in gradual reduction in production and employment over the next year at its Bridgewater, N.J., plant to allow for an orderly transition for customers. It is expected that about 500 jobs will be lost, the company said.

headline: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRENCH ARMS GO TO NICARAGUA
abstract: France said today that it had begun arms deliveries to Nicaragua's leftist junta despite opposition by the Reagan Administration.   Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson made the announcement after Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of the Nicaraguan junta, met with President Francois Mitterrand.

headline: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ZALE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BEGIN VOICES HOPE ON REACHING PACT FOR P.L.O. PULLOUT
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that there were grounds to believe that the besieged Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas ''will leave shortly and that we will not have to enter west Beirut.''   This was his first indication that he seriously considered a peaceful withdrawal of the Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut to be likely.   In a speech at the National Military Academy, Mr. Begin also said he informed Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that Israel had accepted the proposal for a multinational peacekeeping force to enter Beirut, but only ''after most of the terrorists leave Lebanon together with 1,500 Syrians who are besieged there.'' No Timetable Given   The Prime Minister, whose speech was given in Hebrew and was shown, in excerpts, on the evening news program on the state-owned television, did not give a timetable for the withdrawal plan. But he did give the conditions under which Israel would agree to the deployment of the peacekeeping force. While he set conditions that might not be desirable to the P.L.O., the Prime Minister made it clear that he expected the guerrillas to leave west Beirut.

headline: FMC Is Tendered 44% of Scherer
abstract: The FMC Corporation announced that it had received 3.4 million, or 44 percent, of the common stock of the R.P.  Scherer Corporation in its unfriendly takeover attempt of the Troy, Mich., manufacturer of gelatin capsules.   Although the offer ends Aug. 16, FMC so far has failed to attract the 4.1 million shares, or 52.5 percent, of Scherer it sought.  Richard B. Johnston, a spokesman for the Chicago manufacturer, said FMC had made no decisions about continuing the bid.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Besides patents on several heavy mechanical inventions, the Department of Energy received one this week for an alarm switch to be operated by the big toe inside a shoe.

headline: ISRAELI JETS CONTINUE TO HIT PALESTINIAN AREAS OF BEIRUT
abstract: Israeli jets again attacked Palestinianheld areas on the fringe of the city today as the Palestinian guerrillas made preparations to leave Lebanon, apparently under the terms negotiated by the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib.   The Palestine Liberation Organization was drawing up lists of its guerrillas and their destinations in preparation for their evacuation by sea under cover of a peacekeeping force of French, Italian and American troops, according to sources in several wings of the organization.   ''We have been told we are to leave,'' an officer in the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, considered one of the most hard-line groups, said today.   ''They are taking names and making lists,'' he added, saying that those with Jordanian passports would go first.

headline: BLACK MINERS SENT TO THE HOMELANDS
abstract: Gold mine companies began busing home at least 1,000 black workers today after riots that have taken 10 lives in seven days.   A spokesman for the Gold Fields group said 50 armed policemen stood guard as some 2,000 miners were questioned at the Kloof mine, 31 miles west of Johannesburg, where two men died and 25 were injured in riots Tuesday night.   The spokesman said one man died after falling from a roof and another was found dead from severe head injuries ''obviously after a faction fight.'' A third man died of his injuries Wednesday.

headline: Ouster of Kenyan Protested
abstract: The Kenya Union of Journalists today protested the dismissal of George Githii, editor in chief of the Standard, and said the move was aimed at safeguarding local commercial interests of Lonrho, a London-based group that publishes the newspaper. Mr. Githii was dismissed Wednesday after he had written an editorial criticizing detention without trial in Kenya.

headline: VICTORY MARKET INC reports earnings for 13 wks to June 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; U.S. Urges Unesco Not to Restrict News
abstract: The United States has urged delegates at Unesco's world cultural conference not to recommend government restrictions on the international flow of news.

headline: TOUGH, YOUNG LEADER
abstract: Bashir Gemayel, the 34-year-old Maronite Christian who commands Lebanese Christian militias, promised upon election today as President of Lebanon that he would reunify the strife-torn nation.   Within hours, Moslems in west Beirut demonstrated that his task was immense. Moslem militiamen firing antitank shells and rocketpropelled grenades from jeeps wrecked the homes of three members of Parliament who participated in today's election in a special session of the legislature, held in an army barracks.   To them, and to many members of Parliament who boycotted the session in the hope of blocking his election, Bashir Gemayel (pronounced Bah-SHEER Jeh-MAY-el) is an enemy and an ally of Israel, which has backed Lebanese Christian militias for years.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Hurt in Blast
abstract: Six Israeli soldiers were injured when their truck blew up near Tyre in southern Lebanon, the Israeli radio said today. The radio said a smoke bomb carried by one of the soldiers in the truck blew up, causing hand grenades and other arms to explode.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Atlantic City Electric Co. filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 1.5 million common shares.   * Bangor Hydro-Electric Co.'s offering of 750,000 common shares was priced at $11.625 a share through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.   * Corvus Systems Inc.'s offering of 2.5 million common shares was priced at $13 a share through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

headline: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kenya, After Bungled Coup, Is Seeking $125 Million in Aid
abstract: The Kenyan Government has asked Western aid donors for additional assistance of around $125 million to help repair damage caused by an unsuccessful coup Aug. 1, diplomatic sources said today.   The sources said the request was made in a letter circulated last week to Western embassies in the Kenyan capital.  Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi, has estimated the damage caused in a few hours of looting in the capital's main shopping centers at $110 million.

headline: ISRAEL TO FINANCE MORE SETTLEMENTS IN OCCUPIED LANDS
abstract: The Israeli Government, ignoring President Reagan's call for a freeze on Jewish settlements, allocated $18.5 million today to build three new settlements in the occupied West Bank and announced approval to build seven others.   The action coincided with the disclosure of the text of a firm letter of protest from Prime Minister Menachem Begin to President Reagan. The Israeli leader Text of Begin letter is on page 4. warned that the American proposals for the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip would lead to a Palestinian state and ''a Soviet base in the heart of the Middle East.''

headline: Ghana Oil Company
abstract: Ghana's ruling Provisional National Defense Council has approved plans to set up a national oil company to oversee exploration by foreign corporations, industry sources said today. A committee in the Fuel and Power Ministry is studying the new company's structure, they said.

headline: Biggest Advertiser: Procter & Gamble
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company was the country's largest-scale advertiser during 1981, the trade publication Advertising Age reported last week, with total outlays of $671.8 million on advertising, not counting local newspaper advertising other than inserts.

headline: Car Imports Fall in Japan
abstract: Japan imported 20,562 passenger cars from the United States and Western Europe in the first seven months of this year, down 11.8 percent from the same period last year, a spokesman for the Japan Automobile Importers Association said.

headline: Imperial Oil Cuts
abstract: Imperial Oil, Canada's largest oil company, said today that it had cut 500 top management jobs and that its president, James Livingstone, 62 years old, is to retire early.

headline: American Express Class Action Suit
abstract: The American Express Company's famous ''Don't leave home without them'' advertisements for its traveller's checks have led to a class action lawsuit on behalf of all those who left home carrying the traveller's checks, lost them and could not get the next-day refund the ads promised.   New York State Supreme Court Judge Andrew Tyler yesterday certified a class action lawsuit charging that the company's television ads misrepresented its practices on refunding lost traveller's checks.

headline: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. AND INDONESIA, LONG CLOSE, DRIFT APART ON SEVERAL ISSUES
abstract: A modest protest recently at the United States Embassy in Jakarta by a group of Moslem youths protesting American support for Israel was just one example of the tensions between Indonesia and the United States.   Disagreements on China and the world economy are also straining a relationship that has remained friendly since General Suharto came to power in the mid-1960's.   Indonesians believe that the tensions are the fault of the United States. Although relations have grown closer in recent years, it is the complaints of the Indonesian Government that are being voiced most clearly.

headline: People
abstract: * George G. Guimaraes has joined SSC&B/New York as an executive vice president.   * Ricardo Calvillo has been appointed executive vice president and general manager of the New York office of Marsteller Inc.

headline: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Playboy Trade Account
abstract: Playboy magazine confirmed yesterday that it was bringing its trade advertising account, which had been at Epstein Raboy Advertising since December 1976, back in-house. Billings have been in the $1 million area. Scali, McCabe Sloves will continue to do the circulation promotion through the magazine's Chicago office.

headline: Swiss Refusing to Extradite 4 Who Seized Polish Embassy
abstract: Switzerland will definitely not extradite the four gunmen who occupied the Polish Embassy for three days last week and is determined to try them in a Swiss court, the Justice Ministry said today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SON'S WIDOW FIGHTS MRS. GANDHI   NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 (UPI) - The widowed daughter-in-law of Indira Gandhi posed a direct challenge to the Prime Minister today, forming a rival political party to oppose her mother-in-law's rule.   Maneka Gandhi, whose husband, Sanjay, was widely viewed as a successor to Mrs. Gandhi before he died in a plane crash in 1980, announced that she was forming a party that will try to win power.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Astradyne Computer Industries, Garden City, L.I., has appointed Irving Fitterman executive vice president and chief operating officer.   * Chessie System Railroads, a unit of the CSX Corporation, has named Alvin R. Carpenter senior vice president in charge of the company's coal department and coordinations; Paul R. Goodwin, senior vice president in charge of finance, and Frederic W. Yocum Jr., vice president-transportation.   * Dictaphone Corp., Rye, N.Y., has appointed N. David Wheeler vice president-operations of its Mountain View, Calif., word processing development and manufacturing facility.

headline: DECISION IS SURPRISE
abstract: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, is resigning to return to academic life. The announcment was made tonight in St. Louis, where President Reagan is making an overnight trip.   The resignation of Mr. Weidenbaum, a former economics professor, came as a surprise, but a White House spokesman insisted that no policy differences were involved. Although Mr. Weidenbaum had apparently had some problems with aspects of the Reagan economic program this year and last, in public he had been one of the chief proponents of the President's program.

headline: Cable TV Penetration
abstract: As of July, the A.C. Nielsen Company Cable Universe Estimates placed cable television penetration for the country at about 34 percent, or 27.9 million TV households. It represents about a 2 percent increase from May, and a 25 percent increase from July 1981.

headline: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Nabisco Agrees To Sell Williams
abstract: Nabisco Brands Inc. said it agreed to sell its J.B. Williams Company toiletries business to the Beechman Group of Britain, a maker of pharmaceuticals and health-care products, for about $100 million in cash.

headline: G.I.'s Phrases Stilted, U.N. Korea Office Says
abstract: The United Nations Command said today that statements attributed by North Korea to an American soldier quoted as having said he defected ''must be considered suspect.''   ''The language is stilted and totally unlike a Westerner's speaking style, particularly that of a U.S. Army soldier,'' said a spokesman for the command.

headline: Financial Statements For Mickelberry
abstract: Now that the Mickelberry Corporation is completely out of meatpacking and into advertising agencies, its financial statements become interesting in this area.

headline: Civilian Rule to Return To Bolivia on Oct. 10
abstract: Bolivia's military rulers said today that they would transfer power Oct. 10 to a civilian president elected by Congress, which is to convene on Friday.

headline: Market Place; Insider Buying At Recognition
abstract: DORMANT Recognition Equipment has awakened to post impressive stock market gains in recent sessions. The shares touched 6 yesterday and closed at 5 7/8, up 7/8, for the second best percentage gain of the day. The shares traded as low as 4 3/8 as recently as last week.   Strength in the shares may reflect in part insider purchases by a confident new management and growing support among professionals.  Data compiled by the Stock Research Corporation show that William G. Moore, the company president, bought 1,000 shares at 4 1/4 between June 6 and June 9.

headline: Morgan Hires Bond Official
abstract: Arthur J. Kalita, executive director of the Public Securities Association, is leaving to work in the public finance department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

headline: Pope Sees Lebanon Accord
abstract: Pope John Paul II said today that a settlement to the Lebanese conflict was not only possible but even imminent. He asked some 10,000 people gathered at his summer retreat here to intensify their prayers for a speedy end to the fighting in what he called ''these decisive moments'' in Lebanon.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Renegotiation of Debt Is Requested by Cuba   HAVANA, Sept. 2 (Reuters) - Cuba officially announced to foreign ambassadors today that it had asked Japanese and Western banks to renegotiate the terms of debt payments that fall due in the next three years.   Jose Viera, Cuba's Deputy Foreign Minister, said the country's fast declining supply of hard currency had prompted the request.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Ex-Foreign Minister Testifies in Teheran    NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 16 (AP) - Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, the former Foreign Minister of Iran who has pleaded innocent to charges of plotting to assassinate Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, testified in his defense today, Iran's official press agency reported.   It gave no details of Mr. Ghotbzadeh's testimony, saying only that he appeared before the military revolutionary court in Teheran's Evin Prison compound and answered the charges against him.

headline: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Avis-F.T.C.  Credit Accord
abstract: Norton Simon Inc.'s Avis car rental company, accused of keeping credit information from the people who bought their used cars, agreed yesterday to pay a $30,000 penalty and prepare more than 3,000 public service advertisements on credit laws.   A similar agreement was expected later in Miami involving the RCA Corporation's Hertz company, said Cyril Hyman, the Assistant United States Attorney in New York who handled the matter for the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: GALTIERI MUSES ON WHAT-IF'S OF FALKLAND WAR
abstract: Argentina should have continued its war with Britain even after Argentine forces were defeated in the Falkland Islands, former President Leopoldo Galtieri said in an interview published today.   General Galtieri, who as President ordered the Argentine occupation of the Falklands on April 2, said assistance from Latin America, Libya and others in the third world would have allowed Argentina to continue the fight.   In an interview with the weekly magazine Siete Dias, General Galtieri said Libya had sent five planes loaded with ''very valuable elements'' in the war.

headline: XEROX SLASHES COPIER PRICES
abstract: In an apparent acknowledgement of the inroads being made on its business by Japanese competitors, the Xerox Corporation slashed prices on some copiers yesterday by as much as 47 percent and said that for the next three months it would offer several discount financing programs to ''meet competition head-on.''   Analysts said that the sharp cuts, which averaged 27 percent and affected primarily reconditioned machines at the lower end of Xerox's product line, were an effort to stimulate sales in a weak economy as well as to rebuff stiffening competition from Japan.   The price reductions, effective today, range from 10 percent for the Xerox 2350 and 2830 copiers, originally priced at $3,995, to 47 percent for the Xerox 3109, originally $7,495.

headline: TRADE TALK SPECIALIST
abstract: He likes to tinker - with the ancient, luminous, fire-engine-red Austin-Healy in his garage or with the odd chair made out of driftwood or with the lamp made out of a wine bottle in the den.   But at the Commerce Department, where he is Under Secretary for International Trade Administration, Lionel Herbert Olmer does not have such a free hand. As the point man in the disputes with Europe over steel and the Soviet gas pipeline and in the quarrels with Japan over general trade policy, the 47-year-old Mr. Olmer has to balance competing interests in one of the toughest jobs in Washington.   Making the balancing act all the more difficult is the keen interest that trade issues have generated in the other major departments such as State and Defense, with their own special constituencies, and the constant pressure applied by these departments in shaping final policy.

headline: KILLINGS A SHOCK, ISRAELI AIDES SAY
abstract: Senior Israeli officials said today that they never imagined that the Lebanese Christian militiamen would massacre scores of Palestinian men, women and children in west Beirut. They added, however, that they knew in advance that the Phalangists were planning to enter the refugee camps as part of an overall plan to root out remaining guerrillas.   The Israeli Cabinet, meeting in emergency session, issued a statement tonight calling allegations of Israeli responsibility a ''blood libel.'' It said it felt ''deep grief and regret'' over the mass slayings and declared, ''No one will preach to us ethics and respect for human life, values of which we have educated and will continue to educate generations of Israeli fighters.''   (The Israeli radio said the Cabinet, apparently in response to a new Security Council resolution, decided to permit the entry of United Nations observers into Beirut, Reuters reported. The resolution called for 40 more observers to join the 10 alreadt there.)

headline: CONSOLIDATED FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GROWTH OF A COAST LAW FIRM
abstract: When William French Smith left Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher in 1981 to become the United States Attorney General, his law firm scarcely missed a beat.   Instead, Gibson, Dunn became the largest firm in California, pulling ahead of its two traditional rivals, San Francisco's Pillsbury, Madison & Sutro, and Los Angeles's O'Melveny & Meyers.  With 325 lawyers in branches from Newport Beach to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Gibson, Dunn has long-term expansion plans that may make it the first major California law firm to tackle Manhattan.   ''We are thinking about New York,'' said Daniel Frost, an affable 60-year-old whose business acumen has made him the firm's very popular managing partner. ''Obviously, we should be there. And we'd like to be in Tokyo, if we can work out some problems with local restrictions on foreign lawyers. We have an impatience at the moment, a need for more people at the partnership level.''

headline: Mexico Limits Oil Sale Credits
abstract: Petroleos Mexicanos, the state oil company, confirmed today that it had tightened credit terms for buyers, effectively raising oil prices about 40 cents a barrel, starting today.   Pemex will ask customers to pay for oil within 30 days instead of the previous 60 days, the company said. It also confirmed that official prices would remain unchanged through the end of September, at $32.50 a barrel for its top-quality grade and $25 for its lowerquality crude.

headline: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dome Said to Owe $8 Billion Canadian
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s debt totals about $8 billion (Canadian), about $3.4 billion of it owed to five Canadian banks, according to Canadian Press, a national news agency that said it had acquired a financial statement prepared by the company and so far unreleased.

headline: ABBOTT'S CHIEF EXPECTS PHARMACEUTICAL GAINS
abstract: When Robert A. Schoellhorn took over as chief executive officer of Abbott Laboratories three years ago, after 26 years at the American Cyanamid Company where he had headed its pharmaceutical division, most analysts expected big things from Abbott's pharmaceutical operations.   Indeed, earnings per share have grown at a compounded annual rate of 21 percent over the last five years.

headline: Guardian Plant
abstract: The Guardian Industries Corporation, a flat glass manufacturer, said it had signed a definitive agreement to purchase a reflective glass facility in Northville, Mich., from the Airco Inc. unit of BOC International Ltd. for undisclosed terms. In an unrelated development, Continental Mortgage Investors, which has been operating under Chapter 10 of the Bankruptcy Act since 1976, said it had signed a letter of intent under which Guardian Industries would invest $25 million in the company to aid Continental Mortgage's plan of reorganization.

headline: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: All United States stock and commodities markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Foreign markets were open.

headline: SIMMONDS PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LITTON NET OFF 14.8% IN QUARTER
abstract: Litton Industries, noting the recession's impact on several of its businesses, reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter dropped 14.8 percent, while sales fell 12.2 percent.   The diversified producer of defense and industrial electronics products said that net income in the final period of its fiscal year 1982, ended July 31, declined to $75.4 million, or $1.84 a share, from $88.5 million, or $2.16 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.   Sales dropped to $1.15 billion from $1.31 billion.  For the full fiscal year, the company, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said that net income rose 1.1 percent, to $315 million, or $7.69 a share, from $311.6 million, or $7.61 a share, in the preceding fiscal year.

headline: MITSUI'S AMERICAN SUBSIDIARY PLEADS GUILTY TO STEEL FRAUD
abstract: The American subsidiary of one of Japan's huge trading companies pleaded guilty today to charges of fraud and making false statements in a conspiracy to sell imported steel below allowable prices.   Mitsui & Company (U.S.A.) agreed to pay $11 million in civil penalties and $210,000 in criminal fines, the largest criminal-civil settlement in the history of the Customs Service, according to United States Attorney Joseph Russoniello. Federal officials said they had been investigating Mitsui's trade practices since 1980.   The guilty plea was entered at a hearing before Judge Marilyn H.  Patel in Federal District Court just one day after Mitsui and three current or former employees had been named in a 21-count Federal grand jury indictment.

headline: Iran Agrees to Supply Natural Gas to Turkey
abstract: Iran has agreed to supply natural gas to Turkey through a pipeline to be built between the neighboring countries, the Foreign Ministry said today.   It said agreement on the pipeline was reached in last week's visit to Teheran by a Turkish delegation.

headline: FINANCIAL GENERAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KEY LAWMAKERS EXPRESS DOUBTS ABOUT PLAN
abstract: Key members of Congress voiced deep concern today over President Reagan's decision in principle to involve American forces in a peacekeeping role in Beirut.   At the same time, strong doubts were raised within the Administration that the plan would ever be put into effect.  Administration officials said it was questionable whether the Palestine Liberation Organization, whose approval is needed for the Americans to be sent to Lebanon, would accept the plan now that it has become public. Officials said the premature disclosure of the plan by Israel might make it impossible for Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O.  leader, to agree to the American-dominated multinational force.

headline: RATES ON TREASURIES INCH UP
abstract: Interest rates for Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday.  Weak investor demand led market participants to worry more about such potential problems as a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds and faster growth in the money supply.   The absence of new reports of loan defaults or bankruptcies also encouraged lower prices and higher rates for Treasury bills, which have recently been favored by investors and speculators seeking lowrisk, highly liquid securities. By late in the day, bill rates had increased as much as 20 basis points, with the three-month issue rising to 8.3 percent from 8.1 percent.

headline: Frontier's Net Declines 2.7%
abstract: Frontier Holdings Inc., the holding company for Frontier Airlines, reported today that its second-quarter net income declined 2.7 percent from a year earlier, to $5.76 million, or 60 cents a share, from $5.92 million, or 64 cents a share.

headline: MAJOR JEWISH PAPER IN BRITAIN URGES BEGIN TO QUIT
abstract: Britain's most respected Jewish publication, The Jewish Chronicle, called today for the resignation of Menachem Begin and Ariel Sharon.   In an editorial entitled ''End of the Line,'' the paper said that both Israeli leaders must bear indirect responsibility for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians last week in Beirut. The editorial was a departure from the paper's previous conservative support of Israeli leadership, and followed by a few days statements by the Chief Rabbis of England and Ireland expressing disbelief and revulsion over the murder of hundreds of Palestinians at the hands of Christian Lebanese militiamen.

headline: OPPENHEIMER NAMES A PRESIDENT FOR FUNDS
abstract: Donald W. Spiro, president and chief executive officer of the Oppenheimer Management Company, has been named president of Oppenheimer's 11 funds, with assets of $8.5 billion.   Mr. Spiro, 56, replaces Leon Levy, also 56, who was named to the new position of chairman of the funds.  Mr. Spiro said yesterday that Oppenheimer planned to expand its fund operation internationally with its acquisition by Mercantile House Holdings of Britain.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BIZARRE PROXY FIGHT FOR GLOBAL
abstract: When the ballots are counted today on a remote island in the British Channel, the contest for seats on the board of directors of Global Natural Resources will go on record as one of the most bizarre proxy fights in memory.   At stake is control of an international oil and gas exploration company that has rich - but, until recently, inaccessible - oil reserves in the Canadian Arctic. But to most investors, Global remains an obscure foreign company based on the tax-haven island of Jersey, the largest of the Channel Islands.   At the same time, the company does not know, and has no effective way of learning, the identities of most of its shareholders. ''We have knots in Venezuela, a large group in Germany and a lot in the U.S.,'' Frank G. Beatty, Global's president, said. ''But we can't communicate directly with our shareholders, and a majority of them remain a mystery.''

headline: WAR SPARED FALKLAND WILDLIFE, BUT WILL THE PEACE
abstract: The penguins, seals and other wildlife of the Falkland Islands were spared serious damage in the fighting here ''through a bit of good luck,'' said Ian J. Strange, the islands' conservationist.   The penguins and seals, he said, ''were out to sea.'' The large colonies of seabirds, meanwhile, migrate in the winter, the season it was during the fighting and still is in these remote islands in the South Atlantic. ''If the fighting had commenced three months earlier,'' Mr. Strange said, ''it could have had a disastrous effect.''

headline: Spain Holds Drug Smugglers
abstract: The police said today that they were holding five Latin Americans who had tried to smuggle 10 pounds of cocaine into Spain. They said the smugglers, four Colombians and a Chilean, had the drug hidden in their clothes when they arrived at Madrid's Barajas Airport Monday on a flight from Bogota, Colombia.

headline: ECONOMISTS DEBATE IMPACT OF REDUCTION
abstract: The 10 percent cut in tax rates and the increases in Social Security payments that take effect today are expected to return $48 billion to an economy plagued by a recession and high interest rates. But economists are debating whether this will propel the economy out of recession or merely inflate the deficit and abort a recovery.   The Reagan Adminstration clearly hopes the tax cut will help stimulate an economic recovery. ''It'll be a plus in the early stages of the recovery that's now under way,'' said Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. He predicted the tax cut would be an ''important shot in the arm'' to the economy, although he declined to give specific figures on its anticipated effect.

headline: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Real Estate; Financing Apartment Buildings
abstract: THE Federal Government is trying to revise its program for refinancing apartment buildings in hopes of making new mortgage money available to landlords and preserving the nation's multifamily housing.   Many apartment buildings across the country have been financed in recent years with relatively short-term loans. So instead of the debt being paid off at the end of the loan, it must be refinanced.  Sometimes rental buildings are financed with balloon mortgages where little if any of the payment has been put toward amortizing the mortgage.

headline: 60 Worshipers Killed In Storm in El Salvador
abstract: Sixty people killed by a mudslide that razed a church during services last Sunday were the latest deaths reported in seven days of flooding that killed 600 people in El Salvador, relief workers said today.   They said the mudslide crushed the evangelical church in rural Ataco, west of San Salvador, killing 60 of the 75 people who had gathered for services.

headline: Interest Rates Increase Again; Doubts Grow On Fed Policy
abstract: Interest rates increased for the second consecutive day yesterday as dealers blamed weak investor demand and a lack of fresh evidence that the Federal Reserve has eased monetary policy.   Short-term interest rates rose by a quarter to half a percentage point, while note and bond prices fell by a half to 1 point. The declines in the past two days have erased about half of last week's gains.   The lower prices were accompanied by growing doubts among some traders that the Federal Reserve has eased monetary policy. Last week, a large $3.7 billion drop in money supply, plus an increased availability of reserves in the banking system, provided traders with a motive for expecting an easier monetary policy and evidence that the Fed had already decided to make credit more available in the banking system.

headline: Market Place; Competition On Air Parcels
abstract: YEAR-OLD Federal Express could pass the $1 billion revenue mark in the current fiscal year despite the recession and tough rivalries.   But Wall Street analysts are asking whether the excitement over this remarkable airborne package delivery company may soon wane.  There are two schools of thought, and that's what makes a market.   Last week, Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc. dropped recommendations on Federal Express and a rival overnight deliverer, Purolator, calling their near-term outlook ''jeopardized.''

headline: BUSCH HOLDING TALKS WITH BAKERY
abstract: The nation's biggest brewer, Anheuser-Busch Companies, disclosed yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger talks with Campbell Taggart Inc., the nation's second-largest bread company.   The merger, if consummated, might involve as much as $650 million and would push Anheuser-Busch deeper into the food and wine business, which it has gradually been entering.   But Wall Street sources, who asked not to be identified, said the likelihood of such a merger seemed remote, partly because recent rises in the price of Campbell Taggart's stock might make the company too costly to purchase.   With Campbell Taggart's stock selling at about $30 a share before yesterday's announcement, Anheuser-Busch would have to offer close to $40 or more to gain the company's support for a takeover, analysts said. At that price, Campbell Taggart's nearly 16 million shares would be worth close to $650 million.

headline: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1982; International
abstract: Additional funding to help debt-ridden nations is needed soon, to ''assure the stability of the international financial system,'' the head of the I.M.F. said. Jacques de Larosiere, the group's managing director, said he hoped for an increase in the fund's resources by April. He spoke at the fund's joint annual meeting with the World Bank in Toronto. (Page A1.)

headline: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNEVEN DIP IN GAS USE
abstract: America's gasoline consumption fell more than 11 percent, over all, between 1978, when it peaked, and the end of 1981. But a recent analysis shows that the rate of decline on a state-by-state basis has been far from uniform.   Aside from price, other determinants of consumption used by the Lundberg Letter in a recent analysis included shifts in population and auto registration levels.

headline: ISRAELIS ARE AWAITING RESULTS OF U.S. TALKS WITH ARAB MINISTERS
abstract: Israel adopted a wait-and-see attitude today toward the United States-Arab talks in Washington aimed at solving the impasse over Palestinian guerrillas besieged in west Beirut.   President Reagan conferred today with the Saudi and Syrian foreign ministers in an effort to agree when, how and where the estimated 6,000 guerrillas could be evacuated.

headline: A BUSINESS SCHOOL'S STRUGGLE
abstract: Columbia University's Graduate School of Business is, by many accounts, an institution with an inferiority complex.  Indeed, at this summer's student revue the biggest laugh line went something like this: ''What are Harvard, Stanford, and Columbia?'' ''Two prestigious business schools and a small country in South America.''   ''I'd say we're definitely one of the top five business schools in the country,'' said Boris Yavitz, who stepped down after seven years as dean this summer. However, in the next breath he concedes, ''But I know there are twelve schools in the top five.''   Asked to name the top five business schools in the country, though, the deans of other national business schools do not come up with Columbia: ''I'm sorry, but they're not up there yet,'' said Donald Carroll, dean of the Wharton School. ''They're on an attractive trajectory, though. Columbia had a bad period in the early 70's, and it has been getting better steadily since then. But reputation lags behind the fact.''

headline: Tampa-London Route
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave permission today for Arrow Airlines, a Miami-based carrier, to offer service temporarily between Tampa, Fla., and London. The service was halted in February when Laker Airlines went out of business. The agency said it would select a permanent carrier, not necessarily Arrow, early next year.

headline: PHILIPPINE DAM IS A BOON FOR MOSLEM REBELS
abstract: In this southern and predominantly Islamic city of 85,000 people, there is growing sympathy for the anti-Government struggle of the leftist Moro National Liberation Front.   ''The reason is the dam,'' said Somerado D. Bayakao, a community worker in a nearby village. ''The dam changed life here.'' When dam construction for the Agusan River hydroelectric project began seven years ago, it was welcomed as the beginning of a new surge of development for Mindanao island. At the urging of Middle Eastern countries, particularly Saudi Arabia, Mindanao was to be developed largely for the benefit of its minority Moslem population.
