headline: U.S. WON'T ASK BETTER STEEL OFFER
abstract: Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said today that the Government had no plans to ask the European Community to improve its offer to resolve a steel trade dispute, despite rejection of the offer last week by the domestic steel industry.   His comment came in an interview as the Commerce Department prepared to issue findings that could set new penalties on imports of European steel to the United States. Such penalties would further intensify the trade conflict that involves tough competition for the American industry from European exporters.

headline: Forest Fires Ravage Canada's Northwest
abstract: Forest fires raged across Northwest Canada Sunday, blackening as much as 500,000 acres, closing the Alaska Highway, burning out resorts and homes and and forcing evacuation of villages.   The Alaska Highway was closed for northbound traffic at Fort Nelson, 192 miles south of the fire, and closed for southbound traffic at Watson Lake, six miles north of the Yukon border.   The fires burned in an area of northeast British Columbia just south of Yukon and up to 100 miles west of the Alberta border.

headline: PIPERS GATHER AT SCOTS' RITE IN ARGYLL HILLS
abstract: All morning long, the ferries chugged across the mouth of the Clyde, laden with men in kilts, some carrying bagpipes, some starting work on the flasks early, and also with more ordinarily-dressed people.   By midafternoon, the boats had put about 25,000 people ashore in Dunoon, a town of less than 10,000 huddled at water's edge beneath the brooding hills of Argyll. There were pennants everywhere, and tartan banners on every lamppost, and the air was filled with the insistent skirl of ''Scotland the Brave.''   For this was the biggest day of Dunoon's year, the second and final day of the Cowal Highland Gathering. There are gatherings in 70 Scottish towns every summer, and there were gatherings elsewhere on Saturday, at Urquhart, where the Loch Ness monster is said to live, and even in Edinburgh.

headline: JONES & VINING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOTH HOUSES PASS CUTS IN SPENDING SOUGHT BY REAGAN
abstract: Both houses of Congress today approved a bill to cut spending by $13.3 billion, an action that sets the stage for a vote, expected Thursday, on a measure to increase taxes.   The votes on the spending bill, which came within six hours of each other, put in place the first part of a package aimed at reducing the Federal budget deficit by $130 billion in the next three fiscal years. The bill had bipartisan support in both the House of Representatives and the Senate.   Later this evening, the House approved a $14.2 billion supplemental appropriation bill that would permit almost every Federal agency to finance programs until this fiscal year ends Sept.  30. David A. Stockman, the budget director, has said he will recommend that President Reagan veto the measure, although it includes money for Mr. Reagan's plan to provide economic assistance to Central American and Caribbean nations.

headline: Oak Cuts Salaries
abstract: Oak Industries announced that it was cutting salaries of executives and professional employees by 10 percent and salaries of administrative and clerical workers by 5 percent. The action, effective with pay periods in mid-August, was taken to preserve Oak's profitability in the face of the continuing recession, it said. The company also plans to institute salary and hiring freezes, as well as more stringent cost controls.

headline: Toyota Production
abstract: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its vehicle production in 1982 would likely fall short of the 3,380,000 target because of a drop in export sales.

headline: More Layoffs Are Reported
abstract: Layoffs were announced by major corporations in several industries; most cited the slow economy as the reason.  The General Electric Company said it would lay off about 700 hourly workers at its Appliance Park facility in Louisville, effective Sept. 13 and that it would temporarily cease production of room air-conditioners for one week in both August and September.

headline: MARCOS LEAVES MANILA FOR U.S. VISIT
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos left tonight for his first official visit in 16 years to the United States, the Philippines' chief economic partner and military ally.   In a prepared departure statement, Mr. Marcos said he would try to explore with President Reagan how the Philippines' relations with the United States could be made ''yet more meaningful and fruitful.''   Diplomatic and opposition sources here said they expected that President Reagan might sound out Mr. Marcos on how he could insure a stable political transition from his authoritarian rule.

headline: Washington Watch; Help Wanted: Supply-Siders
abstract: WASHINGTON THE supply-side-oriented Reagan Administration has a problem: finding some supply-side economists to fill two of the top economic posts in the Treasury Department. Part of the problem may be solved by dropping one of the jobs, however.   It seems odd, with two key jobs available, that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan cannot find replacements. But his aides say there just are not many supply-side economists around.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Emerson Quiet Kool Corporation, Woodbridge, N.J., a subsidiary of the National Union Electric Corporation, to Lewis & Gilman, Philadelphia. * WYNY/FM Radio to D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York.   * Champion International to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson Inc. for its packaging and paper divisions.

headline: Apple Computer Sues 4 Companies
abstract: In a bid to step up protection of trademark, copyrights and letters of patent, Apple Computer Inc., of Cupertino, Calif., has sued four more Hong Kong companies, charging infringement of rights.

headline: AMERICAN DIAGNOSTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EASING THE COST OF COLLEGE
abstract: IF you're about to send a child to college or already putting one t hrough, the financial aid outlook is far rosier than one would have p redicted six or eight months ago.   The educational community has fought a fierce and successful battle to restore many of the educational assistance cuts proposed by President Reagan, and funding for Federal aid programs for the 1982-83 academic year is at roughly the same levels as for the previous year. Furthermore, many of the Administration's harshest proposals - which would have drastically reduced the amount of funds available for the children of middle-class families - did not survive the Congressional budget process. The Senate override of the President's budget veto earlier this month, for example, preserved $212 million in funding for Pell grants, the basic component of student financial aid, as well as for some supplemental assistance programs.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WORRY SPREADS AFTER PESO CURBS
abstract: The Mexican Government has taken the unprecedented measures of ordering the temporary closure of foreign exchange markets and declaring that all foreign currency bank accounts here would be convertible only to pesos.   The moves came in the form of a joint announcement Thursday night by the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Mexico and followed, by just one week, Mexico's second major devaluation of the peso this year.   The latest action is apparently aimed at curbing a continuing flight of capital, but it sent fresh shock waves through an already unnerved financial community. Many bankers said they were thoroughly confused as to the new rules of the game.

headline: Former Inc. Publisher Is Weighing New Offer
abstract: Norman Raben, president of the Goldhirsh Group, publisher of Inc.  magazine, confirmed yesterday that C.C. Randolph 3d, known to all as Jim, is out as publisher of Inc. and that he is now on Nantucket deciding whether to accept a Goldhirsh offer to run the group's teleconferencing operation. That decision should come today or Monday.   Mr. Randolph, chairman of the Magazine Publishers Association from 1975 to 1977, came to Inc. last fall, previously having been publisher of Geo under its original owner, Gruner & Jahn, and of Business Week.

headline: Arco to Trade Stock for Debt
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it had agreed to issue up to 2.25 million common shares to Salomon Brothers in exchange for $109 million principal amount of various debentures.

headline: Advertising; Bozell Also Acquires Executives
abstract: WHEN Charles D. Peebler Jr., president and chief executive of Bozell & Jacobs, acquires agencies, he adds to his client list and billings, certainly, and he also seems to have a penchant for acquiring good executive timber.   So, who knows what corporate slot might be filled if the current conversations with Lee King & partners, Chicago, come to fruition.Jaye S. Niefeld, an executive vice president-marketing and research of Bozell & Jacobs with a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Vienna, was acquired along with Niefeld, Paley & Kuhn, Chicago; J.  Liener Temerlin, chairman, with Glenn Advertising in Dallas; Joseph Caggiano, vice chairman and chief financal officer, with Emerson Foote Inc., New York, and David Arthur Bell, who is president of not one, but two divisions of Bozell, came aboard with the Knox Reeves agency in Minneapolis.   Mr. Bell, still only 39 years old, in his seven years with the agency has acquired that unusual Peebler smile, a broad flashing of the teeth that is used like some sort of punctuation in midsentence, and that comes and goes in a flash.

headline: ATOM ARMS POLICY COMES UNDER FIRE
abstract: President Reagan's nuclear arms control policies have come under criticism from a bipartisan group of 21 senators and from six former senior Government officials.   On Monday, Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, and his colleagues sponsored a resolution urging Mr. Reagan to clarify his policies and recent actions, which, the measure states, ''have caused anxiety at home and abroad.''   In addition, the six officials, who are either former directors of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency or former arms negotiators, said in a statement that they could not support the President's decision to defer talks on a treaty for a comprehensive nuclear test ban. Tests are now banned in the atmosphere, the sea and outer space, but are permitted under ground.

headline: NATIONAL SECURITY INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Manufacturers Push Exports
abstract: The United States manufacturing industry is increasingly dependent on exports for growth, the Conference Board said in a report yesterday.   The analysis of the manufacturing industry also said that while the United States steadily is becoming a service-oriented economy, manufacturing accounted for 23 percent of the gross national product and 19 percent of the civilian labor force in 1981.

headline: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 2 OTHERS SHOW INTEREST IN BUYING CITIES SERVICE
abstract: The Phillips Petroleum Company and the Union Pacific Corporation have displayed more than a routine interest in discussing the purchase of the Cities Service Company, sources close to all three companies said yesterday.   The Allied Corporation, moreover, which eliminated itself earlier as a buyer of Cities Service, is understood to have a continuing interest in buying what insiders described as ''a piece of the company.''   The first litigation against Cities Service's directors in the wake of Gulf Oil's withdrawal of its merger offer last Friday also emerged yesterday: Sidney Wolgin, a Rydal, Pa., businessman charged them with failing to consider the Mesa Petroleum Company as a merger partner, wasting corporate assets by paying Mesa $55 a share for 4.1 million Cities Service shares and manipulating the market by planning to buy up to 20 million shares of company stock.

headline: IMPELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARINES' LANDING IN BEIRUT DELAYED BY LACK OF ACCORD
abstract: The United States said today that the Marines would not land in Beirut on Sunday, as planned, because no accord had been reached on the Israelis' pullback from Beirut International Airport.   In a separate incident, officials said, four United Nations military observers, including two American officers, were killed outside Beirut today when their vehicle ran over a land mine. (Page 22.)   Also in Beirut, Israeli officials said they expected their troops to be out of West Beirut by Sunday night, paving the way for deployment of the multinational peacekeeping force. (Page 23.)

headline: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Comark Seeks $12.5 Million
abstract: Comark, a defunct government securities brokerage based in Newport Beach, Calif., and now undergoing liquidation, has told its 165 limited partners to provide $12.5 million in new capital.   In a statement sent to investors, which include some top Los Angeles area financial leaders, the firm contended that many of its financial troubles developed because the Marine Midland Bank, of Buffalo, suspended securities clearing operations for Comark, withdrew a key line of credit and seized Comark's assets to pay off part of the firm's debt.

headline: Chrysler Near Canadian Aid
abstract: Chrysler Canada Ltd. is near agreement with the Canadian Government on financial aid needed to begin production of a new, turbocharged diesel engine at an idle plant in Windsor, Ontario, the company said today.   ''We're very close to one,'' said Walt McCall, a spokesman.

headline: SCHICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: United Carolina Rejects Offer
abstract: The board of the United Carolina Bancshares Corporation voted unanimously to rejected the unsolicited offer for its shares by the First Union Corporation, Lawrence R. Bowers, chairman, said. First Union had bid about $86 million in cash, stock and notes last week.   In other bank merger developments, The Republicbank Corporation of Dallas and the First National Bank of Sherman, Tex., said they had canceled their agreement for Republic to acquire the Sherman institution, and the Chase Home Mortgage Corporation and the Suburban Savings and Loan Association of Wayne, N.J., terminated plans for Chase to acquire most of the assets of Suburban's mortgage banking subsidiary, the Suburban Coastal Corporation, Chase said.

headline: A MAN WHO CHALLENGES PRESIDENTS
abstract: Back in 1978, when President Carter tried to block exports of advanced oil exploration equipment to the Soviet Union, John V.  James came out fighting. The chairman of Dresser Industries, maker of the equipment, Mr. James publicly branded the President's move "sheer idiocy."   This time around, as Dresser battles to avoid being penalized by the Reagan Administration for its French subsidiary's sales to the Soviet gas pipeline project, Mr. James has left the public discussion to Dresser's senior vice president, Edward R. Luter, and to the company's lawyers in Washington, at least so far.   Is Mr. James reticent because he was an early and avid supporter of the Reagan-Bush ticket (George Bush is a former Dresser employee) and because President Reagan named him to his Export Council in 1979?

headline: THE SUM OF BEIRUT'S HUMAN MISERY GOES BEYOND THE MASSACRE IN CAMPS
abstract: Well over 200 people are known to have died violently in Beirut since Tuesday night, and more than 330 to have been wounded.   Hundreds have been widowed, orphaned or bereaved. Thousands have lost their homes. Hundreds of thousands are living without electricity, drinkable water, gasoline or the right to travel freely. Countless others are living in fear.

headline: ...AND THE MAN WHO WAGES IT
abstract: HANGING in a closet in his opulent Wall Street office is a s kyblue, silk boxer's robe that proclaims on the back: ''Don Carter, P roxy Fighter.'' It is from Irwin L. Jacobs, the dissident s hareholder who began an unsuccessful proxy fight against the Pabst B rewing Company late last year.   The gift seems appropriate. As the person hired by dissident shareholders or management to solicit proxy votes in such contests, Donald C. Carter, the 34-year-old president of the Carter Organization, has fought his way into clients' pocketbooks with his wellregarded techniques.

headline: BEIRUT'S ONLY SYNAGOGUE IS CASUALTY OF THE ISRAELIS
abstract: Israeli shells have fallen on Beirut's only synagogue, sending dozens of Jewish families fleeing for safety, residents said today.   Before the Israelis invaded Lebanon to crush the Palestine Liberation Organization, about 100 Jewish families lived in the quarter near the Maghen Abraham synagogue on Wadi Abu Jamil Street in the northern half of Israeli-ringed west Beirut. It is a few blocks from the so-called green line that divides the capital into Moslem and Christian sectors.

headline: Big Silver Producers In Trouble
abstract: Some of the world's major silver producers are in trouble, with prices insufficient to cover mining costs.   Peru, the second biggest silver nation after Mexico, has been seeking ways to raise prices by suspending exports and forming a producers' pact. It also announced emergency measures last month to prevent widespread mine closures. Mines have been shut down in thirdranked Canada and the United States, the fourth largest producer.

headline: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Akzona Takeover Final
abstract: Akzona Inc. said today that its shareholders had approved Akzo N.V.'s purchase of the 34 percent of Akzona that the Dutch company did not already own, at $16.25 a share. As a result, Akzona is wholly owned by Akzo.

headline: WEAN UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GENERAL ASSEMBLY OPENS 37TH SESSION
abstract: The 37th annual session of the General Assembly opened here today, and the United States made clear it would wage a determined fight against Cuba's effort to declare that Puerto Rico is an American colony.   Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, told reporters: ''The issue is important to us as an issue of fairness. It matters a lot to us. We are not prepared to shrug it off.''

headline: FEUDS BETWEEN MOSLEMS AND CHRISTIANS ENDURE OVER DECADES
abstract: The explosion at the Phalangist party headquarters that killed President-elect Bashir Gemayel, and the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian and Lebanese civilians at the Sabra and Shatila camps are part of the cycle of violence that has been a fact of life in this country for decades.   Perhaps because of the nature of the Lebanese population, split between Moslems and Christians, blood feuds in this country are long and enduring, and the occasional periods of truce and coexistence uneasy.   In 1860 Maronite Christians and Moslem Druze fought pitched battles in the Chouf mountains southeast of here, bringing the intervention in Lebanon by France and other Western powers. Maronite Christians are a sect that follows the eastern rite but acknowledges the spiritual supremacy of the Pope in Rome. The Druze faith is an amalgam of Christian and Moslem beliefs.

headline: Credit Curb Bill Advances
abstract: A House subcommittee today approved legislation that would give the President authority to restrict the use of credit in efforts to combat inflation, recession or unemployment. The Reagan Administration opposes the bill.

headline: CONTINENTAL BANK ACTS ON OIL LOSS
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, which suffered heavy losses in the failure on July 5 of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, has placed John R. Lytle, a vice president in the oil and gas group, on ''special assignment,'' a bank spokesman confirmed yesterday.   The 47-year-old Mr. Lytle, who has been with the bank since 1959, had been responsible for Continental's lending to oil and gas producers in Oklahoma and nearby states.   Continental, the nation's sixth-largest bank, had invested more than $1 billion in loans generated by Penn Square and in loans made directly to the failed bank.   Most of the Penn Square loans reportedly went to small oil and gas producers in Oklahoma. With energy prices declining in recent months, many of these poorly capitalized and high-cost producers apparently were unable to meet their loan payments, according to banking sources, and this caused Penn Square's failure.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; British Frighten Off Argentine Fishing Ship   BAHIA BLANCA, Argentina, Aug. 11 (UPI) - An Argentine fishing vessel operating within 150 miles of the Falkland Islands was intercepted and forced out of the area in the first such incident since this spring's war in the South Atlantic, officials said today.   The Argentine vessel Arengus was searching for hake last Thursday when a British Sea King helicopter equipped with rockets flew over the boat, forcing it to leave.

headline: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RESPECTED BY THE HOUSE:THOMAS STEPHEN FOLEY
abstract: When the House majority whip, Thomas S. Foley entered the Speaker's office this morning shortly before the House of Representatives convened, he received a round of applause from members of the Democratic leadership.   ''A star is born,'' declared House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.  Mr. Foley's response to President Reagan's appeal for support for the $98.3 billion tax bill Monday night received almost universally positive reviews. Instead of rebutting Mr. Reagan's speech, the Washington Democrat, looking firm and fatherly, called for a vote of ''political courage,'' of ''economic reality'' - in favor of Mr.  Reagan's compromise tax increase package. Debut as Party's Point Man   Mr. Foley's television performance - his debut as his party's point man on a Presidential speech - proved that a House leader can also be a good soldier. Mr. Foley, several colleagues agreed, ardently believes that, despite the party's disagreement with President Reagan's economic strategy, supporting the tax measure is the ''responsible'' course.

headline: Computer Sadness
abstract: To the Business Editor: A feeling of ineffable sadness overcame me upon reading Andrew Pollack's ''In The Classroom, Another Mr. Chips?'' (Sept. 5). My wife and I had come to the conclusion that the reverse of the scheme outlined in the article, was not only possible now, but was socially useful.

headline: J.W.T. to Start Drive For Timex Computer
abstract: The advertising campaign for Timex Computer's new Sinclair 1000, a new $99 personal computer, will begin soon and run through the end of the year.   Created by J. Walter Thompson/ USA, the campaign will reach the top 30 markets using 30-second spots, newspapers and national magazines.  Timex Computer, an affiliate of the Timex Corporation, will be trying to carve out its own piece of the personal computer business, which last year totaled about $2.2 billion in retail sales, according to a generally accepted industry estimate.

headline: United Technologies And AEG Plan Link
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle to form a joint venture in electronic subsystems and components with AEG-Telefunken, the West German electrical products giant that has financial problems.   United Technologies, based in Hartford, also acknowledged that it was talking to AEG about taking an interest in its capital goods business - an interest that Britain's General Electric Company has apparently decided to stop seeking.   Harry J. Gray, chairman and president of United Technologies, said that completion of the electronic agreement ''will establish a strong base of operation in Europe to serve increasingly competitive electronic markets.''

headline: PITNEY-BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Petroleum Data Delay
abstract: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a delay in compiling the data because of the Labor Day holiday. The figures will be published on Friday.

headline: Cockfield Brown Buys McConnell Advertising
abstract: North of the border last week, the big advertising news was acquisition news as Cockfield Brown, part of the Canadian agency scene since 1928, acquired - for cash - the more venerable McConnell Advertising, 79 years old.   Pierre Gervais, president of the publicly held Cockfield, estimated that the $25 million in additional billings would push his company well over the $100 million mark and, he estimated, into the top four, where the No.1 spot is a contest between McKim Advertising and Foster Advertising.

headline: No Headline
abstract: TOP IRANIAN AIDE ADAMANT ON WAR   LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) - The Speaker of Iran's Parliament, denying that his country had approached Algeria to negotiate an end to the war with Iraq, said today that Iran intended to pursue the 22-month-old conflict.   The announcement by the Speaker, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, appeared to be a rebuff to Prime Minister Hossein Mousavi, who said last week that Iran would welcome mediation.   Hojatolislam Rafsanjani told the Teheran radio in an interview monitored here that Iran was likely to step up its military pressure on Iraq.

headline: LONG-TERM RATES POST A DECREASE
abstract: With little fanfare outside the financial markets, long-term interest rates passed a milestone of sorts last week when they dropped below the levels that prevailed at the start of the Reagan Administration. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, a benchmark for all other long-term rates, including those on home mortgages, stood at 11.82 percent late Friday, compared with about 12.04 percent on the afternoon of Jan. 20, 1981.   Erratic changes in the long-term rate have helped mask a downward trend from late September 1981, when the 30-year bond yield was about 15 1/8 percent. On Feb. 9, 1982, the yield was still as high as 14.77 percent.

headline: United Fare Cut
abstract: United Airlines said it had filed for new fares up to 63 percent lower that full coach fares between eight Eastern cities and Hawaii to become effective Jan.5. A roundtrip fare between New York and Honolulu would be $519, compared with the current full coach fare of $1,368. Analysts said the move was the latest in a fare war sparked by weak advance bookings and fierce market competition by smaller airlines.

headline: Occidental Merger
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has deposited $1.89 billion to pay for its 45 percent interest of the Cities Service Company, thereby setting into motion its $4.2 billion takeover of the company. Warren Shimmerlik, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said in a new report on the implications of the merger that he thought Occidental was taking on too much debt at the wrong time, and lowered his estimate of Occidental's 1983 earnings to $2 a share, from $4.

headline: KISSINGER BACKS PIPELINE SANCTIONS
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger lashed out today at what he called the ''self-righteous'' reactions of allies in opposing the Reagan Administration's sanctions against companies supplying equipment for the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.   Mr. Kissinger, taking a tough line on East-West economic relations, deplored the lack of European support for the sanctions, which had been ordered by the Reagan Administration as a means of protesting the Soviet Union's support for Poland's military Government.   The countermeasures bear directly, he asserted, on the fundamental issue of the West's relations with the Soviet Union, an issue that should be reviewed at a time of increasing Soviet economic and political vulnerability.

headline: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Cautious View Of a Chartist
abstract: member of the American Stock Exchange, is one of those market watchers who predict stock movements based on statistics from the past performance of stocks. He argues that the action will be so fast that only the luckiest and nimblest of traders can get profits before the rally fizzles.   This belief puts Mr. Mamis in a quandary. He has written a new book called ''How to Buy: An Insider's Guide to Making Money in the Stock Market.'' Unfortunately, the tests that his book suggests for picking promising holdings rule out nearly every stock he can find these days.

headline: THURSDAY, JULY 8, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Antitrust officials asked the largest telephone companies for data on their plans to form joint ventures in a new type of mobile phone service called cellular radio, a computer-based technology that is expected to revolutionize the industry. Although the full import of the request was not immediately clear, one official confirmed that a preliminary inquiry was underway. (Page D1.)   The F.T.C. dismissed charges that The Los Angeles Times had unfairly favored large advertisers by charging them substantially lower rates than lower-volume or one-time advertisers. The agency also ruled that Russell Stover Candies illegally coerced retailers into selling chocolates at ''suggested'' prices. And it upheld the right of Beltone Electronics to require dealers to sell its hearing aids only within assigned areas and to deal exclusively in its products. (D5.)

headline: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Industrial production fell 0.5 percent in August, after a rise of 0.1 percent in July. The fall was seen as evidence that recovery may be delayed until late fall or early winter, beyond the Congressional elections. Economists said continued high unemployment has nullified the effect of the July tax cut, the decline in interest rates and the surge in the stock market. (Page D1.)   The House passed a bill that largely exempts shipowners from antitrust laws. The bill, opposed by consumer groups, marks a sharp break with recent maritime antitrust policy. It was supported by the Administration as well as by shipowners and unions. A similar bill is awaiting action in the Senate. (D1.)

headline: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for 12 weeks Aug 12
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTERSTATE SHOPPING: CURBING TAX LOSSES
abstract: When Brooks Brothers, the genteel, 164-year-old clothing store, opened its first store in Connecticut last Saturday, it ended a long-standing tax advantage for Connecticut residents.   Although upsetting to some consumers, the move is bound to please New York and other state authorities who, in an effort to capture millions of dollars in lost revenue, are trying to end these interstate tax advantages.   Under regulations as old as most tax statutes, a buyer does not have to pay any sales tax for most items purchased out of state and shipped to the buyer's home - as long as the seller does not have an outlet in the state of the buyer.   Thus the tax-free status does not apply to Connecticut shoppers at such New York stores as Macy's and Lord & Taylor, and now at Brooks Brothers, all of which have outlets in Connecticut.

headline: Falkland Sanctions Removed
abstract: The Argentine Government has accepted a British proposal to mutually lift financial sanctions imposed by the two countries after the start of the Falkland conflict, the Economy Ministry said tonight.   A communique issued here said the sanctions were lifted simultaneously at 7 P.M. E.D.T. by both Governments. That freed $1 billion in Argentine funds frozen in Britain since last spring and lifted the ban on the sale of assets or the transfer of funds overseas by British citizens or companies in Argentina.

headline: P.L.O. AIDE KILLED IN AMBUSH
abstract: Abu Walid, chief of military operations for the Palestine Liberation Organization, was killed in the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon today when his group was ambushed, a P.L.O. spokesman here said.   Abu Walid, who had been commander of P.L.O. forces in Lebanon, was ambushed in Riyaq, about 30 miles east of Beirut, in the upper part of the valley, and died later in a Damascus hospital, the spokesman said.

headline: AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Attaching Silica Tiles To Shuttle
abstract: WASHINGTON THE method of attaching silica tiles to protect the space shuttle, which has had four successful test flights, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.  Patent 4,338,368 was granted Robert L. Dotts of the Johnson Space Centar in Seabrook, Tex., and Jack W. Holt of the Rockwell International Corporation, Downey, Calif., a contractor.

headline: THE TIMES, THEY ARE TOUGH IN KILKENNY, IRELAND
abstract: The world recession finally caught up with Kilkenny one day last spring. In the rest of Ireland and the world the process had been like a drought: slowly parching and cracking and drying up economies. In Kilkenny it came like a thunderclap.   In June an American textile company closed its Kilkenny mill, a modern two-year-old plant that produced luxury bath towels for the European market. The decision threw 630 people out of work. That is not a large figure in the context of deteriorating conditions in Ireland, where the jobless rate is 16 percent. Nor is it large in the context of Ireland's nine trading partners in the European Economic Community.   But in Kilkenny, a city of 14,000 in southeastern Ireland where graystone Norman parapets share the horizon with granite church spires, the figure represents nearly 20 percent of the active local workforce.

headline: Interest Rates Post Decline; Fed Injects More Funds
abstract: Interest rates declined yesterday as the Federal Reserve continued to inject money into the banking system.  Economists are not sure if the Fed's willingness to provide credit to the banking system during the past two weeks is a sign of an easier monetary policy. Traders, however, said the Fed's buying - including yesterday's temporary one-day purchases of Treasury bills - have definitely helped raise prices of short-term Treasury securities. The rate for three-month bills, for example, fell to 11.53 percent yesterday from 11.96 percent, while the six-month rate fell to 12.02 percent from 12.22 percent.   Although prices rose as much as half a point for some note and bond issues yesterday, analysts said that the gains were not accompanied by a surge in buying from institutions.

headline: Pabst Receives Stake in Olympia
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company said that its had received 2.33 million shares, or about 90 percent, of the Olympia Brewing Company under its $28-a-share tender offer for up to 1.27 million shares.   The offer is part of a merger agreement between the companies, under which Olympia is also bidding $25 a share for 49 percent of Pabst, or about 100 million shares.

headline: IN BRAZIL'S WILD NORTHEAST, NO END TO BLOODLETTING
abstract: The outline of the state of Alagoas resembles a revolver, and that could just as well be taken as the shape of things around here.   A tradition of settling personal and political scores with a gun has long given this state in Brazil's impoverished northeast a reputation for being the most violence-prone part of a region already known for its frontier justice. But the phenomenon is gaining fresh attention now because of a bloody vendetta between two families that the local authorities acknowledge they cannot stop.   Neither side seems to worry much about the authorities, local or otherwise. The murders generally occur around midday in the crowded heart of this capital city, between the legislative assembly and the central market. One took place so close to the Church of the Deliverance that the fatal bullet lodged in its whitewashed facade after passing through its victim.

headline: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: People
abstract: * Gail F. Lieberman is joining Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc. as a senior vice president and chief financial officer.   * William L. Clayton has been named a senior vice president of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Reports a Deficit
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, suffering from the lowest level of steel orders in 20 years, said yesterday that it lost $47.1 million in the second quarter of 1982. In the same period last year, Bethlehem earned $77.6 million, or $1.78 a share.   The results announced yesterday widened the No.2 steel producer's loss for the first six months to $113.8 million. The company earned $103.5 million in the first six months of 1981 and $210.9 million, or $4.83 a share, for the full year.

headline: Poland's Rulers Chided Over the Pope's Trip
abstract: A letter from Poland's Roman Catholic bishops blaming the authorities for the postponement of a planned visit by Pope John Paul II to his homeland next month will be read to congregations throughout the country on Sunday.   A pastoral letter signed by the Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, indicated a deep disappointment that the trip was put off and said the church hoped a new date could be set soon.

headline: BUDGET OFFICE AGAINST NEW RULES REQUIRING ADDED BANK DISCLOSURE
abstract: The Office of Management and Budget has unexpectedly disapproved new rules issued by Federal bank regulators that would have required banks to begin disclosing more information about their financial condition.   Among other things, the rules would have required that, starting this fall, banks report details about problem loans of the sort that caused the collapse of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.   The disapproval stated that the proposals were premature, but it also listed several other objections, raising the possibility that the budget office might never approve them in their present form.   Because the agencies that regulate state-chartered banks can override the budget office, the disapproval created the possibility that such banks would be subject to the rules while federally chartered banks would remain exempt.

headline: WORLD AIRWAYS WINS DEBT DEFERRAL
abstract: World Airways Inc., which had been a pioneer in offering discount fares, said yesterday that its creditors had agreed to defer about $14 million of debt and lease payments coming due between now and next June, thus staving off a shutdown.   But the airline, which lost $13.3 million in its first quarter and $20.2 million last year, faces the possibility of another major financial burden in October. At that time, World has said that it will terminate a lease on two Boeing 747's that was due to expire in 1989.

headline: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEDNESDAY, JULY 28, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office issued a new economic forecast that is more pessimistic than the Reagan Administration's. It said annual budget deficits would range from $140 billion to $160 billion over the next three fiscal years. (Page D1.)   President Reagan may try to restore some arms spending cuts, according to officials, by using his original arms spending projections in a midyear economic report due this week rather than those approved by Congress last month. (A1.)

headline: Helicopter Death Toll In Germany Put at 45
abstract: Authorities said today that the probable death toll in the crash of a United States Army helicopter carrying an international parachute team was 45 rather than 44.   West German and American investigators, meanwhile, began searching for the cause of Saturday's crash.

headline: U.S. ACTS TO EASE SANCTIONS' IMPACT
abstract: The Administration, under pressure from business, is seeking to limit the impact of the trade sanctions that President Reagan has imposed on companies involved in building the Siberian natural gas pipeline.   ''It would not have been appropriate to reach out and capture all the secondary suppliers,'' said one harried official of the Commerce Department, which administers the sanctions. ''You have to stop somewhere.''   ''The department has been swamped,'' said another official who asked not to be identified. ''Literally hundreds of companies are requesting clarification of their position with the Office of the General Counsel.''

headline: 4 Spanish Policemen Slain in Basque Ambush
abstract: Basque separatists ambushed two police cars on a country road today, killing four officers in what was seen as the start of a new terrorist campaign six weeks before Spain's general elections.   The gunmen opened fire on the police cars just before noon at a bend in a country road north of San Sebastian, setting off a heavy exchange of shooting, with three of the policemen returning gunfire - one as he lay dying, the police said.

headline: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Emhart Plans Layoffs
abstract: The Emhart Corporation plans to lay off 32 hourly production workers Thursday because poor economic conditions have reduced business and forced the company to cut costs, a company official said today. The layoffs will bring the number of workers taken off the job at the Berlin plant during the past month to 109, said Raymond Nieman, Emhart personnel director. Emhart's Berlin plant makes hardware products, such as doorknobs, locks and latches.

headline: McLouth Receives Offer for Assets
abstract: The McLouth Steel Corporation, reorganizing under Federal bankruptcy laws, said without elaboration that it had received a conditional proposal from Tang Industries for the acquisition of most of its assets.

headline: HOW TO AID LEBANON VICTIMS
abstract: The following is a list of charitable organizations that have established relief programs for victims of the conflict in Lebanon.  Officials of the groups say that most of the initial aid is being used for medicine and food and that later, their funds will also go toward various rebuilding projects   According to Leon Marion, a spokesman for the American Council of Voluntary Agencies for Foreign Services, an umbrella group, the organizations all now have people working in Lebanon. Mr. Marion suggested that since the agencies have projects throughout the world, donors wishing to do so can specify that their contributions go to the Lebanon programs.

headline: MARKET IS MIXED AFTER SELL-OFF
abstract: A spate of selling in the final hour left stock prices mixed yesterday.  At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.24 points, to 832.19, after ranging between 840.37 and 832 during the session.   But stocks that gained in value outnumbered those that fell by 812 to 630. Big Board volume increased to 66.8 million shares from 61.1 million on Tuesday.

headline: PRO-ISRAEL ARAB AIDE FOUND DEAD
abstract: An Israeli military spokesman said today that a member of the pro-Israeli village leagues in the West Bank was found shot to death Wednesday at military government headquarters in Tulkarm.   Israeli and Palestinian sources said it was not certain that the death of the man, identified as Abdul Rahim Ahmed Salameh, 69 years old, was a suicide.

headline: TAKING A NEW LOOK; 'GOURMET' JELLY BEAN
abstract: Herman Rowland cannot help pushing his product with a bit of tongue-in-cheek humor. ''What!'' he cries in mock horror to the unitiated. ''You mean you've never had a Jelly Belly?'' It is difficult, after all, to be completely serious about ''the original gourmet jellybean.''

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Aide Indicted
abstract: A former employee of the International Business Machines Corporation, Raymond J. Cadet, was indicted today on three counts of stealing trade secrets from the computer manufacturer during a six-month period beginning November, 1980.   In addition, a Federal grand jury in San Jose, Calif., indicted Japan's Hitachi Ltd., one of the world's largest computer manufacturers and an I.B.M. competitor, for illegally attempting to acquire confidential I.B.M. documents and materials for the past two years. Fourteen of Hitachi's employees, all of whom were charged by the Justice Department last week, also were indicted.

headline: Top Operating Officer Named at Square D Co.
abstract: Charles B. Yates, executive vice president of the Square D Company of Chicago, has been elected vice chairman and chief operating officer.   Mr. Yates, 43, will succeed Paul A. Christenson, 67, formerly president and chief operating officer, in the position. Mr.  Christenson will retire effective Dec. 31, but will serve as a senior vice president to help affect an orderly transition.

headline: U.S. AND ISRAEL WEIGH OPENING BEIRUT AIRPORT
abstract: Israeli officials conferred today with a United States official on the possible reopening of the Beirut airport and withdrawal of United States marines from Lebanon.   Morris Draper, deputy to Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, was quoted by the Israeli radio, monitored here, as having said that the marines occupying the Beirut port would start leaving in nine days.   The 800 American marines currently in the port area are scheduled to be replaced by troops of the Lebanese army. Large numbers of Lebanese soldiers could be seen inside the port today. There were also 25 to 30 Israeli soldiers inside a warehouse at the port's eastern end. Their equipment included six armored personnel carriers and a tank.

headline: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRIMATE DEMANDS POLES FREE WALESA
abstract: Addressing a multitude of over 350,000 worshipers at the nation's holiest shrine, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland demanded today that the authorities free Lech Walesa.   The Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, said the Government must also make other concessions to bring about a reconciliation with an ''angry'' people.   With an eye on anti-Government demonstrations planned for next week on the anniversary of the Gdansk agreements that recognized the Solidarity union headed by Mr. Walesa, the Archbishop repeatedly sounded an appeal for calm. He called on Poles not to take to the streets but to submerge their anger in the consolation of prayer.

headline: WESTON, GEORGE, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EMBASSY GUNMAN SERVED JAIL TERM AS SPY
abstract: New information has emerged on the identity of the four gunmen who seized the Polish Embassy in Switzerland this week.  But there are still many uncertainties about the gunmen's motives and possible outside support.   News organizations in Poland and several other Eastern-bloc countries have stepped up a campaign to describe the leader of the group, Florian Kruszyk, 42 years old, as an anti-Communist fanatic and criminal who worked for Western intelligence agencies and news outlets. They said the embassy attack was inspired by the suspended Solidarity trade union and by members of the now disbanded dissident movement known as KOR.

headline: Moroccan Visiting Abu Dhabi In a Bid for Talks on Lebanon
abstract: Foreign Minister Mohammed Boucetta of Morocco arrived in Abu Dhabi today from Oman to canvass support for a meeting of Arab heads of state on Lebanon.   Morocco has offered to be host for the meeting, which it says should discuss Israel's invasion of Lebanon and the Arab-Israeli conflict in general.   Mr. Boucetta, who has visited Saudi Arabia, Syria and Jordan, was quoted by a Saudi newspaper today as saying such a meeting could be held in three or four weeks.

headline: PABST ASKS SHAREHOLDERS TO ACCEPT OFFER BY OLYMPIA
abstract: The Pabst Brewing Company recommended yesterday that its shareholders accept a tender offer for 49 percent of its shares made by the Olympia Brewing Company with Pabst's blessings. Pabst said the bid was intended to defeat a competing offer for 39 percent of its shares by an investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a dissident shareholder.   The Olympia offer of $25 a share for the Pabst stock, or a total of $100 million, was announced late Monday. It offers Pabst shareholders, some of whom are dissatisfied with Pabst's management and who might otherwise have tendered their shares to the Jacobs group, a higher bid from Olympia. And it appeared to take Olympia and Pabst one step closer to a merger that would create the nation's third-largest brewer.

headline: Jacobs Ends Offer For Pabst Shares
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessman and dissident shareholder of the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee, yesterday ended his tender offer for the company.   Mr. Jacobs, who has been trying to take control of Pabst for more than a year, attributed his decision to the Justice Department's announcement on Thursday that it would challenge his bid, which included plans to sell some of Pabst's assets to the rival G.  Heileman Brewing Company.

headline: Party Rally Reported Raided by Afghan Rebels
abstract: Afghan guerrillas attacked a rally attended by leaders and officials of Afghanistan's ruling party in Pagman, nine miles northwest of Kabul, last Thursday, a Western diplomatic source in New Delhi said today.

headline: Opposition Parties in Ireland Seek Confidence Vote Today
abstract: The opposition parties in the Irish Parliament announced today that they would force a formal vote of confidence in the Government on Thursday.

headline: DEBATE OVER OFFICE 'NETWORKS'
abstract: THE idea seemed quite simple: Link all of a building's computers, word processors and ''smart'' copiers, its terminals, typewriters and printers in a single i nteractive communication network.   By enabling all of those devices to communicate with one another, the reasoning went, workers would be more efficient; there would be less duplication of record-keeping, costs of printing and copying could be cut by sharing office machines and the much-vaunted ''office of the future'' would be part of the here-and-now.   But the simplest ideas can be the most difficult to bring to market -even when the market is expected to reach $1 billion - perhaps even $6 billion - by 1990. A 1981 report by the Yankee Group, a Cambridge, Mass., computer consulting firm, declared: ''It is clear that the local network will be a market imperative for office automation vendors within the next two years.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Floods in El Salvador Leave at Least 70 Dead   SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 19 (AP) - Torrential rains led to severe floods and mudslides across El Salvador today, killing at least 70 people in one area. The Government declared a national state of emergency.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The French Government's turnabout from economic expansion to at least temporary austerity has given the Communist Party, badly eroded by its uncomfortable junior partnership with the Socialists, some new political opportunities.   Until now, the Communists, who lost a great deal of ground to the Socialists in last year's election, have been careful to support publicly virtually every move of the Government, in which they hold 4 of 44 Cabinet positions. The party leadership reasoned that Socialist popularity and Communist electoral weakness made President Francois Mitterrand's coattails the only viable, if undignified, form of political transport.   Now the party is beginning to give the coattails some vicious tugs, while still riding. The Government's decision to impose a four-month freeze on prices and wages, raise payroll and corporate contributions to the unemployment fund and cut some social benefits has been the Communists' signal to move out to the left.

headline: FOR THE F.D.A., A THREAT TO NEW PROCEDURES
abstract: THE controversy surrounding Eli Lilly's Oraflex, the anti-arthritic drug that was removed from the market this month, has prompted critics of the Food and Drug Administration to advocate a more detailed review of clinical reports and patient records in new drug applications.   The Oraflex case, these critics say, comes at the worst possible time for the F.D.A., which has proposed changes in its procedure for reviewing new drug applications. The changes would reduce the amount of paperwork submitted in new drug applications by as much as 70 percent, and in many cases bring the drugs to market sooner.   In an interview, Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr., the F.D.A.  commissioner, rejected charges that Oraflex's abrupt removal from the market resulted from oversights at his agency or that it would jeopardize the proposed procedural changes. The F.D.A.'s rewrite of procedures, which has been advocated by the pharmaceutical industry for years, was completed in June and sent for approval by the Office of Management and Budget.

headline: Teledyne Drops; CPC Rises 11.3%
abstract: Teledyne Inc., hurt by a generally weak economy and lower results from its specialty metals operations, reported yesterday a 35.5 percent decline on a sales drop of 11 percent for the second quarter.    The diversified Los Angeles-based conglomerate said that net income in the latest three months fell to $77.7 million, or $3.76 a share, from $120.6 million, or $5.84 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales for the quarter fell to $737.3 million, from $828.5 million.   ''There has been some pressure on margins, but they are still somewhat on the high side and I think before the end of ths year we will see further margin erosion,'' said Carol P. Neves, an analyst at Merrill Lynch Inc. ''There is a limit on how much lower the insurance subsidiary's earnings can go since the impact of the recession of the workmen's compensation claims - the bulk of unit's business - apparently has reached its limits''   For the first six months of the year, Teledyne said that net income dropped 22.5 percent, to $168.9 million, or $8.18 a share, from $218 million, or $10.55 a share in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped 6.7 percent, to $1.52 billion, from $1.63 billion.

headline: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.A.O. EXPRESSES DOUBT ON MARITIME SUBSIDIES
abstract: The American ocean shipping industry is ''not in a state of general distress'' and would benefit from less protection, contrary to widespread public opinion and to legislation now pending in Congress, the General Accounting Office says in a study expected to be published later this week.   The conclusion, in a 110-page study now in draft form, contrasts sharply with commonly accepted views of the nation's maritime industry. According to the report, data purporting to show a slide in the maritime industry's health over the last 10 years - a decline usually portrayed as a threat to national security - may have been misinterpeted.   The agency, the investigative arm of Congress, contends that the industry's figures indicate that advances such as containerization of cargo have permitted the shipping industry to do more with fewer vessels - meaning that it has become more efficient and not less healthy.

headline: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1982; International
abstract: Citicorp has disguised billions of dollars in foreign deals in an attempt to get around foreign banking regulations, Government and bank documents show. The documents also show that senior bank officials were aware of or approved some of the practices. Citicorp subsidiaries in Latin America, Europe and Asia have sidestepped reserve requirements and other rules by routing funds through the Bahamas, Monaco and other countries, according to documents obtained or prepared by the S.E.C. Citicorp declined to comment on the documents. (Page A1.)

headline: UNITED STATES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUICIDE IS REPORTED
abstract: President Antonio Guzman, who was scheduled to leave office next month, died today from a gunshot wound in the head.   The Dominican Republic's Government said Mr. Guzman's pistol had accidentally discharged, fatally wounding him.  Privately, high Government officials said the 71-year-old President had committed suicide in the bathroom of his office, but they offered no explanation of why he might have killed himself.

headline: BRITONS JAILED IN ARGENTINA SAW WAR FROM A CELL'S WINDOW
abstract: Simon Winchester, one of the three British journalists imprisoned for 77 days by Argentina on spying charges, reported this weekend that while in prison he kept records of the movements of military planes and ships ''which we could glimpse through the cell's grimy little window.''   Mr. Winchester, of The Sunday Times, was being held in Ushuaia, at the southern tip of Argentina, with two staff members of another Sunday newspaper, The Observer: Ian Mather, a reporter, and Tony Prime, a photographer. They were freed on bail last Tuesday and said on their arrival in Britain that they would return to stand trial.

headline: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI PILOT TELLS OF GREAT EFFORT TO SPARE CIVILIANS
abstract: An Israeli pilot who took part in the bombing of Beirut said today that every precaution was taken to avoid civilian casualties.   The pilot, a major who wished to remain anonymous, discussed in an interview how the bombing missions were selected, how targets were assigned and how the results were assessed. He did not deny that there were civilian casualties, but wondered whether blame was being assigned fairly.   Charges of indiscriminate bombing of Beirut prompted the 34-yearold major to seek out, through a mutual friend, a foreign reporter so that he could present a pilot's view on the extended bombing of the Lebanese capital, an effort that Israeli officials say persuaded the Palestinian guerrillas to leave.

headline: British Await U.S. Reaction
abstract: The British Government is awaiting United States reaction to the plans of John Brown P.L.C. to start loading turbines for the Soviet Union on Monday before deciding on any contingency measures, according to informed sources.   The sources said a small Soviet freighter, the Stachanovetch Erinolenko, is expected to take several days to load 500 crates from docks at Glasgow.

headline: Greek Economists Join New Cabinet
abstract: A new Greek Cabinet was sworn in today after the first shuffle of the Government since the Socialists came to power nine months ago.   Its main feature is the inclusion of a large number of specialists, not members of Parliament, who are expected to deal with the economy.

headline: AETNA SETS TIE TO BANK IN BRITAIN
abstract: In an unusual international alliance of financial institutions, Aetna Life and Casualty Company said yesterday that it is going into partnership with the Midland Bank of Britain in ownership of the Samuel Montagu & Company group, a leading British investment bank and bullion house. Aetna is the largest publicly owned insurance company in the Unites States and Midland is Britain's third-largest clearing bank.   While the affiliation is part of the growing internationalism of the financial community, it is unusual because of the great size of the two partners, and also because of the degree of Aetna's involvement. Other United States insurers have purchased equity in foreign investment banks, but the stakes have been in the 10 percent to 15 percent range, according to Donald G. Conrad, Aetna's chief financial officer.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BY RONALD L. RHODES
abstract: Less than 20 years ago, AEG-Telefunken was a power to be reckoned with in the burgeoning world market for consumer electronic products.  AEG engineers, who had developed the first magnetic tape recorder and one of the world's three color television broadcasting technologies, were justifiably proud when, in June 1970, they introduced their own videodisk playback system. The Telefunken product was intended to take on RCA, CBS, Phillips, Avco and Sony in what would be a decade-long, $1 billion industry-wide battle.

headline: Consumers Still Prefer To Get Free Samples
abstract: People still like to get something for nothing. That is the sage conclusion of a study by Target Advertising and Research, a Hauppauge, L.I., promotional firm.

headline: People
abstract: * Jeffrey A. Devlin has been named senior vice president at SSC&B, New York.

headline: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Saxon Revises Financial Accounts
abstract: Saxon Industries, a New York-based paper and photocopier manufacturer that filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in April, said that possible overstatements in its financial accounts could ''substantially'' exceed a previous estimate. The company has previously said that the overstatements in inventories and accounting at its Miami Lakes, Fla., business products group could be ''at least $24 million.''

headline: MORTON TO ACQUIRE THIOKOL
abstract: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Thiokol Corporation, a manufacturer of rocket propulsion systems and chemicals, in a cash and stock transaction valued at $540 million.   Both Morton-Norwich, a Chicago-based chemicals and consumer products manufacturer, and Thiokol make specialty chemicals that are used in the electronics industry, particularly as etching substances and coating materials for semiconductors. A formal statement, made jointly by Charles S. Locke, chairman and chief executive officer of Morton-Norwich, and Robert E. Davis, chairman and president of Thiokol, said ''specialty chemicals will represent the largest segment of the new company, with annualized sales of approximately $600 million.''   Morton-Norwich's announcement comes a month after it completed the sale of its pharmaceuticals division to Procter & Gamble for $371 million. At the time, Morton-Norwich said it was seeking an acquisition that would complement its chemicals business. The company had sought to sell its small but profitable pharmaceuticals business because of the big research and development costs associated with that industry.

headline: YOUNG POLES FIND A HOME IN MANHATTAN
abstract: A worn desk, a telephone and a few square feet of office space at Freedom House in Manhattan serve as headquarters these days for 200 young Poles who came to the United States to visit and are now seeking political asylum.   Members of the Polish Independent Students Association, which was formed six months ago, are seeking financial help from American philanthropic groups, according to Slavomir Suss, a 24-year-old philosophy major who serves as chairman of the group, and his 22-year-old wife, Barbara.   They also say they are seeking ''visibility'' for their own and other Polish organizations, saying the struggle for change led by the Solidarity union, which is now suspended, seems to have been forgotten after American attention shifted to the conflicts in the Falkland Islands and in Lebanon.

headline: MAJOR CHANGES ARE EXPECTED
abstract: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, today opened the 12th congress of the Chinese Communist party, which is expected to abolish the party chairmanship and thoroughly revamp the leadership.   In an opening speech, he pledged that China would continue to follow an open-door policy toward the outside world but stressed that China would never become any nation's vassal state.   ''Independence and self-reliance have always been and will forever be our basic stand,'' Mr. Deng told the 1,600 delegates in the Great Hall of the People here.

headline: U.S. SEES CUBAN MILITARY THREAT
abstract: Cuba's military relationship with the Soviet Union represents a ''not inconsiderable'' threat to American security interests in the Western Hemisphere, according to a State Department report.   The report, entitled ''Cuban Armed Forces and the Soviet Military Presence,'' says Cuba's military modernization program and its combat experience in Africa have enabled it to acquire a ''substantial regional intervention capability.''

headline: LEBANON CRAZY QUILT LAND OF CONFLICT
abstract: Lebanon's history of violence and instability, underscored anew by the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel, is rooted in a mire of ethnic and religious strife.   Mr. Gemayel promised when he was elected on Aug. 23 to bring unity to his strife-torn, once-prosperous nation. Yet in less than a month he became the latest victim of that strife - killed, it was generally assumed, by political enemies of him and his Phalangist Christian militia.   As a son of Pierre Gemayel, founder of Lebanon's Phalangist Party, Bashir Gemayel inherited a leader's role. But he also inherited a large part of Lebanon's factional hatred.

headline: An Unfair Trade?
abstract: To the Business Editor: Representative George Miller and Senator Gary Hart agree in their ''Forum'' articles (Sept. 5) that assuring asbestos victims ''adequate compensation on a timely basis'' is the ''key issue'' in advocating a Federal system for payment of asbestos disease compensation. Debating the Federal Government's role in supporting such a program, however, only obscures a key question: Is trading away the right to sue worth a promise of 'fair and timely' compensation?

headline: Martin Marietta Directors to Meet
abstract: Directors of the Martin Marietta Corporation will hold a special meeting Monday to discuss an unsolicited, $1.5 billion takeover bid from the Bendix Corporation, Martin Marietta said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Akzona Inc. of Asheville, N.C., said it had scheduled a special shareholders' meeting for Sept. 8 to consider a takeover bid by Akzo N.V. of the Netherlands.   * American First Corp. of Oklahoma City said it had agreed to sell its American First Land Title Insurance Co. unit to Synergy Investments Inc. for about $3.2 million.   * British National Oil Corp. and Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles announced plans to proceed with the previously delayed development of two North Sea oilfields.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Ball Corp. declared a two-for-one stock split and raised its quarterly cash dividend to 52 cents a share, from 45 cents. The split will be payable on Oct. 1 to shareholders of record on Sept. 1.    * Carnation Co. said acquisition discussions with National Color Laboratories Inc., a supplier of photographic laboratory services, had been terminated. Carnation did not elaborate.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Hermes L. Ames, Baldassaro A.  Bascone, Carole Lynne Bell, Robert P. Bowles, William J. Burke Jr.  and Carlos A. Burns vice presidents.   * Fairchild Industries, Germantown, Md., announced that Mason Phelps had resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer of its VSI Corporation subsidiary.   * Fugazy Express Inc., an operating unit of the Fugazy International Corporation, has appointed Dominic A. Polimeni executive vice president-operations.
