headline: CONCERNS OVER TERRORISM INCREASE AFTER A SERIES OF ATTACKS IN PARIS
abstract: In the Marais, Paris's Jewish quarter since the Middle Ages, the mood in the narrow streets and appealingly worn buildings is apprehensive.   Knots of people stand outside Jo Goldenberg's shuttered restaurant, where an attack on Monday left six people dead.  But the fears and worries of terrorism have gone far beyond France's 700,000 Jews. The wave of attacks - the one on the restaurant was only one of eight incidents in Paris in just two weeks - has touched Jews and non-Jews alike and has left the country nervous and clamoring for action. In yet another incident, a fire set early today by an arsonist damaged a hall used for Jewish prayer meetings.

headline: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES HIRES BRANIFF OFFICER
abstract: To hundreds of journalists who covered the financial throes of Braniff Airways, the soft drawl of Sam Coats, its vice president for domestic and international affairs, became a familiar sound. As public relations spokesman for the airline, he rarely lost his sense of humor even during the dark days of its collapse.   Mr. Coats, who had spent six years as vice president and general counsel at Texas International Airlines, joined Braniff shortly after Howard D. Putnam took over as president and chief executive officer in September 1981. He helped Mr. Putnam in what turned out to be a futile effort to turn the ailing Braniff around.

headline: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JULY 24, 1982; The Economy
abstract: Consumer prices rose 1 percent in June, keeping the annual inflation rate at a double-digit level for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported. As in May, the increase in the Consumer Price Index resulted from a sharp rise in gasoline prices combined with higher food costs and a baffling rise in housing prices. Medical costs were also higher. Despite the two-month surge, however, the inflation rate is down from the levels of 1979 and 1980: In the past 12 months, the index has risen just 7.1 percent. Most economists predict it will be about 6 percent for the year. (Page 1.) Prices in the New York area rose 1.7 percent. (37.)   The Senate passed the largest revenue-raising bill ever after a sometimes acrimonious all-night session. In three years, the bill would recover for the Government $99 billion of the tax cuts enacted a year ago. As a last-minute means of achieving the mandated figure, the Senate voted to halve business deductions for meals other than those on overnight trips. (1.) That provision drew a negative reaction from restaurateurs and credit card sponsors. (35.) Another provision, establishing a 10 percent withholding tax on dividends and interest, was criticized in the banking and thrift industries. (36.)

headline: People
abstract: * Peter Tate has been elected a senior vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.  ADVERTISING

headline: Jordache Seeking Fashion Show Record
abstract: Jordache, the jolly jean maker, places a great premium on being first, like being the first of its class to use the television advertising medium. That's exciting.

headline: THE TURNAROUND OF BRITAIN'S FERRANTI
abstract: In a country where most companies have found their profits battered by recession, Ferranti P.L.C., one of Britain's foremost arms and electronics manufacturers, seems hardly to have been bruised.   Since 1980, Ferranti has more than doubled its pretax profit and increased its revenue from $364.8 million, to $521.7 million. In the year ended March 31, 1982, earnings per share were 26 percent higher than in the previous year.   That represents a striking change for a company that in the mid-1970's was virtually insolvent and had to be bailed out by the Government.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Aug 7
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Argentina Restores Political Parties' Rights
abstract: Political parties in Argentina formally recovered their legal right tofunction today with the lifting of a ban imposed after President Isabel Martinez de Peron was toppled in 1976.   President Reynaldo Bignone, who took over on July 1 with a mandate to restore democracy by early 1984 at the latest, signed a law ending the political freeze Friday night.

headline: UNILEVER PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Rates Up a Bit in Erratic Day; Demand for Issues Softens
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly in erratic trading yesterday as the credit markets continued to digest large new issues of Treasury securities.   Prices moved higher early in the day, but declined during the afternoon as dealers recognized that demand for the Treasury's new seven-year notes was not as great as that for the 12 1/4 percent, four-year notes sold on Tuesday. In the long bond market, the 14 percent issue due in 2011 traded above 119, but then declined to an offered price of about 117 1/2 to yield 11.80 percent. The threemonth Treasury bill was as low as 7.15 percent early in the day but closed at 7.35 percent for no change.

headline: DISC Ruling Is Delayed
abstract: The council administering the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade today put off consideration of a European Economic Community proposal to penalize United States exporters for participation in a tax-deferral program. The council will reexamine the American tax plan in October.

headline: A CONVENTION IN RIO LEADS TO AN INTRIGUE
abstract: A Soviet delegate to a political science convention here has disappeared, and the case has taken on the aspects of international intrigue because of the discovery of a dead body resembling him and reports that he was seeking asylum in the United States.   The man, Sevim Geraibekov, was last seen buying shirts and popular music tapes in a Copacabana shopping mall on Aug. 14, a day before the Soviet delegation to the International Political Science Association's world congress was to return to Moscow.   On Aug. 18, an anonymous phone call led the police to a sewage canal in a suburban industrial park where they found a body of a tall white man, a ''biotype,'' according to the coroner, ''that is very uncommon in Brazil.'' Fingerprint checks turned up no record.

headline: ISRAEL WEIGHING IMPACT OF GULF WAR
abstract: Senior Israeli officials believe that Iran's invasion of Iraq, if it proves to be a full-fledged and sustained attack with the aim of overthrowing President Saddam Hussein, is likely to overshadow the war in Lebanon in its importance for East-West relations and the future of the Middle East.   The officials see the Iranian drive against Iraq as an onslaught on a country that is both an important center of Soviet influence and Israel's most unrelenting enemy in the Middle East. They noted that Iraq was the only country in the region that refused to sign the 1949 truce that ended the Israeli war of independence and still refuses to refer to Israel by any terms but ''the Zionist entity'' or ''occupied territory.''

headline: Fire in U.S. Mission in Seoul
abstract: A minor fire broke out in the United States Embassy building here today, and the South Korean police said it was probably caused by an electric fault. The blaze damaged a room and destroyed furniture and documents.

headline: KEY PHALANGIST AIDES IMPLICATED IN OPERATION THAT LED TO KILLINGS
abstract: The operation that started in the Shatila Palestinian refugee camp in Beirut and resulted in the massacre of more than 300 civilians was directed by the top Phalangist military commanders and involved the elite corps of the Phalangist militia, according to Phalangist and Western diplomatic sources in Beirut.   President-elect Amin Gemayel, according to the same sources, is not believed to have known much about the operation, which spread to the adjacent Sabra camp. Although he was in the leadership of the Phalangists and now heads the right-wing party, he was effectively excluded from its military circle and was apparently not involved in the planning. His brother, Bashir, who was also President-elect and was assassinated Sept. 14, said before his death that he planned to disband the Christian militia and strengthen the regular Lebanese Army, which is a separate force of about 22,000 men.   From the information supplied by the sources, it could not be determined whether the massacre that occurred after the troops went in was planned from the beginning.

headline: Two Brokers to Merge
abstract: Two brokerage houses, Laing & Cruickshank and McNally, Montgomery & Company, are to merge Nov. 29, subject to approval by the London Stock Exchange, a joint statement said today. The merger will result in some 60 layoffs, leaving the combined company with a staff of about 350.

headline: Fashion Submits Plan to Reorganize
abstract: Fashion Two Twenty Inc., an Aurora, Ohio, maker and marketer of cosmetics that filed for protection from its creditors on Dec. 10, 1981, said that it had submitted a plan of reorganization to the United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland. Fashion Two Twenty had unsecured debt of $700,000, owed mostly to cosmetics suppliers, at the time.

headline: U.S. HAS TRADE SURPLUS OF $2.1 BILLION IN QUARTER
abstract: The United States posted a $2.1 billion overall trade surplus in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today. The country had a deficit in merchandise trade, but that was offset by the sale of services.   The surplus, the largest in the nation's current account since the first quarter of 1981, reflected success by the United States in overcoming the consequences of recession at home and abroad. The current account includes trade in services and financial transactions, as well as merchandise trade.

headline: FIRST AMERICAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The start of the fiscal year 1983 on Friday will also mark the opening of President Reagan's campaign to reduce the Federal budget deficit for 1984. White House watchers say the new campaign may be even more divisive than the battle over the 1983 budget. (Page D1.) The 1982 deficit will set a record. (D5.)

headline: Week in Business; CHANGES IN THE A.T.&T. SETTLEMENT
abstract: Federal District Court Judge Harold H. Greene (left) approved the basic antitrust settlement reached in January between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but insisted on major modifications before he would give final approval to the spinoff of A.T.& T.'s 22 local units. Judge Greene, who presided over the year-long trial prior to the proposed settlement, said he wanted to be allowed to review and approve each step in the divestiture. He also urged that A.T.& T. delay entry into the electronic-information services field and that the phone companies be allowed to sell equipment and publish the Yellow Pages directory.

headline: Crop Projections Stun Grain and Soybean Pits
abstract: The grain and soybean futures markets, which had marked time for days while awaiting the Government's August crop estimate, was stunned when it came out after yesterday's close. The figures were far more bearish than the direst forecasts.   With the grain and oilseed prices deeply depressed by huge supplies left over from the record and near-record harvests of last year, the latest crop projections by the Government were expected to crush any hope corn, wheat and soybean farmers held for a recovery in prices this year and next year. Indeed, the surpluses from the current season are expected to swell already burdensome supplies and add further pressure on prices in 1983.

headline: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Chancellor Government Securities, a low-load open-end diversified managment company, said it would offer shares of its Trust-Intermediate series, with a minimum initial investment of $1,000, through Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.   * Citicorp announced that an average rate of 10.857 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 10.694 percent last week.

headline: Somalis and Ethiopians Continue to Battle
abstract: Fighting raged between Somali Government troops and Ethiopian forces inside central Somalia today, a Defense Ministry communique said.   President Mohammed Siad Barre declared a state of emergency Sunday in areas along the Somali border with Ethiopia.

headline: Ex-Vietcong Reports Seeing P.O.W.'s Alive
abstract: A former Vietcong official now living in Switzerland was said to have seen 30 to 40 American pilots alive in North Vietnam in 1973, two months after the Hanoi Government declared that it had freed all American P.O.W.'s.   The former official, Nguyen Duc Yen, was quoted in an article to be published Sunday by Parade magazine as saying the Americans were doing ''hard labor'' in the North Vietnamese highlands.   He said they were to be used as bargaining chips to help Hanoi establish diplomatic ties with Washington.

headline: Amex Plans Gold Options
abstract: The American Stock Exchange's board of governors has voted to open an options market in gold bullion and has requested approval for the new market from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Arthur Levitt, the exchange's chairman, announced yesterday. The commission recently proposed regulations that would permit options trading on many physical commodities.

headline: TV to Carry Reagan Speech
abstract: President Reagan's speech at 8 P.M. will be covered live by the three major television networks, ABC, CBS and NBC, and by Cable News Network, their spokesmen said yesterday.

headline: Stake in Newmont
abstract: The Newmont Mining Corporation said that Consolidated Gold Fields, a British company that directly or indirectly owns about 22 percent of Newmont's voting stock, and its Amcon Group Inc. subsidiary could buy an additional 4 percent under an amended agreement. Under the arrangement, ownership of 25 percent or more of Newmont's voting stock by a noncitizen would not cause those companies to be in violation of United States maritime laws.

headline: JUDGE LETS MARIETTA PURSUE BENDIX BID
abstract: The Bendix Corporation last night failed in its last-ditch effort to convince a court to halt the Martin Marietta Corporation's $900 million bid for a controlling stake in Bendix, which already owns 70 percent of Marietta.   The argument presented by Bendix lawyers was that Marietta's board should not be allowed to go ahead with a purchase it knew was opposed by Bendix, which became Marietta's majority shareholder on Monday through a $48-a-share tender offer. Rejected by Two Courts   That position was rejected both in the Federal District Court and in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, and John H. Lewin Jr., one of the lawyers for Bendix, said the company did not intend to appeal to the United States Supreme Court before the midnight deadline.

headline: Artificial Thought Funding by Digital
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it was granting funding to Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst for studies on artificial intelligence, the process in which computers are made able to perform tasks requiring thought when done by humans.   Under its agreement with the University of Massachusetts, Digital will be entitled to an irrevocable royalty-free, nonexclusive license to any technology developed. Patent rights would remain with the university.

headline: RABBI AND 2 CHRISTIAN CLERICS DENOUNCE INVASION
abstract: A rabbi and two Christian clergymen from the New York area yesterday jointly denounced Israel's invasion of Lebanon and called for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Israeli military forces.   The rabbi, Israel Dresner, president of the Association of Reform Rabbis of Greater New York and Vicinity, spoke out for himself and not in behalf of the association he heads.  The forum was a news conference held by the newly formed National Emergency Committee on Lebanon. The conference was held at the United Nations Church Center at 777 First Avenue.

headline: DRY DOCK ARRANGES DOLLAR LINK
abstract: Seeking to avoid being auctioned off by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the financially ailing Dry Dock Savings Bank has arranged its own merger into the stronger Dollar Savings Bank, the two banks have announced.   But the plan requires financial support and approval from the F.D.I.C., the Government agency that insures deposits in savings banks, and it remains uncertain whether such approval will be forthcoming. The insurance corporation declined to comment on the banks' Tuesday announcement.   It was learned yesterday that the agency is accepting bids for the merger of the failing United Mutual Savings Bank, which with $833 million in assets is the 22d-largest state-chartered mutual savings bank in New York City. United Mutual reported a $5.8 million loss in the second quarter. If that rate of loss were to continue, the bank would run out of capital within less than nine months.

headline: No Headline
abstract: South Africa Intends to Build New Generation of Warships   PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 25 (Reuters) - South Africa plans to build its own submarines and a new generation of warships, according to the outgoing navy chief, Vice Adm. Ronnie Edwards.

headline: Polish Minister in Moscow
abstract: Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski of Poland arrived here today on a two-day visit for talks. He met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to discuss Soviet-Polish relations, the press agency Tass said.

headline: Israeli Consul Predicts Trials For Many Seized in Lebanon
abstract: An Israeli official said in New York yesterday that many of the 5,800 Palestinians taken prisoner by the Israeli Army in Lebanon would be tried as criminals.

headline: 2 Killed as Swiss Jet Crashes
abstract: A Swiss air force jet fighter crashed into a mountain pasture today, killing a 10-year-old child and a 17-year-old youth. The police said the pilot had ejected safely when his Hunter fighter had engine failure shortly after takeoff.

headline: Pope Voices Concern Over People in Beirut
abstract: Pope John Paul II today prayed for peace in Lebanon and voiced concern about food and water shortages in Beirut.

headline: LIMITED EFFECT SEEN IN SWISS ACCORD
abstract: Individuals seeking to engage in insider trading on American stock markets are likely to turn to banks in countries other than Switzerland as a result of the agreement reportedly reached yesterday between United States and Swiss authorities, according to bankers in New York.   For this reason, the bankers predicted that the agreement would have only limited effect on the ability of individuals to use foreign banks to circumvent American laws against insider trading.  The only disadvantage to such individuals, the bankers said, would be that they would have to deal with smaller banks with lesser reputations than the big Swiss banks. Among the countries with strong bank secrecy laws are Panama, Liechtenstein, the Bahamas and other islands in the Caribbean.

headline: Chromalloy Trims Jobs and Spending
abstract: The Chromalloy American Corporation said that it had cut its domestic employment by about 2,500 workers since January, to 15,000, through layoffs, early retirement and job terminations.

headline: DeLorean Bailout
abstract: A new company formed by American businessman John DeLorean has agreed to the initial terms set by receivers to purchase the car plant he built here from them, a Government spokesman said today. He said the deal, seen here as the last change to save the failed sports car factory started up three years ago by the former General Motors executive, still depended on the American company producing the necessary money. The plant closed in May because of finance problems and low sales.

headline: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Cummins Layoffs
abstract: The Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind., said it would reduce its worldwide employment by 1,750 persons, including more than 1,000 in southern Indiana. The action would bring the number of employees laid off to 6,000, the company said.

headline: TRUDEAU SAYS OTTAWA WON'T 'BAIL OUT' DOME
abstract: The Canadian Government went on record Monday for the first time that it would not ''bail out'' financially troubled Dome Petroleum Ltd. The statement, by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau in a radio interview, appeared to contradict the federal Government's earlier position that it was willing to come to the rescue of Canada's largest oil company.   But Dome was quick to assert that the Prime Minister's remarks ''are in no way incompatible with our understanding of the federal Government's position.''

headline: RATES RISE IN QUIET TRADING
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants said they were waiting for signals from the Federal Reserve that would guide the markets to higher or lower rates.   ''There is a fear that the Federal Reserve has stopped easing,'' one Government securities dealer said. To see whether or not the Fed is continuing to make reserves more available in the banking system, analysts were watching the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market. Since the funds rate tends to fall when the Federal Reserve makes credit more available to the banking system and rise when reserves are scarcer, it is regarded as a weather vane to the Fed's intentions.

headline: AFGHAN TALKS HELD BY U.S. AND SOVIET
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union have just concluded an unpublicized round of talks in Moscow on the possibility of a political solution in Afghanistan, Administration officials said today.   Officials said they did not have a full report on the results of the discussions but there were no signs of any breakthrough leading to the withdrawal of the approximately 100,000 Soviet troops in that country.   On a related matter, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said in Geneva today that 4,350 Afghan refugees living in camps in Pakistan would be flown to Turkey next month. The move will be the first major resettlement operation since the Soviet thrust into Afghanistan in December 1979. The spokesman said that 13 planes involved in the operation would also fly the tribesmen's cattle to Turkey.

headline: Law of the Sea Pact To Be Signed in Jamaica
abstract: The United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea will culminate nine years of negotiations in December by signing a treaty in Kingston, Jamaica.

headline: PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Controlling Money Supply
abstract: IN a more ideal world, better short-term monetary marksmanship is not especially important for its own sake. Few would argue that brief, and perhaps even sizable, deviations of money from a desired longer-term path have significant repercussions either for total spending and inflation or for expectations about their future movements as long as market participants recognize that the deviations will be corrected.   Today's market participants, however, have neither the information for making that judgment, nor the requisite amount of faith in the intention or the ability of the Federal Reserve to carry out its objectives. An improved money control mechanism buttressed by more specific information about the central bank's objectives would help to rebuild credibility.

headline: FLEXI-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARABS ADOPT PLAN FOR MIDEAST PEACE AT MOROCCO TALKS
abstract: Arab leaders adopted a resolution late tonight that they said represented a united Arab peace plan for the Middle East containing a solution to the problem of the Palestinians.    The eight-point plan was approved by the 20 Arab League members represented at a four-day Arab summit conference here. According to an unofficial translation from the Arabic, the plan did not contain any specific references to Israel's right to exist, but it specifically referred to the creation of ''an independent Palestinian state.'' (In Washington, the State Department said it had no immediate comment on the Arab proposals.)

headline: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1982
abstract: Companies   Allied acquired Bendix, and Martin Marietta is independent again, as a takeover battle that changed the shape of three major corporations finally came to an end. (Page 1.) Allied agreed to retain about 38 percent of Marietta's stock. This was meant to accommodate Marietta, which is heavily in debt as a result of its 30-day takeover battle with Bendex. Allied also agreed not to try to take over Marietta for the next 10 years. (39.)   Woolworth is shutting down all 336 of its Woolco discount stores in the U.S. because of mounting losses incurred by the chain. The Woolco stores, though scattered throughout the country, are concentrated in the southeastern and south-central states. The decision leaves in doubt the prospects of nearly 25,000 workers. The company said it hopes to absorb or find new jobs for them. The Woolworth variety stores are not affected by the action. (39.)

headline: G.M. Plans 9,100 Layoffs
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would lay off 9,100 workers indefinitely in the coming weeks because of production cutbacks necessitated by weak sales of intermediate, compact and subcompact cars.   G.M. attributed the curtailments in production schedules for 1983 models to ''current market conditions.''

headline: TREASURY ISSUES LEAD PRICE RALLY
abstract: Interest rates plummeted yesterday as a surging rally in Treasury securities set the tone for an overall improvement in fixed-income markets, dealers said. Meanwhile, brisk demand for new corporate offerings continued.   A key factor in stimulating what market participants called ''a flight to quality'' - bills, notes and bonds backed by the United States Government - was the news that Lombard-Wall Inc., a company that trades in Government securities and other money market instruments, had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankrupcy Act. Similar action was taken by its subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets Inc.

headline: China Seeks French Jets
abstract: China wants to buy and co-manufacture French Mirage fighter planes, French sources said today. The sources said the Communist Party Chairman, Hu Yaobang, told a delegation of French journalists that China is pleased with its purchase of 50 French helicopters and an agreement to co-produce 150 more, and wants to expand Chinese-French cooperation to include the Mirage jets. Mr.  Hu did not say how many of the planes China wanted.

headline: PETROLANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 1 WOUNDED IN PARIS BY BLAST AT A BANK ONCE JEWISH-OWNED
abstract: A bomb exploded early today outside a bank that had been Jewish owned, severely wounding a woman who was walking her dog.   The police said the explosion was caused by a bomb placed outside a street-level window of an eight-story commercial building housing the Banque de Gestion Privee.

headline: STRONG DOLLAR, WEAK INDUSTRY
abstract: American industry, it would appear, is paying the price of the strong dollar.  For American tourists, the dollar's sharp rise against other currencies has been an boon. They can now buy at least 50 percent more French francs and Italian lire and 35 percent more West German marks than they could only two years ago.   And in the fight against American inflation, the currency's strength has been of some help - and for the Administration, a sign of success for Reagan policies.

headline: O.A.U. SAID TO TRY TO REVIVE MEETING
abstract: On the beachfront here stand Tripoli's new hotels, the Bab el Bahar, for one, the Grand for another, white and dazzling. They were built quickly to house delegates, officials and journalists for what should have been the Organization of African Unity's annual conference in August.   The gathering, however, did not take place in the manner aspired to by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi because there were not enough participants to form the two-thirds quorum required. Consequently, Colonel Qaddafi, Libya's isolated leader, did not become the organization's chairman - a position that would have bestowed on him unfamiliar prestige as a continent's spokesman. The hotels, these days, are half-empty, monuments to Africa's and the colonel's failures.

headline: ISRAEL CHANGING FACE OF WEST BANK
abstract: Occupied West Bank - The boundary separating Israel proper from the occupied West Bank has become invisible. It has vanished from Israeli maps. It has dissolved into the stonestrewn hills that rise gracefully from the outskirts of Tel Aviv. It has left no reminder of the tense frontier between Jordan and Israel that it once was - no scrap of fence, no army checkpoint, no clue to the traveler that he is passing from one world into another.   After 15 years of Israeli occupation, the West Bank can no longer be defined by its old border. Israel has not annexed the territory outright, but is spilling into it, infiltrating it, changing its residential and land-ownership patterns until the dividing lines between Israeli and Arab societies, between elected and appointed government, between civilian and martial law, have been gradually redrawn into a jigsaw puzzle of Israeli townships and Arab villages existing under two entirely separate systems. A Deeply Entrenched Presence   Most of this has happened in the five years that Menachem Begin has been Prime Minister. He is determined to see the West Bank, which he calls by the ancient names Judea and Samaria, under permanent Israeli sovereignty. The situation has progressed so far that a freeze on further Jewish settlement, as proposed by President Reagan, would still leave the Israeli presence deeply entrenched.

headline: PLANNERS ON ENERGY THRIVING
abstract: For the Masonite Corporation, the huge cost of its energy bill each month brought with it an urge to conserve. But, like many companies trying to cut such costs, the nation's No.1 maker of hardboard found it had to bring in outside help.   Altering corporate habits from the inside, it turns out, can be awkward. Few in-house engineers have a free hand in changing the way things are done by higher-ranking executives. And then there are the uninspired janitors who leave lights on as they leave, and the top executives who have never dissected an energy bill to see where it all goes.

headline: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dalai Lama to Visit Malaysia
abstract: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual and temporal head of the Tibetan people, will arrive here July 27 to begin a tour of Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and Australia, Government officials said today. The Dalai Lama, who lives in exile in India, will be a guest of Malaysian Buddhist associations, an official said.

headline: TAX SHELTERS
abstract: To the Business Editor: In ''The Continued Appeal of Tax Shelters,'' a statement is made that write-offs of three and four to one ''are highly suspect.'' This may lead the reader to doubt the soundness of many tax-sheltered programs offering multiple write-offs.

headline: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KAISER ALUMINUM
abstract: A.S. Hutchcraft, president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, ordered a reexamination of the company's $600 million modernization program for its primary aluminum plants in Mead and Tacoma, Wash., and asked Kaiser's attorneys to explore its legal remedies. He said he viewed with ''extreme concern'' the Bonneville Power Administration's new direct service industrial electric rates, which, he said, would increase the company's rates in the next fiscal year from a previously estimated 2.2 cents per kilowatt hour to 2.59 cents.

headline: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Panhandle Algerian Gas
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today that Algeria would start loading the first shipment of liquefied natural gas for its Lake Charles, La., terminal on Sept.  11. It also said it had agreed to modify the formula governing the future price of the gas, noting that the change in its agreement with Sonatrach, Algeria's state oil and gas company, was subject to approval by both Governments.

headline: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BANKERS TROUBLED IN WEST GERMANY
abstract: A succession of setbacks in domestic and overseas business has spread a mood of uncertainty through West Germany's banking industry.   Years of explosive growth in the 1970's catapulted Germany's big banks into the top ranks of the international banking community. Now, they seem to be bracing themselves for a harsher period of markedly slower growth and reduced profitability.   Indeed, some bankers are raising uncomfortable questions about the long-term effects of the pinch on Germany's banks and on the country's overall economy.

headline: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Poland and Catholics Agree on Visit by Pope
abstract: The Government and the Roman Catholic Church agreed today on a new date for a visit by Pope John Paul II.

headline: INEXPERIENCE WILL CAUSE OTHERS TO FAIL
abstract: SINCE the folding of Drysdale Government Securities in May and Lombard-Wall 10 days ago, i nvestors who thought they understood the United States Government s ecurities market are having second thoughts. And rightly so. Where t his market once functioned at the hands of highly capable traders, i ts many-fold expansion over the last eight years has attracted i nexperienced, complacent and greedy players. Thus, for someone who h as monitored the goings on in repurchase agreement trading, the two c ollapses came as no surprise. If anything, they were long overdue.  The Lombard-Wall and Drysdale failures may result in the failure of other small firms that trade in repurchase agreement of Government securities. But for its impact on Wall Street as a whole, the event will amount to no more than a small brush fire.

headline: Peabody Weighs Plan
abstract: The Peabody Coal Company of St. Louis, the nation's largest coal producer, expressed interest yesterday in participating as a joint venture partner in the North Alabama Coal gasification project to convert 1.7 million tons of high-sulfur Middle Western coal annually to 375 million gallons of methanol for use in transportation.

headline: Business Conditions; COPPER PRICE DOLDRUMS
abstract: The recent drop in interest rates has improved the prospects for a turnaround, but copper prices have not yet responded to the decline, leaving producers mired in their worst depression since the 1930's.   The only thing that will pull the copper market out of its slump is a depletion of inventories, said Robert Lesemann, a vice president at the Commodities Research Unit, a consulting group specializing in the minerals industry.

headline: Cook International
abstract: Cook International Inc., an insurance brokerage firm, said it would soon complete the purchase of an additional 17.5 million stock units of NCC Energy P.L.C., of London, thus bringing its ownership of NCC to about 34.8 million units, or about 94.6 percent. Cook said its total acquisition cost for NCC Energy was approximately $21.5 million and that its tender offer of about 45 cents for each NCC Energy unit had been extended indefinitely.

headline: Chief of A.& A. Services Heads British Unit Also
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the large New York-based insurance brokerage firm, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, John A. Bogardus Jr., had assumed the same posts at its newly acquired subsidiary in London, the Alexander Howden Group.   A.& A. Services, as it is called, paid $300 million in cash and securities for Howden earlier this year. Last month, the company said it was reviewing Howden transactions involving reinsurance coverage and the termination of the reserves of certain subsidiary insurance companies.

headline: FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Administration, in its midyear economic review, predicts a recovery this year and next that would be more extensive than many current projections. The report, which has been rejected by some of the President's top advisers, forecasts a budget deficit of $115 billion for fiscal year 1983. (Page A1.)   The House approved a $13.8 billion supplemental spending bill that might be vetoed by the President. The bill provides $362.6 million for military programs, $2.1 billion less than the Administration sought. The House used most of the difference to bolster domestic programs. The measure now goes to the Senate. (A1.)

headline: U.S. Currency Intervention
abstract: The Government entered the foreign exchange markets on Aug. 4, for only the third time in 16 months, Treasury Department officials said today.   The Administration appeared to be trying to halt a rise in the value of the dollar by selling dollars in exchange for foreign currencies, thereby increasing the supply of dollars and reducing demand.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Avnet Inc. has elected to its board J. Sidney Webb, former vice chairman of TRW and former president of the TRW-Fujitsu Company.   * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Elizabeth M. Engel, Melvin J.  Fontana, William F. Fox Jr., Linda J. Freshwater and Robert C.  Gottschall vice presidents.   * Chi Systems Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., has appointed Stephewn W.  Hatch vice president and senior consultant.

headline: United Technologies Reorganizes Pratt Unit
abstract: As part of what the United Technologies Corporation of East Hartford, Conn., yesterday termed a major strategic reorganization of its power sector, Richard J. Coar was named president of the Pratt & Whitney Group.   Mr. Coar, 61, will be responsible for worldwide operations of design, development and manufacture of the company's jet engines.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Applied Data Research Inc., Princeton, N.J., has appointed Joseph W. Farrelly, Edwin C. Millsap and E. Linwood Pearce vice presidents.   * Continental Air Lines, Los Angeles, has named Mickey P. Foret vice president and treasurer.   * Columbia Gas Distribution Companies of the Columbia Gas System, Columbus, Ohio, appointed Richard J. Gordon a senior vice president and director for general operations and engineering activities, and C. Ronald Tilley senior vice president and director with responsibility for rates and financial matters.

headline: Dow Up 1.33 at End After Early Decline
abstract: The stock market bounced back from a morning slide to close slightly higher yesterday. Analysts said that investors were disappointed by a rise in producer prices, but encouraged by the prospect that the Federal Reserve Board would not have to tighten its control over the money supply and thus end the recent decline in interest rates.   The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 828.67, up 1.33 points for the day and up 14.55 points for the week. New York Stock Exchange issues advancing outnumbered those declining 770 to 623.  Volume was 58.7 million, down from 61.1 million on Thursday.

headline: REAGAN AND MRS. GANDHI RESOLVE DISPUTE ON NUCLEAR FUEL FOR INDIA
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and President Reagan agreed today to increase scientific, cultural and economic cooperation between the nations and resolve a longstanding dispute over India's nuclear program.   Under the nuclear agreement, low-enriched uranium fuel for a United States-built atomic power plant near Bombay is to be provided to India by a third country, France, instead of by the United States.  The move gets around a problem created by an American law blocking shipments from this country.   The problem had hurt relations between the United States and India for several years, and its apparent solution contributed to the cordial mood evident as the two leaders met here today. 'An Adventure'   ''Every journey is an adventure,'' Mrs. Gandhi said, standing in a silk sari on the sun-drenched South Lawn of the White House during welcoming ceremonies. ''And I can say that this one is an adventure in search of understanding and friendship.''

headline: BENDIX SAFEGUARDS EXECUTIVE BENEFITS
abstract: The Bendix Corporation disclosed yesterday that its board chairman, William M. Agee, and 15 other officers would get at least $16 million in salary and other benefits if the United Technologies Corporation succeeded in its $1.5 billion takeover bid for Bendix.   Bendix said that the so-called golden parachutes, granted on Tuesday, the same day United Technologies made its offer, would give the 44-year-old board chairman guaranteed protection against dismissal or loss of status for five years. The other 15 would receive similar protection for three years.   The disclosure was made to investors in connection with a Sept. 21 stockholder meeting to strengthen company bylaws against a takeover.  Bendix told stockholders that if any company dismissed or demoted Mr. Agee in the next five years, his basic salary, bonus, welfare benefits and pension would be continued until 1987. Mr. Agee's current annual rate of basic salary and bonus - $805,000 -would mean that he would receive at least $4 million in severance pay if United took over the company.

headline: Israelis Fired On Again In Lebanon, They Say
abstract: Israel said today that its troops were fired upon for the second time in four days with bazookas and automatic weapons in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley in Lebanon.   The military command in Tel Aviv said Syrian or Palestinian forces fired on Israeli forces about 7 P.M. in the Mansura area, northeast of Lake Qaroun, and that Israeli soldiers returned the fire.

headline: President of Angola Shuffles His Cabinet
abstract: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola shuffled his Cabinet and dismissed a key member of his Government, the official Angolan press agency said today.   The agency, in a report monitored here, said Mr. dos Santos on Saturday dismissed Lopo Ferreira do Nascimento, a member of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola-Workers' Party.

headline: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARKET TAKING RUSH IN STRIDE
abstract: With the record-shattering stock market volume of recent days came the question of whether the stock exchanges and the brokers could keep up with the paperwork involved. The answer was a solid yes.   With hardly a ripple, the New York Stock Exchange handled 455.1 million shares last week - more than in the entire year of 1953 - including a record 132.7 million shares on Wednesday. So far this week, volume has exceeded 100 million shares a day.

headline: ANHEUSER-BUSCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Article 027272 -- No Title
abstract: The first survey of war damage in southern Lebanon shows that in the town of Tyre alone, which was a major Palestinian headquarters, the Israeli invasion resulted in losses of approximately $75 million in housing, industry, schools, hospitals, agriculture and public utilities.   The report, by the Lebanese engineering concern of Jalal Bitar, was made available by Israeli relief workers here. It is said to be based on a house-to-house survey but does not include the destruction of furniture, medical equipment or automobiles, which one relief official estimated could run $10 million more.   The report lists 310 residential dwellings completely destroyed and 1,550 damaged, 250 of them seriously. Three hospitals and 14 schools are listed by name as damaged, some suffering as little as $15,000 worth, others up to $400,000.

headline: FRANCE AND ITALY SUPPORT REAGAN ON USE OF TROOPS
abstract: The Italian and French Foreign Ministers said today that their joint force with the United States was likely to stay in Beirut until other foreign troops had left Lebanon.   Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy told a reporter that the force's departure was ''tied to a fact, not to a date.'' That fact, he said, is ''the evacuation of the foreign forces, Syrian and Israeli,'' which he said ''must take place in a short time.''

headline: Control Data Buys Firm
abstract: The Control Data Corporation said today that it had acquired Tabershaw Associates, a computer-based employee health protection and monitoring systems company. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition will make it possible for Control Data to add a number of software components and consulting services to its own occupational health system, which has been marketed since 1980, it said.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Intelligence analysts in Washington, London and several capitals in the Middle East have differing views over the Iranians' prospects in any all-out attempt to invade Iraq.   The view in London and Washington is that the Iranians are taking up where they left off in late May, when they swiftly and relatively easily recaptured the port city of Khurramshahr to cap an offensive that had rolled the Iraqi army out of Iran. These analysts believe the Iranians will seize Basra and possibly move north toward Baghdad in the hope that this advance might suffice to unseat Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein. This is one of Iran's war aims.

headline: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1982; International
abstract: A House panel approved the repeal of U.S. sanctions against the sale of equipment for a Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe. The action, a rebuff to the Reagan Administration, reflected concern that the sanctions were costing jobs and straining relations with European allies. Seven Republicans voted for the bill despite an appeal from Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (Page A1.)   Five Common Market countries and Rumania dumped steel in the U.S.  by selling it at prices as much as 41 percent below ''fair value,'' the Commerce Department ruled. The preliminary decision means that stiff duties could be levied on steel imports in addition to the duties that may be imposed as a result of a separate ruling. (D1.)

headline: Your Money; Alternatives To 'All Savers'
abstract: WITH about $30 billion worth of 'All Savers' certificates coming due this quarter, hundreds of thousands of Americans must decide where to invest the funds they will receive. And their choices are legion.   The All Savers program, authorized by the Economic Recovery Tax Act last year, allowed banks, savings and loan associations, credit unions and other financial institutions to issue new one-year savings certificates yielding 70 percent of the interest rate on oneyear Treasury bills.   A major selling point of these federally insured certificates was that those who bought them could exclude up to $1,000 on an individual return and $2,000 on a joint return of the interest earned from Federal taxes.

headline: LYON METAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LEADING INDICATORS ROSE 0.3% IN MAY
abstract: The Index of Leading Indicators, the Government's gauge of future economic strength, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May for its third consecutive advance, the Commerce Department said. The gain was viewed as the beginning of a slow recovery.   The unemployment rate was unchanged at 9.5 percent in June. With 10.4 million people out of work, post World War II levels of joblessness were maintained.

headline: Business Digest; TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1982; The Economy
abstract: The Southeast's current unemployment problem may be a sign of underlying troubles that could hinder the ability of the region's industries to remain competitive. Although many Northerners perceive the Sun Belt as one continuous flow of prosperity, five of the nine Southeast states had unemployment rates higher than the national average in May. (Page A1.)

headline: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KLA INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. CITES SAXON FOR FALSE DATA
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that Saxon Industries, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, and three of its executives had conspired to falsify the company's books.   The S.E.C. said in its complaint that a scheme that lasted from 1968 to 1981 padded the company's books with about $75 million in nonexistent inventory. As a result, the complaint said, misleading documentation was filed with the commission and ''false and misleading information was given to the public.''

headline: Socal Tar Sands
abstract: The Standard Oil Company of California has agreed in principle to develop commercial oil production from the GNC Energy Corporation's 2,000 acres of tar sands holdings near Sunnyside, Utah, the companies said. The first phase of the estimated $1 billion venture will further delineate the estimated 350 million barrels of economically recoverable tar sands and bitumen, and finish development of a commercial process.

headline: DECISION FOR GEMAYEL: INVESTIGATING THE MASSACRE
abstract: President Amin Gemayel is said by knowledgeable Lebanese officials and foreign diplomats to be about to make important decisions on key issues, including one on the question of a Government investigation into the killings of Palestinian civilians this month.   Mr. Gemayel, who took office last week, is a Maronite Christian and head of the political wing of the Phalangist Party, whose militiamen committed the murders in the Shatila and Sabra refugee camps after they were sent in by the Israelis on Sept. 16. The 15,000-member militia was commanded by Amin Gemayel's brother, Bashir, who was elected President on Aug.  23 but was assassinated Sept. 14.   Many of the militiamen are reportedly not ready to show Amin Gemayel the same kind of loyalty they had for his brother, and some American diplomats here believe that he may not even have known that the Phalangists were going into the camps until after the massacre started.

headline: AN APRON FOR SOVIET WOMAN IN SPACE
abstract: The eight-day flight of Svetlana Y. Savitskaya, a 34-year-old Soviet aviator, has been proclaimed here as a triumph of the emancipation of women under Soviet rule.   Miss Savitskaya is the second Soviet woman to be placed in earth orbit and returned safely.  The official press has noted proudly that the event took place eight months before Sally K. Ride, chosen to be the United States' first female astronaut, is to be launched as a mission specialist on the space shuttle.   However, Miss Savitskaya's flight with two male companions has also served to underline the ambiguities in Soviet attitudes toward women, which combine a vaunting pride in the advancement of women with a degree of sentimentality and deference that would jar many Western feminists.

headline: BAR GROUP SPLIT ON TAX SHELTER CASE
abstract: The American Bar Association has angered many leading tax lawyers who are active members by refusing to oppose what they call an ''outrageous'' tax shelter concept, now before the Supreme Court, that could allow the wealthy to escape taxes on millions of dollars in income.   The Board of Governors of the association, now holding its annual convention here, has turned down a request by the association's Section of Taxation to file a brief opposing the tax shelter idea as a threat to the fairness and integrity of the entire income tax system.   In a recent newsletter, John S. Nolan, a Washington lawyer who heads the tax section, called this a ''shocking'' example of tolerating ''serious tax avoidance'' for fear of offending wealthy clients who might benefit from similar tax shelters.   Tax experts, including Mr. Nolan and Bernard Wolfman, a Harvard Law professor, said the case, called Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Tufts, is very important - indeed, in the words of Matthew J. Zinn, another Washington tax lawyer active in the bar association, ''the most important tax case to come to the Supreme Court in at least 10 years.''

headline: MASSACRES SPREAD TERROR IN THE LAND OF MAYA
abstract: It was just before dawn when Pedro Gualin heard the shooting, grabbed his hunting rifle and ran into the foliage. He watched helplessly as the strangers in civilian clothes fired wildly into the huts and set them on fire.   When it was all over, he said, he found his wife, Marcela Laj Kak, dead on the floor. At least 60 other men, women and children in this Pokonchi Indian mountain village were also dead. Many of the 300 survivors who fled to nearby San Cristobal told the townsfolk that the army had come to kill them and that they would never sleep in Las Pacayas again.

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLISH CHIEF VOWS TO PUT DOWN PROTESTS   WARSAW, Aug. 24 (UPI) - Poland's martial-law leader was quoted today as having pledged to take strong action against any new opposition activities.   The pledge, reported by the official press, appeared to be part of a growing Government campaign to counter a call by underground union leaders for mass demonstrations next Tuesday, the second anniversary of the independent union Solidarity, which was suspended with the declaration of martial law last Dec. 13.   ''The enemy knows that time is on our side and will do everything to put obstacles in our way,'' said Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, head of the martial law Government. ''Its next attack must and will be defeated.''

headline: ISRAEL TRIES TO VILIFY PEACE FORCE, U.N. AIDE SAYS
abstract: A senior United Nations official said today that Israel was trying to demonstrate that the United Nations was biased in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization and hence unfit for peacekeeping in Lebanon.   The official spoke in response to an Israeli complaint that arms had been found in a school run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinians and to an Israeli disclosure of a P.L.O.  document suggesting that the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, the peacekeeping force, passed on military information to the guerrillas.   Both incidents are now being investigated, aides said. But the senior official, who characterized the document as ''fairly bogus,'' contended that Israel was exploiting the episodes to blacken the name of the United Nations.

headline: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEXICO'S AWASH IN RUMORMONGERING
abstract: The uncertainty gripping Mexico is being kept alive not just by currency devaluations and economic crisis, but by wild rumors that sweep the country with destructive insistency every day.   Most of the rumors are quickly proved to be untrue, yet such is the psychological crisis affecting the country that many keep circulating among the alarmed middle-classes, undermining the Government's efforts to rebuild confidence.   Some rumors, above all those relating to financial questions, seem to flow almost naturally from the currency crisis, but others are so detailed in spreading word of purported incidents that many political analysts believe they are planted with the intent of causing distress. Anonymous Calls to Housewives   Miguel Angel Granados Chapa, a respected columnist in the daily newspaper Uno mas Uno, reported Sunday that anonymous telephone calls had been received in some Mexico City homes. ''They incite housewives to stock up on food and not to leave home on certain days to avoid being caught up in grave social conflicts,'' he wrote.  ''These rumors aim to provoke panic-buying which would lead to shortages and fear and thus create a spiral that would result in violence.''

headline: Habib Visiting Cairo For Talks on Lebanon
abstract: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, arrived here today, and the authoritative Al Ahram newspaper said he would meet with top Egyptian officials to discuss the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.   Mr. Habib, who negotiated the withdrawal of the main body of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas from Beirut, was greeted at the airport by a Foreign Ministry Under Secretary, Abdel Hamid el-Shafei.

headline: ISRAELI AID GROUP IN WAR RELIEF ROLE
abstract: Every other day, Shimon Biton drives his 1969 Chevrolet ambulance down the bumpy two-lane Lebanese coastal highway taking sick Arabs from Tyre and Sidon to Israeli hospitals.  On alternate days, he drives up the road repatriating them.   His ambulance, donated to the Magen David Adom society, the Israeli equivalent of the Red Cross, by the Bronx Park East Chotiner Jewish Center, is emblazoned with the Star of David.

headline: GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Shcharansky Said to Start Hunger Strike in Prison
abstract: Anatoly Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, began an indefinite hunger strike today because of repeated confiscation of his mail, his mother reported.   Mr. Shcharansky's mother, Ida Milgrom, said he had not been able to send any letters since last December.  Mrs. Milgrom told reporters that she feared that her son could die from the effects of a prolonged hunger strike because he was still weak from a six-month period of solitary confinement last year.

headline: Bastian to Sell Equipment Unit
abstract: Pierre Debroux, president of Bastian Industries, said the company had agreed in principle to sell its food service equipment manufacturing business for $34 million to a group of investors headed by Daniel J. Sullivan, the company's chairman. The transaction, which is subject to completion of a definitive contract and completion of financing arrangements by the purchasers, is expected to close by Sept. 15.   After the sale, Bastian will produce electronic and metal components for the computer, word processing and defense markets and manufacture and distribute energy related products for the petroleum industry.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   AMERICAN AIRLINES-Albert V. Casey, chairman, sold 10,000 shares leaving him directly with a balance held of 500 shares.

headline: Khomeini Warns Region Not to Help the Iraqis
abstract: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini repeated warnings to Persian Gulf nations today against helping Iraq in its war with Iran.

headline: CUTTING BACK ON THE BUSINESS LUNCH...
abstract: ON July 23, after almost 35 hours of debate, the Senate took a t angible giant step toward reducing the alarming Federal deficit witht he passage of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982. T he $100 billion Senate revenue bill is a major piece of l egislation, highly significant in terms of the movement toward tax s implification, spending restraint and lower interest rates.  As chairman of both the Senate Finance Committee and the subcommittee on nutrition - the ''food stamp committee'' - one gets an extraordinary view of the highs and lows of American economics. At one point, you find yourself dealing with the billions of dollars of corporate high finance, and a few hours later, you're considering cuts in food stamps for a family with a gross monthly income of $300.

headline: Telefunken Estimate of Loan Needs
abstract: Hans Friderichs, supervisory board chairman of the insolvent West German electronics giant AEG-Telefunken, said today that his company needed at least $816 million in commercial and Government-backed credits to keep afloat and reorganize.   Mr. Friderichs, a former West German Economics Minister who also heads Dresdner Bank, told the Cologne-based radio station Deutsche Welle that a group of banks is negotiating to grant Telefunken a credit of about half the amount needed.

headline: Wieboldt Dissident
abstract: Duane V. Haas, chairman of the Tri-State Holding Group Inc. and a holder of Wieboldt Stores Inc., said he plans to put up an opposition slate of directors for Wieboldt's annual meeting Oct. 1.

headline: People
abstract: * Philip Cohen promoted to senior vice president at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.   * Bonnie H. Geller coming to Woman's Day as advertising marketing services director.

headline: BROAD NATIONAL BANK OF NEWARK (NJ) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bank Troubles
abstract: To the Business Editor: It seems to me that the steely eyed, no-nonsense, conservative bankers should be able to identify the culprits in bank foul-ups.  (''Trouble Inside the Big Vaults,'' July 25).

headline: American Gets United Mutual
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that it had merged the failing United Mutual Savings Bank into the stronger American Savings Bank. As a result of the merger, which became effective yesterday, all depositors in United Mutual automatically become depositors in American.

headline: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOLID STATE SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTELLIGENT COMMUNICATIONS NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Global Advances McFarlane Bid
abstract: Global Natural Resources P.L.C. said the English High Court of Justice had refused to grant an injunction sought by dissident shareholders against Global's acquisition of the McFarlane Oil Company.

headline: CCI Management Bids for Company
abstract: The CCI Corporation, a diversified industrial holding company, said that its board of directors planned to review a proposal by certain members of the company's management to acquire the entire equity interest in CCI.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: Because of an editing error, an article about Mazda cars and the rotary engine failed to distinguish between Toyo Kogyo's worldwide Mazda sales and its United States sales. In 1973, the company sold 119,004 coventional and rotary-engine vehicles in the United States, and 70,415 in 1974. Its worldwide sales of rotary-engine cars totaled 224,241 in 1973, 43,732 in 1977, and 63,975 in 1981.

headline: Around the World; Use of Atomic Reactors Slowed, Report Says
abstract: The expansion in the use of nuclear energy around the world slowed last year because of falling demand for electricity and financial problems, the International Atomic Agency said today in its annual report for 1981.   The Vienna-based agency said nuclear power supplied about 9 percent of the world's electricity last year, as against 8 percent in 1980.

headline: New Chief At Doyle Dane
abstract: Neil R. Austrian, 42-year-old money man turned adman, yesterday became the primary buck stopper at Doyle Dane Bernbach International, replacing Joseph R. Daly, 64, as chief executive. Mr.  Austrian will remain president, while Mr. Daly, with a contract to 1987, continues as chairman.   The board of the 33-year-old company, the world's 11th-largest agency with 1981 billings of $1.15 billion, also invited Roy Grace, vice chairman, and Barry Loughrane, president of D.D.B./West, as new directors.

headline: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Affairs; THE TAX BILL - JUST A PUFF OF SMOKE
abstract: THE Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 has now taken i ts place on the battlefield of economic recovery. Republican SenatorW illiam V. Roth Jr. has called the bill ''the most constructive and p rogressive reform of the Federal tax code in many years.'' If he andh is senatorial colleagues know this to be the case, it is still the b est-kept secret in Washington.  The standard for judging the effectiveness of the bill is the extent to which it increases the use of idle resources. Tax changes can do this by adding to the demand for goods and services, or, in Kemp-Roth economics, by increasing the supply of productive activity. Ultimately, of course, tax changes can increase prices without affecting the physical amounts of supply and demand.

headline: Wells, Rich Unit Keeps Century 21 Account
abstract: In competition against five other major agencies, Wells, Rich, Greene/ Townsend, based in Irvine, Calif., has pulled the fat out of the fire and saved the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation account.  The business had grown to $20 million in billings since Townsend Advertising started out with the new organization 10 years ago.   W.R.G. acquired the agency three years ago about the same time the client was bought by the Trans World Corporation.

headline: MARIETTA MAKES BID FOR BENDIX
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the target of an unwelcome $1.5 billion takeover bid from the Detroit-based Bendix Corporation, said late yesterday that it would try to acquire Bendix in a transaction valued at close to $1.8 billion.   Martin Marietta, based in Bethesda, Md., said the counteroffer was aimed at thwarting Bendix's overture, made last Wednesday. The Bendix offer, for $43 a share, totaling about $1.5 billion, caught Martin Marietta by surprise.   ''If these two corporations are going to be combined, the interests of the shareholders will be best served by combining the two corporations on the terms contemplated by the Martin Marietta offer, rather than the Bendix offer,'' Thomas G. Pownall, Martin Marietta's president and chief executive officer, said in a statement issued after an all-day meeting of the company's directors in Manhattan.

headline: Commodities; Soviet Able To Dictate Grain Price
abstract: Just as large debtors often end up giving terms to their bankers, the grain-deficient Soviet Union last week found itself in a position to dictate the prices that corn, wheat and soybean producers in the United States will receive for their crops.   This came about after the Department of Agriculture made a forecast Wednesday of record grain and soybean crops this season. The news, not wholly unexpected in the commodity markets, unfolded as farmers were burdened by large unsold surpluses from past harvests.   The record crops were projected after the Soviet leaders - potentially the biggest customers for American grain and oilseeds - conceded that they faced their fourth dismal harvests in a row but still showed little interest in signing a long-term sales contract.

headline: EXECUTIVE SHAKE-UP AT GIMBLES PITTSBURGH
abstract: ''It was not my choice to leave,'' Harvey Sanford said yesterday at a news conference. The 56-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbels Pittsburgh spoke as the company announced that he was being replaced by Daniel Levy, 39, a senior vice president in the corporate office in New York of the Batus retail division. That is the parent company of the Gimbel stores in Pittsburgh, New York, Philadelphia and Milwaukee.

headline: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1982; Markets
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board lowered its discount rate to 11 1/2 percent from 12 percent. Analysts said other interest rates may now drop slightly in the next few weeks. (Page A1.) Interest rates in the credit markets declined, with those for Treasury bills falling to their lowest levels since last December. (D16.) Manufacturers Hanover Trust and First National Bank of Chicago lowered their prime lending rates a half point, to 16 percent. (D16.)   George L. Ball has resigned as president of E.F. Hutton Group to head a new Prudential Insurance subsidiary that includes the Bache Group. The appointment of the 43-year-old Mr. Ball, widely viewed as one of the most effective and innovative managers on Wall Street, appeared to signal that Prudential is dissatisfied with the progress of Bache a year after its acquisition. (D1.)

headline: RESTAURANTEURS CRITICIZE CUT IN MEAL DEDUCTIONS
abstract: Restaurateurs, hotel executives and credit-card sponsors were sharply critical yesterday of the Senate's approval of a tax provision that would halve deductions on business meals and entertainment.   ''I am disturbed because this bill will hurt business,'' said Robert Barbier, business manager for Sardi's Restaurant in Manhattan, who added that he might have to cut back on his staff if business falls off.   At Lutece, a leading East Side restaurant, Andre Solnier, the owner, said: ''We do a considerable business with corporate executives, and I must think that this will affect us very much. If our business should drop because of it, I would do anything I can before cutting the staff.''

headline: Ulster Catholic Party Will Boycott Assembly
abstract: In a setback for the British Government, Northern Ireland's main Roman Catholic party, the Social Democratic and Labor Party, decided today to boycott a new assembly.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * The Ethiopian Government said it planned a $100 million hotel in Addis Ababa, to be managed by the Sheraton Hotels unit of International Telephone and Telegraph Corp.   * GTE Corp. said it was starting a nationwide medical information system that will use data maintained by the American Medical Association.

headline: POLLUTION GROWS IN EASTERN EUROPE
abstract: After dismissing environmental pollution as a byproduct of the capitalist system for years, Europe's Communist countries have begun to recognize that they also have a problem, in some cases a serious one.   In East Germany a health magazine said recently that only one-sixth of the total length of all the country's rivers could be used to provide drinking water.   Air pollution in Prague was said by the Czechoslovak press agency Ceteka to be far above internationally accepted levels, and in the Slovak capital, Bratislava, some people are reported to use bottled mineral water to clean their teeth. Poland's official press has talked of an approaching ecological disaster in some parts of that country.

headline: Blue Cross Campaign Is Using Tommy John
abstract: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York has enlisted the Yankee pitcher Tommy John in a battle to keep medical costs, and therefore the tapping of its till, down in this area.   At the heart of the effort is a brochure, introduced along with the athlete at a news conference yesterday, that gives seven tips to help add 10 years to one's life.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS MOVES TIGHTEN THE SIEGE
abstract: The Israeli military command announced this morning that the attack in Beirut was ''not a general offensive for the conquest of the city.''   Ending seven hours of silence since the beginning of the latest assault on the Lebanese capital, the military spokesman described the action as a ''tightening of the siege'' and ''an improving'' of Israeli positions in the areas of the airports and the race track.   He said the attack was mounted ''in the light of repeated breaches of the cease-fire by the terrorists,'' the Israeli term for Palestinian guerrillas. The spokesman charged that Palestinian forces had tried to send a terrorist unit into the airport area, which Israeli troops captured Sunday.

headline: WHAT'S NEW: 186 MORE ITEMS ON THE SHELF, BUT NO SOUP
abstract: If the confidence of companies issuing new products is any measure of economic health, the recession could be declared over. Businesses last month introduced 152 new products, a record number, says Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the advertising agency that has been keeping tabs since 1964. And that doesn't include a new, separate list of 34 new gourmet and health food products.   Estimates of failure rates for new products range between 35 and 70 percent, depending on who's figuring. But if companies worry about chances of success for their products, they don't show it. After a January-through-May slump, a new optimism has taken over.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Can Co. said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of Transport Life Insurance Co. for $26.50 a share cash, or $152 million.   * Blum's Inc., which owns 8.2 percent of Evans-Aristocrat Industries, said it would solicit proxies against the plan by Evans to buy 150,000 shares each from the Evans chairman, and from its president, for $12.50 a share.   * Caesars World Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell its Ontel Corp. subsidiary, which makes terminal systems and microcomputers, to Visual Technology Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

headline: EXODUS OF THE SUPPLY SIDERS
abstract: WASHINGTON THE newsletter sent out this month by the Council for a Competitive Economy, a libertarian business organization in Washington, was unequivocal. ''It is saddening and bodes ill that the cream of Mr.  Reagan's Administration is leaving or has already left,'' the publication mourned. The roll call of Presidential advisers who have left, the editor hinted, is a clue that the Administration ''is simply another disappointing detour on our road to serfdom.''   Though more outspoken than most, this lament is heard widely in right-wing circles in Washington, and has to do with the exodus of most, if not virtually all, of the supply-side economic theorists who rode into power with Ronald Reagan a year and a half ago.   The list does not, however, include the departure announced Thursday of Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Weidenbaum, who will return to teaching, is a gardenvariety conservative. The supply-siders who left ahead of him were not.
