abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: CHALK up another success for Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky. As 19thcentury Russian nationalist composers go, he had a small output, but his tone poem ''Night on Bald Mountain'' - which features kettle drumming that portrays thunder - lived on as the music for a segment of the Walt Disney movie ''Fantasia.''   And now ''Night on Bald Mountain'' is getting another lease on life, thanks largely to Lee Farrell, advertising manager for Dodge trucks, even though his taste runs more to Neapolitan love songs.   Mr. Farrell and other music lovers at the Chrysler Corporation have adapted a bit of the tone poem into the background music for television commercials for the Turbo Diesel Dodge Ram 50 and other models in the 1983 Dodge line of light-duty trucks.

headline: ANALYSTS EXPECT RATE RISE
abstract: The credit markets benefited last week from a technical rally, which ended a five-week decline and raised prices of long-term Treasury bonds as much as two full points, or $20 for each $1,000 of face value. The intermediate maturities gained about a point, while yields on Treasury bills fell about 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.   During this holiday-shortened week, however, analysts expect the bearish fundamentals of supply and demand to dominate the market again. Specifically, they expect tighter credit to force rates upward, despite the fact that the Government's next round of major debt sales is not scheduled until August.

headline: EX-AIDES CAUTIOUS ON U.S. DEPLOYMENT
abstract: Possible American troop deployment in Lebanon was viewed with caution by Americans with foreign affairs experience yesterday, although some recalled the successful use of 14,357 Army troops and Marines there by President Eisenhower in 1958.   Former Secretary of State William P. Rogers, President Eisenhower's Attorney General at the time, said, ''Under proper conditions and with all necessary safeguards, including conditions and time of withdrawal, which I think President Reagan has proposed, I certainly would support it.''   Henry Cabot Lodge, then Ambassador to the United Nations, said the 1958 move ''did a lot of good,'' but ''the question of how successful it would be depends a lot on the administration.''

headline: U.S. FEARS FOR HABIB'S MISSION
abstract: Israeli armored units, under cover of heavy artillery fire, thrust into west Beirut this morning at two main crossing points connecting the eastern half of the Lebanese capital to the western half, where approximately 6,000 Palestine Liberation Organization fighters are trapped.   It was still not clear early today what the objective of the Israeli advance was - a full-scale assault on west Beirut, the Palestinian-controlled half of the capital, or a limited incursion designed to intensify military pressure on the P.L.O. to withdraw unconditionally from Lebanon, as Israel has demanded.   The exchange of heavy artillery fire was still continuing at 7:30 A.M., and there were reports of intense battles in the port and the airport areas.   (In Israel, the military command said hours after the assault began that the action was ''not a general offensive'' to conquer the city but rather was a ''tightening of the siege.'' Page A10.)

headline: PENN SQUARE: THE RESIDUE
abstract: James P. Hudson's job involves sitting at another man's desk, being surrounded by the other man's choices in western art (all tagged for identification) and even being waited on by the other man's personal staff. There is an inevitable sense of displacement, reflecting the temporary nature of his task.   ''A liquidation office is not a place for permanent employment,'' he said with a shrug.  Mr. Hudson is chief liquidator of the Penn Square Bank, and the desk at which he sits is that of Bill P. Jennings, formerly the bank's chairman and still its largest shareholder.   Under Mr. Jennings's leadership, the bank surged to become the fourth biggest in Oklahoma City on the strength of its free-wheeling energy loans. But on July 5, with the bank having run up an estimated $40 million to $50 million in bad loans, with its internal procedures under attack and its financial position deteriorating, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ordered it closed. Now, Mr. Jennings is gone and no one is available to discuss the problem at his elegant house north of town.

headline: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In recent days, the credit markets have been reinvigorated by conjecture that the Federal Reserve Board has reduced pressures that have kept interest rates high. However, in the view of some bankers and economists, the Fed's injection of large amounts of reserves into the banking system last week was primarily an effort to calm jittery financial markets.   The major factor that unsettled the markets was the failure last Monday of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.  In more ordinary times, the failure of a bank with $500 million in assets would have been greeted more calmly. But the collapse occurred in a time of great economic uncertainty, with many corporations starved for cash, with corporate profits depressed and with a number of major companies on the brink of bankruptcy.

headline: TEXT OF COUNCIL RESOLUTION
abstract: Following is the text of Resolution 517 censuring Israel for its actions in Beirut, adopted by the Security Council Wednesday by a vote of 14 to 0 with 1 abstention: Special to the New York Times   THE SECURITY COUNCIL, DEEPLY SHOCKED AND ALARMED by the deplorable consequences of the Israeli invasion of Beirut on 3 August 1982, 1. RECONFIRMS its resolutions 508 (1982), 509 (1982), 512 (1982), 513 (1982), 515 (1982) and 516 (1982); 2.

headline: REGAN TRIES TO LESSEN PRIME RATE'S INFLUENCE
abstract: Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan has started a campaign to discredit the prime rate as the benchmark of the nation's interest-rate structure.   It appears that most economists, including many who bitterly disagree with Mr. Regan on broad policy issues, go along with his contention that the prime is a misleading indicator of the general level of interest rates.   ''The prime rate has many shortcomings,'' said Victor Zarnowitz, professor of economics and finance at the University of Chicago Business School. ''There are various rates that indicate different things, and the prime is only one of them,'' he said.

headline: 2 Cuban Aides at U.N.  Being Expelled by U.S.
abstract: The State Department today announced the expulsion of two Cuban diplomats, including the chief Cuban intelligence operative in New York, for buying advanced electronic equipment.   Dean Fischer, the department spokesman, said Federal agents in Orlando, Fla., seized a television monitoring system last Thursday that had been bought by the Cubans by mail from an American concern.

abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would temporarily suspend two aluminum potlines at its Troutdale, Ore., plant.

headline: Avis Coupon Giveaway Set for Fall, Winter
abstract: With Bozell & Jacobs, Avis Rent a Car System is planning a premium giveaway program Sept. 1 through Dec. 31 that it maintains is the biggest ever in its industry.   Demographic editions of Time and Newsweek aimed at business executives, as well as full runs of U.S. News & World Report, Business Week and the Wall Street Journal plus in-flight magazines will be used to promote the caper and some of the ads will carry the coupons that are to be redeemed when a car is rented.   Further advertising will run on radio, as well as spot television in 12 markets.

headline: Oil Minister Is Forced Out
abstract: Ecuador's oil minister, Eduardo Ortega Gomez, said today that he had resigned after being censured for reportedly mishandling energy policy.

headline: INCOME UP BY ONLY 0.3%
abstract: Personal income of Americans rose threetenths of 1 percent in June, about half as much as in the two previous months, the Government reported today. Consumer spending, though, fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest decline since last fall.   The Commerce Department reported that June's total personal income rose $8.7 billion, to an annual rate of $2,561 billion. The increase, however, was less than the rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in May and the gain of six-tenths of 1 percent in April.

headline: Living Costs Soar in Poland
abstract: Living costs surged by more than 104 percent and real wages plummeted as Poland's debt-ridden economy continued to decline during the first six months of this year, the Government announced today.   The official press agency, P.A.P., in a semiannual summary, reported that overall production dropped by 7.8 percent, despite the labor discipline imposed by martial law.

headline: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PENTAGON SEES 'PACIFIC' ROLE FOR U.S. TROOPS IN LEBANON
abstract: The chief spokesman for the Defense Department said today that the Marine Corps troops ordered into Lebanon would be on a ''pacific job'' but would have the right of self-defense.   Henry C. Catto Jr., echoing President Reagan's statement that the Marine Corps would have a ''carefully limited, noncombatant role,'' told reporters at the Pentagon, ''This is a pacific job. This is not a combat operation.''   Mr. Catto declined to discuss the rules of engagement governing the circumstances under which American forces would enter combat, other than to say they would be ''adequate to protect our forces if they are fired upon.''

headline: U.S. Flag Burned in Kuwait
abstract: About a dozen Kuwaitis burned an American flag near the American Embassy Monday night to protest what they called United States support for the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. The incident coin@cided with public calls by a number of Kuwaiti businessmen for a boycott of American goods.

headline: HOWELL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Apple Computer Inc. said it renewed its buying contract with Team Central Inc.   * Blount Inc. said its Blount Brothers unit won a $97.7 million contract for medical facility additions, alterations and upgrading at the Wright Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio.   * Burroughs Corp. announced it had combined its Federal and Special Systems Group and its Systems Development unit into a new group.

headline: LEFTISTS IN BRITISH UNION GROUP SUFFER SETBACK
abstract: Delegates to the annual conference of the Trades Union Congress voted today to give some of the smaller unions the right to select their own representatives on the labor movement's general council.   The vote represented a setback to the more militant left wing of the Trades Union Congress, Britain's 11 million member labor organization.   In the voting, delegates overrode the recommendations of their general council and forced through an organizational change.  At tonight's vote, in which delegates cast ballots representing the strengths of their respective unions, 5.4 million members supported the general council, but were outvoted by a margin of 250,000.

headline: MANVILLE ASSERTS U.S. MUST SHARE COSTS OF ASBESTOS DAMAGE CLAIMS
abstract: The Manville Corporation today rejected allegations that it was seeking a Federal ''bailout'' by asking a bankruptcy court for protection from its creditors. And it said the Government must bear a large part of the burden of settling thousands of lawsuits filed against the company for asbestos-related illnesses.    Manville, the largest single asbestos producer in the world, filed the bankruptcy petition on Thursday because of what it called the prohibitive cost of contesting over 16,000 asbestos-related lawsuits.  The effect of the filing is to suspend damage suits pending against the company from claimants who blame it for lung disease and cancer caused by exposure to asbestos.

headline: Abbott Labs Narrows Murine Agency Field
abstract: Abbott Laboratories has confirmed that it is down to three ad agencies in its search for a new home for its Murine eye drops.

headline: The U.N. Today; Sept. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Decolonization Committee - 11 A.M.

headline: Israeli Ambassador to Britain Flown Home for Medical Care
abstract: The Israeli Ambassador to Britain, Shlomo Argov, whose attempted assassination purportedly sparked Israel's invasion of Lebanon on June 6, was flown home tonight for further treatment in a Jerusalem hospital.   Mr. Argov suffered severe head injuries and underwent brain surgery in a London hospital after the attack, blamed by the Israelis on Palestinian guerrillas but denied by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: Accounting Board Picks New Member
abstract: Victor H. Brown, chief financial officer of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, has been appointed to the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a seven-member body that makes the accounting and financial reporting rules that corporations must follow.   Members of the board, which is in Stamford, Conn., are named to a five-year term and are eligible to serve one additional five-year term. Mr. Brown, 53 years old, will succeed Robert A. Morgan, 64, who asked not to be considered for a second term since it would extend beyond his normal retirement age.

headline: Ethiopia a Scapegoat, Diplomat Complains
abstract: An Ethiopian official accused the Reagan Administration today of trying to make Ethiopia the scapegoat in new fighting involving Somalia in the strategic Horn of Africa.

headline: Cetus Reduces Staff And Cuts Programs
abstract: The Cetus Corporation, the oldest and best financed of the startup companies attempting to cash in on gene-splicing, yesterday announced the first layoffs in its 11-year history and the discontinuation of several programs.   The moves were described as consistent with company plans announced in July to focus on research and development in areas of biotechnology that have nearer-term commercial potential.

headline: Gulf-Cities Service
abstract: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had extended until July 30, from today, the deadline for its offer to purchase Cities Service Company stock.

headline: Massey-Ferguson
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the troubled farmequipment producer, is meeting with its international bankers to try to arrange debt relief, a company spokesman said.

headline: JARUZELSKI ALLY PREDICTS LIFTING OF MARTIAL LAW
abstract: A prominent Communist intellectual predicted in a newspaper interview today that authorities would gradually lift martial law despite recent protests, but would retain special police powers to keep a tight rein on dissidents.   ''To tame the relatively small but dangerous group of conspirators we don't have to maintain the state of war,'' Prof. Jerzy Wiatr, a leading ally of the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, said in an article published by the Government daily Rzeczpospolita.   ''What we need,'' he said, ''is a law creating the possibility of effective antiterrorist action, and at the same time, society must realize that some special forces are needed to carry on these actions.''

headline: Carter Rebuts Israelis On Reagan Proposals
abstract: Former President Carter today disputed an Israeli Government statement that President Reagan's plan for new Middle East negotiations represented a retreat from the Camp David peace plan.   ''There is absolutely nothing in the President's speech last night which is contrary to either the letter or spirit of the Camp David agreement,'' the former President said.

headline: RELIGIOUS CLASHES BRING NEW FEARS
abstract: Lebanese Christian forces backed by Israeli troops have been engaging in artillery duels in mountains east of here with Syrian-supported Lebanese Moslem militiamen.  Clashes have also been reported between Lebanese Christian and Druse gunmen in several villages in the area.   These developments have added to fears that a new round of sectarian fighting may be under way in the wake of Israel's invasion of Lebanon. Lebanese Moslems are deeply concerned by the Lebanese Christian military upsurge, seeing it as a portent of greater fighting to come once Israel completes its elimination of the Palestinian guerrillas as a force in Lebanon.

headline: Airport Challenges Braniff Ruling
abstract: Braniff International's landlord, the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport Board, is taking the bankrupt carrier back to court, appealing a Federal judge's decision allowing the airline not to pay $500,000 monthly rent on its corporate headquarters.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Avantek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., named E. Oran Brigham president, chairman and chief executive officer.   * Federal National Mortgage Association appointed John H. Kline Jr. vice president for negotiated transactions, Gary J. Kopff vice president for policy development and John K. Watsen vice president for auditing.

headline: ABC's Profit Grows 6.7%
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that a strong performance in television operations in the second quarter helped lift net income 6.7 percent, to $59.3 million, or $2.06 a share, from $55.6 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier.

headline: XEROX PROFIT DECLINED 10.2% IN SECOND QUARTER
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that net income in its second quarter declined 10.2 percent from a year earlier. And were it not for special gains, the company said, net income for the period would have fallen by about 36 percent.   Although the company had stated previously that earnings would be lower in the quarter than they were a year ago, Wall Street analysts said they had not anticipated the steepness of the decline. Xerox stock fell 1 1/2, to 30, in consolidated trading yesterday.

headline: G.E. TAKES A PAGE FROM JAPAN'S BOOK
abstract: GEORGE STATHAKIS gets his exercise these days from tennis, sailing a nd golf, but the president and chief executive of the General E lectric Company's new trading subsidiary clearly reserves a special p lace in his heart for football.   A center on the University of California team that played in the 1950 Rose Bowl, Mr. Stathakis is convinced that football is a good way to prepare for business. ''You learn that when you get knocked down, you have to get up,'' he told a recent visitor to the office that he is occupying in Westport, Conn., until he can find an apartment near the trading company's Manhattan headquarters.   That lesson has come in handy during his 29-year career at G.E., especially during the time when he served as general manager of G.E.'s troubled nuclear energy business. In that assignment, he tackled normal management problems as well as the need to represent G.E. in the sometimes controversial debate over nuclear power. His move in 1977 to international trading brought a respite from such public responsibility, but that ended with G.E.'s decision in March to place him at the helm of a new trading subsidiary, with the new task of exporting goods made by other companies in addition to many made by G.E.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Chips & Twigs, a Philadelphia-based boys' wear company, to Levy, Flaxman & Associates.

headline: Cuba Issue and Namibia Separate, Angola Says
abstract: The Angolan authorities have again rejected Western proposals to link the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers to a pullout of South African forces from neighboring South-West Africa, the Angolan press agency reported today.   The agency, monitored here, quoted unidentified sources at the office of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos as saying officials in Luanda rejected the restated ''linkage'' position during talks with Gen. Vernon Walters, the roving United States envoy, last Tuesday and Wednesday.

headline: ISRAEL REPORTS EIGHT OF ITS SOLDIERS APPARENTLY CAPTURED BY SYRIANS
abstract: Eight Israeli soldiers were apparently captured Saturday at an observation post north of Bhamdun, Lebanon, the military command announced today.   The command issued a statement tonight calling the incident, which it said occurred east of Beirut, a ''most serious violation of the cease-fire'' and demanding the release of the eight soldiers.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM BEGIN SPEECH AT NATIONAL DEFENSE COLLEGE
abstract: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech made Aug. 8 by Prime Minister Menachem Begin at the National Defense College and published today in The Jerusalem Post:   The Second World War, which broke out on Sept. 1, 1939, actually began on March 7, 1936. If only France, without Britain (which had some excellent combat divisions), had attacked the aggressor, there would have remained no trace of Nazi German power and a war which, in three years, changed the whole of human history, would have been prevented.   This therefore, is the international example that explains what is war without choice, or a war of one's choosing.  Let us turn from the international example to ourselves. Operation Peace for Galilee is not a military operation resulting from the lack of an alternative. The terrorists did not threaten the existence of the state of Israel; they ''only'' threatened the lives of Israel's citizens and members of the Jewish people. There are those who find fault with the second part of that sentence. If there was no danger to the existence of the state, why did you go to war?

headline: OLD NEMESIS HAUNTS CHINA ON BIRTH PLAN
abstract: After Gao Lihua, a teacher from Jilin Province in northeastern China, married Chen Xudong, a soldier, she committed an unpardonable sin in the eyes of his family. She gave birth to a daughter.   Forboding filled the family even before the birth, because the baby had been conceived in May, a month that folk tradition holds produces girls.   Miss Gao's mother-in-law tried to make her get an abortion. Her father-in-law, a Communist Party member who headed the county planning commission, complained that the family lineage would end.  Both parents pressed their son to get a divorce.

headline: Mrs. Gandhi to Visit Soviet
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, whose visit to the Soviet Union was postponed from June to September, will make the visit Sept. 20 to 26, officials said today.

headline: CHINA SAYS ACCORD IS JUST BEGINNING
abstract: China said today that the agreement with the United States on limiting arms sales to Taiwan was only the first step toward solving the dispute over the island.   China warned that the American law providing for continuance of unofficial relations with Taiwan could lead to ''another grave crisis.''   China's Foreign Ministry said the new agreement indicated that the United States would eventually end arms sales to Taiwan, but it added that the accord ''only marks a beginning of the settlement of this issue.''

headline: No Elections in 1983, Argentine President Says
abstract: Argentina's President said it would be ''premature'' to hold elections in 1983, but he insisted the military still planned to restore democracy.

headline: Saxon Ends Plan To Sell 80% Stake
abstract: The Saxon Oil Company said yesterday that it would not complete a previously announced plan to sell 80 percent of the company to an investor group that would have guaranteed it $65 million additional bank financing.   The investors - James P. Linn, Gary M. Gray and the Rock Island Refining Corporation - had intended to obtain some financing through the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which is operating under the receivership of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and from the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, which expects to incur losses from Penn Square's collapse.

headline: VOICE OF AMERICA TO BROADCAST MORE OPINION
abstract: The director of the Voice of America said last week that he would increase the amount of editorial opinion the Voice broadcasts and that he was naming a former reporter for Fortune magazine to a newly created position as chief editorial writer.   The director, John R. Hughes, who was in New York on Tuesday to mark the opening of a new studio for the Voice of America, also said the Government radio service had started broadcasting in its 40th and 41st languages - Pashto to Afghanistan and Azerbaijani to the Soviet Union, Iran and Turkey. The Pashto service is particularly timely, he said, because the Soviet thrust into Afghanistan increased the need to send outside news to that country.

headline: Criton to Merge With PC Industries
abstract: The Criton Corporation of Seattle and PC Industries, a subsidiary of the privately held Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, yesterday announced a definitive merger agreement. Criton accepted a sweetened $46-a-share cash offer, giving the transaction, if all shares are tendered, an indicated value of more than $160 million.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Indian Opposition Irked at Mrs. Gandhi   NEW DELHI, Aug. 13 (Reuters) - Indian opposition parties walked out of Parliament today accusing Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of disrespect because she did not make a personal report on her recent visit to the United States.

headline: Exxon Oil Search Plan
abstract: The joint Exxon Corp/Broken Hill consortium wants to surrender at least one of its two Exmouth Plateau oil search licenses, a Broken Hill spokesman said today.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Gains 24.3%; NL Slips Slightly
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest brewer, reported yesterday that record volume and an enthusiastic reception for the company's latest light beer helped earnings in the second quarter rise 24.3 percent, while sales grew 17.5 percent.   Anheuser-Busch, which controls about a third of the domestic market, said that net income in the latest three months rose to $75.3 million, or $1.59 a share, from $60.6 million, or $1.34 a share, in the second quarter of last year. Net sales increased to $1.17 billion from $995.8 million   August A. Busch 3d, the company's chairman and president, disclosed that beer volume sales reached a record 15.7 million barrels in the second quarter, a 10.9 percent increase from the 14.1 million barrels of the second quarter of 1981.

headline: 600 Falkland Prisoners Being Moved by British
abstract: About 600 Argentine prisoners, the last large group still held from the war over the Falkland Islands, were being taken today by ship from the islands to an undisclosed location, the Defense Ministry announced.   A spokesman did not rule out the possibility that the prisoners, mostly officers and noncommissioned officers, might be brought to prisoner of war camps in Britain.

headline: PALACE INTRUDER IS ACQUITTED BY LONDON JURY
abstract: Michael Fagan, the man who entered the bedroom of Queen Elizabeth II one morning last July, was acquitted by a jury in only 14 minutes today on a charge of having broken into Buckingham Palace the month before and stolen a bottle of wine.   Mr. Fagan, a 30-year old unemployed laborer, was not charged after the incident involving the Queen, with whom he chatted for 10 minutes. Palace spokesmen explained that he had done nothing more serious than trespassing on private property, which in Britain is a violation of civil law but not a crime.   Charged with burglary in the earlier incident because he drunk part of a bottle of wine belonging to the Prince of Wales, the defendant spent less than 15 minutes in the witness box at the Old Bailey.

headline: China Accuses U.S. Right Of Pro-Taiwan Drive
abstract: China accused right-wing Americans today of having begun a new anti-Communist, pro-Taiwan campaign in the hope of exploiting Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s replacement by George P. Shultz as Secretary of State.

headline: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pay-TV Talks By Studios End
abstract: Negotiations among three major movie studios seeking to become partners in a pay-television movie network have been suspended, just two weeks after the participants were on the verge of agreement.   Under the plan, Paramount Pictures, owned by Gulf and Western Industries; MCA Inc., and Warner Brothers would have paid $25 million each to become one-quarter partners in Movie Channel, a 24-hour allmovie network that reaches two million subscribers.

headline: Economic Scene; Some Success At Conference
abstract: TORONTO AN annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, with 10,000 financial officials, bankers, bureaucrats and journalists from more than a hundred countries, is like a great amorphous blob. Yet such assemblies as the one now winding up in Toronto sometimes mysteriously bear fruit.   Japan's Minister of Finance, Michio Watanabe, brought the wisdom of the East to explain this mystery. ''I would like to close,'' he told his fellow delegates, ''with my favorite expression in Oriental philosophy: 'What is emptiness, that is form.' As 'emptiness' also means 'sky' in Japanese, it symbolizes what is infinite and intangible, such as the heart.

headline: Sanyo Settles Suit On Stereo Prices
abstract: Sanyo Electric Inc. and its southern California sales representative, CMA Sales Inc., have agreed to pay $109,437 in penalties and court costs to settle an antitrust suit that charged the two companies with price fixing.

headline: BIG THREE AUTO SALES DROP 34.6%
abstract: The nation's three major auto producers today announced a 34.6 percent drop in new-car sales for the Aug. 11-20 period.   The decline compares with a strong selling period last year, when rebate programs helped make August the best-selling month of 1981.  The Big Three sold 127,425 units in this year's period and 194,836 in last year's period.   The daily selling rate, including sales by the American Motors Corporation and Volkswagen of America, was 14,662 - the lowest since 1961, when the rate was 14,475. In the same period last year, the five companies sold at a rate of 22,559 a day. For this year's period, output totaled 131,956 units.

headline: JAPAN PLEDGES TEXTBOOK REVISION
abstract: Japan promised today to amend in two years' time school textbooks that were criticized by China, South Korea and other Asian countries for distorting history and glossing over World War II and prewar Japanese atrocities.   ''The Government will undertake on its own responsibility to make necessary amendments,'' said a written statement by the Chief Cabinet Secretary, Kiichi Miyazawa, who is a spokesman for Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki.

headline: Amway Disputes Canada's Charges
abstract: The Amway Corporation, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., and a subsidiary, Amway of Canada Ltd. of London, Ontario, are being sued by Canada for $147.8 million for making false statements to Canadian customs officials regarding the value of goods it imported into Canada and thereby avoiding paying proper duty.   The charges appear in documents filed in federal court in Toronto in December 1980 and examined by reporters this week.

headline: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Braniff Seeking To End Pensions
abstract: Braniff Airways Inc., a unit of Braniff International, is seeking to terminate pension plans covering more than 9,300 former employees.

headline: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VISIT CALLED 'NET PLUS' FOR MARCOS
abstract: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos returns to the Philippines on Tuesday, he will carry with him a generous package of economic and trade agreements and promises of more American aid to come.   Mr. Marcos appears to have accomplished much of what he sought from his American visit, which officially began 10 days ago with President Reagan's warm welcome at the White House. Mr. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, will end their visit Monday, when they leave Hawaii for Manila.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.S. AND EUROPE REMAIN AT IMPASSE OVER STEEL EXPORTS
abstract: The United States and the European Economic Community were immersed in a new, high-level effort today to resolve an acrimonious steel trade dispute that has contributed to trans-Atlantic political and economic tensions.   American and European officials said that while both sides were optimistic about an eventual settlement, it was uncertain whether a breakthrough could be arranged this week.   The aim of the talks is to establish quota limitations for European steel shipments that in 1981 totaled 6.5 million tons, or 6.3 percent of the American domestic market. The talks come against the backdrop of high unemployment in the steel industry both here and in Europe. Jobless steelworkers were among those demonstrating against Reagan economic policies in front of the White House early today.

headline: Export Credit Compromise
abstract: Finance ministers of the Common Market accepted with minor modifications today the compromise plan offered by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development to increase interest rates on subsidized export credits, Willy de Clercq, Belgium's Finance Minister, said.   Mr. de Clercq said the Common Market hoped that a consensus on export credit rates could come in the next few days, with interest rates raised 1.15 percentage points for relatively rich nations and 0.35 point for intermediate countries.

headline: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Ship Loading Gas Turbines
abstract: Dock workers today began loading a ship with turbines manufactured by a unit of AEG Telefunken for the Siberian gas pipeline.

headline: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW ACCEPTING A YEAR'S EXTENSION OF U.S. GRAIN SALES
abstract: The Soviet Union has accepted President Reagan's offer of a one-year extension of a grain sales agreement due to expire Sept. 30, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block announced today.   The acceptance was delivered in writing today to the American Embassy in Moscow, Mr. Block said. He added in a statement that ''the willingness of the Soviet Union to accept this extension is proof that the Soviets believe the President's pledge that the United States will again be a reliable supplier.''   That statement was in contrast to the acrimony that has surrounded President Reagan's ban on the use of American-made or Americanlicensed equipment for the construction of a 3,700-mile pipeline to bring natural gas from Siberia to the Soviet Union.

headline: Hathaway Departing From Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: That man in the eyepatch wearing the Hathaway shirt is leaving Ogilvy & Mather for the second time.  During their first relationship, which lasted from 1953 to 1970, they helped make one another famous.

headline: RISE IN HEALTH CARE AT HOME BENEFITING OXYGEN ENTERPRISE
abstract: Tinkering with a reel of audiotape in 1952, a senior engineer at the General Electric Company invented the cassette. But he left his unpatented invention to gather dust after a G.E. executive told him, ''There's no future in tape.''   Next time around, Richard Blackmer followed his own instincts.  When General Electric halted development of a medical device on which he had been doing research for years, Mr. Blackmer decided that if the company would not market it he would.

headline: SUBURBAN PROPANE GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Continental Off C.D. List
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has asked temporary removal from a list of banks whose certificates of deposit are used for settling futures contracts traded on the International Monetary Market.   Nine banks remain: Bank of America, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan, Chemical Bank, Citibank, First National Bank of Chicago, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Morgan Guaranty Trust and Security Pacific National Bank.   Continental had to pay slightly higher interest than the others after losses on loans it bought from Oklahoma's Penn Square Bank, which failed.

headline: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ITEL RETURNS, SLIM AND PROFITABLE, SEEKING RECOVERY FROM CHAPTER 11
abstract: ON an otherwise bright October day in 1980, the headquarters suite o f the Itel Corporation, high above San Francisco's imposing skyline,h ad taken on the atmosphere of a wake. James H. Maloon, who had b ecome chairman of the troubled equipment-leasing corporation six m onths earlier, set the tone at a news conference about the company's 1 979 loss of $433.3 million.   ''This is one of the great tragedies of the American corporate experience,'' he said. And those at the news conference, sharing the kind of cynical humor that then prevailed among Itel's office staff, took their turn by speculating that the rich oriental carpets on Mr.  Maloon's floor might be included in the company's disposal of assets.    What was to follow three months later, when Itel filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, seemed to justify Mr. Maloon's assessment. It was one of the largest, and perhaps the most complicated, bankruptcies on record.

headline: Dow Names Chairman
abstract: Robert W. Lundeen, executive vice president of the Dow Chemical Company since 1978, was elected chairman of the company's board of directors today. Mr. Lundeen, 61 years old, succeeds Earle B. Barnes, who is retiring at age 65 after completing 42 years with the company.

headline: Fluor Properties
abstract: The Fluor Corporation said it had agreed to sell some of its domestic oil and gas producing properties to the Petro-Lewis Corporation of Denver for $174 million in cash. The properties - owned by the Coquina Oil Corporation and Coquina Petroleum Inc., both units of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, a Fluor subsidiary - include proven reserves equaling 15.8 million barrels of oil and gas.

headline: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hitachi Spurning U.S. Warrants
abstract: Hitachi Ltd., the Japanese electronics company, said that nine of its employees, charged with trying to steal industrial secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation, would not appear in court despite arrest warrants issued by a judge in California.   ''The warrants have no binding power in Japan,'' a company spokesman said.  Hitachi, along with the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, is accused of having been involved in attempts to obtain trade secrets stolen from I.B.M. Both concerns have denied the charges and plan to contest them.

headline: SCHMIDT'S FOES VOW TO PRESS OUSTER BID
abstract: The leaders of the center-right, three-party coalition that wants to govern West Germany pledged today to follow through on their plans to replace Chancellor Helmut Schmidt on Friday despite a poor showing in the Hesse state elections on Sunday.   ''I am, in spite of all the difficulties, optimistic,'' Helmut Kohl, chairman of the opposition Christian Democrats and the party's candidate to succeed Mr. Schmidt, told reporters today.   Hans-Dietrich Genscher, after a seven-hour meeting of his splintered Free Democratic Party, which was the big loser in the key Hesse vote, also expressed confidence that the ''constructive vote of no-confidence'' in Mr. Schmidt would carry Friday, making Mr. Kohl the Chancellor.   The party's executive committee reportedly backed Mr. Genscher by a vote of 7 to 4, but the Free Democrats' secretary general, Guenter Verheugen, expressed doubts that Mr. Kohl would be elected.  ''Several high hurdles remain,'' he said.

headline: People
abstract: * Gerald D. Oakes named executive vice president of Spiro & Associates, Philadelphia.   * Theodore J. Charron has joined the Providence office of Creamer Inc. as senior vice president and creative director.

headline: Filene's Sets Campaign For Opening on L.I.
abstract: With the proper drum-rolling by Grey Advertising, the legendary Filene's Basement of Boston will open three outlets next Thursday on our own Long Island - in Manasset, Huntington and Levittown.

headline: SALVADORAN CHIEF PLANS '84 ELECTION
abstract: El Salvador's provisional President, Alvaro Alfredo Magana, said Wednesday night that the Government planned early next week to announce details of plans for municipal and national elections.   In an interview in the heavily guarded presidential palace, Mr.  Magana said that he expected a new constitution to be ready by the second quarter of 1983 and that elections would follow in 1984.   At the same time, he said that since the elections last March for a Constituent Assembly, in which more than 85 percent of eligible Salvadorans were officially reported to have voted, the Government had seen a ''definite decline'' in overseas political support for leftist and Marxist guerrillas who sought unsuccessfully to block the vote.   ''The Minister of Foreign Affairs came back from Europe last Monday,'' he said, ''and told me the whole thing has changed substantially. The Socialist groups in Europe, they are not so enthusiastic as they were before. They were really involved before.  Now it is quite different.''

headline: Text of resolution, page A6.
abstract: The Security Council, hastily summoned to debate Israel's latest attacks on west Beirut, unanimously demanded a cease-fire today and asked United Nations military observers to insure that it is maintained.   By the time the vote was taken, Israel had already announced that a new cease-fire, the ninth since Israeli forces invaded Lebanon June 6, was in effect.   The Council's action today, however, marked the first time that it has agreed to install even a symbolic United Nations presence in the Lebanese capital. Until now, Israel has strenuously opposed any such move, and it was unclear tonight whether it would accept the United Nations observers. But since the United States joined the other 14 Council members in voting for the resolution, it would be difficult for Israel to say no. Today's Security Council meeting was requested by Lebanon.

headline: Home Federal Rejects Offer
abstract: The Home Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Palm Beach, Fla., thrift institution, said yesterday that it had received and rejected a revised offer from a Knoxville, Tenn., businessman, C.H. Butcher Jr., for all of Home Federal's common stock.   For every Home Federal share, Mr. Butcher offered $16.50, plus a $10 unsecured promissory note in a new company to be formed from Home Federal's assets.

headline: South Pacific Rebel Seized
abstract: Jimmy Stevens, leader of an unsuccessful rebellion in 1980 in the former French-British colony of New Hebrides, now the nation of Vanuatu, escaped from jail Sunday night but was recaptured today, official sources in Port Vila said.

headline: GRIEF AT LIST OF 'LES VICTIMES'
abstract: EN-VALOIS, France, July 31 (AP) - Parents stood by the typewritten lists taped to the Town Hall door and wept. Every few moments, a new arrival scanned the names and sobbed, ''My God, it's not true.''   The column marked ''Les Victimes'' listed seven children from the Guillot family. Six others were from the Martin family.  By midafternoon today, 44 children of Crepy had been reported dead, all trapped in a blazing bus on their way to camp. Nine adults were also killed in the accident, the worst road disaster in French history.

headline: Argentine-Chilean Pact Wins an Extension
abstract: Argentine and Chilean delegations exchanged documents today in which they agreed to extend a 1972 nonaggression treaty that Argentina renounced in January, the Vatican announced.

headline: Dow Off 6.25, to 919.52; Volume at 7-Week Low
abstract: Stock prices retreated yesterday as investors worried over the uncertain course of interest rates and the timing of the economic upturn.   Volume sank to a seven-week low.  The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.25 points, to 919.52.  For the week, the indicator advanced 2.58 points, thanks to an 18 1/2-point surge on Tuesday that was sparked by a bond market rally and carried equity prices to a 13-month high at 934.79.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: ISRAELI ARMOR UNIT IN EASTERN BEIRUT CORDONS OFF WEST
abstract: Israeli armored troops today sealed off the Moslem western part of Beirut while Israeli and Palestinian gunners traded artillery and machine-gun fire on the southern outskirts.   Although Israeli forces have been deployed for some time in the hills outside Christian-controlled eastern Beirut, it was the first time that their armored equipment set up positions in the city at the so-called Green Line, which has separated the two sections since the Lebanese civil war of 1975-76.   The move appeared designed to tighten the stranglehold on western Beirut to force the withdrawal of Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and 6,000 guerrillas. Israelis All Over East Beirut   A reporter who visited the east side said that the Israelis were no longer making any effort to conceal their presence and that their armored personnel carriers, jeeps and soldiers were all over the city, with many tanks poised in the eastern hills.

headline: 4 Seychelles Plotters Sentenced to Hang
abstract: Four foreign mercenaries were sentenced today to death by hanging and another was sentenced to 20 years in jail for their role in a bungled attempt to topple the Seychelles' socialist Government.   Diplomatic sources on the islands said President France Albert Rene, the man the mercenaries came to kill last November, would probably commute the sentences to life in prison.

headline: 38 Dead and 37 Are Missing As Typhoon Strikes in Japan
abstract: Thirty-eight people were dead and another 37 were missing after a typhoon battered central Japan during the night from the Pacific into the Sea of Japan, the police said today.   Officials said 78 people were injured as the storm caused floods and hundreds of landslides that destroyed homes and washed out bridges, roads and railway lines.   Nearly 300 houses were destroyed, and 17,000 flooded and road and rail communications were disrupted over a widespread area, including parts of Tokyo, the police said.

headline: U.S. SAYS THE TOLL IS AT LEAST 300
abstract: Lebanese Christian militiamen massacred scores of Palestinian men, women and children in a refugee camp on the southern edge of west Beirut Friday night, according to witnesses and reporters who visited the camp.   Residents of the Shatila camp said no Israeli soldiers were directly involved in the killings. The residents said the Israelis sealed off the area surrounding the Shatila camp and the nearby Sabra camp Friday and then permitted Christian militiamen from the army of Maj. Saad Haddad, which is armed and trained by Israel, and the Phalangist militia of the late President-elect Bashir Gemayel to move into the camp. Major Haddad's forces had been brought to the area by the Israeli Army.   A spokesman for the Phalangists categorically denied that any members of the Lebanese Forces, the name of the Phalangist militia, had been involved in the killings in Shatila.

headline: Advertising; Marketing Of Solar Energy
abstract: ''I 'VE seen you cover a variety of subjects,'' said the letter from Jackson S. Gouraud, but never ''direct marketing as it relates to solar energy.''   You know something, when a man's right, he's right. And since Mr.  Gouraud has been an obliging chap ever since the old days when he was general marketing manager of Liggett & Myers Tobacco, he was quick to leap into the breach and supply information for just such an effort.   He was totally prepared since he was back in this Eastern metropolis yesterday from the San Francisco area specifically to hold a cocktail party at the City Midday Club to explain the workings of Servamatic Solar Systems of Concord, Calif., to Wall Street. He called it ''interfacing with the financial community.''

headline: LEBANESE SEE U.S. AT FAULT IF PLAN FAILS
abstract: Lebanon's Foreign Minister said today that if Israel rejected the plan of the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, for the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut and resorted to military action, world opinion would hold the United States responsible.   ''If the Habib plan fails because Israel doesn't accept it and the P.L.O. does accept it,'' Foreign Minister Fuad Butros said, ''the United States will be held responsible for the destruction of Beirut.''   The Habib plan is now sometimes referred to as the Lebanese plan because of certain modifications suggested by the Lebanese side and agreed to by the United States envoy.   The plan calls for the deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force simultaneously with the departure of the first group of Palestinian fighters. The role of the international force would be to assure the Palestinian withdrawal, not to maintain the status quo, according to Lebanese sources.

headline: NEW CANON COPIERS SMALLER, SIMPLIFIED
abstract: With the personal computer industry booming, is the world ready for the personal copier?  Canon Inc. thinks so. Yesterday, the Japanese manufacturer of office equipment and cameras introduced two copying machines it said would open up the small business market and perhaps even the home market for plain paper copiers.   The two new models are about the size of an electronic typewriter and promise to sell for substantially less than the $2,000 price of the least expensive plain paper copier now on the market. While analysts stopped short of saying the home market for copiers was about to explode, they said the new machines would certainly expand the market for plain paper copiers.

headline: SOVIET OPTIONS ON G.E. ROTOR
abstract: THE case of the General Electric rotor appears to be an example of superior American technology being used as a diplomatic weapon.  The Soviet Union was planning to use dozens of turbines designed by the General Electric Company on a pipeline to deliver natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe. President Reagan, in hopes of delaying or killing the project, which he thinks will enrich the Soviet Union and make Western Europe too dependent on the Russians for energy, has banned the use of American technology on the pipeline.   But the case is not as simple as it seems. The turbines involved do not represent the latest in high technology; they have been on the market for more than 10 years. Until last December, they were considered commonplace enough that no license was needed to export them to the Soviet Union. Indeed, many of the same turbines already operate in the Soviet Union on other pipelines.

headline: Interest Rates Decline Sharply; Liquidity Rise Cited
abstract: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, spurred by what money market analysts said was a temporary aberration caused by a surge of liquidity in the banking system.   Although the Bankers Trust Company surprised the market by cutting its prime lending rate by a half-point, to 13 percent, the move had no discernible impact on the money market, dealers said.   The increased liquidity caused rates on overnight interbank lending, known as Federal funds rates, to fall to as low as 8.75 percent, down a full point from the opening level. The cheaper credit subsequently led to sharp declines in short- and long-term Treasury debt instruments.

headline: PRESIDENT OF ZIFF TO LEAVE COMPANY
abstract: I. Martin Pompadur, 47 years old, will step down as president of the Ziff Corporation on July 31, Ziff has announced. Mr. Pompadur has made a preliminary deal for the purchase of four of Ziff's six television stations.   The privately held company, which is based in New York, decided last year to sell its television stations and expand its operations in magazine publishing, which is its primary business.   Industry sources said Mr. Pompadur's successor as Ziff's president was expected to be either its chairman, William Ziff, 52, who would retain the chairmanship, or Philip Korsant, 38, who is executive vice president.

headline: SALES DECLINE DIMS RECOVERY PROSPECT
abstract: The nation's largest retailers announced that sales were down in June, dashing hopes for a strong second-quarter recovery. Sears and K Mart reported sales declines of 1 and 1.2 percent, respectively, while other retailers, including J.C. Penney and Woolworth, reported slight gains. In another sign of sluggish consumer buying, sales of new cars by the Big Three domestic auto makers were down 17.5 percent in the final 10 days of June.

headline: New Zealand Restoring Ties With Argentina Cut Off in War
abstract: New Zealand said today that it was restoring trade and diplomatic links with Argentina, cut off in April because of Argentina's occupation of the Falkland Islands,   Prime Minister Robert Muldoon said the trade ban would be lifted, except for the export of strategic goods.  No timetable was announced for the return of an Argentine ambassador to New Zealand. But Mr. Muldoon said his Government was ''ready to restore the diplomatic relations which have existed between our two Governments and countries.''

headline: 7 Spots Are Withdrawn After Ad Board Review
abstract: Fifteen challenges to advertising claims were resolved in July by the National Advertising Review Board of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. Eight cases were closed when the advertisers were able to substantiate their claims; in seven cases, the advertising was withdrawn or modified.

headline: Marine Bank Lists Loans
abstract: The Marine Midland Bank disclosed yesterday that it has $290 million in loans to Mexico and $140 million in loans to Argentina, two countries in financial difficulty.   The information was released because Marine, which is controlled by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, is seeking to raise a $125 million, 12-year loan in the international markets.   This quarter's net operating earnings, according to the bank, are expected to be slightly higher than the $21.5 million reported for the third quarter of 1981.

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hunts Invest In Film Studio
abstract: Sherwood Productions, the fledgling movie studio here that hired David Begelman as president on Aug. 4, is being financed partially by Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt, the Texas oil billionaires.   Tom Whitaker, a vice president of the Hunt Energy Corporation in Dallas, confirmed today that the Hunt brothers are partners in Sherwood with Bruce P. McNall, a Beverly Hills businessman.

headline: HONDURAS AND NICARAGUA ACCUSE EACH OTHER OF ARMED INCURSIONS
abstract: Honduras and Nicaragua accused each other today of instigating fighting along their border.  President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras, here on a visit, said that Nicaraguan troops had crossed into his country and that Honduran forces might have driven into Nicaragua to repel the incursion.   Nicaragua charged that rightist exiles had crossed the border from Honduras, and the Nicaraguan Defense Minister said 60 rightists and 40 Nicaraguan soldiers had died in clashes in the last few days.  Nicaragua has charged that incursions have been frequent in the last year, though not of this size.

headline: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AT PRISON, POLES AWAIT RELEASE OF KIN
abstract: A small knot of people sat on a bench by the guardhouse outside Bialoleka prison today, waiting to see whether their husbands and sons would be released.   From time to time the gray metal door in the prison wall opened, and they would freeze with attention. Sixteen martial law internees had walked out this morning, some into the arms of waiting relatives, some to walk alone to the bus stop 200 yards away. A few stayed behind to see whether their friends would be released.

headline: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS THROW U.S. PACT INTO DOUBT   MADRID, Sept. 27 (Reuters) - Spain's Socialist leader said today that his party would try to negotiate a new agreement on United States military bases in Spain if, as is widely forecast, it wins next month's general elections.   Felipe Gonzalez, speaking to the Foreign Press Club in Madrid, said the Socialists would not be interested in the continued presence of American troops on Spanish soil if Washington was not prepared to open new negotiations.   The Socialist leader said Spain had in a sense been selling its sovereignty ever since Madrid agreed to grant the land and sea bases to the United States in 1953.

headline: CONGRESS PASSES $98.3 BILLION TAX BILL
abstract: Congress approved a $98.3 billion tax package in a dramatic victory for President Reagan. In addition to establishing a 10 percent withholding tax on interest and dividends and additional levies on cigarettes and telephone calls, the bill would cut spending by $17 billion over the next three years in such areas as Medicaid, Medicare and welfare.   International bankers rushed to create a financial program intended to save Mexico from financial disaster. Mexican officials met with leading New York banks during the week, finally obtaining consent to roll over some $10 billion of Mexico's debt.

headline: SEMICONDUCTOR TIES UNIT TO I.B.M. CASE
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation, the big manufacturer of electronic integrated circuits, disclosed today that it might face possible claims by I.B.M. in a case involving the theft by Japanese companies of United States computer secrets.   National Semiconductor, in its annual report, said it had been advised by the International Business Machines Corporation that certain proprietary I.B.M. data might be involved in the design of advanced computer models supplied by Japan's Hitachi Ltd. to a National Semiconductor subsidiary, National Advanced Systems, which markets computer products. Indictment of Hitachi   Hitachi and 14 of its employees were indicted by a Federal grand jury in California last June 30 for conspiring to illegally obtain plans for an advanced I.B.M. computer. Mitsubishi, another big Japanese electronics producer, has been charged with conspiring to transport stolen I.B.M. secrets. However, I.B.M. itself has not filed any suits to date against any of the companies involved.

headline: BANKS EASE POLISH INTEREST PAYMENTS
abstract: In a highly unusual move, Western banks have agreed to postpone interest payments owed by Poland as part of an agreement to reschedule $3.4 billion in Polish debts that fall due in 1982, according to banking officials of Western Europe.   Final details have not been reached, but the broad outlines of the agreement have been laid out, the bankers said.  Of the $3.4 billion, $2.3 billion represents principal and $1.1 billion represents interest. Although banks often agree to stretch out payments of principal for countries in financial difficulties, it is rare for banks to agree to postponements of interest payments. In the United States, the failure of a borrower to make interest payments as originally scheduled requires the bank to list such credits among its ''nonaccruing,'' or problem, loans.

headline: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OHIO-FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for QTr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Video Game Client To Benton & Bowles
abstract: Benton & Bowles has reported that it is now in the booming video games business, thanks to Games by Apollo Inc. of Dallas, itself new to the scene.   The client, headed by Patrick J. Roper, president, makes cassettes and is promising an annual budget of $20 million.

headline: A FASTING RUSSIAN SEES WIFE
abstract: A Soviet hunger striker, Sergei Petrov, was reunited with his American wife today on the 47th day of his protest fast to gain a Soviet exit visa.   Another Soviet hunger striker, Yuri Balovlenkov, was getting acquainted with his 2-year-old daughter, Yekaterina, whom he met for the first time Saturday when she and his wife, Elena Kusmenko Balovlenkov, arrived in Moscow from Baltimore.

headline: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; World Loan Responsibility
abstract: Karin Lissakers is a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. This is the first of two columns by her. Leonard Silk is on vacation.  THE Polish debt crisis has once again raised the question of who stands behind the offshore transactions of private commercial banks when large loan losses may threaten their solvency. In 1974, after the Eurocurrency market was virtually paralyzed by the collapse of a small West German bank, Herstatt, which was heavily involved in foreign exchange speculation, the central banks of the major industrial countries announced that each of them would come to the rescue of any bank in its jurisdiction if that bank's liquidity problems threatened to destabilize international financial markets.

headline: NEW YORK AIR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 3 Rightists Joining Begin's Bloc
abstract: Techiya, the extreme right-wing party in Parliament, signed an agreement in Jerusalem today to join Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing coalition.   Prof. Yuval Neeman will represent the party in the Cabinet as Minister of Science and Development.

headline: 15 SOUTH AFRICAN SOLDIERS KILLED IN ANGOLAN DRIVE
abstract: South Africa said today that it had begun a new drive against guerrilla bases in southern Angola, killing at least 314 guerrillas so far this week and losing 15 soldiers.   Military headquarters in Pretoria said the 15 South Africans had died when a helicopter flying paratroopers into battle in Angola was shot down.   It was the largest loss suffered by South Africa in any single incident of the 16-year-old war against the guerrillas of the South West Africa People's Organization, which is seeking to end white rule in South-African-controlled South-West Africa, also known as Namibia .

headline: A New Publication Aimed at Physicians
abstract: Physicians are prime advertising targets on two grounds: they prescribe billions of dollars worth of pharmaceuticals and they have among the highest incomes of professions. So there are those publications that want to reach them with health care advertising and those with consumer product advertising.

headline: EGYPTIANS BITTER OVER BEIRUT KILLINGS, HAVE SECOND THOUGHTS ABOUT ISRAEL
abstract: In the beginning, Ahmed el-Soudani was excited about peace with Israel because it would bring new tourists to his tiny shop in Cairo's teeming Khan el-Khalili marketplace.   But, like many other Egyptians, Mr. Soudani's feeling about Israel has changed sharply in recent months.  ''Israel talks to us about peace,'' he said angrily, standing among the displays of leather bags, brightly colored gowns and stuffed toy camels in his store. ''Instead, they give us more killing. We may not all like the Palestinians, but they are Arabs like us. Israel is not to be trusted.''

headline: NATO Chief Assails Nuclear Freeze Call
abstract: Gen. Bernard W.  Rogers, the NATO commander, said today that the movement in the United States for a nuclear arms freeze would encourage Moscow not to negotiate an arms reduction.   He also renewed his call for increased military spending by America's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to close the gap with the Warsaw Pact in conventional fighting strength.

headline: Business Conditions; VIDEOTAPE DEMAND OFF
abstract: Compared to 1980 and 1981, times are tough for manufacturers of video casette recorders. But the problems are those any industrialist would love to have: Instead of seeing production and sales expand at an annual rate near 100 percent, as has happened for the past two years, the 1982 market may only grow by 30 percent from 1981 levels.   ''From the manufacturers' perspective, times are tough right now,'' said Reggie Duquesnoy, vice president of international research at Merrill Lynch. ''Inventories are swollen, and demand has dropped sharply. But the miseries afflicting VCR manufacturers are of their own making.''

headline: U.S. Says Moscow Is Stalling Progress on Nuclear Test Ban
abstract: The United States, in its last scheduled statement at the summer session of the United Nations Disarmament Committee, accused the Soviet Union today of blocking efforts to reach an international agreement banning tests of nuclear weapons.   The chief American delegate, Louis G. Fields, told the 40-nation panel that the ''attitude of the Soviet Union and its allies'' threatened the survival of a test ban working group set up in March.

headline: LEBANESE VALLEY QUIET AFTER A DAY OF FIGHTING
abstract: Quiet returned today to the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon after a day of fighting Thursday that broke the cease-fire that had held since June 25.   Israel said it had staged air and shelling attacks on Syrian positions in the valley because the Syrians had been allowing Palestinian guerrillas to operate from their lines, ambushing Israeli patrols and mining roads used by the Israelis as well as by Lebanese civilians.   Israeli and Syrian troops face each other in the valley across a narrow no man's land that begins just north of the village of Amik and runs 10 miles south of the battered city of Zahle.   Despite the Palestinian raids and occasional clashes, daily life in the Bekaa Valley areas occupied by Israel was nearly peaceful earlier this week.

headline: PATENTS; Snake Bite Treatment Lessens Tissue Damage
abstract: A method of treating snake bites was patented this week. Eugene L.  Giroux, a biochemist, assigned patent 4,347,255 to Merrell-Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc., a subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, in Cincinnati.

headline: Uniworld Starts Unit To Create Hispanic Ads
abstract: The Uniworld Group, specialists in communicating with the black consumer, is one of the country's most successful black-owned ad agencies. It is now adding to its capability to create advertising as well for the fast-growing Hispanic community.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
