abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEITHER SIDE IN SALVADOR APPEARS TO BE DOMINANT
abstract: Recent fighting in the two-year-old Salvadoran civil war does not appear to be going well for the Salvadoran Government. But the guerrillas, who seem stronger now than they were 18 months ago when they attempted a nationwide offensive, do not appear to be close to a military victory.   In political developments, the Salvadoran National Assembly is functioning, heatedly debating economic and social legislation.  The army, historically an arbiter in Salvadoran political life, remains a strong force. It is seen as a check on the power of the civilian politicians.

headline: Dome Cutbacks in U.S.
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd., $8 billion in debt, plans to lay off 60 employees at its Denver and Oklahoma City offices. The company employs about 220 people in Denver and 25 in Oklahoma City.

headline: PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Patents; Reusable Medical X-ray Tube
abstract: WASHINGTON APROFESSOR at Georgetown University here believes he has invented the first medical X-ray tube that is reusable. The tube, for which Dr. Robert S. Ledley was granted a patent this week, issues fine Xray beams from a source 25 millionths of an inch in diameter.

headline: Offer for Giddings
abstract: About 92 percent of the stock outstanding of Giddings & Lewis Inc. has been tendered to AMCA International Ltd. under a takeover offer worth almost $300 million, AMCA, a multinational engineering, manufacturing and construction concern with a subsidiary based here, said today. AMCA's offer of $30 a share for Giddings, a machine tool maker based in Fond du Lac, Wis., expired Monday.

headline: Delta Sells Planes
abstract: Delta Air Lines said it would sell 11 of its Boeing 727-295 planes and five spare Pratt and Whitney JT8D-15 jet engines to Piedmont Airlines. The price was not disclosed. Delta said it would modify the aircraft extensively for Piedmont and that five would be delivered before the end of 1982 and the other six before June 30,1983.

headline: Petrofina Sells Unit
abstract: Petrofina S.A. said today it had raised 8.8 billion Belgian francs from the sale of 29 percent of Petrofina Canada. It said the rise of the dollar since the deal was transacted had provided extra benefit.

headline: BRAND INSULATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Press Is Rebuked Over Sandinist Activities
abstract: A Reagan Administration official told a meeting here today of the Inter American Press Association that American news organizations and human rights groups had failed to report adequately on what he said were threats to the independence of the Roman Catholic Church in Nicaragua.   In an address to the general assembly of the association, Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, was also sharply critical of what he characterized as the tendency to overplay reports that civil warfare in Central America was spreading or ''regionalizing.''

headline: FORD'S 2d-QUARTER PROFIT CLIMBS TO $205 MILLION
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said today that it earned $205 million, or $1.70 a share, in the second quarter, its first quarterly profit since the second period of 1981, when it earned $60.2 million, or 50 cents a share.   But the No.2 auto maker, behind the General Motors Corporation, said that 61 percent of its latest profit resulted from the sale of property and from accounting changes.   The company also restated its first-quarter earnings, trimming the loss from $355 million to $302 million.Ford lost $1.06 billion in all of 1981.

headline: SOUND AND FURY
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''Our national discussion of poverty is superficial,'' wrote Professor Bergmann. As her discussion of poverty proceeded, she proved her point.   She dismissed the case for income guarantees that would let unemployed and underemployed people lead ''modestly comfortable'' lives with this sweeping statement: ''Such a system would make sense only for the aged and the highly disabled. However, if applied universally, it would increase the number of free-loaders beyond bounds.'' That conclusion is not only superficial, but empirical studies have indicated that it is false.

headline: Your Money; A New Twist In Options
abstract: THE basic rule of success on Wall Street has always been, ''Buy cheap and sell dear.'' Today, in the fast-moving options field, there is a new trading technique that makes it possible for a person to do so all the time.   The technique involves ''lookback'' options, called that because an investor can look back at the period of time covered by the option to determine when the market was at the bottom and when it was at the top. By acquiring such an option, the investor is guaranteed the right to buy a commodity at its lowest price during the specified time or sell it at the highest price. And since their introduction, about six months ago, interest in lookback options has been growing.

headline: Fuji Bank Sets Benson Accord
abstract: Fuji Bank Ltd. said today that it had agreed in principle to buy Kleinwort Benson Ltd.'s 30 percent stake in their joint securities firm in London, Fuji International Finance Ltd., formed in 1973.   The price and timing of the capital share purchase is still being negotiated.  The Japanese Finance Ministry said there is no problem over the purchase, as in June last year it lifted an unofficial guidance restricting entry into the securities business abroad by Japanese banks.

headline: Executive Has Faith In Hearts of Tomorrow
abstract: In the future, people may get artificial hearts when their own wear out. John C. Moise is betting on it.  Mr. Moise, 57, has organized a new research and development company called Nimbus Inc., based in a suburb of Sacramento, Calif. He had worked at the Aerojet-General Corporation for 27 years, the last 10 on artificial heart research, and when Aerojet decided to divest itself of the program and concentrate on defense contract work, Mr.  Moise and a group of other employees stepped in.

headline: Bomb Scare at U.S. Embassy
abstract: The United States Embassy here was evacuated for 40 minutes today after a telephone caller said there was a bomb in the building. No explosives were found, an embassy spokesman said.

headline: ARAFAT SAILS AWAY AS SYRIAN TROOPS LEAVE WEST BEIRUT
abstract: Yasir Arafat, whose Palestine Liberation Organization began concentrating its power here 12 years ago, left the city today by ship, vowing to fight again.   At the same time, troops of the Syrian Army, which has occupied Beirut since 1976, also began leaving. The Syrians, who first entered the city to protect right-wing Lebanese Christians during their civil war against Palestinians and Moslem leftists, had become the Palestinian guerrillas' major ally against Israel.   The Syrian departure today, according to the Israeli military spokesman here, made it likely that the entire withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas and Syrian soldiers could end as early as Wednesday, three days sooner than had been expected.

headline: New Roles for Bendix and Agee
abstract: What began as an all-out assault ended as a negotiated surrender for the Bendix Corporation and its chairman, William M. Agee. Unsuccessful in its attempt to take over the Martin Marietta Corporation, Bendix is to become a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation and Mr. Agee an employee.   The decision by Mr. Agee to drop his bid for Martin Marietta and accept a takeover by Allied would appear to end a tumultuous two years for Bendix, once a relatively obscure producer of automotive components and aircraft equipment. Although Mr. Agee will remain chairman of Bendix and become president of Allied, the ultimate decisions affecting the company will be made in Morris Township, N.J., the headquarters of Allied, and not at Bendix.

headline: Prudential-Feldco Head To Take Over as Owner
abstract: Alan Hodes, who started his career with the Prudential-Feldco Company 15 years ago as a management trainee, wound up as the company's president eight years later. Now, he is scheduled to become the company's major owner.   Mr. Hodes, 38 years old, heads a group that is buying Prudential-Feldco, a producer and marketer of school supplies and related stationery, from its parent, Williamhouse-Regency Inc. ''I've always had an aspiration to buy the company,'' Mr. Hodes said. ''To me, now that it's happening, it's a little bit surreal.''

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's decision to propose a one-year extension of the Soviet-American grain agreement has set off a guessing game here about whether the Kremlin will negotiate on Mr.  Reagan's terms or let the six-year-old pact lapse. Generally, Western diplomats and businessmen who follow the trade think that the Soviet Union's pressing need for grain imports will impel it to accept a 12-month extension, just as it did when a similar extension was offered last year. This year's Soviet harvest will be a poor and possibly even disastrous one, and Western forecasts are that the Kremlin will be looking abroad again for at least 40 million tons of wheat, corn and other grains.   But the Soviet decision is by no means certain. A week after President Reagan announced his decision, choosing a middle course between those in the Administration who wanted a long-term agreement and those who favored abandoning it, the Soviet press has offered no comment on the American move. This in itself suggests that there is debate inside the Kremlin about how to react.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Metals Service Co., a Miami concern, said it had closed its Connecticut warehouse and transferred its customer service and inventories to its Ohio warehouse.   * Belmoral Mines Ltd. said it and Continental Illinois Bank (Canada) had agreed to adjourn Belmoral's application for an injunction which would enjoin Continental and others from dealing with Belmoral's assets.   * Bethlehem Steel Corp. of Bethlehem, Pa., announced it had sold its San Francisco ship repair yard to Todd Shipyards Corp. for $14 million.

headline: WAR PRODS BRITISH INTO MILITARY CHANGES
abstract: The Falkland war has prompted Britain to consider some military and naval changes, but without major alterations in its Atlantic fleet or its commitment to the North Atlantic alliance.   John Nott, the Minister of Defense, has decided to replace all the aircraft and ships lost in the fighting, in some cases by reversing plans to remove vessels from service, while also improving the quality of equipment being built or designed.   But he has insisted that the Treasury will pay for the replacement costs, which were not made public, out of contingency funds, while the new costs would not push the defense budget, $24.5 billion for 1982-83 at current prices, beyond the 3 percent annual increase in military spending committed under NATO agreement.   The projections, reflecting lessons learned in the Falkland fighting, were announced last week by Mr. Nott in introducing a white paper listing military objectives. The general plan was approved by the House of Commons yesterday, but with the likelihood that details will come under more intense scrutiny when public spending is debated in the fall.

headline: U.S. YOUTHS FIND SURPRISES AT CAMP IN CHINA
abstract: When a group of American teen-agers wanted to bicycle around this somnolent seaside town on China's Gulf of Bohai, their Chinese hosts objected that the roads would be too hazardous.  Then they relented, on condition that the Americans maintain an orderly procession behind an escort vehicle.   Some teen-agers, used to racing about on their bicycles back home, thought such protectiveness silly, but they complied because it was their big chance to get around like the Chinese.   ''They had a guy with a flag and we all had to stay behind him,'' said Margaret Rhinelander, a 17-year-old from McLean, Va.  The teen-agers - 37 from the United States and four from Canada - have been participating in the first joint summer camp for American and Chinese youth and finding it hardly what they had anticipated.

headline: Black Found Hanged In Johannesburg Cell
abstract: A 21-year-old black charged under South Africa's security laws was found hanged in his cell today at Johannesburg police headquarters, the police said.   The victim, Ernest Dipale, was believed to be the 47th person to die in police custody under the white Government's sweeping security laws since 1963.   All of the dead have been black except Dr. Neil Aggett, a white organizer for black trade unions who was found hanged in his cell at the same police station in February.   Mr. Dipale was found hanged by a strip of blanket at the John Vorster Square police office at 12:13 A.M.

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL CONDEMNS LATEST ISRAELI INCURSION
abstract: The United States and the 14 other Security Council members today condemned the Israeli incursion in west Beirut and demanded that Israel withdraw its forces at once.   After hours of negotiation, a resolution was agreed on in an unusual bargaining session involving diplomats from the United States, the Soviet Union, Lebanon and Jordan.   But Council members were skeptical that their resolution would have much effect on Israel. Even before the vote was taken, Yehuda Z.  Blum, the chief Israeli delegate, walked out of the chamber, saying he had to observe the Jewish New Year celebration.

headline: Marine Pays Boycott Fine
abstract: The Marine Midland Bank of New York has agreed to pay a $14,500 penalty in connection with Commerce Department allegations that the bank violated antiboycott laws, bank officials said today.   The officials, though not admitting any violation, ''agreed to pay the civil penalty and to take corrective measures to insure future compliance with the regulations,'' a Commerce Department statement said.

headline: Lightning Kills 11 Children
abstract: Eleven children were killed and three seriously burned Wednesday when lightning struck the verandah of a school near Kisii in western Kenya, the police said today.

headline: GLOBAL ALLOWED TO VOTE NEW STOCK
abstract: Global Natural Resources P.L.C., the oil and gas concern that is attempting to fend off a takeover bid by dissident shareholders, received a boost yesterday when a Federal judge in Cincinnati denied a request for a preliminary injunction that would have prevented Global from voting newly issued shares at the annual meeting next Monday.   Judge S. Arthur Spiegel denied the request from Marvin Warner, a member of the dissident group, saying that the recent denial of a similar request in the British courts had ''comported with American standards of due process.''   In a formal statement, Frank G. Beatty, Global's president and chief executive officer, asserted that the court decision yesterday ''affirms Global's position'' in an election of board members scheduled to take place at the annual meeting.

headline: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: The Auto Debate
abstract: To the Business Editor: The Fraser-Baldridge fight over automobile imports, in ''Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars?'' (July 25), was ridiculous. Two otherwise intelligent men were fighting over whether or not the shotgun should be fired. Why argue about a shotgun when a well-aimed pellet gun will do the job nicely, and not kill a lot of innocent (European) bystanders in the process? The problem which they were grappling with is not imported automobiles. The problem is imported Japanese automobiles without comparable exports of United States products to Japan.

headline: ISRAELIS, AT HUGE RALLY IN TEL AVIV, DEMAND BEGIN AND SHARON RESIGN
abstract: Several hundred thousand Israelis demonstrated tonight against Prime Minister Menachem Begin's handling of the question of Israeli involvement in the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut.   Rallying in a plaza before City Hall here, the throng gave thunderous roars of applause and cheers to speakers who called on Mr. Begin and his Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, to resign.   Equally raucous eruptions greeted calls for the creation of an independent judicial inquiry commission to assess the Israeli role in the massacre last weekend by members of rightist Christian Phalangist militias in the refugee camps of Shatila and Sabra.   The killings of more than 300 refugees, including women, children and old people, have sent waves of revulsion through this country and brought a surge of anger against an already controversial Government that rules by a narrow majority.

headline: ROBINS, A H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.R.A. BOMB ATTACKS IN LONDON KILL 8
abstract: Eight British soldiers were killed and 51 people were wounded today when two bombs planted by the Irish Republican Army exploded in two London parks.   In Hyde Park, two members of the Queen's Household Cavalry were killed by a car bomb at about 10:45 A.M. as they rode from their barracks to a changing of the guard ceremony at Whitehall. Among the 23 wounded were 17 bystanders and two policemen. Six horses were also killed and another had to be destroyed.

headline: Cartier Mining
abstract: The Quebec Cartier Mining Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Company, said it would close two of its iron-ore mining operations from Nov. 1 until some time in January. As a result 1,200 workers at the Mount Wright operations, who have been idled since July 20 and will return Sept. 29, will be laid off again for the winter shutdown. In addition 700 workers at the Lac Jeannine-Fire Lake operation, who were affected by a June 30 to Aug. 25 summer shutdown, will also be affected by the winter closure, and 450 employees will be laid off permanently.

headline: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 16 wks to July 4
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: P.& G.'S BATTLES WITH RUMORS
abstract: Cathy Gebing's telephone rings every few minutes, and the question is always the same: Is the moon-and-stars design on Procter & Gamble's 70-odd products the mark of the Devil?   ''No, sir, that's a false rumor,'' Mrs. Gebing answers patiently.  ''That's our trademark, we've had it about 100 years.'' Normally the consumer services department, this is now the rumor control center for Procter, the consumer goods giant that has lately become the focus of a nationwide rumor campaign.   The rumors, first appearing about two years ago, essentially contend that Procter's 132-year-old trademark, which shows the Man in the Moon and 13 stars representing the original colonies, is a symbol of Satanism and Devil worship. The rumor-mongering also urges a Christian boycott of Procter's products, which include Pampers, Duncan Hines and Folger's plus dozens of other well-known names.

headline: A REVIVAL FOR MOVING FREIGHT BY RAIL
abstract: IT'S been a tough fight for the nation's railroads. In the past few decades, they have watched the trucking industry - fueled by the expanding network of interstate highways - wrest away lucrative traffic in fresh foods and manufactured goods. At the same time, they have been hobbled by dilapidated equipment, rising costs and an inability to create new markets.   But the once lumbering rail freight business has, in many ways, become much leaner and far more aggressive for its hard times, and it is now making a comeback that some say is reminiscent of the industry's heyday.   ''For a while it looked like the pendulum was swinging away, that it was an industry on the way out,'' said Richard H. Fischer, a rail analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. ''But it is an industry with renewed vigor and strength.''

headline: CADO SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Chemical Warfare Reported in Afghanistan
abstract: A Soviet soldier captured by Afghan guerrillas has said Soviet soldiers are using lethal chemical weapons against guerrillas in Afghanistan, according to a tape-recorded interview supplied to reporters.   The soldier, Anatoly M. Sakharov, 19 years old, said in the interview that Soviet troops used three types of chemical agents mainly in operations in the north of the country along the highway from Kabul, the capital, to the Soviet Union.

headline: MEXICAN BANKS SEEN EASING RATES
abstract: Mexico's banking system, nationalized this week, will lower interest rates when banks reopen Monday in the hope of appeasing business opposition to the takeover, according to wellplaced officials.   ''Once they see interest rates dropping,'' one key official said optimistically, ''businessmen will soon forget about the banks. After all, how many people have been directly affected by the nationalization? Twenty? Twenty-five? Surely no more.'' In recent months, banks have been charging their best customers between 55 and 60 percent interest on peso loans, and the expectation is that the rate will drop by four or five points next week.

headline: A FINAL WORD; 'HAROLD GENEEN-GOD-BLESS-HIM!'
abstract: THE other day I was talking on the phone to my tough 83-year-old g randmother about the stock market, a topic that has caused some of o ur more memorable verbal clashes over the years.  ''I hear the market's well,'' she said, as if she were speaking of an acquaintance who had earlier suffered a mild coronary. ''It's good to see the market back on its feet. You see, it pays to hold on to your stocks.''

headline: A SCANDAL IN FINANCIAL MARKETS ROCKS SOUTH KOREA'S BUSINESS AND; POLITICAL LEADERS
abstract: SEOUL, South Korea ON Wednesday, the trial of 29 bankers, business executives and moneylenders began here in what prosecutors have called ''the biggest financial scandal in Korean history.''  Considered far more important than the Tongsun Park influencebuying scandal that rocked Washington and Seoul in the late 1970's, the latest embarrassment grew out of a loan business in Seoul's shady money markets. The whole affair has gravely weakened the right-wing regime of President Chun Doo Hwan, whose wife's relatives have been linked to it.  At the center of this growing political and financial maelstrom is Chang Yong Ja, a 38-year-old Seoul socialite, who is related to President Chun's wife. Her third husband and business partner, who is also on trial, is the former No.2 man in the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. Mrs. Chang, who was taken to court bound with rope and handcuffed, pale and defiant, admits only to minor infractions of the law, such as foreign exchange regulations offenses.

headline: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROLLS-ROYCE CHAIRMAN
abstract: William Duncan, the 59-year-old deputy chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, will become chairman of Rolls-Royce Ltd., Britain's state-owned producer of aircraft engines. Next April the Scot will succeed Lord McFadzean, 66, who will retire after having been chairman since 1980. Mr. Duncan will begin a five-year term in which he hopes to see the company begin moving toward denationalization.   ''I would hope to improve Rolls-Royce's profit and profitability until it can be restored to the private sector,'' Mr. Duncan said in a telephone interview. ''I would be very much in favor of a robust and healthy private company.''

headline: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TAKING A NEW TACK; A NEW PUBLISHER GIVES GEO MAGAZINE A FACELIFT
abstract: If nothing else, it was a textbook lesson in how not to start a magazine: Begin with $20 million, spend liberally on elaborate promotions, pepper with frequent in-house argument, then douse with often grim, sometimes directionless editorial content. And frost with a $4 cover price.  Such was the recipe for the spectacular failure of Geo magazine, the much-ballyhooed ''Earth Diary'' brought to America in 1979 by West Germany's Gruner & Jahr publishing company. In just two years - during which its circulation base reached only 275,000 - Geo lost three publishers, two managing editors, the confidence of its advertisers and up to an estimated $50 million.

headline: DISILLUSIONMENT SPROUTS IN CHRISTIAN EAST BEIRUT
abstract: When Israeli troops moved into the predominantly Christian sector of this city nearly two months ago, they were welcomed as liberators. But now expressions of disenchantment are being heard.   ''If they had walked through Beirut in a week, like they did in the south, it might have been acceptable and probably fewer lives and property lost,'' said a pharmacist in east Beirut.   Such comments about the assault on positions held by Palestine Liberation Organization fighters in west Beirut emerged from conversations with scores of Lebanese Christians. Though their views on many issues are divergent, many expressed deep anxieties over the Israeli presence.

headline: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Express Co. has named George F. Thierry vice president, service establishment sales, U.S. division of the Consumer Financial Services Group, responsible for all U.S. sales activities with establishments honoring the American Express card.   * Bank of New York has elected Geoffrey W. Bennett, Robert Gardella, Alan R. Griffith and Fordyce B. St. John Jr. senior vice presidents, and Robert E. Keilman comptroller.   * Cluett, Peabody & Co. has appointed Norman K. Matheson president of Cluett, Peabody Canada Inc., suceeding Irvine L. Wismer.

headline: Market Place; Energy Effort: Profits Sought
abstract: FOR more than two decades, Energy Conversion Devices has failed to produce much revenue from operations. Yet its stock has been one of the most spectacular - if erratic - in modern market history.   As recently as January the shares of this producer of synthetic noncrystalline materials, traded over the counter, were at 10 bid.  But last week, buoyed by reports that some of the company's products are about to become commercial, the shares reached 25 bid. Still active and remarkably strong despite the worst bear market since 1974, the shares touched 24 yesterday and closed at 23 1/4.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Manville Corporation's filing for protection from its creditors is a peculiar kind of bankruptcy petition, one motivated as much by legal considerations as financial ones.   It raises a number of novel legal questions, the most basic of which is whether bankruptcy court is the right place to resolve the thousands of lawsuits filed by workers claiming to suffer asbestosrelated health problems. Bankruptcy lawyers say it is: ''If there's not enough money to satisfy everyone who may ultimately have a claim, the bankruptcy court is an appropriate place to apportion the damages, just as it is whenever creditors' claims exceed assets,'' said Ronald Orr, a lawyer in Los Angeles.   The claimants' lawyers say it isn't: ''I just don't think a company can walk into bankruptcy court with more than $2 billion of assets and hundreds of millions of dollars worth of insurance coverage, and say, 'Your honor, please excuse me from these claims' - as a matter of equity, it just doesn't wash,'' said Robert Sweeney, a Cleveland lawyer who represents about 300 asbestos litigants. ''I think the corporate lawyers for Manville are manipulating to misuse the bankruptcy laws.''

headline: Timex Assignment
abstract: The Timex Corporation has assigned J. Walter Thompson the job of making the ads to sell the three electronic digital products it will introduce in the health-care field - a blood-pressure reader, a scale and a thermometer. In addition to the Timex Medical Products Corporation assignment, J.W.T. does advertising for the Timex computers, while Grey Advertising handles the watches.

headline: French Mine to Close
abstract: Societe Miniere et Metallurgique de Penarroya is to close its lead, zinc and silver mine at Largentiere, France, before the end of the year, a company spokesman said today.  The mine was opened in 1962 and the company originally intended to operate it for 15 years, he said, but exploitable reserves have run out, making the mine uneconomic. In 1981 the mine produced 15,000 metric tons of lead, 1,700 tons of zinc and about 30 tons of silver.

headline: AMIN GEMAYEL ELECTED PRESIDENT IN A DISPLAY OF UNITY BY LEBANESE
abstract: Amin Gemayel, a 40-year-old Maronite Christian, was elected President of Lebanon today by a nearly unanimous vote of Parliament in an unusual display of Christian and Moslem unity.   As President-elect, he replaces his brother, Bashir, who was chosen by Parliament on Aug. 23 and was killed in a bomb explosion a week ago today.   Amin Gemayel, a lawyer who has been a Member of Parliament for 10 years, is due to be sworn in on Thursday morning for a six-year term, succeeding President Elias Sarkis. 'It Is Time to Work'   Pledging to work toward ''reuniting and reconstructing Lebanon,'' the President-elect told Parliament that ''Bashir is calling us'' to face the nation's vast problems.

headline: Ex-G.I. and Filipino Arrested On Explosion in Manila Hilton
abstract: A former United States Army sergeant and his Filipino uncle have been arrested on charges of illegal possession of explosives and are being investigated for links to a reported anti-Government plot, the authorities said today.   The police said Elvin Abellanosa Laurel, 36 years old, of Buena Park, Calif., and his uncle had been arrested after a small incendiary device went off on Mr. Laurel's lap Saturday at a cocktail lounge at the Manila Hilton.

headline: RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Allis-Chalmers Reduces Base Pay
abstract: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said it was temporarily reducing base pay for all salaried employees 10 percent.

headline: F.A.A. Certifies Boeing 767 Jet
abstract: The Boeing Company received Government certification for its new fuel-efficient 767 jetliner to begin carrying passengers.   The Federal Aviation Administration, which has had personnel aboard 767 test flights the past three weeks, presented its certificate for commercial service in a ceremony at the Everett, Wash., plant where the 211-passenger airplane is manufactured.

headline: Arms Control Chief Says Soviet Seeks Domination
abstract: The director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today that the Soviet Union wanted to bring all Europe, Asia, Africa and the Middle East under its control, leaving the United States ''no choice but to acquiesce in Soviet hegemony.''   The agency's director, Eugene V. Rostow, said that a ''wholly onesided'' Soviet proposal in current arms negotiations was aimed at achieving these goals and that Moscow might succeed unless the United States maintained a strong nuclear deterrent.   He said the Soviet Union was demanding absolute security for itself, ''which is tantamount to absolute insecurity for all other countries.''

headline: TAKEOVER PLEASES U.S. BANKS
abstract: The nationalization yesterday of Mexico's private banks was decreed by the Government to save them from insolvency, according to bankers in the United States.   Despite their philosophical commitment to private ownership, most American bankers applauded the nationalization as a much needed step to bolster international confidence in the Mexican banking system.   Fearing that the Mexican Government would not stand behind the debts of the private banks, other banks around the world had been refusing to deposit money in Mexican banks or to lend money to them, thereby putting them in danger of failure.   ''This is a positive step in that it puts the Mexican Government clearly behind its banking system,'' said a spokesman for the Bank of America, which has about $3 billion in loans to Mexico.

headline: Della Femina Post
abstract: Ned H. Gelband, 40, has come to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners as senior vice president, media services. He is replacing Herbert Maneloveg, who remains on the payroll as a consultant. Mr. Gelband has been vice president, media and programming, at Jordan, Case & McGrath, having previously worked at Young & Rubicam, Benton & Bowles and Kelly, Nason.

headline: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT OFF 0.1% IN JULY
abstract: The nation's industrial production and factory utilization declined in July for the 11th time in 12 months, the Government reported today.   However, the seasonally adjusted declines were small - just onetenth of 1 percent for production and two-tenths of 1 percent for factory use -and that encouraged hopes that the recession might be coming to an end.   Manufacturers operated their factories at 69.5 percent of capacity in July, the Federal Reserve Board said, the lowest rate since the record low of 69 percent in March 1975.

headline: Subway Car Export Study
abstract: The Commerce Department started an investigation today to determine whether the Canadian Government was subsidizing the export of subway cars to the United States by a Montreal company.   The Budd Company of Troy, Mich., filed a petition with the department charging that Budd had lost a contract with the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority for 825 subway cars because the Canadian Government had offered interest rates below the prevailing rates set in international trade agreements.

headline: 6 JAPAN CONCERNS FOCUS OF INQUIRY
abstract: The United States Government has begun a formal investigation into possible price fixing by six Japanese companies selling sophisticated semiconductor computer chips in the American market, Japanese and American Government officials said here today.   The investigation by the Justice Department is focused on the practices of the companies in marketing 64K random access memory chips - the most advanced of the computer memory devices now available. John P. Stirn, a spokesman for the United States Embassy, said the embassy had notified Japan's Foreign Ministry of the investigation last Thursday.   The six Japanese companies under investigation are: Hitachi, Nippon Electric, Toshiba, Fujitsu, Mitsubishi Electric and Oki Electric.  They are Japan's largest makers of semiconductors, which are gridlike circuits etched on tiny chips of silicon. They are used for calculation and information storage, the basic functions of computers.

headline: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LAST GUERRILLAS QUIT WEST BEIRUT
abstract: The withdrawal of Palestinan guerrillas and Syrian troops from west Beirut came to an end today as the last shipload of guerrillas left the port of Beirut and headed for Syria.   (Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived in Athens aboard a Greek vessel. Page A10.) The pullout brought the total number of departing guerrillas to almost 15,000, according to Lebanese security sources.  Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who visited Beirut today before going to Israel, announced that the 800 United States marines occupying the port would be withdrawn from Lebanon ''in a few days.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Financial Corp. said it had raised its interest in Mission Insurance Group Inc. to 19.8 percent and had reached an agreement under which the stake could rise to 25 percent without Mission's consent.   * Academy Insurance Group of Valley Forge, Pa., announced that Associated Madison Cos. had acquired 317,900 shares, or 5.6 percent, of Academy's common stock.   * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it had lowered its stake in Georgia Pacific Corp. to 8.9 percent of the $2.24 series B cumulative preferred stock outstanding.

headline: Coffee Panel Nears Accord
abstract: The International Coffee Organization appeared set today to extend the third International Coffee Agreement to Sept. 30, 1985, following talks between producers and consumer nations.   The amended six-year 1976 agreement, already extended for one year until Sept. 30, 1983, is widely expected to receive final approval by early Thursday.

headline: BLUE CHIPS LEAD RALLY
abstract: Responding to a long-awaited drop in interest rates, stock prices rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 9.14 points, to 814.12, bringing its increase for the week to 17.13 points.   With blue chips leading the way, stocks that advanced in price led those that declined by 1,118 to 367. Trading was the heaviest in nearly a month.

headline: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iowa Bank Closed
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had been named receiver for the Mount Pleasant Bank and Trust Company of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, and hoped to begin paying off depositors next week. The F.D.I.C. said the bank, which has an estimated $25.5 million in deposits, was closed today by state authorities because of the poor quality of its assets.

headline: OUTLOOK CALLED DIM FOR HYDRO POWER
abstract: Cold, clear water thundered through the gaps of a ledge behind John Downs, who owns a share in the property here.  ''It's a tragedy,'' Mr. Downs said, bemoaning the fact that the water would not be used at any time soon to generate electricity.   The location is one of thousands around the country that could be turned into small, but valuable, hydroelectric projects. By fall, Mr. Downs said, it might have been producing electricity to replace oilgenerated power. Instead, it will not produce any energy, at least not this year.

headline: Barton Brands Sold
abstract: Amalgamated Distilled Products P.L.C., a Scotch whisky distiller and dealer, said it was buying Barton Brands Ltd., a Chicago liquor producer, for about $38 million. Barton, a limited partnership whose shares are traded over the counter, had estimated profits in the past fiscal year of $10 million on sales of $180 million. Amalgamated Distilled, which had pretax profits of about $2.1 million on sales of about $125.4 million in the year ended March 31, said it was making a $16.7 million rights issue to finance part of the acquisition.

headline: IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT UPSURGE IN THE FIGHTING IN PORT AREA
abstract: Both Iraq and Iran reported an upsurge of fighting between their forces today, and each said it had inflicted heavy losses on the other.   Fighting was said to have erupted in the area northeast of the Iraqi port of Basra, where Iranian forces had made five attempts to invade Iraq since July 13.

headline: BEGIN AGREES TO ESTABLISH A PANEL TO INVESTIGATE THE BEIRUT MASSACRE
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin bowed to relentless political pressure within his governing coalition today and agreed to establish a full-fledged judicial commission to investigate the Beirut massacre.   Mr. Begin originally argued that the appointment of such a commission would be taken as an admission of Israeli guilt, and last week he pushed his coalition partners into voting down, 48 to 42, an opposition motion in Parliament on establishing a panel of inquiry.  He reversed himself today, after a week of rising criticism across the Israeli political spectrum, and from foreign governments and Jewish organizations abroad.   His proposal to set up the commission, made at a special Cabinet meeting today, received the unanimous approval of his ministers, many of whom had been lobbying privately for him to take the step. A commission had also been advocated by the Bar Association, by a group of former Israeli ambassadors, by respected intellectuals and by a huge demonstration last Saturday in Tel Aviv at which, according to police estimates, 350,000 people, nearly 10 percent of the country's population, participated.

headline: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sundstrand Sells Unit
abstract: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Sundstrand Corporation of Rockford, Ill., said yesterday that Northwestern Mutual had agreed to buy all the stock of the Standard of America Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sundstrand. The price was not disclosed. Northwestern Mutual is based in Milwaukee and Standard, based in Park Ridge, Ill., will be operated as a subsidiary.

headline: I.T.T. Publishing Aide To Join Chilton as Chief
abstract: Gary R. Ingersoll has been named president and chief executive of the Chilton Company, a publisher of trade magazines, among them Iron Age and Hardware Age.   Mr. Ingersoll, 45, will come to Chilton Sept. 27 from the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, where he ran three companies in I.T.T.'s publishing division.

headline: No Headline
abstract: POLICEMAN IS KILLED IN PARIS BOMB BLAST   PARIS, Aug. 21 (UPI) - A bomb planted beneath the car of an American diplomat exploded near the Eiffel Tower today, killing a police bomb-disposal specialist who had been trying to dismantle it.  Two other policemen were wounded, one critically.   ''The bomb was an apparatus meant to kill,'' Police Chief Jean Perier said as he surveyed the scene of the explosion, which occurred the instant the bomb was touched by the two-man disposal team.

headline: Californian Climber Killed in Himalayas
abstract: A United States-British expedition has given up its attempt to climb Gasher Brum 2, in the western Himalayas, after one of its members was killed in an avalanche, the team leader, Michael Clarke, said today.   The climber killed was identified as Glen Albert Brianderio, 38 years old, of Turloc, Calif. Mr. Clarke said Mr. Brianderio had been swept over a precipice of the 26,515-foot-high mountain on July 2.

headline: Times Co. Net Up 6% on 13% Revenue Gain
abstract: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 6 percent, to $15 million, or $1.19 a share, from $14 million, or $1.13, in the 1981 period.   The gain came on a 13 percent increase in revenues, which rose to $238 million from $210 million in the second quarter of 1981.  Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer, said that the operating profit of the newspaper group, which is made up of The New York Times and 18 smaller-city papers in the South, increased 30 percent in the second quarter, to $19.1 million from $14.6 million in the 1981 quarter.

headline: FRUSTRATED AND WARY, LABOR MARKS ITS DAY
abstract: "LABOR Is Alive.'' Unionism's high command is rallying around that declaration of faith on this 100th anniversary of Labor Day. It is the central slogan of the key celebration - the unveiling in Texas of a monument to Samuel Gompers, founding father of the American Federation of Labor. But this exercise in ancestor worship is itself an ironic reflection of the cross pulls between barnacled tradition and the need for change that make the union movement's future health decidedly problematical.   The Gompers gospel of ''more'' as the main function of unionism has become a shaky proposition in a year when many unions find it necessary to settle for less under the hammer blows of mass unemployment, savage trade competition and the threatened extinction of highly unionized industries that had been traditional frontrunners in wages and benefits.   The new realism forced on the bargaining table by these pressures is bringing some electrifying moves away from adversarial relationships between management and labor, especially in the direction of joint problem-solving and shared authority at the shop level. But atavistic hostilities remain so ingrained that every advance toward greater cooperation for mutual survival is in constant danger of being wrecked by some clumsy misstep or by adverse developments elsewhere in the recession-mired economy.

headline: Biscayne's Founder, 74, Is Retiring
abstract: E. Albert Pallot, who founded the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association in Miami 26 years ago, is retiring at the age of 74 at a time when he sees the thrift industry returning to financial health.   Mr. Pallot said he is leaving his own institution in good shape, having just agreed to sell eight of its 34 branches to the California Federal Savings and Loan Association, a transaction that he said will net Biscayne $56 million.   Mr. Pallot, a lawyer, has been president, chairman and chief executive of Biscayne. Ronald H. Kabot, 44, a Biscayne director and senior vice president of Kaufman & Broad Inc., was named chairman and chief executive. Kaufman & Broad, which is involved in manufactured housing and life insurance and financial services activities, owns about 25 percent of Biscayne. Laurence S. Harmelee, 44, executive vice president of Biscayne, was named president and chief operating officer.

headline: Natomas Oil Unit
abstract: The Natomas Company said it had begun operating a new oil processing operation off Indonesia in the Krisna Field that would enable it to increase oil production significantly later this year. Natomas's president, Dorman L.  Commons, said the unit, the Krisna Platform, will double the liquid processing capacity in the Sumatra contract area to 600,000 barrels of oil and water a day.

headline: PERSIST
abstract: West Africa, Aug. 15 - There was, by some accounts, to have been a first implanting of peace today in this fractured land that would have started its long-discussed transformation from South African-controlled South-West Africa to independent Namibia.   But the deadline seems to have slipped. And so there has been no cease-fire declared in the shadowy 16-year-old bush war between South Africa's forces and the insurgents of the South-West Africa People's Organization fighting to make the land their own.   Western negotiators mediating between the combatants initially mentioned Aug. 15 as a target date when they began in early June what in their assessment was their most promising initiative yet to bring about a settlement.

headline: Hutton Ends Link
abstract: The E.F. Hutton Group said it had sold its holdings in the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation for $20 million in cash, which would result in an after-tax gain of $9 million in the third quarter, ending Sept. 30. The company received the shares in May 1980 as an investment banking fee in connection with a leveraged buy-out for which it gave financial advice.

headline: Producer Prices Up By 0.6%
abstract: The Government today reported another moderate rise in the Producer Price Index, a harbinger of future consumer price changes.   The report indicated that the economy's inflationary forces remained largely in check.  The index, released by the Labor Department, climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in August. Energy prices, one cause of the increase, rose at a slower rate than in June and July. Also, food prices, which had declined sharply in July, rose slightly last month.

headline: ISRAELIS CONCEDE AND DEFEND USE OF CLUSTER BOMB
abstract: Israel has officially acknowledged to the United States that it used cluster bomb weapons in its invasion of Lebanon, but has asserted that its actions were consistent with Israeli-American agreements on the use of those weapons, according to Israeli sources here familiar with the message.   The Israeli note was delivered Friday night, and White House and State Department officials said this afternoon that it was still being reviewed.   They said ''no final decision'' had been made on whether to go ahead with a planned delivery to Israel on Monday of 4,000 rounds of cluster munitions designed for use in 155-millimeter howitzers.   Some Administration officials said, however, that they anticipated at least a delay since they doubted that the review would be concluded by Monday.

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1982; Markets
abstract: Interest rates broke sharply, sending the stock market to its largest gain in history. Stock volume was the second largest on record. Bond prices soared as hopes grew that a recent decline in rates for Treasury bills and other short-term borrowings had spread to the long-term issues. However, the rate decline was attributed not to hopes for recovery but to the persisting recession and the prospect of shrinking demand for business loans. The break in the markets came after Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist, reversed his prediction that rates would rise later this year. (Page A1.)   The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 38.81 points to 831.24 in the landmark session. The previous record was set Nov. 1, 1978, when the Dow rose 35.34 points. Advances outnumbered declines by a 10-to-1 ratio. Volume on the Big Board rose to 92.86 million shares. The record turnover was 92.88 million shares on Jan. 7, 1981. (D1.)

abstract: The Zenith Radio Corporation said it would omit the quarterly dividend.

headline: Business Conditions; POPCORN'S GROWING POPULARITY
abstract: A growing number of consumers seem to be discovering that they do not have to go to the movies or the ballpark to eat popcorn. In recent years, sales of one of mankind's oldest snacks have been rising steadily.

headline: African Ministers Conferring On Issue of Western Sahara
abstract: African foreign ministers met here privately today to resolve a dispute over the Polisario guerrilla group, which is seeking independence for Moroccan-controlled Western Sahara.

headline: Spot TV Spending Rises to a Record
abstract: National and regional spot television expenditures by advertisers in the first half of 1982 rose to a record of $1.5 billion, an increase of 18 percent from the first six months of 1981, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising.

headline: GUNMAN KILLS 13 IN A PENNSYLVANIA RAMPAGE
abstract: BARRE, Pa., Sept. 25 -A state prison guard killed 13 people, including seven children, in a rampage through two houses early today, the police said. A 14th victim was critically wounded.   Five of the victims are believed to have been the gunman's children.  The guard, George Banks, 42 years old, surrendered to the police this morning after they surrounded a vacant house here where he had been hiding.

headline: Wine Group Shopping
abstract: The Wine Group in San Francisco, marketer of Mogen David and Franzia wines and Tribuno vermouths, will be looking for a West Coast agency to replace Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson. R.S.&L. was forced to resign the $1 million-plus account when it acquired Savitt, Tobias, Balk, which has the Manischewitz account.

headline: Cabinet in Chile To Be Shuffled Soon
abstract: President Augusto Pinochet of Chile has asked all Cabinet members to resign, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: Dutch Papers Report Plot To Kidnap Queen
abstract: A group of Moluccans arrested this month on charges of firing on a police car planned to kidnap Queen Beatrix and Prime Minister Andries van Agt, two major Dutch newspapers said today.

headline: German Zinc Sale
abstract: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said it had agreed to sell 50 percent of its wholly owned zinc-producing subsidiary, Ruhr-Zink G.m.b.H., to an Australian company, Mim Holdings. Mim will also buy one-third of Rheinzink G.m.b.H.

headline: Around the World; Somalia Says It Repulses An Attack From Ethiopia
abstract: Somali forces repulsed an attack by several hundred Ethiopian troops Friday in renewed fighting along the border between the two countries, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: A Cable Chief Quits in Florida
abstract: Burnup & Sims Inc., a cable television company based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that its president and chief executive officer, Nick A. Caporella, 46 years old, had resigned.

headline: Advertising
abstract: TELEVISION in every home, a dish antenna on every roof - and a commercial reaching every European consumer. That is the heady vision these days of many advertisers and agencies who, long frustrated by European regulation of commercial television, are looking hard at the potential of satellite networks.   Among the agencies taking the hardest look is BBDO International, which a couple of years ago set up an international committee on the newmedia and has been advising clients on appropriate marketing strategies.   ''The satellite as a mass broadcast phenomenon in Europe is five years away,'' said William Wilson, executive vice president. However, he added, satellites are already broadcasting for a few hours each day in parts of Scandinavia and will soon come to Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands. In a clash between regulations and technology, the BBDO people predict, technology will triumph.

headline: HEAD OF ITALIAN POLICE GROUP NAMED TO CRIME POST
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini today created a post of high commissioner for the fight against organized crime.   Meeting in emergency session, the Cabinet named to the position the head of a secret police agency attached to the Prime Minister's office. The official, Emanuele de Francesco, was simultaneously appointed successor to Gen. Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa as prefect, or regional governor, of Palermo.   General Dalla Chiesa and his wife were murdered in the center of Palermo Friday night. Two cars and a racing motorcycle ambushed the small private car that Mrs. Dalla Chiesa was driving and opened a barrage of automatic fire. Mr. Spadolini had sent the general, who had gained a considerable reputation for his success in leading the battle against political terrorism, to Palermo last May with the special mission of combating the Mafia.

headline: Economic Scene; A Weak Spot For Japanese
abstract: TOKYO THE Achilles' heel of the dynamic Japanese economy lies in the rapid aging of our population, at present the youngest among the advanced countries. The ratio of the labor force (ages 15 through 64) to retirees is 8.5 to 1, compared with 5.5 to 1 in other advanced countries.  At the turn of the century, however, the ratio in Japan will drop to nearly 2.5 to 1. At the same time, the population will reach its saturation level of 130 million, compared with less than 120 million today. Thus in less than 20 years our population will have gone from the youngest among the advanced countries to the the oldest, which will put an increasingly heavy burden on the economy..

headline: Southwestern Bell Paid by Lloyd's
abstract: A three-year-old dispute arising from a fraud scheme involving computer equipment has been settled with a $1.8 million payment by Lloyd's of London to the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company   The insurer had sued the utility in November 1979, contending that it should not be liable for obligations with insurance policies covering computer equipment sold or leased as part of a multimilliondollar fraud scheme.   A retired Bell vice president, Ray A. Acker of Diana, Tex., pleaded guilty in 1978 to accepting $900,000 in kickbacks in return for providing inside bid information to computer leasing companies.

headline: Commodities; Outlook For Prices Of Pork
abstract: FOR consumers, the price of pork, ham and bacon will probably continue at record levels, perhaps go even higher this winter and early next spring and remain high during much of 1983.   The price of cash hogs tells the story. John Ginzel, livestock analyst in Chicago for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., explained Friday that ''hog values have been in a long general uptrend from lows made late last year.''   He noted, ''There were record high cash hog prices a few weeks back when cash hogs at terminal locations peaked at about $67 a hundredweight and over.'' That compares with $41 a hundredweight (or 41 cents a pound) late last year.

headline: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES IN PEACE BID TO BENDIX
abstract: Breaking a long silence, the United Technologies Corporation told the Bendix Corporation yesterday that it was prepared to increase its current $75-a-share offer for a controlling interest in Bendix to $85 if the two could reach an agreement to merge on friendly terms.   Harry J. Gray, chairman of United Technologies, proposed the increase in a letter to William M. Agee, chairman of Bendix, as a way to resolve what he called the ''intolerable situation'' created by efforts of Bendix and the Martin Marietta Corporation to take over each other.   With Bendix free to buy control of Marietta after midnight tonight, the proposal was viewed as an 11th-hour effort to head off a situation in which Bendix buys Marietta and then Marietta gets control of Bendix, thus touching off what many on both sides acknowledge would be ''a real mess.'' Marietta is free to buy control of Bendix after midnight on Sept. 22.

headline: British Rail Strikers Ignore Work Appeal
abstract: Striking train engineers today ignored a final appeal by British Rail to return to work, forcing management to consider shutting the national network and dismissing the strikers.   Only 718 of British Rail's 17,000 daily trains ran by noon today, the ninth day of the strike, which is costing the state-run railroad $14 million a day.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: HOPES GROW FOR LOWER RATES
abstract: Was last week's sharp decline in interest rates just temporary or was it a turning point in the credit markets that will be followed by still lower rates in the second half of the year?   As the Federal Reserve aggressively bought Treasury securities last week to supply credit to the banking system, traders could be led to conclude that the Fed had eased its monetary policy. The prospect of an easier monetary policy with lower short-term rates was enough to change market psychology and, for the time being, replace the fear that record amounts of Treasury borrowing would push rates higher.   Although Treasury note and bond prices are still below the levels of mid-May, last week's gains were sharp. For example, the new 14 7/8 percent notes due in 1986 rose 2 5/8 points, to 103, to yield 13.86 percent, while the 14 percent bonds due in 2011 rose four points, or $40 per $1,000 bond, to 104 1/4, to yield 13.42 percent.

headline: TAIWANESE ARE HAPPY TO KEEP PEKING AT ARM'S LENGTH
abstract: To the people of Taiwan, their Government's unceasing call for ''recovery of the mainland'' is a hollow exhortation.   The political arithmetic of Taiwan is as follows: at least 90 percent of the population of this island in the East China Sea is native Taiwanese, but nearly all of the key Government posts are held by former mainlanders who fled to Taiwan in the late 1940's, when the Communists came to power.   The Nationalists, led by Chiang Kai-shek, took Taiwan by force.Chiang Kai-shek, whose likeness in pictures, paintings and statues is seen everywhere in Taiwan, is a hero by fiat.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * B.O.C. International P.L.C.'s Airco Inc. subsidiary said it would build a $4 million carbon dioxide production facility in Franklin, N.Y., beginning this summer.   * BRT Realty Trust said lending banks had waived any default under its credit agreement until Aug. 30 arising from its failure to meet repayment deadlines.   * Coca-Cola Co. said it had completed the acquisition of Association Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Daytona Beach, Fla, for $417 million.

headline: Morgan Stanley Aide Knows Forest Products
abstract: Morgan Stanley has hired Donald P. Brennan to head a newly formed group that will specialize as investment bankers to the forest products industry.   ''Morgan Stanley has always been involved with some of the larger companies in this industry,'' Mr. Brennan said yesterday.

headline: AMID THE CALLS TO PRAYER, THE THUNDER OF GUNFIRE
abstract: As dawn broke over west Beirut today, the muezzen's call to the Moslem faithful to prayers was practically drowned out by the continued thunder of artillery.   Vast clouds of black smoke rose from the Mazraa quarter and swirls of white smoke rose from sites that were believed to be Palestinian ammunition dumps.   As Israeli tanks, armored personnel carriers and bulldozers moved into the predominantly Moslem section of the capital, the heavy artillery fire intensified. At the same time, Israeli loudspeakers mounted on some of the tanks repeated over and over again in Arabic: ''Run for your lives. Clear the battle zone.''

headline: F.T.C. Drops Case on G.M.
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed a 1976 case against the General Motors Corporation involving charges that the auto maker's policy of selling repair parts only to its own dealers was unfair.   The ruling overturned a 1979 decision by an administrative law judge, who ruled that G.M.'s practice of selling crash parts - those most commonly damaged in accidents - exclusively to its franchised dealers discriminated against competitors.   Although the commission acknowledged today that competitors were put at a disadvantage, it found the practice had ''business justification.''

headline: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Conservatives Win In Prince Edward Island
abstract: The opposition Conservatives have retained Prince Edward Island, Canada's smallest province, and gained an extra seat in the provincial legislature, according to election results today.   But the Liberals managed 45 percent of the popular vote against 53 percent for the Conservatives, virtually the same figures as in the 1979 poll.
