abstract: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

headline: INTERSTATE MOTOR FREIGHT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STRATEGIES FOR THE CORPORATE BRASS
abstract: AMERICA'S top business executives are delighted these days that the s tock market's burst of enthusiasm has added millions of dollars in v alue to their corporate pension funds and that it may not be long b efore they can float a new stock offering.   But when it comes to their own personal portfolios, many of them are less eager to participate at present. That's because two of the largest firms that provide personal financial counseling to corporate brass are waving the flag of caution.   At Heublein Inc. last Tuesday, for instance, Guy Palmer, senior vice president of the Ayco Corporation, told senior executives, including the president, Hicks Waldron, that if they still had any money in short-term debt they should keep it there. ''Normally, we don't get that cute with market timing,'' Mr. Palmer said. ''But the magnitude and speed of the rally in stocks and bonds tempered the enthusiasm I had this summer. I expect to pull back in the next few weeks.''

headline: Zenith-Erin Training
abstract: The Zenith Radio Corporation's Zenith Data Systems unit said today that it had agreed with Erin Computer Learning Centers of Great Neck, L.I., to provide customers for Zenith desktop computers with coupons for rebates on Erin software training. A coupon will be good for $110 of the $200 training program.

headline: ZIMBABWE CLASH LINKED TO SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: In a hospital mortuary here lie the cadavers of three white men, dressed in motley military uniforms and killed in a firefight with Zimbabwean troops last Wednesday.   The facility where the bodies were taken, once called Andrew Fleming Hospital, is now known as Parirenyatwa, after a black nationalist hero, and the city is Harare, not Salisbury, as it used to be.   The changes of name are tokens of the political reversal that has occurred here since white-ruled Rhodesia became Zimbabwe, Africa's newest black-ruled independent nation, in April 1980, an event that ended 90 years of minority rule.   But the bodies are themselves evidence that the change has not gone unchallenged, either by those who fought to prevent black rule or, in the view of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, by the Government of South Africa, the white-ruled economic and military power that borders his country to the south.

headline: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TOLL OF LEBANON DEAD AND INJURED IS STILL UNCERTAIN IN CHAOS OF WAR
abstract: More than five weeks after the Israeli Army invaded Lebanon and fought its way northward to Beirut, the number of civilian casualties remains unknown.   The chaos of the warfare, the destruction of city neighborhoods and refugee camps, the haste with which bodies were buried in mass graves and the absence of impartial agencies gathering statistics have made a reliable accounting impossible.   It is clear to anyone who has traveled in southern Lebanon, as have many journalists and relief workers, that the original figures of 10,000 dead and 600,000 homeless, reported by correspondents quoting Beirut representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross during the first week of the war, were extreme exaggerations.   It seems equally clear that the much lower figures provided later by the Israelis do not include all the casualties suffered in Lebanon since the operation began June 6.

headline: Sony Profit Falls 32.5%
abstract: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter profit tumbled 32.5 percent from a year earlier despite a 19 percent sales gain. Profit fell to $42.3 million in the quarter ended July 31, while sales rose to $1.1 billion, given a currency translation rate of 260 Japanese yen to the dollar. For the first three quarters, sales rose 11 percent, to $3.3 billion, but net fell 14.7 percent, to $166.7 million.

headline: FEW ISSUES ARE OFFERED THIS WEEK
abstract: Only about $225 million of corporate notes and bonds are scheduled for sale this week, though investment bankers said more issues might emerge if investor demand is strong and yields on competing Treasury issues continue to decline.   Treasury financing this week is confined to the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month bills.

headline: Washington Watch; A Little Less Swiss Secrecy
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission may be close to reaching agreement with Swiss officials, after months of secret talks, over curbing illegal insider trading channeled through secret Swiss bank accounts.   The agreement, which may come in a meeting later this month, would make it easier for United States authorities to investigate possible securities law violations in Switzerland, sources familiar with the situation say.   While John M. Fedders, the commission's chief enforcement official, will neither confirm nor deny the reports, he says that the agency is making considerable progress on this issue.   Until recently, the Swiss have bristled at any attempts by foreigners to challenge their durable and highly lucrative ways of doing business. Perhaps most vexing to United States officials is the fact that insider trading - trading in stock to make a profit or limit losses on the basis of information not available to the public - is not illegal in Switzerland.

headline: UNION CARBIDE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: J.P. Stevens Posts a Profit
abstract: J.P. Stevens & Company, a textile manufacturer, has reported earnings of $6.2 million, or 43 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter, ended July 31, in contrast to a loss of $36.6 million in the similar period a year earlier. Sales fell 17.7 percent, to $423.7 million, from $514.7 million.

headline: BEGIN HINTS THAT MITTERRAND REMARK PAVED WAY FOR TERRORISTS' ATTACK
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin suggested today that a statement last month by President Francois Mitterrand had helped create an atmosphere that encouraged terrorist attacks of the type that occurred Monday in a Jewish neighborhood in Paris.   In that attack, six people, including two Americans, were killed and 22 wounded by a group of unidentified gunmen.  Mr. Begin, in a statement read by a spokesman, also said that if French authorities could not prevent such attacks, he would call upon young French Jews to organize their own self-defense forces.   Mr. Begin's statement was read to reporters by the Cabinet Secretary, Dan Meridor, after a meeting of the Cabinet in Jerusalem.

headline: HUBBEL, HARVEY, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CRIMINAL INQUIRY ON PENN BANK SET
abstract: Federal bank regulators investigating the collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City have referred 30 cases to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution, according to confidential documents obtained by a Congressional subcommittee.   The documents show that the 30 cases involve dozens of individuals, transactions totaling more than $70 million and a wide range of potential violations. These include kickbacks, misapplication of bank funds, conspiracy, bank fraud, concealment, wire fraud, falsified books and records and interstate transportation of stolen property.   The documents do not show the names of individuals involved in the various cases, but sources familiar with the inquiry say that many of the cases involve bank officers or directors as well as some large borrowers from the bank. More referrals are expected.

headline: DRUMMOND MCCALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The presence of United States Marines in Beirut seems to have underscored the powerlessness of the Soviet Union to affect events in Lebanon now that the Syrians and the Palestinians, Moscow's allies in the region, have been routed.   The participation of the marines in the withdrawal of Palestinian forces from the Lebanese capital has been particularly galling to the Russians in the wake of a warning by Leonid I. Brezhnev that Moscow ''will continue to categorically object'' to any United States military presence in Lebanon. The warning, published in Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, went unheeded as Israeli and Palestinian leaders agreed on a joint operation by French, Italian and American troops to assist in the Palestinian pullout.   Since Mr. Brezhnev's warning, references to the role of United States troops by senior Soviet officials and commentators in the official press have generally omitted any implication of a Soviet response.

headline: Getzler Firm Treats Ailing Companies
abstract: When Abraham E. Getzler knocks on the corporate door, he is often greeted like ''a carrier of the plague,'' to use his expression. For Mr. Getzler is usually there at the behest of a bank, insurance company or factor worried about the company's ability to pay its debts, and his job is to correct management's mistakes and try to save the company.   Mr. Getzler, 56, heads A.E. Getzler & Company, a specialized management consulting firm in New York. When a company gets into trouble, the lender recommends that the company hire Mr. Getzler, or somebody like him. Mr. Getzler's first job is to persuade management that it needs to hire him and to cooperate.

headline: Market Place; Liquid Assets At Tandycrafts
abstract: THREE top officials of the Tandy Corporation who migrated to Tandycrafts after the 1975 spinoff of that segment of the business are attempting to apply Tandy's retailing expertise to Tandycrafts.   Tandy's business today is essentially limited to Radio Shack, a consumer electronics chain that ranks as one of the greatest retailing successes in history.   In 1963, Tandy, then a leathercraft manufacturer and retailer, acquired the nine consumer electronic stores of the near-bankrupt Radio Shack company in Boston. Today, the Radio Shack chain is an 8,500-store juggernaut that has given Tandy a rate of growth seldom equaled in retailing or elsewhere.   Since the 1974 recession, Tandy earnings have grown at a compounded rate of more than 40 percent. The shares have also gone up more than fortyfold from the low in that recession year.

headline: Collaborative Research Names a New President
abstract: Modesto A. Maidique, 42, has been named president and chief executive officer of Collaborative Research Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in Lexington, Mass.   Mr. Maidique, who has a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in solid state physics, has been chairman of the company's executive committee and a director, in addition to serving as associate professor of engineering management at Stanford University - from which he is now on leave.   As Collaborative's president and chief executive, he will replace Orrie M. Friedman, 67, a founder of the company, who will stay on as chairman.

headline: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kraft Off; General Foods Rises
abstract: Three leading makers of food and other consumer products reported substantially improved earnings in their food divisions for their most recent quarters, largely because the recession has not dampened consumer demand for the basic food items the companies sell.   Nevertheless, one of the companies, Dart & Kraft Inc., said that changes in foreign currency translations forced it to restate overseas earnings, resulting in an 18.6 percent drop in profits for the second quarter. The General Foods Corporation, for its first fiscal quarter ended July 3, and Nabisco Brands Inc., for its second, reported gains of 24.7 percent and 34.8 percent, respectively.   Dart & Kraft said its net income fell to $105.3 million, or $1.93 a share, from $129.3 million, or $2.37 a share, in the second quarter of 1981. Sales slipped by 4.2 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $2.61 billion in the period last year.

headline: BANK'S BID TO ACQUIRE STOCK FIRM FACES TEST
abstract: In an action that could develop into a test of the legal barrier that separates the banking and securities industries, the Federal Reserve Board will begin hearings Wednesday on a bid by the BankAmerica Corporation to acquire Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm.   If the Fed approves the merger, it would allow BankAmerica, the corporate parent of the nation's largest commercial bank, to offer a full range of one-stop financial services, from checking accounts to stock trading.   The proposal, bitterly opposed by the securities industry, comes at a time when the outlook for any Congressional action on broad-based banking deregulation appears uncertain. Officials of the securities industry fear that banks may breach the wall between the two industries before Congress can take a close look at the issue.

headline: Hess Looking At Cities Assets
abstract: The Amerada Hess Corporation said that it was ''obtaining information'' from the Cities Service Company ''to explore the possibility of purchasing certain refining, marketing and transportation assets'' of the oil company.

headline: TUMBLING BOAT SALES
abstract: High interest rates, a continuing recession and extremely wet spring weather, which further dampened consumer enthusiasm, have becalmed the nation's pleasure boat industry.   ''This has been an extremely slow year,'' said George Rounds, director of services for the National Marine Manufacturers Association.

headline: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTEREST RATE PICTURE IS MIXED
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as the Treasury sold $5 billion of 13 3/4 percent notes due in May 1992 at an average yield of 13.69 percent.   Although the yield on the new notes was well below the 14.68 percent available in the secondary market little more than a month ago, it was higher than the 13.4 percent yield quoted by dealers two days ago.   Analysts said that the modest drop in prices and increase in yields in the past few days had helped attract buyers and made the 13 3/4 percent issue the highest-yielding Treasury security of any maturity.    ''We saw some good-sized cash buying from investors who were sellers during the July rally,'' one dealer said. Before this week's flurry of Treasury financing, some dealers were worried that investors would be deterred by the steep decline in note and bond yields that accompanied lower short-term interest rates in July.

headline: Chrysler Canada Venture
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation must win approval from the United States Government before starting a new diesel engine venture in Canada, Chrysler Canada Ltd. officials said today. The venture, announced Thursday, is for the building of engines at Windsor, Ontario, with the Perkins Engines division of Massey-Ferguson Ltd. Lachlan Seward, an official of the United States Loan Guarantee Board, confirmed that the board must review the deal.

headline: The U.N. Today; Aug. 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the Middle East.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M.  and 3 P.M.

headline: Saudi-Dutch Contract
abstract: A Saudi-Dutch group has won a contract to build a 60-mile pipeline to Mecca and Taif in Saudi Arabia from a Red Sea desalination plant, the Saudi Gazette said.  Work is expected to start in September and to take 40 months.

headline: Cabot Acquisition
abstract: The Armada Corporation of Detroit said it had agreed in principle to sell its Hoskins Manufacturing Company unit and a subsidiary, Hoskins Alloys of Canada Ltd., to the Cabot Corporation of Boston for $27.7 million. The units make custom alloys and have plants in Michigan, Indiana and Ontario.

headline: STEEL INDUSTRY IS COOL TO EUROPEAN PROPOSAL
abstract: Domestic steel industry leaders reacted coldly tonight to the latest compromise proposal by the European Economic Community to resolve a steel trade dispute with the United States.   Differences between the United States and Europe were narrowed at meetings here on Wednesday and today between Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and a European delegation led by Viscount Etienne Davignon, the Commissioner for Industry, and Wilhelm Hafercamp, the E.E.C.'s vice president for External Affairs.   But executives of two leading domestic steel companies said after a briefing with Mr. Baldrige that the new proposals were not acceptable to American steelmakers.   The officials, who declined to be identified, said the Europeans did not commit themselves to a sufficiently large cutback in shipments of most steel products to the American market. The domestic industry wants the Europeans to limit their share of the American market to no more than 5 percent for each kind of product, while the latest European proposals are for a market share of between 5 percent and 6 percent, industry and government sources said.

headline: Santa Fe Purchase
abstract: The Santa Fe International Corporation, a division of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, said that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Andover Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla. for $150 million in cash. Andover is a closely held oil and gas exploration company with annual revenues of $78 million. Completion of the merger is subject to approval by Andover shareholders and regulatory authorities, Santa Fe said.

headline: China Simulates Atomic Blast In War Games Aimed at Soviet
abstract: China exploded a simulated tactical nuclear weapon last month during war games aimed at combating a Soviet invasion, Western military sources said today.

headline: Market Place; Growth Curve At Wang Labs
abstract: THE rocketing growth in word processor sales will wane when saturation arrives in the middle of the decade. By that time, Wang Labs may have lost its leadership in the text preparation market to International Business Machines. But most analysts are betting that Wang will not falter.   Among them is a professional investor with lots of Wang shares who talked with the understanding that he would not be identified. He shares the industry view that growth in the market for word processors will slow to 10 or 15 percent yearly by the mid-1980's.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA CONCEDES 3 SOLDIERS WERE KILLED BY ZIMBABWE
abstract: The South African Defense Force has acknowledged that three of its white sergeants were killed in a clash in neighboring Zimbabwe last week. But it said their incursion into Zimbabwe had not been authorized.   These statements were made in Pretoria Thursday night by Gen.  Constand Viljoen, chief of the Defense Force, after an inquiry into the incident.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: LIGHT IN BEIRUT TUNNEL
abstract: A famous columnist once observed that, if he was asked to invent a journalism school, it would be a very simple affair. It would consist of a classroom with a large door in front. Every hour a man would come in and say ''no comment'' and the class would have to write a story about it.   If such a classroom exists in the real world then it is the Israeli siege of west Beirut, where those who know what is happening, like the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, never speak with reporters and those who don't know speak with them all day long. The reporters do not report facts. They sift through a pile of nocomments, misinformation, half-truths and outright lies that accumulate every 24 hours.

headline: SMALL BONN PARTY SHOWS LOSS IN POLL
abstract: Amid signs of disarray within the Free Democratic Party, an opinion poll showed today that its national support had dwindled to 2.3 percent of the electorate since it decided last week to leave Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's governing coalition.   The poll, conducted in the last three days by the Allensbach Institute, was unsettling news for Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Free Democratic chairman and former Foreign Minister, who has been criticized by the party's left wing.   On Tuesday, a caucus of the party organization in Bremen joined regional groups in West Berlin, Schleswig-Holstein and Hamburg in calling for a special party convention to reconsider the decision to switch alliances by leaving the Government coalition led by the Social Democrats and joining forces with the Christian Democrats.

headline: GUERRILLAS SEIZE U.N. SUPPLIES
abstract: Five armed members of the Palestine Liberation Organization have sealed off a United Nations warehouse in west Beirut, blocking relief supplies for 30,000 Palestinian refugees, the United Nations disclosed Wednesday.   The P.L.O. blockade has been in force since July l9 and has cut off the distribution of flour, rice, sugar, corned beef and skimmed milk powder, the United Nations said.

headline: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONEY SUPPLY UP $900 MILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply increased by $900 million for the week ended July 28. The rise was within expectations and caused no significant change in interest rates.   In credit market activity before the late-afternoon money supply announcement, however, some short-term rates rose about three-eighths of a percentage point, while note and bond prices fell by threequarters of a point to one and a quarter points, pushing up yields.   Securities dealers said that an increase in their cost of financing, to about 10 3/4 percent from less than 8 percent early in the week, made them more eager to cut prices in an effort to attract buyers for the recent heavy supply of Treasury issues. Last week, the Treasury sold $5.5 billion each of three- and six-month bills, $6 billion of 13 1/8 percent three-year notes, $5 billion of 13 3/4 percent notes due in 1992, and $6.25 billion of one-year bills.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Down 4% in August
abstract: The Publishers Information Bureau reports that its member publications - which include most of the country's important magazines - were down 4 percent in advertising pages in August compared with August 1981, but, thanks to rate increases, were about even in ad revenues.   The pages totaled 7,379, while the revenues were $211.6 million.

headline: McDonnell Douglas
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that ALM Antillean Airways had purchased two of its super 80 jetliners, to be equipped with the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney JT8D-217A engines. The planes will replace two DC-9 series 30 jetliners now operated by the Netherlands Antilles airline.

headline: 2 Homes in West Bank Demolished in Reprisal
abstract: Israeli soldiers demolished two Arab houses in the occupied West Bank on Monday in retaliation for a firebomb attack on an Israeli bus, an army spokesman said today.

headline: Diamond Proxy
abstract: The Diamond International Corporation said that its directors had approved a preliminary proxy statement for the proposed acquisition of Diamond by a company affiliated with Sir James Goldsmith for $44.50 a share. It said the material would be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cavenham Holdings Ltd., an affiliate of a British-French holding company controlled by Sir James, had already acquired 40 percent of Diamond's stock by the end of last month.

headline: U.S. SAYS AGAIN THE P.L.O. MUST ACCEPT ISRAEL'S RIGHTS
abstract: The White House said today that the United States would neither recognize nor negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization until it recognized Israel ''in a clear and unequivocal way.''   A White House statement, issued by Larry Speakes, the deputy press secretary, also said the United States would continue to refuse to deal with the guerrilla organization until it accepted United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, which were approved, respectively, after the 1967 and 1973 Middle East wars and set a framework for peace in the region.   The sharply worded White House statement and a similar one issued by the State Department followed a stir of activity after Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., part of a delegation of members of Congress who met with Mr. Arafat on Sunday in west Beirut, announced that the P.L.O. leader had signed a document in which he accepted United Nations resolutions that include Israel's right to exist. However, Mr. Arafat said he had accepted United Nations resolutions dealing with ''the Palestinian question.''

headline: ISRAELI ARMOR HITS AT P.L.O. POSITIONS AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
abstract: Israeli armored troops launched a predawn assault today on Palestinian guerrilla positions around Beirut international airport on the southern outskirts of the city, the Palestine Liberation Organization news agency Wafa reported.   The state-run Beirut radio said Israeli forces had entered the airport, bringing them only a few hundred yards from the largest Palestinian refugee camp of Burj al-Brajneh. in what appeared to be an advance on the Palestinians or toward the Palestinian refugee camps just south of the airport.   The Israeli attack came hours after Lebanon's Foreign Minister said Saturday that final negotiations on how to carry out a withdrawal of the P.L.O. guerrillas from west Beirut were expected to begin within 24 hours. Foreign Minister Fuad Butros, speaking to reporters after a meeting with Philp C. Habib, the special American envoy, Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan and President Elias Sarkis, said the negotiations would involve the P.L.O., the Lebanese Government and Mr. Habib acting through Lebanese intermediaries.

headline: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: YUGOSLAVIA STRUGGLING TO MEET DEBTS TO WEST
abstract: The new Prime Minister, Milka Planinc, says Yugoslavia's economy is in difficulty but her Government will fulfill its international financial obligations.   ''We are making every effort to honor all our commitments vis-avis our partners promptly, to restore the reputation of our economy and to keep the good name of Yugoslavia the way it has always been,'' the Prime Minister said.   Emphasizing the urgent need for medium- and short-term credit, Mrs. Planinc said there was ''somewhat of an overdose of nervousness,'' especially among European and American banks regarding Yugoslavia's financial obligations.

headline: PENSION SYSTEM FACING TEST
abstract: Facet Enterprises is just a modest-sized auto parts manufacturer based in Tulsa, Okla., but the lawsuit it has brought against the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation has dozens of larger companies running scared.   All Facet wants is a judicial ruling that it terminated its pension plan on Nov. 13, 1980, and, in the process, qualified for assistance from the pension agency. But many of the nation's largest corporations - as well as the pension corporation - believe that such a ruling could upset the entire private pension insurance system.   They say that Facet is trying to take advantage of a loophole in the Federal pension law, and unless that loophole is closed, they could wind up footing the bill for some $4.3 billion worth of pension benefits owed by other corporations. 'An Outrageous Loophole'   ''The Facet situation is a perfect illustration of the potential for abuse in the pension law as it's now written,'' said George Pantos, counsel to a group of 112 major corporations that want to see the Federal pension law amended. ''The wording of the law permits companies with unfunded pension liabilities to terminate their plans and have the Government step in and pay the benefits, passing the costs along to other corporations,'' he said. ''It's an outrageous loophole that should be closed.''

headline: GUATEMALA TRAVEL CAUTION EASED
abstract: The State Department has modified its warning to Americans traveling to Guatemala, recognizing that violence has been reduced since Gen. Efrain Rios Montt came to power last March, officials said today.   The new warning, while still strongly worded, was welcomed by the Guatemalan Embassy.

headline: TAIWAN ARMS SALES CRITICIZED
abstract: Senator Henry M. Jackson, a Washington Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, said today that the Administration ''would be making a serious mistake'' in providing additional arms to Taiwan.   Appearing on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' Mr. Jackson warned that China, fearful of its ability to defend itself against the Soviet Union, might turn away from its relationship with the United States and make a deal with Moscow.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TAIWAN REFLECTS IMPACT OF SLUMP ON EAST ASIA
abstract: With Taiwan's exports stagnant and its economic growth running at half the Government target for the year, gloom would seem to be the appropriate demeanor for business executives and Government economic officials here.   But faces turned sour by the economy are scarce in Taiwan. Because of the rapid economic growth in the past, Y.C. Wang, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group, Taiwan's largest private corporation, said that ''people here have been relaxing too much; this slowdown has come at just the right time.''   ''Our businesses have been somewhat spolied by all the growth we have experienced,'' said Vincent C. Siew, a senior official in the Ministry of Economic Affairs. ''The slowdown is helping educate our people.''

headline: Advertising
abstract: Ogilvy Unit Buys Shop In Germany   ''I T used to be that people started ad agencies with plans of going public. Now they start them with an eye to being acquired.'' That observation was made Friday by Marvin Sloves, chairman and chief executive of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, as he announced the acquisition of Hildmann, Simon, Rempen & Schmitz in Dusseldorf, West Germany.

headline: 21 Dresser Compressors Involved
abstract: Compressors are devices that increase the pressure of a gas, vapor, or mixture of gas and vapor by reducing the volume of such fluids as they pass through the device. In a pipeline, they are used to increase the amount of fuel that can be pumped through a line of a given diameter.

headline: Mozambique Rebels Hit City
abstract: A spokesman for the Mozambican National Resistance rebel group said today that guerrillas sabotaged water and power supplies to Mozambique's Indian Ocean port of Beira last week.

headline: Chem-Nuclear Appeals Order
abstract: Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. said it had appealed an order issued last Friday in Federal District Court here denying its motion for a preliminary injunction against Waste Management Inc.'s tender offer for 50 percent of Chem's stock.

headline: 3 South African Blacks Sentenced to Death
abstract: Three members of the banned African National Congress were sentenced to death today after being convicted of high treason and murder.

headline: Lionel Proposal
abstract: The Lionel Corporation and two subsidiaries, Lionel Leisure Inc.  and the Consolidated Toy Company, which filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors earlier this year, said they had presented a plan to pay back the $136 million owed to their creditors. Lionel's unsecured creditors would be paid an initial 37 cents on the dollar of their allowed claims. The rest would be paid in minimum annual installments of 6 percent until the principal amount was amortized.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Satellite and Television Inc. said it had extended to Oct.8, from Aug.9, the expiration date for shareholders to purchase additional shares of common stock.   * Best Products Co. said the waiting period under Federal law had expired and that it would proceed with its acquisition of Modern Merchandising Inc. Under the agreement, Modern shareholders will receive 0.73 share of Best for each Modern share.   * Continental Telecom Inc. said it had agreed to pay $11 a share, or a total of $24 million, for STSC Inc., formerly Scientific Time Sharing Corp.

headline: JAMESBURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARAB ENVOYS CITE FACTORS IN SYIAN SHIFT
abstract: Arab envoys here today cited the military weakness of the Palestine Liberation Organization, lack of Arab support in the fighting in Beirut and American diplomatic pressure as factors in the decisions by Syria, Iraq and other Arab Governments to end their earlier reluctance to accept the Palestinian guerrillas now in Beirut.   Syria, reversing its previous policy, announced Tuesday that it was willing to accept all of the P.L.O. guerrillas. The announcement followed by hours a reported Iraqi offer to accept any of the guerrillas not wanted elsewhere. Tunisia said it would accept the first contingent of guerrillas to leave the city, and there were reports of other conditional offers from Egypt, the Sudan, Yemen and Southern Yemen.

headline: SALES BOON FOR BOTTLED WATER
abstract: These days, H2O means more than water. It also means money.  Rising concern over health and persisent problems with the contamination of municipal water-supply systems have been a boon to the bottled-water industry.

headline: OIL SHALE CONSORTIUM SUGGESTED
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, anticipating continued national reliance on foreign oil, is seeking to form an industrywide consortium to exploit the virtually untapped domestic reserves of oil shale.   Rawleigh Warner Jr., Mobil's chairman, has written to about a dozen other companies to enlist support for the idea, which he says was prompted by the Exxon Corporation's decision in early May to shut down its $5 billion Colony Shale Oil Project in western Colorado.  That had been the country's most ambitious effort at commercial production of synthetic fuels.

headline: Ford Set to Begin Japan Expansion
abstract: The Ford Motor Company will begin an aggressive sales campaign to expand its markets in Japan, the company's chairman, Philip M. Caldwell, said.

headline: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRINCESS STRICKEN BEFORE CRASH, DOCTORS SAY
abstract: Two doctors who attended Princess Grace said today that the automobile accident that led to her death occurred because she suffered an attack similar to a stroke while at the wheel.   The two doctors reported that the 52-year-old Princess experienced a ''cerebral vascular incident'' that caused her to lose control of the car, bringing on the crash Monday. She never regained consciousness.   One of the doctors said that her life had been maintained artificially for several hours until her immediate family, informed of the hopelessness of the situation, determined that the procedures should be abandoned. The Princess died Tuesday night.

headline: McDonald's Votes 3-for-2 Stock Split
abstract: The McDonald's Corporation said its board had voted a 3-for-2 stock split, payable Oct. 6, to shareholders of record Sept. 14.   McDonald's also raised its quarterly dividend, to 22 cents a share from 20 cents a share, on a post-split basis. The dividend is payable Nov. 4, to stock of record Oct. 21.

headline: AEG'S BOARD FAVORS PLAN
abstract: The supervisory board of AEG-Telefunken A.G. has endorsed the corporate reorganization concept proposed by AEG's management on Sept. 10, the company said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ACCU TEST SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Army Copters Grounded After Weekend Crash
abstract: The United States Army grounded its more than 400 CH-47 Chinook helicopters today as it sought to learn what caused a weekend crash that killed 46 people at a Mannheim air show.   ''This is purely a precautionary measure, until we find out what caused the crash,'' an Army spokesman said in Washington.

headline: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN REMOVES U.S. ECONOMIC BAN ON BUENOS AIRES
abstract: President Reagan today lifted the economic sanctions that he imposed on Argentina at the outbreak of the war over the Falkland Islands.   Administration officials said, however, that the ban on sales of military equipment remained in effect, pending a review of both the situation in the Falklands and any progress Argentina has made in the area of human rights.   The economic sanctions, imposed April 30, affected six preliminary commitments totaling $230 million in loans under the Export-Import Bank and an offer of a $2 million credit guarantee under the Commodity Credit Corporation. All of them involved aid to Argentine concerns for the purpose of exporting American products.

headline: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TransCanada Results
abstract: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. said today that its share of income from investments in oil and gas declined in the second quarter, reflecting higher financing costs and slightly lower earnings from the inclusion of a 12.5 percent interest in the Hudson Bay Oil and Gas Company. The company also reported six-month earnings of $89.3 million (Canadian), up from $64.3 million in the similar 1981 period. TransCanada is 47 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd. and Dome Canada Ltd.

headline: Text of communique is on page A12.
abstract: President Reagan said today that the pledge by the United States to gradually reduce arms sales to Taiwan was based on ''the full expectation'' that China would abide by its promise to seek reunification with Taiwan by peaceful means.   Seeking to reassure the Nationalist Government on Taiwan and its American supporters that the Chinese-American communique issued today did not undermine the security or well-being of Taiwan, Mr. Reagan said in a statement that ''we have paid particular attention to the needs and interests of the people of Taiwan'' in agreeing to the communique.   ''My longstanding personal friendship and deep concern for their well-being is steadfast and unchanged,'' he said. Taipei Expresses Regret   In Taipei, the Nationalist Government expressed ''profound regret'' over the United States-Chinese communique. In a sharply worded statement, the Foreign Ministry said the communique was ''in contradiction of the letter and the spirit'' of the Taiwan Relations Act, which provides for continued United States arms sales to Taiwan. (Page A13.)

headline: OF CITY
abstract: Israeli planes attacked Palestinian positions in Beirut and in the hills east of the city today.  The new assaults came as the United States special envoy, Philip C. Habib, put his proposals for withdrawing the guerrillas from Lebanon into final form and reportedly passed them on to Israel.   Mr. Habib met this afternoon with Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, Foreign Minister Fuad Butros and President Elias Sarkis, reviewing the results of his negotiations Sunday with Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, and outlining the ''comprehensive'' withdrawal proposal that he planned to convey to the Israelis.   This evening a senior Lebanese Government official quoted Prime Minister Wazzan as saying that Mr. Habib had passed to Israel a formal proposal for the withdrawal of the 6,000 to 9,000 Palestine Liberation Organization fighters trapped in west Beirut. The official said that if the Israelis accepted the plan - still a major uncertainty -the pullout could begin later this week, possibly Saturday or earlier.

headline: Railroads' Coal Plan Backed by 12 Banks
abstract: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company and the Union Pacific Corporation jointly announced today that they had signed an agreement with a syndicate of 12 banks that will provide $345 million to finance the construction of the Wyoming Powder River Basin coal project.   The banks, led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, First National Bank of Chicago, Mellon Bank, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and the Union Bank of Switzerland, agreed to lend the two railroad companies 75 percent of the $460 million needed to finance the project, and made a commitment to provide an additional $69 million in case of costs overruns.

headline: Stocks Climb; Dow Up 7.33
abstract: Responding favorably to falling interest rates and rising corporate earnings, stock prices forged ahead yesterday. Volume expanded to 61.1 million shares from Monday's 53 million.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.33 points, to 833.43.  Leading this advance were its two latest additions, International Business Machines and Merck, which replaced Chrysler and Esmark among the 30 components in June 1979.

headline: FALKLAND SANCTIONS MAY END
abstract: The British Treasury announced from London today that Britain and Argentina had agreed to mutually lift financial restrictions tonight, but the Argentine Government denied that an agreement exists and said it was studying the proposal.   Lifting the sanctions, which were imposed during the Falkland Islands war, would free more than $1 billion in Argentine funds frozen in British banks and would open the way for Argentina to begin making overdue payments on an estimated $5 billion borrowed from British banks. No payment on this debt has been made since the Falkland crisis started last spring, and British bankers say that about $200 million in interest payments is past due.   The British announcement said that lifting the sanctions reflected British concern over Argentina's huge foreign debt and the problems it is having making debt payments on time. The Treasury said it welcomed ''Argentina's current approach to the International Monetary Fund and wishes to facilitate an appropriate early agreement between the Fund and Argentine authorities'' for an emergency I.M.F. loan.

headline: G.I.'S JOIN HONDURANS IN TOUCHY REGION
abstract: With tensions rising between Honduras and Nicaragua, United States and Honduran troops have been conducting a joint military exercise near the Nicaraguan border.   American and Honduran officers say the primary objective of the two-week exercise, which involves United States Air Force and Army units from Panama, is the establishment of a permanent Honduran base at Durzuna, some 25 miles north of the Nicaraguan border.   The base, which the officers say will be the largest in eastern Honduras, is in a pine forest some 45 miles west of this muggy, rundown port village. They say it will be home for an infantry battalion, supported by an artillery battery and an engineering unit. The Hondurans are also constructing an airstrip at Durzuna that will be capable of handling large transport planes and jet fighters, the officers say.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPUTERS
abstract: Computers have no problem dividing two 10-digit numbers or exploring 10,000 possible chess moves. In fact, they are best at tasks that are tough or impossible for people. But give a computer a task that even a child can do - like identifying a horse in a photograph of a meadow - and it shows its ignorance.   Now, however, there is blossoming commercial interest in artificial intelligence, a science devoted to making computers do exactly those common-sense things that they cannot yet do. In fact,, at the recent National Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Pittsburgh--from which the following items were gleened--academicians reporting their latest work were flanked by venture capitalists on the prowl for next year's hot investment. Both groups are hoping that thinking computers will be made even smarter, eventually taking on new tasks--like those performed by doctors or lawyers.   But how smart are computers, really? Recent research shows that they're not yet Einsteins.

headline: Commodities; Selling Silver Bars To Public
abstract: THERE were two ways of looking at last week's surge in the price of silver bullion, which raised the metal by $1.535 an ounce, to $7.78, based on Friday's close of the spot August Comex futures contract.   One view was that silver was now back to its price of late 1981, when it was still falling from its record level of $50.30, set Jan.  21, 1980.   The other view was that silver took off from that level in the fall of 1979 and didn't stop climbing until it reached its record price.  While not even the most courageous silver bull today thinks the metal will cross the $50 mark in the foreseeable future, two of the major houses in the precious metals industry believe there are enough sound reasons why the metal should interest investors.

headline: Grundig to Buy Into AEG Unit
abstract: Grundig A.G., a privately held maker of home entertainment equipment, is taking an unspecified stake in the home entertainment unit of AEG-Telefunken A.G., both companies said today.   Grundig officials are to take over management functions of Telefunken Fernseh und Rundfunk G.m.b.H., AEG's maker of televisions, stereo equipment and radios, which will remain a separate company with its own trademark.

headline: A CEASE-FIRE STOPS BIG BEIRUT BATTLE LASTING 14 HOURS
abstract: Israeli forces bombarded Palestinian guerrilla positions and residential areas of west Beirut by land, sea and air for 14 hours today in the fiercest shelling of the besieged Lebanese capital since the Israeli invasion began June 6.   The Israeli onslaught began at 3 A.M. and came to a halt shortly after 5 P.M. when a cease-fire arranged by the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, went into effect. At least 70 people were killed and more than twice that number wounded in the barrages, security sources said.   Israeli tanks tried to advance on Palestinian positions and refugee camps just south of Beirut International Airport and along the coastal highway leading from Ouzai to Beirut. Israelis Reach Terminal Building   The Israeli armored units, which were already in control of the airport runways, managed to drive on the runways into the terminal building and a short distance down the road leading toward the city.  This left them only a few hundred yards from the biggest Palestinian refugee camp in west Beirut, Burj al Brajneh.

headline: Alexander & Alexander
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to acquire Clifton & Company, one of the largest independent insurance brokers in the Western United States. The acquisition, valued at about $9 million, will involve the exchange of 355,000 shares of Alexander & Alexander common, the company, an insurance broker, said.

headline: No New Massacre Toll Offered at State Dept.
abstract: Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said today that officials in Washington had no new or authoritative information on the number of people killed and the number of bodies found at the sites of the massacre in West Beirut.

headline: Miners Saved in South Korea
abstract: Four coal miners trapped by a cave-in 800 feet underground were rescued 14 days later in fair condition, officials said today. Rescue workers said the miners survived by drinking from puddles and eating bark from timber inside the pit.

headline: HOMETEL SUCCEEDS WITH ALL-SUITE INNS
abstract: In the early 1970's, a local plumber-turned-real-estateinvestor named Robert E. Woolley began to build some hotels that were quite unlike anything then alongside the highway.   Not only did he serve his guests a free buffet breakfast each morning and complimentary cocktails every afternoon, but he also built every room as a suite. Instead of the usual hotel bedroom, there was a separate bedroom and sitting room, complete with a wet bar.   Mr. Woolley called them ''Hometels.'' Granada Royale Hometels, no less. And he priced them to compete with most traditional hotels catering to the traveling business trade.

headline: Israel's Justices Order Reversal of El Al Move
abstract: The Supreme Court ordered the Government today not to carry out its decison of last month to halt flights of the national airline, El Al, on the Sabbath and holidays, Israel's state radio reported.

headline: U.N. Bids Israel Allow Shipments of Supplies
abstract: The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution tonight urging Israel to permit the shipment of vital supplies, including water, food and medicine, into west Beirut.   Israel forces cut most transportation into the western sector of the Lebanese capital as part of an intensified effort to press the 6,000 Palestinians guerrillas there to withdraw.

headline: WARSAW MAY END SOLIDARITY UNION
abstract: The Polish martial law authorities appear to be preparing to outlaw and eliminate the now-suspended trade union Solidarity.   The attempt to finally crush the rebellious free union movement, hinted at in articles appearing almost daily in the official press, is expected to come in a new trade union bill tentatively scheduled to be presented to Parliament in the next few weeks.   The bill, the subject of debate within the military and party leadership, is expected to contain what is becoming known here as the ''zero option,'' the elimination of both Solidarity and the existing ''social commissions,'' which have drawn little enthusiasm.

headline: LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS TORN BY AN OLD BLOOD FEUD
abstract: Northern Lebanon, the bastion of former President Suleiman Franjieh, has become noticeably tense in the aftermath of Bashir Gemayel's election as President. Much of the atmosphere stems from a four-year-old blood feud between the two Christians. But there is also talk of war, and of Mr. Franjieh's special vulnerability.   Mr. Franjieh, the white-haired patriarch of his own armed Maronite Christian domain, has been the focus of growing attention since he declared a ''boycott'' of Mr. Gemayel's election.

headline: THE CASH MARKET IN AIRPORT SLOTS
abstract: Donald C. Burr, the chairman of People Express Airlines, an expansion-minded carrier based at Newark International Airport, had been looking since fall for landing rights at better airports. In the aftermath of the air controllers' strike, and the resultant squeeze on landing rights at the nation's 22 biggest airports, his fleet of 17 jets had been forced to operate from secondary fields on the fringes of the most desirable transportation markets.   Meanwhile, in Princeton, David A. Van Dyke, the owner and president of the fledgling Princeton Aviation Corporation, a commuter airline that linked the university town to Newark, Boston and Washington, was struggling with the downturn in the economy. Although Princeton had carried an average of 30,000 passengers a year in the four years since its founding, Mr. Van Dyke said the economic downturn had cut into his traffic and led to losses.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Cities Service Co.'s senior debt rating was reduced to BBB+ from A+ and its commercial paper rating to A-2 from A-1 by Standard & Poor's.   * Connecticut Light and Power Co. filed for a $125 million offering of series H first and refunding mortgage bonds.

headline: NOHO PROJECT ENCAPSULATES AN EARLY ERA
abstract: David C. Walentas has an affinity for rehabilitating, for residential use, buildings that seem to embody the era in which they were built and the neighborhood's original character.   That trait is evident in two of his restoration efforts: Alwyn Court, the national landmark apartment house at 180 West 58th Street near Central Park, and his forthcoming development of the landmark Fulton Landing site on the Brooklyn waterfront. It is also apparent in a third effort, the Silk Building, at 14 East Fourth Street in the Noho (north of Houston Street) area of lower Manhattan.   East Fourth Street is the northern boundary of the garment manufacturing district that stretches north along Broadway from Houston Street, and the 81-year-old Silk Building's utilitarian but stately facade bespeaks its original use as factory space for producers of fine silk garments.

headline: Article 182492 -- No Title
abstract: The United States and Zimbabwe signed agreements today worth $7.4 million for family planning and for sugar refining projects. The United States Embassy said $6.9 million was granted to the state-backed Child Spacing and Fertility Association and $524,000 to a project to help make fuel from sugar.

headline: Advertising; Newsweek Marketing Strategy
abstract: THE Newsweek magazine announcements of its innovative four-a-year customary premium on the cost-per-1,000 rate on ads in test markets were the first public signs of what could turn out to be a revolutionary move in magazine publishing: a packaged goods marketing man at the apex of management.   Selig H. Price, who has always been called Steve, was a top gun in the great General Foods empire before being spirited away by a headhunter working for the new president of Newsweek Inc., Mark M.  Edmiston, and installed as executive vice president of Newsweek Inc., and general manager in charge of the entire business side of the domestic operation, over the publisher, Charles J. Kennedy, but under the president.   It is unique in the business, as far as the memory of Kent Rhodes, president of the Magazine Publishers Association, serves.   Marketing at a magazine, Mr. Price said enthusiastically, means defining ''who is the reader and who is the advertiser and finding out what we can do to satisfy them.''
